('79', 0, 1, 2, 44) 1. MYSORE JUSTICE
('79', 0, 2, 3, 62) After I had sent my note 1 on Shri H. C. Dassappa’s Case, I received the following from a Bangalore advocate:
('79', 0, 3, 4, 172) You have now material which is sufficient to give an indication of the independence of the Mysore Judiciary.
('79', 0, 3, 5, 281) It is undoubtedly under the control and lead of Sir D’Arcy Reilly.
('79', 0, 3, 6, 348) The other Judges in the High Court follow in his footsteps, and no single instance can be recalled when any Puisne Judge of the High Court of Mysore has had the strength to demur to even the excesses committed by the chief Justice in the language, form and tone of his judgements, the Government, which professes not to interfere with either the High Court or the Judiciary is evidently well satisfied about the Judges of the High Court of Mysore.
('79', 0, 3, 7, 796) For a dozen years important judgements have come from the Judges of the High Court which have clearly shown that they have yielded to the pressure of the bureaucracy while professing fear of God and of no man.
('79', 0, 3, 8, 1006) Probably it is this practical docility that has made the Government Order on Political Reforms in the State silent to the point of being sinister as regards recommendations for the reform of the Judiciary in the State.
('79', 0, 3, 9, 1225) To cap it all comes the pronouncement in Shri H. C. Dasappa’s case that in this country truth is so often degraded into a political catch word.’ The reference to the country is wide enough in its mischief and implications so as to embrace all people whether Congressmen or others and whether they reside in the States or in British India.
('79', 0, 3, 10, 1564) What basis had Sir D’Arcy Reilly for such an assumption?
('79', 0, 3, 11, 1621) And what evidence had he for such a general charge against a whole country?
('79', 0, 3, 12, 1697) Is it moral on the part of Sir D’Arcy Reilly to condemn Sri H. C. Dasappa and debar him on the ground that he preferred a charge that he could not prove, and do the same thing under a different guise in a judgment?
('79', 0, 3, 13, 1912) My correspondent’s complaint is right.
('79', 0, 3, 14, 1951) But Judges are above all law, at least in Mysore.
('79', 0, 3, 15, 2001) Like kings they can do no wrong.
('79', 0, 4, 16, 2034) SEVAGRAM, July 16, 1940 Harijan, 21 7 1940

('79', 1, 1, 2, 2140) 2. KHAN SAHEB’S AHIMSA 1
('79', 1, 2, 3, 2165) In the storm that shook most of the members of the Working Committee Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan stood firm as a rock.
('79', 1, 2, 4, 2286) He had never any doubt about his position, and his statement which I reproduce below should serve as a beacon light to all of us:
('79', 1, 3, 5, 2416) Some recent resolutions of the Congress Working Committee indicate that they are restricting the use of non violence to the fight for India’s freedom against constituted authority.
('79', 1, 3, 6, 2597) How far and in what manner this will have to be applied in the future I cannot say.
('79', 1, 3, 7, 2681) The near future will perhaps throw light on this.
('79', 1, 3, 8, 2731) Meanwhile it is difficult for me to continue in the Congress Working Committee, and I am resigning from it.
('79', 1, 3, 9, 2839) I should like to make it clear that the non violence I have believed in and preached to my brethren of the Khudai Khidmatgars is much wider.
('79', 1, 3, 10, 2980) It affects all our life, and only this has permanent value.
('79', 1, 3, 11, 3040) Unless we learn this lesson of non violence fully we shall never do away with the deadly feuds which have been the curse of the people of the Frontier.
('79', 1, 3, 12, 3192) Since we took to non violence and the Khudai Khidmatgars pledged themselves to it, we have largely succeeded in ending these feuds.
('79', 1, 3, 13, 3324) Non violence has added greatly to the courage of the Pathans.
('79', 1, 3, 14, 3386) Because they were previously addicted to violence far more than others, they have profited by non violence much more.
('79', 1, 3, 15, 3504) We shall never really and effectively defend ourselves except through non violence.
('79', 1, 3, 16, 3588) Khudai Khid matgars must, therefore, be what our name implies pure servants of God and humanity by laying down our own lives and never taking any life.
('79', 1, 3, 17, 3740) It is worthy of the Khan Saheb [ and all that he has stood for during the past twenty years ] 2 .
('79', 1, 3, 18, 3838) He is a Pathan, and a Pathan may be said to be born with rifle or sword in his hand.
('79', 1, 3, 19, 3923) But the Khan Saheb deliberately asked his Khudai Khidmatgars to shed all weapons when he asked them to join the satyagraha against the Rowlatt Act.
('79', 1, 3, 20, 4071) He saw that this deliberate giving up of the weapons of violence had a magical effect.
('79', 1, 3, 21, 4158) It was the only remedy for the blood feuds which were handed down from sire to son and which had become part of the normal life of a Pathan.
('79', 1, 3, 22, 4299) 3 They had decimated numerous families, and non 
('79', 1, 4, 23, 4348) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 20 7 1940. This translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 1, 4, 24, 4468) 2 This is not to be found in the Gujarati.
('79', 1, 4, 25, 4511) 3 The Gujarati here has: “This marked the limit of violence and showed its bankruptcy.”
('79', 2, 0, 1, 4599) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 3
('79', 2, 1, 2, 4643) violence seemed to the Khan Saheb to have come as a longed for salvation.
('79', 2, 1, 3, 4717) The violent blood feuds would otherwise have no end and would spell the end of the Pathans.
('79', 2, 1, 4, 4809) He saw as clear as daylight that, if he could persuade his people not to retaliate, the suicidal feuds would cease and the Pathans would be able to give a better account of their bravery.
('79', 2, 1, 5, 4997) They took up his message and put into practice what with them became non violence of the brave.
('79', 2, 1, 6, 5093) Being so clear about his own faith and that of the Khudai Khidmatgars, there was for him no escape from resignation of him membership of the Congress Working Committee.
('79', 2, 1, 7, 5262) His continuing on it would have been anomalous and might have meant an end of his life’s work.
('79', 2, 1, 8, 5357) He could not ask his people to join as recruits in the army and at the same time forget the law of tribal retaliation.
('79', 2, 1, 9, 5476) The simple Pathan would have argued with him and the argument would have been irresistible that the present war was a war of retaliation and revenge, and that there was no difference between it and their blood feuds.
('79', 2, 1, 10, 5693) I do not know how far the Khan Saheb has succeeded in carry ing his message to his people.
('79', 2, 1, 11, 5784) This I know that with him non violence is a matter not of intellectual conviction but of intuitive faith.
('79', 2, 1, 12, 5890) Nothing can therefore shake it.
('79', 2, 1, 13, 5922) About his followers he cannot say how far they will adhere to it.
('79', 2, 1, 14, 5988) But that does not worry him.
('79', 2, 1, 15, 6017) He has to do his duty which he owes to them.
('79', 2, 1, 16, 6062) The result he leaves to God.
('79', 2, 1, 17, 6091) He derives his ahimsa from the Holy Koran.
('79', 2, 1, 18, 6134) He is a devout Mussalman.
('79', 2, 1, 19, 6160) During his stay with me for over a year I never saw him miss him namaz (pra yers) or his Ramzan fast (except when he was ill).
('79', 2, 1, 20, 6287) But his devotion to Islam does not mean disrespect for other faiths.
('79', 2, 1, 21, 6356) He has read the Gita.
('79', 2, 1, 22, 6378) His reading is slight but selective, and he immediately assimilates what appeals to him.
('79', 2, 1, 23, 6467) He loathes long argument and does not take long to make up his mind.
('79', 2, 1, 24, 6536) If he succeeds in his mission, it would mean the solution of many another problem.
('79', 2, 1, 25, 6619) But the result no one can predict.
('79', 2, 1, 26, 6654) ‘The lot is cast into the lap, but the whole disposing thereof is of the Lord.’ SEVAGRAM, July 16, 1940 Harijan, 21 7 1940
('79', 3, 0, 1, 6777) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 3, 1, 2, 6817) 3. THE ANNUAL SPINNING SACRIFICE 1
('79', 3, 2, 3, 6852) Shri Narandas Gandhi has issued his usual appeal for intensive spinning during the 71 days before my seventy first birthday.
('79', 3, 2, 4, 6977) He began this way of celebrating it six years ago with an appeal for 66 thousand yards.
('79', 3, 2, 5, 7065) Last year he made an appeal for 70 lakhs of yards, and the response was beyond his expectation over 4 crores of yards of yarn were spun.
('79', 3, 2, 6, 7202) I commend his appeal to all.
('79', 3, 2, 7, 7231) The response to his appeal should increase with my increasing years.
('79', 3, 2, 8, 7300) If the annual quota of the National School in Rajkot is any index, the response would seem to be on the increase.
('79', 3, 2, 9, 7414) But the appetite of Daridranarayana is insatiable, and it demands still greater response.
('79', 3, 2, 10, 7504) It is a Herculean task to liquidate the unemployment and starvation of crores of people.
('79', 3, 2, 11, 7593) Let me hope that every lover of the wheel will contribute his or her quota to this task and make the sacrifice a worthy one.
('79', 3, 2, 12, 7718) Let them approach the task intelligently and with a proper regard for its sacredness.
('79', 3, 2, 13, 7804) Let them, therefore, devote not only more time to spinning, but also endeavour to do it better by keeping all their spinning tackle in proper trim and thus increasing their speed.
('79', 3, 2, 14, 7984) If they will watch the revolutions of the spindle and find out the secret of putting up the speed, I am sure that at the end of the sacrifice they will have nearly doubled the speed.
('79', 3, 2, 15, 8167) SEVAGRAM, July 16, 1940 Harijan, 21 7 1940
('79', 3, 3, 16, 8210) 4. HOW TO CULTIVATE AHIMSA?
('79', 3, 4, 17, 8238) Q. What is the good of your crying ‘ahimsa, ahimsa’ in season and out of season?
('79', 3, 4, 18, 8319) Will it by itself teach people to be non violent?
('79', 3, 4, 19, 8369) Would it not be better, instead, to tell people how pure ahimsa or the ahimsa of the strong can be cultivated?
('79', 3, 5, 20, 8480) A. Your is a very timely and opportune question.
('79', 3, 5, 21, 8529) I have attem pted before this on more occasions than one to answer it.
('79', 3, 5, 22, 8600) But my effort has, I confess, been rather desultory.
('79', 3, 5, 23, 8653) I have not concentrated upon it, or given it the weight I might have.
('79', 3, 5, 24, 8723) This was all right while I was devoting all my energy to forging means to give battle to Govern 
('79', 3, 6, 25, 8820) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 20 7 1940. This abridged English version is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 3, 6, 26, 8953) 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 20 7 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan where it was published under the heading “Question Box”.
('79', 4, 0, 1, 9132) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 5
('79', 4, 1, 2, 9176) But it had the result of retarding the growth of pure ahimsa, so that today we are not even within ken of the ahimsa of the strong.
('79', 4, 1, 3, 9308) If we now want to advance further, we ought, at least for some time, to completely forget the idea of offering non violent resistance to cons tituted authority.
('79', 4, 1, 4, 9469) If non violence in the domestic field is successfully achieved, we shall surely see the non violence against constituted authority revived in its purified form, and it will be irresistible.
('79', 4, 1, 5, 9659) Now that I am no longer in the Congress, I may not offer civil disobedience even in my own person in its name.
('79', 4, 1, 6, 9770) But I am certainly free to offer civil disobedience in my individual capacity whenever it may be necessary.
('79', 4, 1, 7, 9878) No one need suppose that all civil disobedience will necessarily be taboo while the country is still being educated in the ahimsa of the strong.
('79', 4, 1, 8, 10023) But those who may want to join the non violent force of my conception would not entertain any immediate prospect of civil disobedience.
('79', 4, 1, 9, 10159) They should understand that, so long as they have not realized ahimsa in their own person in its pure form, there can be no civil disobedience for them.
('79', 4, 1, 10, 10312) Let not the mention of pure ahimsa frighten anybody.
('79', 4, 1, 11, 10365) If we have a clear conception of it and have a living faith in its matchless efficacy, it will not be found to be so hard to practise as it is sometimes supposed to be, it will be well to remember the immortal Mahabharata verse 1 in this connection.
('79', 4, 1, 12, 10615) The Seer Poet therein loudly proclaims to the whole that dharma includes within itself both legitimate artha and kama, and asks why men do not follow the royal road of dharma that leads to both earthly and spiritual bliss.
('79', 4, 1, 13, 10838) Dharma here does not signify mere observance of externals.
('79', 4, 1, 14, 10897) It signifies the way of truth and non violence.
('79', 4, 1, 15, 10945) The scriptures have given us two immortal maxims.
('79', 4, 1, 16, 10995) One of these is: “Ahimsa is the supreme Law of dharma.” The other is:“There is no other Law or dharma than truth.” These two maxims provide us the key to all lawful artha and kama.
('79', 4, 1, 17, 11176) Why should we then hesitate to act up to them?
('79', 4, 1, 18, 11223) Strange as it may appear, the fact remains that people find the easiest of things oftentimes to be the most difficult to follow.
('79', 4, 1, 19, 11352) The reason, to borrow a term from the science of physics, lies in our inertia.
('79', 4, 1, 20, 11431) Physicists tell us that inertia is an essential and, in its own place a most useful, quality of matter, it is that alone which steadies the universe and prevents if from flying off at a tangent.
('79', 4, 1, 21, 11626) But for it the latter would be a chaos of
('79', 4, 2, 22, 11668) 1 The Gujarati has “Bharat Savitri verse”.
('79', 4, 2, 23, 11711) For the text of the verse, vide “ A Cry in the Wilderness”?
('79', 5, 0, 1, 11771) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 5, 1, 2, 11811) motion.
('79', 5, 1, 3, 11819) But inertia becomes an incubus and a vice when it ties the mind down to old ruts.
('79', 5, 1, 4, 11901) It is this kind of inertia which is responsible for our rooted prejudice that to practise pure ahimsa is difficult.
('79', 5, 1, 5, 12017) It is up to us to get rid of this incubus.
('79', 5, 1, 6, 12060) The first step in this direction is firmly to resolve that all untruth and himsa shall hereafter be taboo to us, whatever sacrifice it might seem to involve.
('79', 5, 1, 7, 12218) For, the good these may seem to achieve is in appearance only, but in reality it is deadly poison.
('79', 5, 1, 8, 12317) If our resolve is firm and our conviction clear, it would mean half the battle won, and the practice of these two qualities would come comparatively easy to us.
('79', 5, 1, 9, 12478) Let us confine ourselves to ahimsa.
('79', 5, 1, 10, 12514) We have all along regarded the spinning wheel, village crafts, etc., as the pillars of ahimsa, and so indeed they are.
('79', 5, 1, 11, 12633) They must stand.
('79', 5, 1, 12, 12650) But we have now to go a step fur ther.
('79', 5, 1, 13, 12689) A votary of ahimsa will or course base upon non violence, if he has not already done so, all his relations with his parents, his children, his wife, his servants, his dependants, etc.
('79', 5, 1, 14, 12873) But the real test will come at the time of political or communal disturbances or under the menace of thieves and dacoits.
('79', 5, 1, 15, 12995) Mere resolve to lay down one’s life under the circumstances is not enough.
('79', 5, 1, 16, 13070) There must be the necessary qualifica tion fro making the sacrifice.
('79', 5, 1, 17, 13139) If I am a Hindu, I must fraternize with the Mussalmans and the rest.
('79', 5, 1, 18, 13208) In my dealings with them I may not make any distinction between my co religionists and those who might belong to a different faith.
('79', 5, 1, 19, 13340) I would seek opportunities to serve them without any feeling of fear or unnaturalness.
('79', 5, 1, 20, 13427) The word ‘fear’ can have no place in the dictionary of ahimsa.
('79', 5, 1, 21, 13490) Having thus qualified him self by his selfless service, a votary of pure ahimsa will be in a position to make a fit offering of himself in a communal conflagration.
('79', 5, 1, 22, 13655) Simi larly, to meet the menace of thieves and dacoits, he will need to go among, and cultivate friendly relations, with, the communities from which thieves and dacoits generally come.
('79', 5, 1, 23, 13839) A brilliant example of this kind of work is provided by Ravishanker Maharaj.
('79', 5, 1, 24, 13916) His work among the criminal tribes in Gujarat has evoked praise even of the Baroda State authorities.
('79', 5, 1, 25, 14018) There is an almost unlimited field for this kind of work and it does not call for any other talent in one besides pure love.
('79', 5, 1, 26, 14143) Ravi shanker Maharaj is an utter stranger to English.
('79', 5, 1, 27, 14197) Even his knowledge of Gujarati is barely sufficient for everyday use.
('79', 5, 1, 28, 14267) But God has blessed him with unlimited neighbourly love.
('79', 5, 1, 29, 14324) His simplicity easily wins all hearts and is the envy
('79', 6, 0, 1, 14378) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 7
('79', 6, 1, 2, 14422) of everybody.
('79', 6, 1, 3, 14436) Let his example provide a cue and inspiration to all those who may be similarly engaged in other field of satyagraha.
('79', 6, 2, 4, 14554) SEVAGRAM, July 16, 1940 Harijan, 21 7 1940
('79', 6, 3, 5, 14597) 5. IMPOSSIBLE 2
('79', 6, 4, 6, 14613) Miss Muriel Lester writes:
('79', 6, 5, 7, 14640) See how you are misquoted by Sherwood Eddy 3 in his latest book I Saw God Do it.
('79', 6, 5, 8, 14721) I have been asked to send you this cutting from it so that you may reply to it if you want to.
('79', 6, 5, 9, 14816) Here is the extract.
('79', 6, 6, 10, 14837) “We have maintained throughout this chapter that some are called to be conscientious objectors as absolute pacifists to challenge the whole war system, but that the majority will feel it to be their duty forcibly to defend their country when it is attacked or its vital interests are threatened.
('79', 6, 6, 11, 15133) Gandhi himself, the most effective and the greatest living pacifist, is not an absolutist
('79', 6, 7, 12, 15223) but a relativist, a realist and, to a large degree, a practical states man.
('79', 6, 7, 13, 15299) He is effectively using non violent resistance to achieve the indepen dence of India, but he recognizes that a modern State cannot be maintained without both a police force and an army.
('79', 6, 7, 14, 15485) When the writer asked him personally how a divided Indian army could be commanded by a Moslem, a Hindu or a Sikh, he told me they could first ask an American or some foreign neutral to lead their army.
('79', 6, 7, 15, 15687) But Gandhi pacifists and Indian nationalists would defend their country if attacked by Japan or Soviet Russia or any other foreign power by the full force of their army.
('79', 6, 7, 16, 15857) So, I believe, should our own country.” I can only say that I have no recollection of my having ever made such a statement.
('79', 6, 7, 17, 15981) I know Dr. Sherwood Eddy well.
('79', 6, 7, 18, 16012) I remember too his visit.
('79', 6, 7, 19, 16038) The astounding statement put into my mouth belies all I have ever written or said about the defence of India.
('79', 6, 7, 20, 16148) Even if I believed in armed defence, I should never want a foreign general to lead my army.
('79', 6, 7, 21, 16240) I may have foreign instructors but not officers.
('79', 6, 7, 22, 16289) If, therefore, Dr. Eddy sees these lines, and instead of correcting himself persists in his statement, I can only say I must have been absent

('79', 8, 3, 8, 18188) 9. UNREPENTANT
('79', 8, 4, 9, 18203) By writing that “Appeal to Every Briton” 1 I have invited upon my head an extra load of work which without God’s help I would be ill able to bear.
('79', 8, 4, 10, 18350) If it is His will that I should shoulder it, He will give me the strength to carry on.
('79', 8, 4, 11, 18437) When I decided to confine myself mostly to writing in Gujarati or Hindustani, I had no notion that I would have to write the appeal.
('79', 8, 4, 12, 18570) It came to me like a flash, and the courage to write it came with it.
('79', 8, 4, 13, 18640) I had resisted till then all pressure from English and American friends to give guidance.
('79', 8, 4, 14, 18730) But I could not see my way.
('79', 8, 4, 15, 18758) Now having addressed that appeal, I must follow up the reactions to it.
('79', 8, 4, 16, 18830) A large amount of correspondence is pouring in upon me.
('79', 8, 4, 17, 18886) Save for one angry telegram, I had nothing but friendly criticism from Englishmen and even appreciation from some.
('79', 8, 4, 18, 19001) I was grateful to H. E. the Viceroy for forwarding my offer to His Majesty’s Government.
('79', 8, 4, 19, 19090) The correspondence with regard to it the readers have already seen or will see in this issue.
('79', 8, 4, 20, 19184) Though no better response to the appeal was to be expected, I cannot help saying that is was the knowledge of the determination to carry the war to a victo rious end that had prompted my appeal.
('79', 8, 4, 21, 19379) No doubt the determi nation is natural and worthy of the best British tradition.
('79', 8, 4, 22, 19460) Nevertheless the awful slaughter that the determination involves should induce a search for a better and braver way to achieve the end.
('79', 8, 4, 23, 19596) For peace has its victo ries more glorious than those of war.
('79', 8, 4, 24, 19658) The non violent method would have meant no abject surrender.
('79', 8, 4, 25, 19719) It would have confounded all modern tactics of war, indeed rendered them of no use.
('79', 8, 4, 26, 19803) The new world order which all dream of would surely have been found.
('79', 8, 4, 27, 19872) I hold a new order to be impossible if the war is fought to a finish or mutual exhaustion leads to a patched up peace.
('79', 8, 5, 28, 19991) 1Vide “To Every Briton”
('79', 9, 0, 1, 20015) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 9, 1, 2, 20056) Let me, therefore examine the argument advanced in a letter received from a friend 1 .
('79', 9, 1, 3, 20143) Here it is:
('79', 9, 2, 4, 20155) Two English friends who admire you, say your appeal to every Briton cannot have any effect just now.
('79', 9, 2, 5, 20256) It is impossible to expect the man in the street to do a complete volte face with any degree of understanding indeed it is impossible for the understanding [sic] to do, as you say, without a heart belief in non violence.
('79', 9, 2, 6, 20477) The time to mould a new world on your lines will be after the war.
('79', 9, 2, 7, 20544) They realize your way is the right one, but they say it needs endless preparation and instruction and big leadership none of which they possess.
('79', 9, 2, 8, 20689) Regarding India they say the attitude of the present authority is deplorable.
('79', 9, 2, 9, 20767) Long ago India should have been declared as independent as Canada, and her people should be allowed to work out their own constitution.
('79', 9, 2, 10, 20903) But what they are extremely perplexed about now is that you want absolute independence straightaway, and the next step you will take is ‘no further help to Britain in the prosecution of war, surrender to Germany, and opposition to her by non violent means’.
('79', 9, 2, 11, 21161) You must explain what you mean in more detail so as to remove this misunderstanding.
('79', 9, 2, 12, 21246) This is an honest reaction.
('79', 9, 2, 13, 21274) The appeal was intended to produce the effect now.
('79', 9, 2, 14, 21325) It could not come out of a mathematical calculation.
('79', 9, 2, 15, 21378) If the conviction could have come, action was an easy matter.
('79', 9, 2, 16, 21440) The mass mind responds under pressure.
('79', 9, 2, 17, 21479) That the appeal has not produced the intended result shows that either my word has no power or that God has a purpose of which we have no knowledge.
('79', 9, 2, 18, 21628) The appeal has come from an anguished heart.
('79', 9, 2, 19, 21673) I could not suppress it.
('79', 9, 2, 20, 21698) It was not written for the moment.
('79', 9, 2, 21, 21733) I am quite sure that it enunciates a truth of eternal value.
('79', 9, 2, 22, 21794) If the ground is not prepared from now, there may be no time left after a dismal termination of the war for evolving a new order.
('79', 9, 2, 23, 21924) Whatever the order, it will be in response to a conscious or uncon scious effort from now.
('79', 9, 2, 24, 22015) Indeed the effort began before my appeal.
('79', 9, 2, 25, 22057) I hope that it has stimulated it.
('79', 9, 2, 26, 22091) Perhaps given it a definite direction.
('79', 9, 2, 27, 22130) I suggest to the non official leaders and moulders of British opinion, if they are convinced of the truth of my position, to work for its ado ption.
('79', 9, 2, 28, 22279) Compared to the big issue raised in my appeal, the question of Indian independence pales into insignificance.
('79', 9, 2, 29, 22389) But I hold with the two Englishmen that the British Government’s attitude is deplorable.
('79', 9, 2, 30, 22478) The two friends are wholly wrong in the deduction they have drawn from
('79', 9, 3, 31, 22549) 1 Amrit Kaur; Vide “Letter to Amrit Kaur”, 19 7 1940.
('79', 10, 0, 1, 22603) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 11
('79', 10, 1, 2, 22648) the assumed recognition of India ‘s independence.
('79', 10, 1, 3, 22698) They forget that I am out of the picture.
('79', 10, 1, 4, 22740) Those who are responsible for the Working Committee’s last resolution have meant free India’s co operation with Britain.
('79', 10, 1, 5, 22861) With them, there is no question of surrender to Germany or non violent opposition.
('79', 10, 1, 6, 22944) But I must not here tarry on Indian independence and its implications, tempting though the subject is.
('79', 10, 1, 7, 23047) The cuttings and correspondence before me say that the Congress rejection of my advice to abstain from preparation for military defence of India precludes me from making the appeal to Britain or from expecting a favourable response.
('79', 10, 1, 8, 23280) The argument is plausible, but only plausible.
('79', 10, 1, 9, 23327) The critics say that , if I have failed with my people, I have no right to expect Britain whilst she is in the midst of a life and death struggle to listen to me.
('79', 10, 1, 10, 23490) I am a man with a mission.
('79', 10, 1, 11, 23517) India ‘s millions have never tasted the bitters of war as the British have.
('79', 10, 1, 12, 23593) Britain, if she is to fulfil her declared purpose, needs a radical change in her policy.
('79', 10, 1, 13, 23682) I feel that I know the change that is needed.
('79', 10, 1, 14, 23728) My inability to persuade the Working Committee is irrelevant to the theme under discussion.
('79', 10, 1, 15, 23820) There is no analogy between India’s case and Britain’s.
('79', 10, 1, 16, 23876) I am, therefore, wholly unrepentant.
('79', 10, 1, 17, 23913) I maintain that in issuing my appeal I have acted wholly as a lifelong friend of Britain.
('79', 10, 1, 18, 24003) A writer, however, retorts: “Address your appeal to Hitler.” In the first place, I did write to Herr Hitler.
('79', 10, 1, 19, 24112) 1 My letter was publish din the Press some time after I addressed it.
('79', 10, 1, 20, 24182) In the second place, there can be no meaning in my appeal to Herr Hitler to adopt non violence.
('79', 10, 1, 21, 24278) He is marching from victory to victory.
('79', 10, 1, 22, 24318) I can only appeal to him to desist.
('79', 10, 1, 23, 24354) That I have done.
('79', 10, 1, 24, 24372) But to Britain, which is just now on the defensive, I can present the really effective weapon of non violent non co opera tion.
('79', 10, 1, 25, 24500) Let my method be rejected on merits, not by bringing inapt analogies or untenable argument.
('79', 10, 1, 26, 24592) The issue raised by me, I venture to think, is of universal importance, the usefulness of the non violent method seems to be granted by all the critics.
('79', 10, 1, 27, 24745) They gratuitously assume the impossibility of human nature, as it is constituted, respon ding to the strain involved in non violent preparation.
('79', 10, 1, 28, 24890) But that is begging the question.
('79', 10, 1, 29, 24924) I say, ‘You have never tried the method on any scale.
('79', 10, 1, 30, 24978) In so far as it has been tried, it has shown promising results.’ SEVAGRAM, JULY 17, 1940 Harijan, 21 7 1940

('79', 11, 1, 2, 25169) 10. TRAVANCORE
('79', 11, 2, 3, 25184) Some Travancoreans have thought I had neglected them.
('79', 11, 2, 4, 25238) But I had not.
('79', 11, 2, 5, 25253) It is no pleasure to me to criticize any State.
('79', 11, 2, 6, 25301) Much of my work is done by negotiation.
('79', 11, 2, 7, 25341) I criticise when I must.
('79', 11, 2, 8, 25366) So when I was told by common friends that Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar would like to meet me if an opportunity occurred, I stopped all reference to Travancore affairs.
('79', 11, 2, 9, 25531) But the meeting was not to be.
('79', 11, 2, 10, 25562) In reply to my inquiry I have the following extraordinary wire from him:
('79', 11, 3, 11, 25635) Have just received your telegram.
('79', 11, 3, 12, 25669) 1 In view developments in India including your recent statement and resolution of Working Committee with similar aims though different programmes, and also having regard to the close though unacknowledged connection existing between many of the leaders of Travancore State Congress and communist activities which have come to light after arrest of K. C. George, and in view of the openly hostile activities of Mr. T. M. Verghese and of Mr. G. Ramachandran who has been chosen by you to give advice as to Tranvancore, no useful purpose is likely to be served by any meeting.
('79', 11, 3, 13, 26243) In these circumstances you are of course free to comment on Travancore affairs, but it is hoped that you will not accept versions furnished by persons who are discredited here and who depend for their influence, collection of funds, and their political existence, on possibility of getting periodical statement from you on one sided data furnished by them.
('79', 11, 3, 14, 26600) Most of the leading members of State Congress including Messrs V. K. elayudhan, M. N. Parameswaran Pillai and others have openly dissociated themselves from State Congress activities.
('79', 11, 3, 15, 26784) They number over 60. I fail to see the connection between the Working Committee’s resolution and my recent statement on the one hand and Travancore affairs on the other.
('79', 11, 3, 16, 26954) The Working Committee have not even interested themselves in Travaneore affairs.
('79', 11, 3, 17, 27035) The idea of our meeting did not originate with me.
('79', 11, 3, 18, 27086) Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar thought of it months ago.
('79', 11, 3, 19, 27138) Even a date was fixed.
('79', 11, 3, 20, 27161) But owing to a pressing engagement he had to keep, our meeting was postponed.
('79', 11, 3, 21, 27239) As late as the 3rd of April he had wired saying he was writing to me about the interview.
('79', 11, 3, 22, 27329) Have the Working Committee’s resolution and my statement so altered the situation that our meeting has become undesirable?
('79', 11, 3, 23, 27452) The other things the worthy Dewan refers to are the very things which would have made our meeting fruitful.
('79', 11, 3, 24, 27560) He had but to convince me that the State Congress was involved in communist activities of a dangerous nature,
('79', 11, 4, 25, 27670) 1 This is not traceable.
('79', 12, 0, 1, 27695) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 13
('79', 12, 1, 2, 27740) and I would have washed my hands clean of the local Congress and its doings.
('79', 12, 1, 3, 27817) All communism is not dangerous.
('79', 12, 1, 4, 27849) I do not know that Shri K. C. George is a communist.
('79', 12, 1, 5, 27902) I warn the Dewan against being preju diced by the mere name.
('79', 12, 1, 6, 27963) I know many friends who delight in calling themselves communists.
('79', 12, 1, 7, 28029) They are as harmless as a dove.
('79', 12, 1, 8, 28061) I call myself a communist in their company.
('79', 12, 1, 9, 28105) The underlying belief of communism is good and as old as the hills.
('79', 12, 1, 10, 28173) But I have strayed.
('79', 12, 1, 11, 28193) If Shri T. M. Verghese and Shri G. Ramachandran are untrustworthy, again our meeting is necessary to convince me of their untrustworthiness.
('79', 12, 1, 12, 28334) I must confess I have profound admiration for their courage, self sacrifice ability and integrity.
('79', 12, 1, 13, 28433) Shri Ramachandran is an old member of Sabarmati who has never given me cause for distrusting him.
('79', 12, 1, 14, 28531) Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar knows me enough to feel sure that I would not hesitate to own my mistake if I discovered it.
('79', 12, 1, 15, 28650) It was his duty, as it still is, to make an effort to convince me that the sources of my information are tainted.
('79', 12, 1, 16, 28764) The extraordinary telegram has made me conclude that Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar has nothing against the Congress or its members except that they are patriots without reproach and without fear.
('79', 12, 1, 17, 28956) He hates their philosophy and seeks to crush them.
('79', 12, 1, 18, 29007) All the evidence in my possession points that way, and the telegram confirms my impression.
('79', 12, 1, 19, 29099) I have made an offer which I repeat.
('79', 12, 1, 20, 29136) Let there be an impartial open inquiry into the whole conduct of the State Congress and its treatment by the State.
('79', 12, 1, 21, 29252) Let the judge or judges be outsiders of known integrity.
('79', 12, 1, 22, 29309) I shall advise the State Congress to accept the findings of such a court.
('79', 12, 1, 23, 29383) If this simple offer is not accepted, I must be pardoned for rejecting the interesting denials by officials of the State Congress allegations and believing them and asking the public to do likewise.

('79', 24, 9, 25, 46408) GANDHIJI: Not a bit.
('79', 24, 9, 26, 46429) It was surrender, and what I have asked for is not surrender but non violent resistance.

('79', 28, 1, 2, 52878) 33. FOREWORD 1
('79', 28, 2, 3, 52893) There are two reasons for printing this edition in the Devanagari script.
('79', 28, 2, 4, 52967) The main reason is that I want to see how far the Gujarati readers can welcome the Devanagari script.
('79', 28, 2, 5, 53069) My dream that there should be one script for all the languages derived from Sanskrit and that should be Devanagari goes back to my South African days.
('79', 28, 2, 6, 53220) However it still remains a dream.
('79', 28, 2, 7, 53254) There is a good deal of talk going on for one script but, as the saying goes, who will bell the cat, who will take the initiative?
('79', 28, 2, 8, 53385) The Gujaratis say,‘Our script is beautiful and easy.
('79', 28, 2, 9, 53438) Why should we give it up?’ And then there is another party that has emerged.

('79', 29, 9, 17, 55267) 36. SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY
('79', 29, 10, 18, 55297) I have avoided mention of the tragedy that has overtaken Gokhale’s greatest creation.
('79', 29, 10, 19, 55383) Through the kindness of Pandit Kunzru I was kept informed of every happening while the Society was going through the agony.
('79', 29, 10, 20, 55507) It was no small matter for the Society to have to expel members or to lose one of its oldest members by resignation.
('79', 29, 10, 21, 55624) The trouble had been brewing for many months.
('79', 29, 10, 22, 55670) But the chief mem bers were putting off what to them was the evil day.
('79', 29, 10, 23, 55741) They tried to bridge differences.
('79', 29, 10, 24, 55775) They failed.

('79', 29, 10, 26, 55870) The Society has a high ideal.

('79', 29, 10, 28, 56044) Gokhale created a certain standard of conduct and tradition for the Society.

('79', 30, 1, 5, 56563) Both are inestimable qualities no doubt.

('79', 30, 1, 8, 56987) I know that the President and the other members left no stone unturned to avoid the crisis.

('79', 31, 1, 2, 58647) 37. QUESTION BOX 1
('79', 31, 2, 3, 58666) Q. What work besides spinning can an active satyagrahi do in cities, especially in Bombay?
('79', 31, 3, 4, 58757) A. I shall reply to your question by a cross question.
('79', 31, 3, 5, 58812) Why do you want anything else besides spinning?
('79', 31, 3, 6, 58860) If you have no interest in spinning, you can be no satyagrahi, active of passive.
('79', 31, 3, 7, 58942) For all satya graha presupposes the qualification of spinning, and this has been before the country for twenty years.
('79', 31, 3, 8, 59060) You can, therefore, do no better than give all your spare time to spinning.
('79', 31, 3, 9, 59136) Do it in a scientific way.
('79', 31, 3, 10, 59163) If there is no room for a spinning wheel, you can ply the takli.
('79', 31, 3, 11, 59228) A way has now been devised for easily increasing the speed on the takli.
('79', 31, 3, 12, 59301) It costs a trifle, and it can be plied in any little corner of the house.
('79', 31, 3, 13, 59375) If you are not doing your own carding , you must do so now.
('79', 31, 3, 14, 59435) You may have no space for a carding bow in your room.
('79', 31, 3, 15, 59489) You should in that case card according to the Andhra method adapted by Vinoba.
('79', 31, 3, 16, 59568) If you can interest yourself in this, it will add considerably to your useful knowledge.
('79', 31, 3, 17, 59657) When you come to think of the romance of cotton, you will get out of it an interest the best novel c a nn o t g i ve y o u, a n d you will probably discover the solution of the problem of Indian poverty.
('79', 31, 3, 18, 59861) Therefore, if you want to be a true satyagrahi, if you want to cultivate true ahimsa, I would suggest to you spinning and nothing but spinning, no matter where you may be.
('79', 31, 3, 19, 60033) Take it from me that without sacrificial spinning non violent swaraj is impossible.
('79', 31, 3, 20, 60117) But if you have enough time on your hands and you are already doing all the spinning that would satisfy me, and if you are longing to do some additional act of service, I can suggest quite a number of things.
('79', 31, 3, 21, 60326) For instance, there is Harijan service.
('79', 31, 3, 22, 60366) Try to enter Harijan's life, go and stay in Harijan quarters, teach them, nurse those who are ill, show them the ways and means of improving their economic condition.
('79', 31, 3, 23, 60533) All this offers a wide field of work.
('79', 31, 3, 24, 60571) Thakkar Bapa is now going to spend a lot of time in Bombay.
('79', 31, 3, 25, 60631) Go and seek his guidance.
('79', 31, 3, 26, 60657) Then I would ask you to cultivate disinterested friendship of the Mussalmans, it is likely that you do not even know your next door neighbours.
('79', 31, 3, 27, 60801) Make their acquaintance and try to render what service
('79', 31, 4, 28, 60856) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandu, 20 7 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.

('79', 32, 1, 2, 61023) you can to them.
('79', 32, 1, 3, 61040) If you do not know those of other faiths, try to culti vate acquaintance with them.
('79', 32, 1, 4, 61124) Your contacts will be the test of your broad mindedness.

('79', 32, 1, 10, 61524) DO NOT JUDGE
('79', 32, 2, 11, 61537) Q. Many Congressmen in Bombay have joined the Congress for the sake of offices.
('79', 32, 2, 12, 61617) They never spin.
('79', 32, 2, 13, 61634) Some have spinning wheels in their homes just for show.

('79', 32, 3, 15, 61707) A. Do not judge others.

('79', 32, 3, 19, 61986) MAY HARIJANS ENLIST AS RECRUITS?
('79', 32, 4, 20, 62019) Q. I Am a Harijan sevak.

('79', 32, 5, 32, 62785) The wonder to me is that even among the suppressed there are some Harijans who have truly learnt the lesson to ahimsa.
('79', 32, 5, 33, 62904) CHIVALRY v.

('79', 33, 1, 5, 63570) IMPLICATIONS OF UNTOUCHABILITY
('79', 33, 2, 6, 63601) Q. In satyagraha camps there often crops up the question of the implications of untouchability.
('79', 33, 2, 7, 63697) In Bihar this certainly is the case.
('79', 33, 2, 8, 63734) If abolition of untouchability consists simply in touching the Harijans, untouchability does not exist in Bihar.
('79', 33, 2, 9, 63847) But if it includes letting the Harijans use your water pot and exchange water with non Harijans, if it includes inter dining and allowing them to enter your dining room and kitchen, even Congressmen are not free from this untouchability.
('79', 33, 2, 10, 64085) What do you say to this?
('79', 33, 3, 11, 64110) A. Abolition of untouchability in me will be really achieved only when I behave towards Harijans as I should towards my own kith and kin.

('79', 33, 3, 16, 64652) I do not often use this word nowadays, but it is there in an important Congress resolution.

('79', 33, 3, 18, 64905) Their lives had undergone a conver sion.

('79', 33, 3, 20, 64989) DONATION OF TAINTED MONEY
('79', 33, 4, 21, 65015) Q. Supposing a man has earned million by exploiting millions of his poor brethren and made a gift of them to a Mahatma like you, and supposing you use that money for the benefit of humanity, is the exploiter absolved from sin?
('79', 33, 4, 22, 65242) Does not some blame attach to you too for having accepted this ill gotten wealth?
('79', 33, 4, 23, 65324) How can one remain blameless in this unending vicious circle?
('79', 33, 4, 24, 65386) How is ahimsa to cope with this immoral exploitation?
('79', 33, 5, 25, 65440) A. Let us assume for the purpose of this riddle that I am really a Mahatma, and then try to solve it.
('79', 33, 5, 26, 65542) The gift of what you assume to be ill gotten gains cannot lessen the guilt of the exploiter.
('79', 33, 5, 27, 65635) If he had kept the money for himself, that would have been an additional count against him.
('79', 33, 5, 28, 65727) If instead he makes a gift of it to me from pure motives, he escapes the additional sin.
('79', 33, 5, 29, 65816) It is also likely that a good use of his gift may wean the exploiter from immoral means of making money.
('79', 33, 5, 30, 65921) But no blame attaches to me for having accepted the gift.
('79', 33, 5, 31, 65979) As the foul waters from drains flowing into the sea partake of its purity, even so does tainted wealth become pure when put to the purest use.
('79', 33, 5, 32, 66122) There is
('79', 34, 0, 1, 66131) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 35
('79', 34, 1, 2, 66176) one condition, however, that we have assumed, viz., that the gift is made and accepted out of pure motives.
('79', 34, 1, 3, 66284) Exploitation of the poor can be extinguished not by effecting the destruction of a few millionaires, but by removing the ignorance of the poor and teaching them to non co operate with their exploiters.
('79', 34, 1, 4, 66486) That will convert the exploiters also.
('79', 34, 1, 5, 66525) I have even suggested that ultimately it will lead to both being equal partners.
('79', 34, 1, 6, 66606) Capital as such is not evil; it is its wrong use that is evil.
('79', 34, 1, 7, 66669) Capital in some from or other will always be needed.
('79', 34, 1, 8, 66722) A FLAW IN AHIMSA
('79', 34, 2, 9, 66739) Q. You have appealed to Briton to lay down arms and to adopt non violence.
('79', 34, 2, 10, 66814) But that raises a moral difficulty.
('79', 34, 2, 11, 66850) A’s ahimsa provokes B to himsa and makes him impervious to appeal to his heart.
('79', 34, 2, 12, 66930) If a non violent man comes up against an inanimate thing his non violence will have no effect on it.
('79', 34, 2, 13, 67031) There is, therefore, some flaw somewhere in your belief.
('79', 34, 2, 14, 67088) It is likely that ahimsa may have success in a a restricted field.
('79', 34, 2, 15, 67155) If so, what use is it for universal purposes?
('79', 34, 2, 16, 67201) Your claim, therefore, of its universal use falls to the ground.
('79', 34, 3, 17, 67266) A. Ahimsa cannot be dismissed so lightly as you think.
('79', 34, 3, 18, 67321) Ahimsa is the strongest force known.
('79', 34, 3, 19, 67358) But if all can use the strongest force with equal ease, it would lose its importance.
('79', 34, 3, 20, 67444) We have not been able yet to discover the true measure of the innumerable properties of an article of daily use like water.
('79', 34, 3, 21, 67568) Some of its properties fill us with wonder.
('79', 34, 3, 22, 67612) Let us not, therefore, make light of a force of the subtlest kind like ahimsa, and let us try to discover its hidden power with patience and faith.
('79', 34, 3, 23, 67760) Within a brief space of time we have carried to a fairly succes sful conclusion a great experiment in the use of this force.
('79', 34, 3, 24, 67885) As you know I have not set much store by it.
('79', 34, 3, 25, 67930) Indeed I have hesitated even to call it an experiment in ahimsa.
('79', 34, 3, 26, 67995) But according to the legend, as Rama’s name was enough to float stones, even so the movement carried on in the name of ahimsa brought about a great awakening in the country and carried us ahead.
('79', 34, 3, 27, 68190) It is difficult to forecast the possi bilities when men with unflinching faith carry this experiment further forward.
('79', 34, 3, 28, 68308) To say that those who use violence are all insensible is an exaggeration.
('79', 34, 3, 29, 68382) Some do seem to lose their senses, but we are bound to be mistaken if we try to base a moral law on those exceptions.
('79', 34, 3, 30, 68500) The safest course is to lay down laws on the strength of our usual exper ience, and our usual experience is that in most cases non violence is the real antidote to violence, and it is safe to infer from it that the highest violence can be met by the highest non violence.
('79', 34, 3, 31, 68772) But let us consider for a moment inanimate objects.
('79', 34, 3, 32, 68824) He will surely break his head who strikes it against a stone.
('79', 34, 3, 33, 68886) But supposing a stone comes against us through space, we can escape it by stepping
('79', 35, 0, 1, 68969) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 35, 1, 2, 69010) aside, or if there is nowhere to step aside, we can bravely stay where we are and receive the stone.
('79', 35, 1, 3, 69111) That will mean minimum injury and, in case it proves fatal, the death will not be as painful as it would be if we made an effort to ward it off.
('79', 35, 1, 4, 69256) Extend the thought a little further, and it is easy to see that, if a senseless man is left alone and no one tries to resist him, he is sure to exhaust himself.
('79', 35, 1, 5, 69417) Indeed it is not quite inconceivable that the loving sacrifice of many may bring an insane man to his senses.
('79', 35, 1, 6, 69527) Instances are not wanting of absolutely insane people having come back to their senses.

('79', 35, 2, 8, 69666) 38. TWO JUST COMPLAINTS 1
('79', 35, 3, 9, 69692) I RIGHT OF TRANSLATION A Calcutta telegram protests against the reservation of copyright in translations of my Gujarati articles, saying that my articles are the property of the nation and therefore there could be no copyright in them, and that I myself had taught that Hindustani was the lingua franca of India, and that I should therefore reconsider my decision.
('79', 35, 3, 10, 70057) This grievance appears on the face of it to be just.
('79', 35, 3, 11, 70110) But it is forgotten that I have prohibited translation from Gujarati into all other langu ages.
('79', 35, 3, 12, 70206) Experience had taught me that English translations of my articles written in any Indian languages were faulty, but it would not have been proper to confine the copyright to translations into English.
('79', 35, 3, 13, 70406) All important Gujarati articles would be translated simultaneously into English and Hindustani and published almost at the same time.
('79', 35, 3, 14, 70540) There is, therefore, no hardship involved, for there is no copyright in the translated articles which can be and are being reproduced.
('79', 35, 4, 15, 70675) My object was clear and unexceptionable.
('79', 35, 4, 16, 70716) if I wanted to enter the hearts of the Indian masses, I should write in an Indian language, and that language could be no other than that in which I could write with the greatest ease.
('79', 35, 4, 17, 70901) If I had the same command over Hindustani as over Gujarati, I should have written only in Hindustani.

('79', 36, 1, 20, 73166) I claim that consciousness on my part of my belonging to Gujarat has never meant any exclusiveness.
('79', 36, 1, 21, 73266) I have always believed and described myself as in Indian.
('79', 36, 1, 22, 73324) When I went to South Africa I found that there were divisions among our countrymen into Tamils, Telugus and Gujaratis.
('79', 36, 1, 23, 73443) Immediately on my landing I abolished the divisions.
('79', 36, 1, 24, 73496) For myself I knew that all the immigrants from India were Indians , and that provincial or religious divisions between them were improper.
('79', 36, 1, 25, 73635) It was true that they belonged to different provinces and to different faiths and that they spoke different languages, but all belonged to the same country, all had the same joys and sorrows, and all were under the same alien rule.
('79', 36, 1, 26, 73867) Besides even the people of the country where they had gone did not know and did not know and did not recognize the distinctions of caste, religion, language or province.
('79', 36, 1, 27, 74037) To them we were all Indians, all coolies, all samis, and all to be governed by the same
('79', 37, 0, 1, 74125) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 37, 1, 2, 74166) We have ceased to be called coolies and samis, but we have not ceased to be Indians.
('79', 37, 1, 3, 74251) Thus alike by temperament and from experience I have been against these divisions, as I think everyone should be.
('79', 37, 1, 4, 74365) Nevertheless when I begin to think in terms of the talents God has given me and of the use I should make of them for the service of the motherland, I cannot afford to ignore the province of my birth.
('79', 37, 1, 5, 74565) As Gujarati is my mother tongue and as I know the Gujaratis more intimately, I could serve India best through Gujarat and the Gujarati language.
('79', 37, 1, 6, 74710) It was this consideration that was at the back of the choice of Gujarat as my place of abode on my return from South Africa.
('79', 37, 1, 7, 74835) But I deliberately did not choose Porbandar or Rajkot, though I had invitations from and facilities in both the places.
('79', 37, 1, 8, 74955) For I had ceased to belong to Porbandar and Rajkot, ceased to belong to my caste.
('79', 37, 1, 9, 75037) My choice has been proved to be cent per cent right.
('79', 37, 1, 10, 75090) It could not be otherwise, as I believe that my footsteps are guided by God, and all my life is based on this belief.
('79', 37, 1, 11, 75208) If the argument presented above appeals to the reader and to the co worker who has made the complaint in question, I need not labour it any more.
('79', 37, 1, 12, 75354) But something more I must say for the sake of the work I want from Gujarat and from the other provinces of India.
('79', 37, 1, 13, 75468) I do not enjoy elsewhere the same intimacy and extent of contact as I do with the Gujarati worker.
('79', 37, 1, 14, 75567) And so if I succeed with them, I should have confidence regarding the rest of India.
('79', 37, 1, 15, 75652) Some of them believe that I should again fix up my abode in Gujarat, but I do not think so.
('79', 37, 1, 16, 75744) If I stayed in their midst, they would lose initiative, and cease to work independently, they have a tried leader like the Sardar to guide them at every step, and I feel that if I stayed in Gujarat my talents would not be put to the fullest possible use.
('79', 37, 1, 17, 75999) It is God who has guided my steps to Sevagram.
('79', 37, 1, 18, 76046) It may be a difficult field or work.
('79', 37, 1, 19, 76083) If it is, surely I may not shirk it.
('79', 37, 1, 20, 76120) Stay in Sevagram has taught me, is teaching me, a lot that is new.
('79', 37, 1, 21, 76187) If I can be one with its six hundred souls, if I can engage them in constructive work and in the necessary work of reform, and if I can easily make a satyagrahi army of them, I should discover the key to do the same work in the whole of India.
('79', 37, 1, 22, 76431) If I chose a big city, I should get lost, puzzled and perplexed.
('79', 37, 1, 23, 76496) Much of what has been done and planned in Sevagram has been done from the point of view of India.
('79', 37, 1, 24, 76594) It is, therefore, but meet that I must deliver my message through Sevagram and in Gujarati.
('79', 37, 1, 25, 76686) There is one fact which can upset the plan of burying myself in Sevagram.
('79', 37, 1, 26, 76760) The khan Shaheb can summon me to his province when ever he likes for his work, which indeed is also my work.
('79', 37, 1, 27, 76869) If he succe eds in expressing real ahimsa, I firmly believe that the whole country
('79', 38, 0, 1, 76952) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 39
('79', 38, 1, 2, 76997) can succeed.
('79', 38, 1, 3, 77010) For the experiment there is out and out that of non violence of the brave.
('79', 38, 1, 4, 77085) God alone knows whether it will or will not succeed.
('79', 38, 1, 5, 77138) This I know that wherever I go I will do His work.
('79', 38, 1, 6, 77189) I regard the winning of Indian independence by non violent means as God’s own work, and if that is achieved, the whole world would be saved from being drowned in a sea of bloodshed.
('79', 38, 1, 7, 77371) The reader will now see that I am prompted by partiality for neither Gujarat nor anything else.
('79', 38, 1, 8, 77467) If there is any partiality, it is for truth and non violence.
('79', 38, 1, 9, 77529) It is through these that I can have some glimpse of God.
('79', 38, 1, 10, 77586) Truth and non violence are my God.
('79', 38, 1, 11, 77621) They are the obverse and reverse of the same coin.
('79', 38, 1, 12, 77672) My co worker’s complaint is true that in the abolition of untouchability and in love of khadi Gujarat lags behind other provinces.
('79', 38, 1, 13, 77803) But that does not mean that I should leave Gujarat alone.
('79', 38, 1, 14, 77861) If these who items cannot be accomplished in Gujarat, Gujarat will be an obstacle to the independence of India.
('79', 38, 1, 15, 77973) If I can inspire the Gujaratis to lay down their lives for the abolition of the curses of untouchability and unemployment, what a glorious thing it would be!
('79', 38, 1, 16, 78131) It would be a sight for all India to see and copy.
('79', 38, 1, 17, 78182) Hindu Muslim troubles would automatically come to an end, for the moment we cast out untouch ability from our hearts Hindu Muslims unity will be an accomplished fact and many another good thing would follow as a matter of course.
('79', 38, 1, 18, 78412) All this is only a dream today.
('79', 38, 1, 19, 78444) But it is in order to realize that dream that I have undertaken in my old age this Gujarati enterprise.
('79', 38, 1, 20, 78548) If it is God’s will thus to take work from me, age will be no bar.
('79', 38, 1, 21, 78615) SEVAGRAM, July 22, 1940 Harijan, 28 7 1940
('79', 38, 2, 22, 78658) 39. OPEN LETTER
('79', 38, 3, 23, 78674) MY DEAR GANDHIJI,
('79', 38, 4, 24, 78692) I am still hoping and praying daily that Congress may see that its supreme opportunity is not to win a doubtful political victory over a foe but .
('79', 38, 4, 25, 78839) to win the lasting friendship of all who love liberty, in England and in all the world, by revealing the only adequate zeal for India’s defence or defence of democracy in the world the non violent war to the finish against the whole structure of man’s inhumanity to man.
('79', 38, 4, 26, 79110) The combined might of India, building a third rate military force, can at best but become the support of force.
('79', 38, 4, 27, 79222) But defence committees and those who know no better way should not be discouraged.
('79', 38, 4, 28, 79305) What I do mean is that, at the same time, those who understand and love peace should build up a non violent defence force for the precise purpose for which military force is being established.
('79', 38, 4, 29, 79498) Like the military
('79', 39, 0, 1, 79516) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 39, 1, 2, 79557) forces, these should also be non political and voluntary.
('79', 39, 1, 3, 79615) Besides being negatively harmless to the interests of the defence of India, such a force should at the very outset place itself at the disposal of the Government for the purpose either of defence or offence against all the foes of liberty in India or elsewhere, as the non violent army of India.
('79', 39, 2, 4, 79911) I think that this war has already revealed that armed force cannot defend even the institutions of democracy without first nullifying them and second destroying them.
('79', 39, 2, 5, 80078) Further, the very strongest military defence force in the world has not been able to make its nation secure in this war mad world.
('79', 39, 2, 6, 80209) I am convinced that a non violent war against all aggression, the economic as well as the poitical, not only will prove more effective than all the armies but can very rapidly be made available, if the non violent of the world will but put their minds and hearts to the matter.
('79', 39, 3, 7, 80487) Traditional democracy theoretically reserved the right of violent rebellion to aggrieved people whose will was no longer represented in their government.
('79', 39, 3, 8, 80641) But pure democracy must repudiate the violence, while reserving the right of rebellion.
('79', 39, 3, 9, 80729) This is because violence, however employed, is the antithesis of democracy, .
('79', 39, 3, 10, 80807) I do not think there is a single instance in his tory where defensive war has ever settled the problems for which the defen ders have supposed they fought.
('79', 39, 3, 11, 80963) But Denmark, on the other hand, is the supreme illustration of a nation setting itself on the road to liberty by the deliberate repudiation of the “glory” of imperial conquest or defence of integrity.
('79', 39, 4, 12, 81164) Kristagraha has already taken its unequivocal stand for the non violence of Christ its Master, in it two manifestos.
('79', 39, 4, 13, 81281) It will perhaps be reviewing its stand shortly in order to make its present position fully clear in the face of the new turn of events, though that may seem unnecessary.
('79', 39, 4, 14, 81451) Many missionaries have recently received copies of Memorandum A, under which all non British missionaries serve in India.
('79', 39, 4, 15, 81573) It was surprise to most of them to note that the Government had provided for them to “influence” politics in the interest of assisting in the preservation of the nation’s security and well being.
('79', 39, 4, 16, 81769) Here then, I believe, is the supreme opportunity for Christian lovers of freedom, missionary and non missionary, to serve their nation and the world while adhering to their Master’s injunction not to take up the sword.
('79', 39, 4, 17, 81988) I can only say for myself that I am prepared to surrender fully to
('79', 39, 5, 18, 82055) this great cause, and do hereby pledge to follow your leadership if you decide to launch the Satyagraha Army of the World.
('79', 39, 5, 19, 82178) I do this because I believe it is the only way that the real aggression can ever be uprooted from its soil in mankind’s unbrotherliness and the world established on a basis of justice, quality and peace .
('79', 39, 5, 20, 82383) I can see no hope whatever in the way the United States and England have so far taken.
('79', 39, 5, 21, 82470) The war of 1940 will never be won.
('79', 39, 5, 22, 82505) Chaos can win over order, barbarity over civilization, autocracy over democracy,
('79', 40, 0, 1, 82586) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 41
('79', 40, 1, 2, 82631) darkness over light, and violence over goodwill.
('79', 40, 1, 3, 82680) That has already transpired over a large part of the world and is fast coming in the rest.
('79', 40, 1, 4, 82771) But generous application of goodwill can still arrest this in every part, especially when men in large numbers are ready to lay down their lives for the Truth that is in them.
('79', 40, 2, 5, 82947) I pray that God may lead you in His own way.
('79', 40, 2, 6, 82992) You have countless friends encircling our earth.
('79', 40, 2, 7, 83041) Through the instrumentality of non violent resistance to the mountainous lovelessness and stupidity or our ago, the way may yet open into the new day and a peace of full justice prevail among the nations.
('79', 40, 3, 8, 83246) With the deepest appreciation of your single minded devotion to Truth, and with the sincerest affection.
('79', 40, 3, 9, 83351) I am, Yours for the World Satyagraha Army, Ralph T. Templin I gladly publish this letter.

('79', 40, 4, 19, 84009) 40. TRAVANCORE
('79', 40, 5, 20, 84024) In the hope of having a talk with Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar and possibly arriving at some way out of the impasse, I was suppres sing the manifestos sent to me by succeeding acting Presidents.
('79', 40, 5, 21, 84216) The last received was from Shri Achuthan, a Harijan advocate, about the last week of June.
('79', 40, 5, 22, 84307) From the manifesto I extract only statements of facts, omitting as far as possible all argument and inferences:
('79', 40, 6, 23, 84419) Processions and meeting have been violently broken up by the special police and the ordinary police without even the semblance of prohibitory orders.
('79', 40, 6, 24, 84569) To quote from the speech of Shri.
('79', 40, 6, 25, 84603) K. Santhanam, M. L. A. (Central) which he delivered at Madras after a brief visit to Travancrore, he said: “My impression is there is police raj in Travancore.
('79', 40, 6, 26, 84763) No one could speak with any
('79', 40, 7, 27, 84791) 1 Only extracts have been reproduced here.
('79', 40, 7, 28, 84834) 2 Vide “Discussion with Emily Kinnaird”, 20 7 1940
('79', 41, 0, 1, 84885) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 41, 1, 2, 84926) sense of security or discuss matters even with friends.
('79', 41, 1, 3, 84982) The Government appear determined not to allow any discussion on responsible government, and are willing to resort to any methods to prevent it.
('79', 41, 1, 4, 85126) All normal channels of public expression have been stopped.”
('79', 41, 2, 5, 85187) Repression has worked ruthlessly along three main lines: 1. Legal terrorism, 2. Police terrorism, 3. Complete muzzling of the Press.
('79', 41, 3, 6, 85320) 1. Legal terrorism has taken the shape of ‘the Defence of Travancore Proclamation’.
('79', 41, 3, 7, 85404) It is not the actual number of those arrested and detained for indefinite periods under this Act, but the threat of it against every man and woman with any active sympathy towards the State Congress that has created a grave situation.
('79', 41, 3, 8, 85639) Several people have been arrested under this Act and then let off, just to show that the authorities can do anything with anybody.
('79', 41, 3, 9, 85770) Many important leaders have been imprisoned under this Act without trial and for indefinite periods.
('79', 41, 4, 10, 85871) 2. Police terrorism has meant more than what will be ordinarily understood by that term.
('79', 41, 4, 11, 85960) In Travancore it has meant more than the forcible dispersal of processions and meetings.
('79', 41, 4, 12, 86049) It has meant secret as well as open goondaism by what are called the special police who wear no uniforms and who get only Rs. 5 a month.
('79', 41, 4, 13, 86186) This body of special police contains in many cases the worst rowdies and drunkards in various localities.
('79', 41, 4, 14, 86292) Their special business is to quietly mix with the crowds and start sudden goondaism.
('79', 41, 4, 15, 86377) It has become physically impossible to hold any decent meeting or procession or demonstration n the face of such goondaism.
('79', 41, 4, 16, 86501) In Neyyattinkara, Alleppey, Palai, Karunagapilly and many other place such goondaism has appeared openly.
('79', 41, 5, 17, 86607) 3. Muzzling of the Press.
('79', 41, 5, 18, 86633) No doubt there are several papers in Travancore which appear regularly.
('79', 41, 5, 19, 86705) Not one of them would publish reports or news of State Congress meetings and demonstrations.
('79', 41, 5, 20, 86798) Statements issued by Acting Presidents of the State Congress or by State Congress leaders never appear in them.
('79', 41, 5, 21, 86910) In many cases people in one part of the State never knew anything of what happened in another part except from news appearing in the English papers at Madras.
('79', 41, 5, 22, 87069) This was proved when police frightfulness occurred in Neyyattinkara and Palai.
('79', 41, 6, 23, 87148) But the Travancore Government did not rest content with the above items of repression.
('79', 41, 6, 24, 87235) Every officer from the highest to the lowest went about the country treating every State Congressman or sympathizer not merely as one belonging to a disturbing political party but as an enemy to be hunted down by every means in their power.
('79', 41, 6, 25, 87476) Another severe trial for those engaged in the struggle has been police violence in lock up.
('79', 41, 6, 26, 87568) Volunteers who are under arrest and awaiting trial are mercilessly beaten and very often discharged after several weeks of detention without trial.
('79', 42, 0, 1, 87716) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 43
('79', 42, 1, 2, 87761) Every time State Congress leaders published allegations against the Travancore police, the Government as often came out with categorical and wholesale denials.
('79', 42, 1, 3, 87921) But Shri G. Ramachandran’s specific allegations regarding police terrorism at Neyyattinkara and Palai published in The Hindu of Madras supported by unimpeachable data have at last compelled the Government to order an official enquiry.
('79', 42, 1, 4, 88156) It is significant that the enquiry has been ordered long after the Government had published categorical and wholesale denials of the allegation!
('79', 42, 1, 5, 88301) The public are still awaiting the findings of the enquiry.
('79', 42, 2, 6, 88360) The most disquieting development in the present situation has yet to be related.
('79', 42, 2, 7, 88441) This is the direct and open encouragement given to the various com munal organizations in Travancore by the authorities including the Dewan, Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar himself.
('79', 42, 2, 8, 88617) At one time Sir.
('79', 42, 2, 9, 88634) C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar used to say that it was the presence of various communal organizations in Travancore which prevented him from inaugurating any scheme of responsi ble government in Travancore.
('79', 42, 2, 10, 88832) But today his policy clearly appears to be to encourage each and every communal organization to develop along separate lines and thus make political unity impossible.
('79', 42, 2, 11, 88999) Officers of Government inclu ding the Dewan take part in meetings of the various communal organiza tions.
('79', 42, 2, 12, 89105) Lovers of Travancore know that, if this process is allowed to continue, Travancore will soon become a battleground for the various communal organi zations.
('79', 42, 2, 13, 89261) I know that there will be an official contradiction.
('79', 42, 2, 14, 89314) I have alre ady suggested that such contradictions can have no value unless they are backed by a definite promise of an impartial enquiry.
('79', 42, 2, 15, 89453) Officials stake nothing when they issue unprovable contradictions, whereas State Congress Presidents stake their liberty and the prestige of their institution when they make rash statements.
('79', 42, 2, 16, 89644) The balance of probability therefore, must be in their favour.
('79', 42, 2, 17, 89707) The quotation given by Shri Achuthan from Shri Santhanam’s spe ech in his support is not to be lightly brushed aside.
('79', 42, 2, 18, 89825) I sent a copy of Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar’s wire to Shri Ramachandran.
('79', 42, 2, 19, 89897) He sends a comment from which I take the following:
('79', 42, 3, 20, 89949) I can show that our Working Committee kept ‘communist tendencies’ clearly and absolutely out of the struggle.
('79', 42, 3, 21, 90059) Mr. K. C. George who is referred to was one of the severest critics of our Working Committee, and considered our work and programme as thoroughly useless.
('79', 42, 3, 22, 90214) It is absolutely false to say that we depend on Bapu’s periodical statements for collecting our funds and for our existence.
('79', 42, 3, 23, 90339) If this were so, there should be today no State Congress.
('79', 42, 3, 24, 90397) During the last eight or nine months Bapu has not said a word about Travan core.
('79', 42, 3, 25, 90478) Our cause is so patently just that it does not depend even on Bapu.
('79', 42, 3, 26, 90546) It depends on its own inherent justice.
('79', 42, 3, 27, 90586) Bapu can of course help our cause.
('79', 42, 3, 28, 90621) But that is different from saying that our movement depends on Bapu.
('79', 43, 0, 1, 90690) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 43, 1, 2, 90731) Most of the leading members of the Travancore State Congress including Shri V. K. Velayudhan and M. N. Parameswaran Pillai and others have openly dissociated themselves, says Sir C. P. Yes, these two gentle men have done so.
('79', 43, 1, 3, 90956) But neither of them has said that the State Congress is in the wrong.

('79', 43, 1, 9, 91533) 1 Then there is my second statement on the Palai atrocities which The Hindu published and a copy of which I am enclosing.
('79', 43, 1, 10, 91655) It was then stated on behalf of the Travancore Government that there would be an official enquiry and a press communique.
('79', 43, 1, 11, 91777) It is weeks now since this appeared, and no enquiry or communique has been heard of.

('79', 43, 1, 19, 92464) A friend sent me the other day a bon mot of an American President: ‘One true man of courage represents a majority.’ I have quoted from memory.
('79', 43, 1, 20, 92607) But there is no mistake about the meaning.

('79', 45, 1, 2, 94824) 42. NOT QUITE SO BAD
('79', 45, 2, 3, 94845) A friend quotes from a letter received from an English friend.:
('79', 45, 3, 4, 94909) Do you think that Mahatma’s appeal 1 to every Briton is going to pro duce right reactions in the mind or heart of a single Briton?
('79', 45, 3, 5, 95040) That appeal has probably created more ill will than anything else recently.
('79', 45, 3, 6, 95116) We live in asto nishing and critical times, and it is frightfully difficult to decide what should be done.
('79', 45, 3, 7, 95223) At any rate we should try to avoid obvious dangers.
('79', 45, 3, 8, 95275) So far as I can see, Mahatma’s unadulterated policy must inevitably lead to disaster for India.
('79', 45, 3, 9, 95371) How far he himself intends following it I do not know, for he has a wonderful way of adapting himself to his material.
('79', 45, 3, 10, 95490) Well I happen to know that many more than one single heart have been touched by my ‘Appeal to Every Briton’.
('79', 45, 3, 11, 95599) I know that many English friends were anxious for me to take some such step.
('79', 45, 3, 12, 95676) But I do not want to take comfort from the approbation, however pleasing in it self, of English friends.
('79', 45, 3, 13, 95781) What is of value for me is to know that at least one Englishman thinks as stated in the extract.
('79', 45, 3, 14, 95878) Such knowledge should put me on my guard.
('79', 45, 3, 15, 95920) It should make me more careful, if possible, in the selection of the words I use to express my thought.
('79', 45, 3, 16, 96024) But no displeasure even of the dearest friends can put me off the duty I see clearly in front of me.
('79', 45, 3, 17, 96125) And this duty of making the appeal was so peremptory that it was impossible for me to put it off.
('79', 45, 3, 18, 96223) As certain as I am writing this, the world has to come to the state to which I have invited Britan.
('79', 45, 3, 19, 96323) Those who will be witnesses of that happy and not far off event will recall my Appeal with gladness.
('79', 45, 3, 20, 96424) I know that the Appeal has hastened its advent.
('79', 45, 3, 21, 96472) Why should a single Briton resent an appeal to him to be braver than he is, to be better than is in every respect?
('79', 45, 3, 22, 96587) He may plead inability, but he cannot be displeased by an appeal to his nobler nature.
('79', 45, 3, 23, 96674) Why should the Appeal breed any ill will at all?
('79', 45, 3, 24, 96723) There is no cause given for it by the manner or the matter of the Appeal.
('79', 45, 3, 25, 96797) I have not advised cessation of fight.
('79', 45, 3, 26, 96836) I have advised lifting it to a plane worthy of human nature, of the divinity man shares with God Himself.
('79', 45, 3, 27, 96942) If the hidden meaning of the remark is that by making the Appeal I have strengthened Nazi hands, the suggestion does not bear scrutiny.
('79', 45, 3, 28, 97078) Herr Hitler can only be confounded by the adoption by Britain of the novel method of fighting.
('79', 45, 3, 29, 97173) At one single stroke he will find that all his tremendous armament has been put out of action.
('79', 45, 3, 30, 97268) A warrior lives on
('79', 45, 4, 31, 97287) 1Vide “To Every Briton”
('79', 46, 0, 1, 97311) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 47
('79', 46, 1, 2, 97356) his wars whether offensive or defensive.
('79', 46, 1, 3, 97397) He suffers a collapse if he finds that his warring capacity is unwanted.
('79', 46, 1, 4, 97470) My Appeal is not from a coward to brave people to shed their bravery, not is it a mockery from a fair weather friend to one in distress.
('79', 46, 1, 5, 97607) I suggest to the writer to re read my Appeal in the light of my explanation.
('79', 46, 1, 6, 97684) One thing Herr Hitler, as every critic, may say: I am a fool without any knowledge of the world or human nature.
('79', 46, 1, 7, 97797) That would be a harmless certificate which need excite neither ill will nor anger.
('79', 46, 1, 8, 97880) It would be harmless because I have earned such certificates before now.
('79', 46, 1, 9, 97953) This one would be the latest of the many editions, and I hope not the last, for my foolish experiments have not yet ended.
('79', 46, 1, 10, 98076) So far as India is concerned, my unadulterated policy can never harm her, if she adopts it.
('79', 46, 1, 11, 98168) If India as a whole rejects it.
('79', 46, 1, 12, 98200) There can be no harm accruing except to those who may foolishly pursue it.
('79', 46, 1, 13, 98275) The correspondent has lighted upon my strong point when he says: “Mahatma has a wonderful way of adapting himself to his material.” My instinctive knowledge of my material has given me a faith which cannot be moved.
('79', 46, 1, 14, 98491) I feel within me that the material is ready.
('79', 46, 1, 15, 98536) My instinct has not betrayed me once.
('79', 46, 1, 16, 98574) But I must not build much upon past experience.
('79', 46, 1, 17, 98622) “One step enough for me.” SEVAGRAM, July 24, 1940 Harijan, 28 7 1940

('79', 49, 1, 2, 101724) 49. LETTER TO SUSHILA NAYYAR
('79', 49, 2, 3, 101753) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, July 25, 1940
('79', 49, 3, 4, 101785) SUSHILA, I have your letter.
('79', 49, 3, 5, 101814) 1 understand about the patients.
('79', 49, 3, 6, 101847) I see your point about the dispensary too.
('79', 49, 3, 7, 101890) Even as your view becomes stronger, mine does too.
('79', 49, 3, 8, 101941) My mind will never accept that I have let you down.
('79', 49, 3, 9, 101993) I claim to have actually saved you when you felt you were being let down.
('79', 49, 3, 10, 102067) I have saved you like a mother saves her child.
('79', 49, 3, 11, 102115) The child would think with irritation that the mother was stopping its progress.
('79', 49, 3, 12, 102196) But you are and are not a child.
('79', 49, 3, 13, 102229) Hence, we shall call it a differenceof opinion and pull the curtain down over the affair.
('79', 49, 3, 14, 102319) Moreover, in spite of my explaining it you refuse to be convinced that none of those staying with me have any certainty of tenure.
('79', 49, 3, 15, 102450) I can let any of them go whenever I like.
('79', 49, 3, 16, 102492) If any of them assume any such right, it is a mistake on their part.
('79', 49, 3, 17, 102561) Even though some of them may have been with me from the beginning, it is not by virtue of any such right.
('79', 49, 3, 18, 102667) I may have acted as though they had this right, but there has been a reason for it.
('79', 49, 3, 19, 102751) But why go into that discussion now?
('79', 49, 3, 20, 102788) I am accepting your decision.
('79', 49, 3, 21, 102818) Come here when you cannot help it.
('79', 49, 3, 22, 102853) You do have a place here.
('79', 49, 3, 23, 102879) I shall welcome you.
('79', 49, 3, 24, 102900) I do not wish to make you unhappy by dragging you here against your will.
('79', 49, 3, 25, 102974) I am not able to send you the English matter early because I have not been able to get it ready.
('79', 49, 3, 26, 103071) I see from Pyarelal’s letter that you wish to have the Tata scholarship (or something) if you can get it.
('79', 49, 3, 27, 103177) It would be nice if Mahadev could do something.
('79', 49, 3, 28, 103225) Then why do you not let Mahadev talk straight to you?
('79', 49, 3, 29, 103279) You take from me whatever money you need.
('79', 49, 3, 30, 103321) Or I shall arrange to raise the amount.
('79', 49, 3, 31, 103361) This should be the easiest way for you.
('79', 49, 3, 32, 103401) Your health has deteriorated.
('79', 49, 3, 33, 103431) It is my wish and demand that you should improve it.
('79', 49, 3, 34, 103484) It can be easily done.
