('79', 50, 3, 7, 104094) 51. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW July 26, 1940
('79', 50, 4, 8, 104138) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, This is a purely personal letter.
('79', 50, 4, 9, 104194) No one shall see it except those in charge of the office.
('79', 50, 4, 10, 104252) It is reported to me by persons of status that money is being spent like water in the name of the war.
('79', 50, 4, 11, 104355) Men who have enjoyed fat salaries in their respective jobs are being taken up for the war at much higher salaries and given ranks to which they have never been used before.
('79', 50, 4, 12, 104528) The largest number of these are said to be Europeans or Anglo Indians.
('79', 50, 4, 13, 104599) If patriotism is the deciding factor, these gentlemen should take, and be given, no more than just enough to keep them and their dependants.
('79', 50, 4, 14, 104740) On the one hand money is said to be spent on a most extra vagant scale; on the other it is collected in a manner bordering on force.
('79', 50, 4, 15, 104873) It is being squeezed from rich and poor.
('79', 50, 4, 16, 104914) I have letters from all parts of India complaining of these exactions giving graphic details which it is difficult to believe.
('79', 50, 4, 17, 105041) 3 If you would care to have details I could furnish them.
('79', 50, 4, 18, 105099) The result of these measures but more especially of the colle ctions is much silent discontent and ill will.
('79', 50, 4, 19, 105208) I have been advising corr espondent that they are in no way obliged to yield to pressure unless they are willing.
('79', 50, 4, 20, 105322) I very much fear that a fair part of these collections never reaches the treasury.
('79', 50, 4, 21, 105405) In my opinion they ought to be stopped
('79', 50, 5, 22, 105444) 1 Not reproduced here.

('79', 51, 8, 15, 106515) 53. IS IT PROPER?
('79', 51, 9, 16, 106533) Shri Gopinath Bardoloi, ex Premier of Assam, sends me a newspaper cutting which contains the full text of the speech of H. E. The Governor of Assam at the inaugural meeting of the Assam War Committee.
('79', 51, 9, 17, 106734) From it I take the following extract:
('79', 51, 10, 18, 106772) Let me say how fortunate we are in Assam to have a Ministry which is not only prepared to work the Constitution, but also in pledged to do its best to further the ends of this righteous war, an attitude indeed which reflects clearly the general attitude which prevails throughout this Province.
('79', 51, 10, 19, 107067) One of the finest gestures which the Ministry has made was that which was published recently, but I consider did not get half the publicity it deserved, the gift out of public funds of Rs. 100,000 for war purposes, a gesture of which Assam may well be proud, for so far it is unique in India.
('79', 51, 10, 20, 107360) It symbolizes in a concrete and in a valuable form the sentiments which the Ministry feel as members of the British Commonwealth, a proof of their belief in the righteousness of our cause, of their conviction that the outcome of this war is vital to India, and of their determination to do all in their power to achieve victory.
('79', 51, 10, 21, 107689) And anyone
('79', 51, 11, 22, 107700) 1 The news item carrying the report is dated July 27. 2 H. S. Pamnani, a Congress M. L. A.
('79', 52, 0, 1, 107791) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 53
('79', 52, 1, 2, 107836) who has the temerity to criticize this gift must inevitably stamp himself as an enemy of India and a friend of Hitler.
('79', 52, 1, 3, 107955) In reply to this Shri Gopinath Bardoloi has issued the following statement:
('79', 52, 2, 4, 108031) The speech delivered by His Excellency Sir Robert Reid, Governor of Assam, at the inaugural meeting of the Assam War Committee, will have aroused mixed feelings of surprise and regret amongst all those who hold the democratic rights of fair criticism and free speech dear.
('79', 52, 2, 5, 108304) It is indeed unfortunate that the speech should lend itself to the interpretation that criticism of the Ministry’s gift of a lakh of rupees to the War Fund would be an act of temerity and prove the critic to be an enemy of India and a friend of Hitler.
('79', 52, 3, 6, 108557) I do not indeed understand by virtue of what power the Ministry can make such a gift.
('79', 52, 3, 7, 108643) To me it seems clear that no rules of budgetary and accounts procedure can sanction it.
('79', 52, 3, 8, 108731) The only authority to do so might probably have been the Assembly, and as it gave no such sanction the gift must be unconstitutional.
('79', 52, 3, 9, 108865) That is probably the only reason why other provinces have not done anything of the kind.
('79', 52, 4, 10, 108954) That we are no friends of Hitler need not, I think, be proclaimed; but when the gift is a ministerial act, I do not see why as Opposition we should not criticize it.
('79', 52, 4, 11, 109120) The Congress resolution on India’s co operation in general and of Congressmen in particular is before the country, and His Excellency might well know that a fair proportion of the House and the major section of the people in the country are in full agreement with it.
('79', 52, 4, 12, 109388) In view of this he should not have identified himself with the gift as he has chosen to do.
('79', 52, 4, 13, 109480) Shri Gopinath Bardoloi deserves congratulation on his dignified protest.
('79', 52, 4, 14, 109553) It was certainly unbecoming of a constitutional Governor to Identify himself with the act of his Ministers irrespective of the pro priety or legality of their act and of the wishes of the Opposition in such a matter as a public gift.
('79', 52, 4, 15, 109787) Apart from the legality of the transa ction it is a serious thing for a Ministry to pay out of public funds any sum without previous provision and without the sanction of the House in whose name they have to act and from whom they derive their authority.
('79', 52, 4, 16, 110042) I think Shri Bardoloi was quite right in raising the question.
('79', 52, 4, 17, 110105) And I hope the money will not be paid without a thorough examination of the legality of the transaction.
('79', 52, 4, 18, 110210) I myself so further and suggest that, even if the gift is held to be within the rights of the Mini stry, His Excellency would put himself right if he has the gift san ctioned by the Assam Assembly.
('79', 52, 4, 19, 110408) One lakh of rupees is insignificant compared to the daily expense of nine million sterling incurred by the
('79', 53, 0, 1, 110515) 54 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 53, 1, 2, 110556) British Treasury.
('79', 53, 1, 3, 110574) It is, in my opinion, all the more necessary why extra care should be taken to ensure constitutional propriety.
('79', 53, 1, 4, 110686) SEVAGRAM, July 27, 1940 Harijan, 4 8 1940
('79', 53, 2, 5, 110728) 54. WOMAN’S ROLE 1
('79', 53, 3, 6, 110747) The Standing Committee of the All India Women’s Conference met recently at Abbottabad.
('79', 53, 3, 7, 110834) This was their first venture in the Frontier Province.
('79', 53, 3, 8, 110889) The members, I understand, had a very happy experience.
('79', 53, 3, 9, 110945) There were no caste distinctions, no religious differences.
('79', 53, 3, 10, 111005) Muslim, Sikh and Hindu women freely mixed together.
('79', 53, 3, 11, 111057) The Standing Commit tee passed the following three resolutions:
('79', 53, 4, 12, 111121) 1. The members of the Standing Committee of the All India Women’s Conference assembled at Abbottabad desire to place on record their immense grief and despair at the continuance of war in Europe and the Far East.
('79', 53, 4, 13, 111334) They are in deep sympathy with all those countries which have lost their indepen dence and are under the iron heel of Nazi and Fascist domination against which all sections of India have expressed their opinion in no uncertain terms.
('79', 53, 4, 14, 111568) They appeal again to the women of the world to realize the utter futi lity of trying to settle disputes and grievances by means of war and to throw their whole weight into the cause of peace.
('79', 53, 5, 15, 111760) 2. The Standing Committee reaffirm their belief in non violence as the only effective means of ensuring a lasting peace in the world by the formation of abrotherhood of nations.
('79', 53, 5, 16, 111938) They realize how difficult of attainment this ideal is, and therefore they appeal to Indians women to try to develop the practice of non violence in their individual and collective live, for they feel that with their traditional inheritance of service and sacrifice they could give a lead to the women of the world in this respect.
('79', 53, 6, 17, 112270) 3. The members reiterate the opinion of the A. I. W. C. that the recognition of India’s free status would be a first and logical step towards the attainment of the goal for which Britain is at War namely, the freedom of all nations, and a world democracy.
('79', 53, 6, 18, 112526) Evidently the sisters who met at Abbottabad believe like me that in the war against war women of the world will and should lead.
('79', 53, 7, 19, 112655) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 3 8 1940. The English translation has been reproduced from Harijan, where it was published under "Notes".
('79', 54, 0, 1, 112820) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 55
('79', 54, 1, 2, 112865) their special vocation and privilege.
('79', 54, 1, 3, 112903) Therefore the Committee have reaffirmed their belief in non violence.
('79', 54, 1, 4, 112973) Let me hope that the women who are under the influence of the Conference share the Committee’s belief, and that they will work to that end.
('79', 54, 1, 5, 113113) SEVAGRAM, July 27, 1940 Harijan, 4 8 1940
('79', 54, 2, 6, 113155) 55. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR

('79', 56, 1, 2, 116541) 57. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('79', 56, 2, 3, 116568) WARDHA, July 27, 1940 I have seen the Associated Press message in the Press to the effect that I intend to open a class in Bardoli under the guidance of Sardar Prithvi Singh for training a non violent army and that all preliminary arrangements have been made.
('79', 56, 2, 4, 116828) There is no foundation whatever for this report.
('79', 56, 2, 5, 116877) Sardar Prithvi Singh had intended, under Sardar Patel’s guidance, to open a vyayam class in Bardoli.
('79', 56, 2, 6, 116978) As the final decision was to rest with me, with the concurrence of Sardar Prithvi singh even that has been stopped.
('79', 56, 2, 7, 117094) I can but repeat my request to the Press not to publish news about persons without reference to them, especially when reference is easy and the public is not likely to suffer any harm by a little delay.
('79', 56, 2, 8, 117297) The Hindu, 28 7 1940
('79', 56, 3, 9, 117318) 58. THERE IS VIOLENCE IN IT 1
('79', 56, 4, 10, 117348) Shri Surendra, a co worker from Boriavi, who reads my articles usually in Harijanbandhu, the Gujarati edition of Harijan, has expres sed his painful surprise that in my article on the Working Committee’s statement issued from Wardha, I had written to the effect that ‘ I was unhappy that the privilege of a friendship of many years had now become a thing of yesterday.’ ‘Is there not violence in these words?’ he asks.
('79', 56, 4, 11, 117767) I was startled to see these words put into my mouth, and wrote to him at once that I could not have said them.
('79', 56, 4, 12, 117878) For I had no doubt that there was violence in the very thought that a friendship of twenty years had become a thing of yesterday.
('79', 56, 4, 13, 118008) I could say this of no friendship I have formed, much less of my friendship with the Sardar.
('79', 56, 4, 14, 118101) Having repeated all these year the precept of loving even one’s enemies, how could I break my friendship with a colleague like the Sardar?
('79', 56, 4, 15, 118240) My differences with Malaviyaji and Sahstriar have not affected in the least my friendship with them.
('79', 56, 4, 16, 118341) That a friendship should not bear the strain of difference in views is a sure sign of intolerance.
('79', 56, 4, 17, 118440) So I turned to Harijanbandhu and found that what Surendraji was referring to was translation of the following words: “Unhappy because my word seemed to lose the power to carry with me those whom it was my proud privilege to carry all these many years which seem like yesterday.” These words could not possibly bear the
('79', 56, 5, 18, 118759) 1 The Gujrati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 3 8 1940. The English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 57, 0, 1, 118884) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 57, 1, 2, 118925) meaning that was attributed to me in the translation.
('79', 57, 1, 3, 118979) Besides it was plainly inconsistent with the words I had written only a few sentences before: “Though it is a break in the common practice of a common ideal or policy, there is no break in the friendship of twenty years’ standing.” My unhappiness was not over any break of friendship— there was no such break—but over the fact that my word seemed suddenly to have lost the power that it had until yesterday.
('79', 57, 1, 4, 119387) The friendship endured, but I had to do more self purification to regain the co operation that I had lost.
('79', 57, 1, 5, 119494) That was the burden of the article.
('79', 57, 1, 6, 119530) But this accidently erroneous translation shows that my decision to write in Gujarati was right in more ways than one.
('79', 57, 1, 7, 119649) Translations made by translators, howsoever competent, are likely sometimes to be faulty.
('79', 57, 1, 8, 119739) The Bible was translated by some forty able scholars, but it has been found to contain errors, be they ever so few.
('79', 57, 1, 9, 119855) The friendship, then, will endure.
('79', 57, 1, 10, 119890) Time will even make it stronger if possible.
('79', 57, 1, 11, 119935) But that does not effect the fact that in spite of my best effort I have not been able to prevent differences on a funda mental issue.
('79', 57, 1, 12, 120070) Yet the more I think about it, the more I feel that in adopting the attitude it has done the Congress has gone off the rails.
('79', 57, 1, 13, 120196) It has lost the capital built with patient labour.
('79', 57, 1, 14, 120247) Perhaps it may be said that the Congress had really no such capital to lose.
('79', 57, 1, 15, 120324) For the non violence of the Congress was confined to its struggle against constituted authority.
('79', 57, 1, 16, 120421) That remains intact.
('79', 57, 1, 17, 120442) It had not defined its attitude—there was no occasion for it—with regard to other fields.
('79', 57, 1, 18, 120532) The permission to use force in individual self defence had been given as early as the Gaya Congress.
('79', 57, 1, 19, 120633) There is force in these arguments.
('79', 57, 1, 20, 120668) But I know that a fair number of Congressmen believe that the Congress non violence applied to all the fields, including internal disorder and external aggression.
('79', 57, 1, 21, 120832) Non violence restricted to a struggle against constituted authority is like a corpse lifeless.
('79', 57, 1, 22, 120927) But no amount of argument for or against can shake convictions that come from the heart.
('79', 57, 1, 23, 121016) All honour to the Sardar and others for holding fast by their conviction.
('79', 57, 1, 24, 121090) The Sardar is no man of words, he is a man of action.
('79', 57, 1, 25, 121144) He does not look around or about himself, when he has decided upon a course of action.
('79', 57, 1, 26, 121231) He simply goes ahead.
('79', 57, 1, 27, 121253) May he always be thus.
('79', 57, 1, 28, 121276) My way is clear before me.
('79', 57, 1, 29, 121303) But what of those who have followed the Sardar and me in the belief that we are always of one mind?
('79', 57, 1, 30, 121403) They are in a difficult situation.
('79', 57, 1, 31, 121438) If their ahimsa is not part of their being but only a reflection of mine, it is their duty to follow the Sardar.
('79', 57, 1, 32, 121551) I have no doubt that the Sardar has gone off the track, or rather that it is beyond his capacity to go my way.
('79', 57, 1, 33, 121662) He has chosen a
('79', 58, 0, 1, 121678) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 59
('79', 58, 1, 2, 121723) different path with my consent, nay, encouragement.
('79', 58, 1, 3, 121775) Therefore those who are in doubt should follow the Sardar.
('79', 58, 1, 4, 121834) I believe the Sardar will see his error and come back to the way he has abandoned, when he discovers in himself the capacity that he feels he has not.
('79', 58, 1, 5, 121985) When that happy moment arrives, if it does, the rest will also come back to me with the Sardar.
('79', 58, 1, 6, 122081) That is the safest way for them.
('79', 58, 1, 7, 122114) But those who have no doubt about their course, those who have assimilated ahimsa, those for whom ahimsa is the only way out of all difficulties, should quietly retire from the Congress and bury them selves in various non violent activities.
('79', 58, 1, 8, 122356) If they are truly non violent, they will prevent a split in the Congress.
('79', 58, 1, 9, 122430) Their retirement makes any split out of the question.
('79', 58, 1, 10, 122484) But even after retiring they will not come in conflict with the Congress.
('79', 58, 1, 11, 122558) They will give the Sardar any help that he summons for non violent activities, and they will try to lay down their lives wherever there is an occasion to do so in the event of internal disturbances.
('79', 58, 1, 12, 122757) If it is possible to from small bands of satyagrahis afters my pattern, it is of course desirable.
('79', 58, 1, 13, 122856) They should be able not only to keep the flag of ahimsa flying, but should also be able to convert Congres smen by their steadfastness and success.
('79', 58, 1, 14, 123004) For there are many Congres smen who desire that ahimsa should be the rule of life in all fields, only they doubt its practicability.
('79', 58, 1, 15, 123137) It is my duty, and that of those who think with me, to dispel this doubt by successful application of ahimsa in the new field.

('79', 58, 2, 17, 123313) 59. FOR KHADI WORKERS 1
('79', 58, 3, 18, 123337) A sister has sent the following complaint:
('79', 58, 4, 19, 123380) The A. I. S. A. khadi bhandars not only render no help to, but even slight, the women who desire to spin in the name of Daridranarayana.
('79', 58, 4, 20, 123517) Some bhandars refuse to give them slivers.
('79', 58, 4, 21, 123560) Now those who are beginners need to be induced with slivers.
('79', 58, 4, 22, 123621) Every bhandar should stock slivers.
('79', 58, 4, 23, 123657) At certain bhandars some sisters purchased khadi hundis but were given no receipts for them, for they had run out of stock.
('79', 58, 4, 24, 123781) We pay money in advance for fine saris, but there is vexing delay in getting them.
('79', 58, 5, 25, 123864) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 3 7 1940. The English translation has been reproduced from Harijan, where it was published under "Notes".
('79', 59, 0, 1, 124029) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 59, 1, 2, 124070) The sister who has written this is known for her care and for the pains she takes over selling khadi.
('79', 59, 1, 3, 124172) She has mentioned in her letter the names of the bhandars, but I have deliberately deleted them.
('79', 59, 1, 4, 124269) For if I gave their names, I should not do so without giving them a chance of explanation, and I have no time for writing to them.
('79', 59, 1, 5, 124400) I therefore simply mention the complaints in the hope that the bhandars concerned will benefit by them and mend their ways if they are in error.
('79', 59, 1, 6, 124545) I hold strong views regarding slivers.
('79', 59, 1, 7, 124584) We cannot supply slivers.
('79', 59, 1, 8, 124610) If we under took the work, I am afraid khadi work might in the long run come to and end.
('79', 59, 1, 9, 124699) It is uneconomic.
('79', 59, 1, 10, 124717) We should never be able to cope with the demand.
('79', 59, 1, 11, 124766) This much, however, may be done.
('79', 59, 1, 12, 124799) In the villages where spinning is organized, some may do the carding while the rest do spinning.
('79', 59, 1, 13, 124896) Even this requires careful handling.
('79', 59, 1, 14, 124933) Similarly some of the sisters whom the correspondent has in mind should learn carding and then teach it to the others, or one of them may card for her group or club.
('79', 59, 1, 15, 125099) In no case should slivers be sent by post, or from one centre to another.
('79', 59, 1, 16, 125173) I know this golden rule is honoured more in the breach than in the observance.
('79', 59, 1, 17, 125252) I fancy the A. I. S. A. has not laid down a fixed policy in this behalf.
('79', 59, 1, 18, 125325) I do not, therefore, insist on my opinion being followed for the moment.
('79', 59, 1, 19, 125398) But as the question has arisen I shall have it considered by the A. I. S. A. and, if possible, have some policy laid down in the matter.

('79', 61, 4, 16, 128712) 63. SIR C. P. RAMASWAMI AIYARS EXTRAVAGANCES
('79', 61, 5, 17, 128757) I have seen Dr. Katju’s spirited reply to Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar’s recent statement on the position of Indian States.
('79', 61, 5, 18, 128878) In my opinion the latter’s thesis is self condemned.
('79', 61, 5, 19, 128931) His extravagant claims will make not the slightest difference when the British are ready, or compelled by events, to recognize India’s in dependence.
('79', 61, 5, 20, 129081) Pyarelal has shown from authentic documents the flimsy nature of the status enjoyed by the States.
('79', 61, 5, 21, 129180) The guarantee is a con venient excuse for denying India ‘s claim.
('79', 61, 5, 22, 129246) But it will have no validity when the claim becomes irresistible.
('79', 61, 5, 23, 129312) Surely Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar, as a constitutional lawyer and student of British history, knows all this.
('79', 61, 5, 24, 129421) I wholly agree with Dr. Katju when he says that the Dewan of Travancore is ill serving his own and the other Princes by inducing in them the belief that the British guarantees will perpetuate their and their successor’s’ autocracy against the just claims of the States’ peo ple and the people of India as a whole.
('79', 61, 5, 25, 129735) I venture to suggest that the best guarantee of their status consists not in the treaties with the British but in the goodwill, contentment and co operation of their own people and the friendship of the people of non State India.
('79', 61, 5, 26, 129965) Time a running in favour of Indian independence and against all interests adverse to the people and their natural aspiration.
('79', 61, 5, 27, 130091) I was, therefore, pained and surprised to find the Rana Sahab of Dholpur hastily echoing the phrases of Sir C. P. Ramaswami Aiyar.

('79', 62, 1, 2, 130309) 64. QUESTION BOX 1
('79', 62, 2, 3, 130328) PAKISTAN AND AHIMSA A Gujarati Mussalman correspondent writes:
('79', 62, 3, 4, 130391) I am believer in ahimsa as well as Pakistan.
('79', 62, 3, 5, 130436) How can I use the ahimsa principle for the realization of my ideal?
('79', 62, 3, 6, 130504) A. It is not possible to attain an iniquitous end by non violent means.
('79', 62, 3, 7, 130576) For instance, you cannot commit theft non violently.
('79', 62, 3, 8, 130629) As I understand Pakistan I do not regard it as a worthy ideal.
('79', 62, 3, 9, 130692) But since you consider it to be worthy end, you can certainly carry on a non violent movement on its behalf.
('79', 62, 3, 10, 130801) This means that you will always strive to convert your opponents by patient reasoning.
('79', 62, 3, 11, 130888) You will impress everybody by your selfless devotion to your ideal.
('79', 62, 3, 12, 130956) You will give a respectful hearing to what your opponents might have to say, and respectfully point out to them their mistake if they are in the wrong.
('79', 62, 3, 13, 131108) Finally, if you feel that the people do not listen to you out of sheer bigotry and prejudice although your cause is absolutely just, you can non violently non co operate with the obstructionists.
('79', 62, 3, 14, 131304) But you may not injure or seek to injure anybody and must, on your part, patiently endure any injury that might be done to you.
('79', 62, 3, 15, 131432) All this you will be able to do if impartial persons endorse the justice of your cause.
('79', 62, 4, 16, 131520) PUNJAB SATYAGRAHA CAMP
('79', 62, 5, 17, 131543) Q. (From a letter from the Punjab) Preparations for satyagraha are afoot in the Punjab.
('79', 62, 5, 18, 131631) There is a lot of untruth going on, and it is best to make this known as early as possible.
('79', 62, 5, 19, 131723) Some plied the charkha in name.
('79', 62, 5, 20, 131755) Some signed the satyagraha pledge, but did not so much as touch the charkha.
('79', 62, 5, 21, 131832) The same is the case with khadi.
('79', 62, 5, 22, 131865) In our satyagraha camp our satyagrahis were making fun of you and the Congress policy.
('79', 62, 5, 23, 131952) I am therefore glad that the Congress has absolved you.
('79', 62, 5, 24, 132008) It would be still better if the Congress were to delete the conditions about non violence, truth, spinning , etc.
('79', 62, 5, 25, 132122) All the same I have no doubt that the Working Committee’s resolution has done untold harm to the country.
('79', 62, 5, 26, 132228) What should one like me do in a situation like this?
('79', 62, 5, 27, 132281) A. I have had other letters from the Punjab making similar complaints, and the condition of things in many other provinces is very much, if not quite, the same as in the Punjab.
('79', 62, 5, 28, 132459) It is a tragedy and spells ruin for the Congress if things do not mend.
('79', 62, 5, 29, 132531) If the Congress loses its influence, it will be due to internal disease, never to external attacks.

('79', 63, 1, 4, 133187) WHAT CAN A SOLITARY SATYAGRAHI DO?
('79', 63, 2, 5, 133222) Q. (From a letter from Orissa) There is one solitary satyagrahi in one of our villages.
('79', 63, 2, 6, 133310) The rest do not worry about violence or non violence.
('79', 63, 2, 7, 133364) What discipline is that single satyagrahi to undergo?
('79', 63, 2, 8, 133418) A. Yours is good question.
('79', 63, 2, 9, 133445) The solitary satyagrahi has to examine himself.
('79', 63, 2, 10, 133493) If he has universal love and if he fulfils the condi tions implied in such a state, it must find its expression in his daily conduct.
('79', 63, 2, 11, 133627) He would be bound with the poorest in the village by ties of services.
('79', 63, 2, 12, 133698) He would constitute himself the scavenger, the nurse, the arbitrator of disputes, and the teacher of the childrenof the village.
('79', 63, 2, 13, 133827) Everyone, young and old, would know him; though a householder he would be leading a life of restrain the would make no distinction between his and his neighbour's children; he would own nothing but would hold what wealth he has in trust for others, and would therefore spend out of it just sufficient of this barest needs.
('79', 63, 2, 14, 134150) His needs would, as far as possible, approximate to those of the poor, he would harbour no untouchability, and would therefore inspire people of all castes and creeds to approach him with confidence.
('79', 63, 2, 15, 134350) Such is the ideal satyagrahi.
('79', 63, 2, 16, 134380) Our friend will always endeavour to come up to, wherever he falls short of, the ideal, fill in the gaps in his education; he will not waste a single moment.
('79', 63, 2, 17, 134537) His house will be a busy hive of useful activities centring round spinning.
('79', 63, 2, 18, 134613) His will be a well ordered household.
('79', 63, 2, 19, 134651) Such a satyagrahi will not find himself single handed for long.
('79', 63, 2, 20, 134715) The village will unconsciously follow him.
('79', 63, 2, 21, 134758) But whether they do or not, at a time of emergency he will, single handed, effectively deal with it or die in the attempt.
('79', 63, 2, 22, 134881) But I firmly hold that he will have converted a number of others.
('79', 63, 2, 23, 134947) I may add in this connection that I had come to Sevagram as a solitary satyagrahi.
('79', 63, 2, 24, 135030) Luckily or unluckily, I could not remain alone, several from outside came and settled with me.
('79', 63, 2, 25, 135125) I do not know whether any inhabitant of the village proper can be counted as a satyagrahi, but I do hope that some of them are uncon sciously shaping themselves as such.
('79', 63, 2, 26, 135295) Let me say that I do not fulfil all the tests I have laid down.
('79', 63, 2, 27, 135359) But I should not have mentioned them, had I not been striving to put into practice all of them.
('79', 63, 2, 28, 135455) My present ambition is certainly to make of Sevagram an ideal village.
('79', 63, 2, 29, 135526) I know that the work is as difficult as to make of India an ideal country.
('79', 64, 0, 1, 135601) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 65
('79', 64, 1, 2, 135646) while it is possible for one man to fulfil his ambition with respect to a single village some day, one man’s lifetime is too short to overtake the whole of India.
('79', 64, 1, 3, 135809) But if one man can produce one ideal village, he will have provided a pattern not only for the whole country, but perhaps for the whole world.
('79', 64, 1, 4, 135952) More than this a seeker may not aspire after.
('79', 64, 1, 5, 135998) NO DEATH FOR YOU A friend from Agra writes:
('79', 64, 2, 6, 136042) According to you a satyagrahi may no longer remain in the Congress.
('79', 64, 2, 7, 136110) I too think the same.
('79', 64, 2, 8, 136132) I believe in the Vedas.
('79', 64, 2, 9, 136156) The Vedic text is quite clear on this point: “O thou, himsa free man, there is no death for you, there is no death for you.
('79', 64, 2, 10, 136280) Be not afraid.” Why should we not implicitly believe in this hoary saying?
('79', 64, 2, 11, 136355) My faith in himsa is daily growing.
('79', 64, 2, 12, 136391) I am a Congressman.
('79', 64, 2, 13, 136411) What should I do now?
('79', 64, 2, 14, 136433) A. If you really have that faith in you, you will unhesitatingly leave the Congress organization and render it greater and truer service by remaining outside.
('79', 64, 2, 15, 136592) If you have love, patience and bravery, you will convert Congressmen around you to your view.

('79', 67, 0, 1, 142712) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 67, 1, 2, 142753) 68. OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('79', 67, 2, 3, 142779) It is unfortunate that in answer to Mr. Sorensen’s very relevant question the Secretary of State for India was betrayed into giving a reply which shows want of appreciation of the gravity of the situation in India.
('79', 67, 2, 4, 142994) Who could have known the gravity of the European situation before the declaration of war by the British Government?
('79', 67, 2, 5, 143110) But the British ministers knew how very grave the situation had become since Munich.
('79', 67, 2, 6, 143195) They were so appalled by the gravity that they put off the declaration as long as they could.
('79', 67, 2, 7, 143289) Similarly the layman does not know anything of the gravity of the situation in India.
('79', 67, 2, 8, 143375) But the Secretary of State is not a layman.
('79', 67, 2, 9, 143419) What he does not know, nobody else should know.
('79', 67, 2, 10, 143467) And yet I venture to suggest to him that his questioner gauged the situation more accurately than he himself did, taking his answer at its face value.
('79', 67, 2, 11, 143618) In ordinary times such ignorance as Col.
('79', 67, 2, 12, 143659) Amery’s answer shows may be excusable.
('79', 67, 2, 13, 143698) At this moment it is unpardonable.
('79', 67, 2, 14, 143733) I do not pro pose to enlighten him on all I know.
('79', 67, 2, 15, 143783) I dare not publicly exhibit all the danger signals.
('79', 67, 2, 16, 143835) It would be an unfriendly act on my part to do so.
('79', 67, 2, 17, 143886) Even the warning I am giving here might have been privately given.
('79', 67, 2, 18, 143953) I have slept several nights over the answer.
('79', 67, 2, 19, 143998) I came to the conclusion that to suppress altogether from the public what I know would also be an unfriendly act.
('79', 67, 2, 20, 144112) In spite of my isolation from the Congress, I flatter myself with the belief that a large part of the public still seek my guidance and will continue to do so, as long as I am believed to represent the spirit of satyagraha more fully than any other person in India.
('79', 67, 2, 21, 144378) Amery has grievously erred in underrating the restraint that the Congress has exercised in postponing civil disobedience in order not to embarrass the British Government at a most critical period in the history of the British.
('79', 67, 2, 22, 144605) The restraint expects no appre ciation.
('79', 67, 2, 23, 144645) It is inherent n satyagraha.
('79', 67, 2, 24, 144674) Therefore it is a duty.
('79', 67, 2, 25, 144698) And the discharge of a duty carries no merit, even as payment of a debt does not.
('79', 67, 2, 26, 144780) Nevertheless mention of the restraint becomes relevant in order to show that but for that restraint a conflagration may burst forth whose effect no one can foresee.
('79', 67, 2, 27, 144945) It is true that civil disobedience remains in suspension also because of the internal defects in the Congress organization.
('79', 67, 2, 28, 145069) But I have said repeatedly that, if the Congress is goaded to it, the science of satyagraha is not without a mode of application in spite of the internal weaknesses.
('79', 67, 2, 29, 145235) Therefore the final and deciding motive for suspension is undoubtedly the desire not to embarrass the British Government at the present moment.
('79', 68, 0, 1, 145379) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 69
('79', 68, 1, 2, 145424) But his restraint has its limits.
('79', 68, 1, 3, 145458) Just a suspicion is growing among Congressmen that the British authority is taking advantage of the restraint to crush the Congress.
('79', 68, 1, 4, 145591) They point for example to the numerous arrests of Congressmen.
('79', 68, 1, 5, 145654) The opposition on the part of so many members of the A. I. C. C. to the ratification of the Delhi resolution is, as the Maulana Saheb has said, a sign of their resentment at the feeling that the High Command was letting the British Government to get the better of the Congress.
('79', 68, 1, 6, 145932) If that suspicion is proved to be well grounded, nothing on earth can possibly deter me from adopting some from of effective satyagraha.
('79', 68, 1, 7, 146069) But it is my prayer and corresponding effort to prevent it until the clouds lift from Great Britain.
('79', 68, 1, 8, 146170) I do not want her humiliation in order to gain India’s freedom.
('79', 68, 1, 9, 146234) Such freedom, if it were attainable, cannot be manfully retained.
('79', 68, 1, 10, 146300) I have dealt with the one danger signal on which I can write with special knowledge.
('79', 68, 1, 11, 146385) There are several others which I can easily mention and which are no less grave.
('79', 68, 1, 12, 146466) But these I must not mention.
('79', 68, 1, 13, 146496) If I have publicly discussed one danger, I have done so because the Congress is connected with it and I have to say what is expected of Congressmen.
('79', 68, 1, 14, 146645) If I retired from the congress at Bombay in 1934, I did so to render greater service.
('79', 68, 1, 15, 146731) Events have justified the retirement.
('79', 68, 1, 16, 146769) The present isolation too has the same motive behind it.
('79', 68, 1, 17, 146826) So far as I can judge the immediate future, satyagraha, if it comes, will be confined only to those whom I may select.
('79', 68, 1, 18, 146945) The rest will be expected not to interfere with the course I may adopt.
('79', 68, 1, 19, 147017) All will render very substantial help, if they will carry out the instructions that may be issued for them.
('79', 68, 1, 20, 147125) One permanent instruction is: leave the Congress if you do not believe in the constructive programme, especially spin ning and khadi which are visible symbols of adherence to the Con gress, and if you do not believe in truth and non violence—the latter in the restricted sense now given to it by the recent resolution.
('79', 68, 1, 21, 147444) If this elementary requirement is not fulfilled, any satyagraha that I may lead will be of no avail to the Congress.
('79', 68, 1, 22, 147561) It will merely satisfy my saty agrahi soul.

('79', 71, 2, 3, 151700) BHAI VALLABHBHAI, The accompanying letter is from Nadiad.
('79', 71, 2, 4, 151758) Please see if anything needs to be done about it.
('79', 71, 2, 5, 151808) Your falling ill so often is not good.
('79', 71, 2, 6, 151847) You should take some rest.

('79', 74, 1, 2, 156293) 79. A CONVINCING ARGUMENT 1
('79', 74, 2, 3, 156321) This is what an Englishwoman who knows what war means says about the Working Committee’s decision to insist on non violence for dealing with internal disturbances while fearing to trust non violence to defend India: 2
('79', 74, 3, 4, 156539) .To throw non violence overboard when it comes to facing external aggression seems to me to be throwing it away at the very moment when its efficacy is the most sure and its benefit to mankind the greatest.
('79', 74, 3, 5, 156746) In internal disorder.
('79', 74, 3, 6, 156768) it is more often than not a case of dealing with unintellectual and lower types of humanity.
('79', 74, 3, 7, 156861) But in the case of external aggression, the two elements you are dealing with are intellectually deve loped leaders of nations and masses of innocent soldiers.
('79', 74, 3, 8, 157021) On both of these non violence is bound to have its reactions.
('79', 74, 3, 9, 157083) especially men of such intelligence as Hitler would be deeply moved by its grandeur.
('79', 74, 4, 10, 157168) If the working Committee members ever thought non violence should be and could be the ideal for internal affairs, then how much more it should be and could be the ideal for external affairs!
('79', 74, 4, 11, 157359) SEVAGRAM, August 4, 1940 Harijan, 18 8 1940

('79', 74, 6, 17, 158058) the Travancore Government propose to take appropriate legal proceedings against Messrs Achutahn and G. Ramachandran.

('79', 75, 1, 2, 158588) article on ‘Travancore’ in the Harijan of the 28th July.
('79', 75, 1, 3, 158645) It is worthy of note that none of the Travancore papers has published the Harijan article of the 28th, though the article of the 21st together with the reply of the Dewan had been published.
('79', 75, 1, 4, 158836) I am publishing everything important coming to me about Travancore because I believe it to be true.
('79', 75, 1, 5, 158936) The threatened proceedings against Shri Ramachandran and Achuthan will not disprove the statements published.
('79', 75, 1, 6, 159046) They will confirm the impression that the Travancore State authorities are determined by all means at their disposal to crush the movement for liberty.

('79', 75, 1, 8, 159291) Note how the issues are evaded in the Press note.
('79', 75, 1, 9, 159341) There is no demand for an ‘outside enquiry’ or ‘outside mediation’, nor is there any question of force.
('79', 75, 1, 10, 159445) The Dewan himself and many others in Travancore are outsiders.
('79', 75, 1, 11, 159508) But they are not forced upon the State when the Maharaja engages them, and the use of the word ‘outsider’ ceases to have any meaning for the appointer.
('79', 75, 1, 12, 159660) It is preposterous to use the word ‘force’ for friendly suggestions by the Press or appeals by State subjects, or to use words ‘outsiders’ and ‘outside mediation’ for sug gestions to the State to bring impartial judges from outside.

('79', 75, 1, 15, 160230) The public is bound to give sinister meaning to this gross misuse of the language by the Travancore authorities.
('79', 75, 1, 16, 160343) Again, if the Travancore people are hostile to or apathetic to the doings of the State Congress, where is the occasion for the suppression of the State Congress bulletins and newspaper comments?
('79', 75, 1, 17, 160538) Just causes truthfully and non violently conducted have always survived repression and drawn sympathy from unexpected quarters.
('79', 75, 1, 18, 160666) I call such sympathy divine help.
('79', 75, 1, 19, 160700) God works in mysterious ways.
('79', 75, 1, 20, 160730) Lets the persecuted State Congress people have faith that God is with them.

('79', 76, 1, 2, 160897) 81. DEBT BONDAGE OF A HILL TRIBE 1
('79', 76, 2, 3, 160932) Shri Mandeswar Sarma, who is working among the hillmen of Madugole Agency area in the Vizagapatam District, writes:
('79', 76, 3, 4, 161048) I am glad to inform you that the debt bondage system prevailing from ages in these areas has been abolished very recently by the Government of Madras as the result of the efforts of the Hill Tribes’ Association and the Provincial Zaim Ryots’ Association.
('79', 76, 3, 5, 161303) Debt bondage means that the hill muttahdars and employers advance some money, say Rs. 50 or 60, to tripesmen and exact whole time services of the meek hillmen for 5, 10 and even 20 years, and at times for generations together.
('79', 76, 3, 6, 161530) By this new regulation thousands of hillmen have been set free.
('79', 76, 3, 7, 161594) We are leading the hillmen in all these matters in a non violent groove.
('79', 76, 3, 8, 161667) I am helping them to realize non violent values by themselves.
('79', 76, 3, 9, 161730) It is our ambition to take you to this area after three thousand persons actively take to the spinning wheel and the takli.
('79', 76, 3, 10, 161854) For this we need your blessing.
('79', 76, 3, 11, 161886) They are about twenty thousand.
('79', 76, 3, 12, 161918) At present twelve hundred hillmen are spinning.
('79', 76, 3, 13, 161966) We are also trying to wean them from drink.
('79', 76, 3, 14, 162010) Though the Madras Government have taken long to redress the glaring wrong referred to here, they deserve to be thanked on principle that it is better to be late than never.
('79', 76, 3, 15, 162183) It should now be easier for the workers like Shri Sarma to carry out ameliorative measures among the hillmen.
('79', 76, 3, 16, 162293) My blessing he has.
('79', 76, 3, 17, 162313) I do not know that I can hold out any hope of visiting his area even if he succeeds in getting three thousand charkhas going among the hillmen.
('79', 76, 3, 18, 162457) He should have no difficulty in realizing his modest ambition.
('79', 76, 3, 19, 162520) SEVAGRAM, August 4, 1940 Harijan, 25 8 1940

('79', 79, 2, 5, 166944) 86. IS NON VIOLENCE IMPOSSIBLE?
('79', 79, 3, 6, 166976) The doubt and difficulties raised by this correspondent 2 occur to others also, and I have on various occasions tried to solve them too.
('79', 79, 3, 7, 167113) But when the W o rk ing Committee of the Congress has been instru mental in making of ahimsa a live issue, it seems necessary to deal with these doubts and difficulties at some length.
('79', 79, 3, 8, 167298) The correspondent doubts in substance the universal application of ahimsa, and asserts that society has made little progress towards it.
('79', 79, 3, 9, 167435) Teachers like Buddha arose and made some effort with some little success perhaps in their lifetime, but society is just where it was in spite of them.
('79', 79, 3, 10, 167586) Ahimsa may be good enough to be the duty of an individual; for society it is good for nothing, and India too will have to take to violence for her freedom.
('79', 79, 3, 11, 167742) The argument is, I think, fundamentally wrong.
('79', 79, 3, 12, 167789) The last state ment is incorrect inasmuch as the Congress has adhered to non violence as the means for the attainment of swaraj.
('79', 79, 3, 13, 167918) It has indeed gone a step further.
('79', 79, 3, 14, 167953) The question having been raised as to whether non violence continues to be the weapon against all internal disturbances, the A. I. C. C. clearly gave the answer in the affirmative.
('79', 79, 3, 15, 168134) It is only for protection against outside aggression that the Congress has maintained that it would be necessary to have an army.
('79', 79, 3, 16, 168264) And then even on this matter there was a considerable body of the members of the A. I. C. C. who voted against the resolution.
('79', 79, 3, 17, 168391) This dissent has got to be reckoned with when the question voted upon is one of principle.
('79', 79, 3, 18, 168482) The Congress policy must always be decided by a majority vote, but it does not cancel the minority vote, it stands.
('79', 79, 3, 19, 168598) Where there is no princi ple involved and there is a programme to be carried out, the minority has got to follow the majority.
('79', 79, 3, 20, 168725) But where there is a principle involved, the dissent stands, and it is bound to express itself in practice when the
('79', 79, 4, 21, 168841) 1 The Gurajati original of this appeared in Harijanbandu, 10 8 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 79, 4, 22, 168963) 2 The letter is not reproduced here.
('79', 79, 4, 23, 169000) The correspondent, while admitting the power of non violence, had argued that it was not possible for common people to attain to it.
('79', 80, 0, 1, 169133) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 81
('79', 80, 1, 2, 169178) occasion arises.
('79', 80, 1, 3, 169195) That means the ahimsa for all occasions and all purposes has been recognized by a society, however small it may be, and that ahimsa as a remedy to be used by society has made fair strides.
('79', 80, 1, 4, 169384) Whether it will make further strides or no is a different matter.
('79', 80, 1, 5, 169450) The Working Committee’s resolution, therefore, fails to lend any support to the correspondent’s doubts.
('79', 80, 1, 6, 169554) On the contrary it should in a certain degree dispel them.
('79', 80, 1, 7, 169613) Now for the argument that I am but a rare individual, and that what little society has done in the matter of ahimsa is due to my influ ence, and that it is sure to disappear with me.
('79', 80, 1, 8, 169796) This is not right.
('79', 80, 1, 9, 169815) The Congress has a number of leaders who can think for themselves.

('79', 80, 1, 12, 170006) Experience has taught him that ahimsa alone can make India free.
('79', 80, 1, 13, 170071) It was he who in sisted on the resolution accepting ahimsa as a weapon against internal disturbances.
('79', 80, 1, 14, 170173) Pandit Jawaharlal is not a man to stand in awe of any one.
('79', 80, 1, 15, 170232) His study of history and contemporary events is second to none.
('79', 80, 1, 16, 170296) It is after mature thought that he has accepted ahimsa as a means for the attainment of swaraj.
('79', 80, 1, 17, 170392) It is true that he has said that he would not hesitate to accept swaraj if non violence failed and it could be won by means of violence.
('79', 80, 1, 18, 170529) But that is not relevant to the present issue.
('79', 80, 1, 19, 170576) There are not a few other big names in the Congress who believe in ahimsa as the only weapon at least for the attainment of swaraj.
('79', 80, 1, 20, 170708) To think that all of them will give up the way of ahimsa as soon as I am gone, is to insult them and to insult human nature.
('79', 80, 1, 21, 170833) We must believe that everyone can think for himself.
('79', 80, 1, 22, 170886) Mutual respect to that extent is essential for progress.
('79', 80, 1, 23, 170943) By crediting our companions with independent judgment we strengthen them and make it easy for them to be independent minded even if they are proved to be weak.
('79', 80, 1, 24, 171103) I hope neither the correspondent nor anyone else believes that the Congress or many Congress leaders have bidden good bye to ahimsa.
('79', 80, 1, 25, 171236) To the limited extent that I have pointed out faith in ahimsa has been reiterated and made clear beyond any doubt by the Con gress.
('79', 80, 1, 26, 171368) I agree that the limit laid down by the Congress considerably narrows down the sphere of ahimsa and a dims its splendour.
('79', 80, 1, 27, 171490) But the limited ahimsa of the Congress is good enough for the purpose or our present argument.
('79', 80, 1, 28, 171585) For I am trying to make out that the field of ahimsa is widening, and the limited acceptance of ahimsa by the Congress sufficiently supports my position.
('79', 80, 1, 29, 171739) If we turn our eyes to the time of which history any record down to our own time, we shall find that man has been steadily pro gressing towards ahimsa.
('79', 80, 1, 30, 171891) Out remote ancestors were cannibals.
('79', 80, 1, 31, 171928) Then came a time when they were fed up with cannibalism and they began
('79', 81, 0, 1, 171999) 82 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 81, 1, 2, 172040) to live on chase.
('79', 81, 1, 3, 172058) Next came a stage when man was ashamed of lea ding the life of a wandering hunter.
('79', 81, 1, 4, 172141) He therefore took to agriculture and depended principally on mother earth for his food.
('79', 81, 1, 5, 172229) Thus from being a nomad he settled down to civilized stable life, founded villages and towns, and from member of a family he became member of a community and a nation.
('79', 81, 1, 6, 172397) All these are signs of progressive ahimsa and diminishing himsa.
('79', 81, 1, 7, 172462) Had it been otherwise, the human species should have been extinct by now, even as many of the lower species have disappeared.
('79', 81, 1, 8, 172588) Prophets and avatars have also taught the lesson of ahimsa more or less.
('79', 81, 1, 9, 172661) Not one of them has professed to teach himsa.
('79', 81, 1, 10, 172707) And how should it be otherwise?
('79', 81, 1, 11, 172739) Himsa does not need to be taught.
('79', 81, 1, 12, 172773) Man as animal is violent, but as spirit is non violent.
('79', 81, 1, 13, 172829) The moment he awakes to the spirit within he cannot remain violent.
('79', 81, 1, 14, 172897) Either he progresses towards ahimsa or rushes to his doom.

('79', 81, 1, 20, 173421) Nothing in this world is static, everything is kinetic.

('79', 82, 1, 2, 174398) 87. THE TEST OF NON VIOLENCE 1
('79', 82, 2, 3, 174429) Those who regard themselves as out and out votaries of non violence and believe the step taken by Rajaji and others to be wrong, 2 have to pass through a severe test.
('79', 82, 2, 4, 174596) I have expressed my opinion in the clearest possible language.
('79', 82, 2, 5, 174659) I believe that Rajaji has gone off the track.
('79', 82, 2, 6, 174705) He believes that I have.
('79', 82, 2, 7, 174730) The future alone will decide who is right.
('79', 82, 2, 8, 174773) But as I have not the slightest doubt the correctness of my posi tion., I have not hesitated to advise those who think with me to leave the Congress.
('79', 82, 2, 9, 174923) But this does not mean that they have to do so forth with.
('79', 82, 2, 10, 174982) It is enough if they are ready to retire when I decide upon the date.
('79', 82, 2, 11, 175052) Before the actual step is taken, we shall have to make sure of cer tain things.
('79', 82, 2, 12, 175132) Their retirement must be such as to cause no shock to fellow Congressmen.
('79', 82, 2, 13, 175206) If these do not appreciate the step, I have to ex plain it to them patiently, and to convince them that it is in the interest of the Congress that it should be taken.
('79', 82, 2, 14, 175373) It is common cause between them and us that it would be an ideal thing if we could protect the country against foreign aggression by non violence.
('79', 82, 2, 15, 175520) It is therefore desirable that there should be a group of people pledged to devote their lives to proving the efficacy of non violence.
('79', 82, 2, 16, 175656) If the existence of such a group is good for the country, it is apparent that they should remain outside the Congress, and that the Congress should not only tolerate them but welcome them, render them as much help as pos sible, and regard them as their own.
('79', 82, 2, 17, 175914) That means that far from there being any estrangement or misunderstanding between the Congress and this group, their relations should, if possible, be sweeter than before.
('79', 82, 2, 18, 176086) To bring about this happy consummation, the out and out vot aries of non violence should not even mentally find fault with their erstwhile comrades.
('79', 82, 2, 19, 176235) They may not remind them of their previous statements.
('79', 82, 2, 20, 176290) It is their duty to revise their statements if they feel that they were erroneous, and it is possible that they may not read in them the same implications as others discover in them.
('79', 82, 2, 21, 176473) The best thing, therefore, is to bear joyously with one another.
('79', 82, 2, 22, 176538) This mutual tolerance presupposes their choosing different spheres of action and Working in co operation wherever possible.
('79', 82, 2, 23, 176662) It will be some time before we can create such an atmosphere, but we are sure to succeed if we make a serious endeavour in this direction.
('79', 82, 2, 24, 176801) In the meanwhile let everyone occupy himself with the

('79', 83, 3, 7, 177358) Shri Narandas Gandhi writes from Rajkot as follows about the Spinning Anniversary:
('79', 83, 4, 8, 177441) The 71 days’ Programme for the forthcoming anniversary was com menced on the morning of 20th July with prayers and the song of the ‘True Vaishnava’.
('79', 83, 4, 9, 177590) Spinning is in full swing.
('79', 83, 4, 10, 177617) Some begin from 4 a.m.
('79', 83, 4, 11, 177640) Amritlal gets up at 3.30 a.m.
('79', 83, 4, 12, 177670) and begins spinning from 4 a.m., and by 3.30 p.m.
('79', 83, 4, 13, 177720) with a break for breakfast and lunch spins nearly 6,000 yards in 11 hours.
('79', 83, 4, 14, 177795) After this he learns music, has his walk and rest.
('79', 83, 4, 15, 177846) He has resolved to spin 400,000 yards in 71 days.
('79', 83, 4, 16, 177896) We have the evening prayer at 6.30. About 75 people attend.

('79', 83, 5, 21, 178338) This annual spinning sacrifice goes on without fuss and advertise ment.
('79', 83, 5, 22, 178410) It is worthy of emulation everywhere for it means automatic propagation of khadi.

('79', 84, 3, 18, 180592) 90. THE CASE OF MY FIRST SON 2
('79', 84, 4, 19, 180623) Q. You have failed to take even your own son with you, and he has gone astray.
('79', 84, 4, 20, 180702) May it not, therefore, be well for you to rest content with putting your own house in order?
('79', 84, 4, 21, 180795) A. This may be taken to be a taunt, but I do not take it so.
('79', 84, 4, 22, 180856) For the question had occurred to me before it did to anyone else.
('79', 84, 4, 23, 180922) I am a believer in previous births and rebirths.
('79', 84, 4, 24, 180971) All our relationships are the result of the samskars we carry from our previous births.
('79', 84, 4, 25, 181059) God’s laws are inscrutable and are the subject of endless search.
('79', 84, 4, 26, 181125) No one will fathom them.

('79', 85, 0, 1, 181346) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 85, 1, 2, 181387) This is how I regard the case of my son.
('79', 85, 1, 3, 181428) I regard the birth of a bad son to me as the result of my evil past whether of this life or previous.
('79', 85, 1, 4, 181530) My first son was born when I was in a state of infatuation.
('79', 85, 1, 5, 181590) Besides, he grew up whilst I was myself growing and whilst I knew myself very little.
('79', 85, 1, 6, 181676) I do not claim to know myself fully even today, but I certainly know myself better than I did then.
('79', 85, 1, 7, 181776) For years he remained away from me, and his upbringing was not entirely in my hands.
('79', 85, 1, 8, 181861) That is why he has always been at a loose end.
('79', 85, 1, 9, 181908) His grievance against me has always been that I sacrificed him and his brothers at the altar of what I wrongly believed to be public good.
('79', 85, 1, 10, 182047) My other sons have laid more or less the same blame at my door, but with a good deal of hesitation, and they have generously forgiven me.
('79', 85, 1, 11, 182185) My eldest son was the direct victim of my experiments—radical changes in my life—and so he cannot forget what he regards as my blunders.
('79', 85, 1, 12, 182322) Under the circums tances I believe I am myself the cause of the loss of my son, and have therefore learnt patiently to bear it.
('79', 85, 1, 13, 182450) And yet it is not quite correct to say that I have lost him.
('79', 85, 1, 14, 182511) For it is my constant prayer that God may make him see the error of his ways and forgive me my shortcomings, if any, in serving him.
('79', 85, 1, 15, 182644) It is my firm faith that man is by nature going higher, and so I have not at all lost hope that some day he will wake up from his slumber of ignorance.
('79', 85, 1, 16, 182796) Thus he is part of my field of experiments in ahimsa.
('79', 85, 1, 17, 182850) When or whether I shall succeed I have never bothered to know.
('79', 85, 1, 18, 182913) It is enough for my own satisfaction that I do not slacken my efforts in doing, what I know to be my duty.
('79', 85, 1, 19, 183020) ‘To work thou hast the right, never to the fruit thereof’ is one of the golden precepts of the Gita.

('79', 86, 8, 34, 185310) This is the doctrine of Niet zsche which is followed in practice by Hitler.

('79', 87, 1, 27, 187443) In getting non violent defenders, we have to pick and choose.
('79', 87, 1, 28, 187505) Money cannot buy them.
('79', 87, 1, 29, 187528) The non violent process is wholly different from the one commonly known.
('79', 87, 1, 30, 187601) I can only say that my own exper ience in organizing non violent action for half a century fills me with hope for the future.

('79', 88, 2, 5, 188360) 94. THE BISWA AFFAIR
('79', 88, 3, 6, 188381) Though late in the day I must redeem my promise to give my opinion on this unfortunate case.
('79', 88, 3, 7, 188474) I have letters containing angry protests against the five Congress Ministers in C. P., chiefly the Prime Minister.
('79', 88, 3, 8, 188589) I have carefully read both the judgments, that of the learned Chief Justice and of the concurring Judge.
('79', 88, 3, 9, 188694) There is no doubt whatsoever that there has been a gross miscarriage of justice due to the police bungling.
('79', 88, 3, 10, 188802) I hold pandit Shukla and his fellow ministers to be wholly free from blame.
('79', 88, 3, 11, 188878) These are the remarks of the Chief Justice about Pandit Shukla: In the course of the debate the then Prime Minister himself did not hesitate to use the word ‘murder’ and to indicate that this was not a case of riot but a carefully planned murder ruthlessly carried out.
('79', 88, 3, 12, 189148) I can find nothing objectionable in this statement.
('79', 88, 3, 13, 189200) He made use of the information then in his possession.
('79', 88, 3, 14, 189255) He might have used the orthodox prefix ‘alleged’ in connection with ‘murder’ and used guarded language.
('79', 88, 3, 15, 189359) But there is nothing in his statement to justify the wrath poured upon his head.
('79', 88, 3, 16, 189440) The judges’ finding , however, is that there was a murder and that it was worthy of condemnation.
('79', 88, 3, 17, 189538) Their natural regret was that because of want of reliable evidence the crime had to go unpunished.
('79', 88, 3, 18, 189637) I have not, therefore, been able to understand, much less to appreciate the rejoicing over what is a manifest failure of justice.
('79', 88, 3, 19, 189767) So far as the discharge of the prisoners was concerned, it was a matter for common, not communal, rejoicing that no man suffered unless there was conclusive evidence.
('79', 88, 3, 20, 189934) All must accept the unequivocal judgement of the final court of appeal.
('79', 88, 3, 21, 190006) But there should have been common regret too that there was failure of justice.
('79', 88, 3, 22, 190086) It cannot be to the advantage of any community that a murderer should be screened.

('79', 89, 1, 2, 190814) I hope that my opinion will not revive the dying members of an unfortunate controversy which should never have arisen.

('79', 89, 2, 6, 191115) 95. AUNDH
('79', 89, 3, 7, 191125) Who does not know little Aundh?
('79', 89, 3, 8, 191157) Little it is in size and income, but it has made itself great and famous by its Chief having bestowed, unasked, the boon of full self government on his people.
('79', 89, 3, 9, 191317) Its chief minister Appasaheb Pant has brought out an attractive pamphlet of nine pages describing the experiment, from which I reproduce the following:
('79', 89, 4, 10, 191469) Village democracy is the basis of the new Constitution.
('79', 89, 4, 11, 191525) Every village elects by the vote of all of its adults a panchayat of five persons.
('79', 89, 4, 12, 191608) One of these five is elected by the panchayat unanimously as their president.
('79', 89, 4, 13, 191686) If this unanimity is not possible, then all the adults of the village elect the president out of the panchayat.
('79', 89, 5, 14, 191798) Duty elected presidents of a group of villages constitute the taluka panchayat.
('79', 89, 5, 15, 191878) The taluka panchayat decides in its meetings the way in which it would spend the money that it receives.
('79', 89, 5, 16, 191983) It receives as near as possible half the revenue that is collected in the taluka.
('79', 89, 5, 17, 192065) It receives as near as possible half the revenue that is collected in the taluka.
('79', 89, 5, 18, 192147) The villages prepare their budgets and present them through their presidents to the taluka panchayat.
('79', 89, 5, 19, 192249) These are discussed and a budget for the whole taluka is prepared.
('79', 89, 5, 20, 192316) The villages can spend the money they get as they think fit.
('79', 89, 5, 21, 192377) As yet education and public works constitute the chief items of expenditure.
('79', 89, 5, 22, 192454) The members of the Assembly know not only about the affairs of the Central Government, but they are intimately connected with the everyday work in the villages, and they get acquainted with the work of other villages in their taluka at the meetings of the taluka panchayat.
('79', 89, 5, 23, 192728) The member of the Legislative Assembly, in the way, is an active worker almost 12 hours of the day.
('79', 89, 5, 24, 192828) It is not that he stands for election, gets elected on certain issues, and does not worry about these till the next election.
('79', 89, 5, 25, 192954) He has to face the villagers every day.
('79', 89, 5, 26, 192994) The Constitution gives the power of recall to the villages.
('79', 89, 5, 27, 193054) 4/5ths of the voters can ask for a re election of the panchayat.
('79', 89, 6, 28, 193119) The panchayats dispense justice.
('79', 89, 6, 29, 193152) The villager need not spend money, go out of his village, and spend days at the taluka town to get a hearing.
('79', 89, 6, 30, 193262) The panchayat decides his case on the spot.
('79', 89, 6, 31, 193306) The peasant can get witnesses in the village.
('79', 89, 6, 32, 193352) And in the cases that are difficult and involve intricate points of law,
('79', 90, 0, 1, 193425) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 91
('79', 90, 1, 2, 193470) a sub judge comes to the village and assists the panchayat with the dispensa tion of justice.
('79', 90, 1, 3, 193564) The sub judge not only gives expert advice to the panchayat, but also acts as a guide to the peasant who many a time is completely ignorant of his legal rights and is therefore liable to be misguided by the vested interests—the goondas.
('79', 90, 1, 4, 193801) Justice in Aundh is therefore cheap, swift and effective.
('79', 90, 1, 5, 193859) In the panchayats of two talukas alone 197 criminal and civil suits have been disposed of.
('79', 90, 1, 6, 193950) In 75 per cent of civil suits and 50 per cent of criminal cases no pleaders were engaged.
('79', 90, 1, 7, 194040) The witnesses had to be paid nothing, being themselves on the spot.
('79', 90, 1, 8, 194108) There was thus great saving of time and money.
('79', 90, 1, 9, 194155) Most cases were decided at a single sitting.
('79', 90, 1, 10, 194200) The whole village turns out at the hearing of cases.
('79', 90, 1, 11, 194253) Hence lying is rare, because it can be easily detected.
('79', 90, 1, 12, 194309) Therefore many cases are compromised out of court.
('79', 90, 1, 13, 194360) This method of dealing out justice is itself great adult education.
('79', 90, 1, 14, 194428) There are 88 village schools for 72 villages.
('79', 90, 1, 15, 194474) After the intro duction of adult franchise, 35 per cent of the adult population rece ived education.
('79', 90, 1, 16, 194575) Basic education is not neglected, nor is physical.
('79', 90, 1, 17, 194626) The Rajasaheb himself takes a keen interest in the physical development of his people.
('79', 90, 1, 18, 194713) It is done through suryanamaskar.
('79', 90, 1, 19, 194747) It is a special style.
('79', 90, 1, 20, 194770) If Appasaheb has shown the bright side of the experiment, he has not lost sight of the difficulties and troubles.
('79', 90, 1, 21, 194884) I omit notice of these.
('79', 90, 1, 22, 194908) For they are the usual difficulties that attend all such experi ments.
('79', 90, 1, 23, 194979) The leader of the people, if they retain their faith, will surely surmount them.
('79', 90, 1, 24, 195060) This is how the pamphlet closes:
('79', 90, 2, 25, 195093) Little has been done.
('79', 90, 2, 26, 195115) Much remains to be done.
('79', 90, 2, 27, 195140) It's an important work we are doing.
('79', 90, 2, 28, 195177) We want sympathy and advice.
('79', 90, 2, 29, 195206) I am sure everybody sympathizes with the Aundh people.
('79', 90, 2, 30, 195261) Let those who have any to give send Appasaheb their thoughts.
('79', 90, 2, 31, 195323) Let them be sure that they are sound and relevant.
('79', 90, 2, 32, 195374) SEVAGRAM, August 6, 1940 Harijan, 11 8 1940
('79', 91, 0, 1, 195418) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 91, 1, 2, 195459) 96. NAZISM IN ITS NAKEDNESS A Dutch friend writes: 1
('79', 91, 2, 3, 195512) You will perhaps be able to remember me having made a drawing of you at Romain Rolland’s in 1931. .
('79', 91, 2, 4, 195612) I am a Dutchman and lived for many years in Germany, where I had build up a living as an artist.
('79', 91, 2, 5, 195709) Nazim, which gained hold in Germany seven years ago, caused me many conscientious doubts.
('79', 91, 3, 6, 195799) It is just one year ago since I left my house in Munich to spend some time in Holland.
('79', 91, 3, 7, 195886) On 10th May, by the use of every possible subtle trick.
('79', 91, 3, 8, 195942) Holland was overpowered.
('79', 91, 3, 9, 195967) After four days of the most ruthless bombing we fled to England and are now on our way to Java, the country of my birth, where I hope to find work.
('79', 91, 4, 10, 196115) Hitler aims at nothing less than the destruction of all moral values, and in the bulk of German youth he has already attained that end.
('79', 91, 5, 11, 196251) Your article in Harijan about the Jewish problem in Germany parti cularly interested me since I had many Jewish friends there.
('79', 91, 5, 12, 196378) You say in it that, if ever a war were justified, it is this one against Germany.
('79', 91, 5, 13, 196460) In the same article, however, you write that, if you were a Jew, you would attempt to soften the hearts of the Nazis by non violence.
('79', 91, 5, 14, 196594) 2 Recently you also advised Britain and the British people to surrender their beautiful island to the German invader, without resistance by force, and to conquer him afterwards by non violence.
('79', 91, 5, 15, 196788) 3 There is probably no man in the whole history who has a better knowledge of the practice of non violence than yourself.
('79', 91, 5, 16, 196910) Your views have awakened veneration and love for you in millions of hearts not only in India but in the outside world as well.
('79', 91, 6, 17, 197037) Through Nazism, the German youth has lost all individuality of thought and feeling.
('79', 91, 6, 18, 197121) The great mass of young people has lost its heart and it degraded to the level of a machine.
('79', 91, 6, 19, 197214) The German conduct of the war is absolutely mechanical; machines are driven by robot men who have no qualms of consci ence about crushing under their tanks the bodies of women and children, bombing open towns, killing hundreds of thousands of women and children, and on occasion using them as a screen for their advance, or distributing poisoned food.
('79', 91, 6, 20, 197566) These are all facts, the truth of which I can vouch for.
('79', 91, 6, 21, 197623) I have spoken with many of your followers about the possibility of applying non violence against Germany.
('79', 91, 6, 22, 197729) A friend of mine, whose work it is to cross examine German prisoners of war in England, was deeply shocked by
('79', 91, 7, 23, 197839) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('79', 91, 7, 24, 197876) 2 Vide, "The Jews" 3 Vide "To Every Briton"
('79', 92, 0, 1, 197920) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 93
('79', 92, 1, 2, 197965) the spiritual narrowness and heartlessness of these young men, and agreed with me that non violence could not be applied with any success against such robots.
('79', 92, 1, 3, 198124) The friend has sent his name and address.
('79', 92, 1, 4, 198166) But I withhold both for fear of harm coming to him through unnecessary publicity.
('79', 92, 1, 5, 198248) The letter must be valued on its own intrinsic merits.
('79', 92, 1, 6, 198303) What, however, concerns me is not so much his characterization of Nazism as his belief that non violent action may have no effect on Hitler or the Germans whom he has turned into so many robots.
('79', 92, 1, 7, 198498) Non violent action, if it is adequate, must influence Hitler and easily the duped Germans.
('79', 92, 1, 8, 198589) No man can be turned into a permanent machine.
('79', 92, 1, 9, 198636) Immediately the dead weight of authority is lifted from his head, he begins to function normally.
('79', 92, 1, 10, 198734) To lay down any such general pro position as my friend has, betrays ignorance of the working of non violence.
('79', 92, 1, 11, 198844) The British Government can take no risks, can make no experiments in which they have not even a workable faith.
('79', 92, 1, 12, 198956) But if ever an opportunity could be given to me, in spite of my physical limi tations, I should not hesitate to try what would appear to be impos sible.
('79', 92, 1, 13, 199109) For in ahimsa it is not the votary who acts in his own strength.
('79', 92, 1, 14, 199174) Strength comes from God.
('79', 92, 1, 15, 199199) If, therefore, the way is opened for me to go, he will give me the physical endurance and clothe my word with the needed power.
('79', 92, 1, 16, 199327) Anyway all through my life I have acted in that faith.
('79', 92, 1, 17, 199382) Never have I attributed any independent strength to myself.
('79', 92, 1, 18, 199442) This may be considered by men who do not believe in a higher Power than themselves as a drawback and a helpless state.
('79', 92, 1, 19, 199561) I must admit that limitation of ahimsa, if it be accounted as such.
('79', 92, 1, 20, 199629) SEVAGRAM, August 6, 1940 Harijan, 18 8 1940

('79', 94, 1, 2, 201493) What was the programme before them?
('79', 94, 1, 3, 201529) Should they not retire forthwith?
('79', 94, 1, 4, 201563) These and other questions were troubling them, and they did not know what to do.
('79', 94, 1, 5, 201644) In response Gandhiji began to do some loud thinking.
('79', 94, 1, 6, 201697) Gandhiji said: Wait, watch, and pray.
('79', 94, 1, 7, 201735) You must carefully follow what I am writing from week to week.
('79', 94, 1, 8, 201798) You must be absolutely sure that you are out and out believers in non violence.
('79', 94, 1, 9, 201878) Can your ahimsa stand the test?
('79', 94, 1, 10, 201910) Rehearse to yourselves what you would do in case of riot.
('79', 94, 1, 11, 201968) Those who have differed from us are no cowards.
('79', 94, 1, 12, 202016) If they say that they cannot do without an army and police, they deserve a respectful hearing.
('79', 94, 1, 13, 202111) I my self do not know what I should do in a difficult situation.
('79', 94, 1, 14, 202176) You know I have capitulated on the question of the desirability of maintaining a police force.
('79', 94, 1, 15, 202271) But what I can say is that I shall hope to behave non violently, should the occasion arise.
('79', 94, 1, 16, 202363) I should not like to die before my death.
('79', 94, 1, 17, 202405) I do not want to prepare India for military defence from today.
('79', 94, 1, 18, 202469) We should never forget that we are not the whole of India.
('79', 94, 1, 19, 202528) The Congress is without doubt a powerful organization, but the Congress is not the whole of India.
('79', 94, 1, 20, 202627) The Congress may not have an army, but those who do not believe in non violence will.
('79', 94, 1, 21, 202713) And if the Congress too surrenders, there is no one to represent the no army mentality.
('79', 94, 1, 22, 202801) This was my argument in a nutshell.
('79', 94, 1, 23, 202837) But I failed to carry conviction.
('79', 94, 1, 24, 202871) Therefore I must find fault not with my comrades but with myself.
('79', 94, 1, 25, 202937) There must be some weakness in my argument, and so I must prepare myself to carry conviction to those who differ from me.
('79', 94, 1, 26, 203059) But, I have digressed.
('79', 94, 1, 27, 203082) What you and I have to do is to show our ahimsa when there is rioting or similar disturbance.
('79', 94, 1, 28, 203176) If every one of us, wherever he is, begins doing so there will come into being a non violent army.
('79', 94, 1, 29, 203275) Even the limited non violence that all are subscribing to would not have come into being if we had seen no successful demons trations of it.
('79', 94, 1, 30, 203416) So we have to hold on to our faith, even if when the time comes we may fail.
('79', 94, 1, 31, 203493) There is no use arguing with the comrades who have differed from us, I hope only temporarily.

('79', 97, 6, 11, 208037) 104. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('79', 97, 7, 12, 208069) SEVAGRAM, August 7, 1940
('79', 97, 8, 13, 208094) PREMA, I have your letter.

('79', 101, 3, 5, 212769) Your heart was not in Sevagram.
('79', 101, 3, 6, 212801) It was wherever I was.
