('79', 107, 9, 14, 224099) 120. MORAL SUPPORT 1
('79', 107, 10, 15, 224120) A friend writes as follows:
('79', 107, 11, 16, 224148) On the declaration of war you had advised giving moral support to Britain.
('79', 107, 11, 17, 224223) Many persons never understood the implications of such support.
('79', 107, 11, 18, 224287) You have never explained them either so far as I know.
('79', 107, 11, 19, 224342) I am a regular reader of Harijanbandhu, but I have not seen a clear explanation there.
('79', 107, 11, 20, 224429) Everyone puts his own interpretation on the words.
('79', 107, 11, 21, 224480) At the last sitting of the Gujarat Pro vincial Congress Committee the leaders said: ‘Bapu was ready to give moral support to Britain.
('79', 107, 11, 22, 224614) What else has the Congress done in its latest resolution?
('79', 107, 11, 23, 224672) As a matter of fact the Congress asks for more than it promises to give.
('79', 107, 11, 24, 224745) Bapu was willing to give all for nothing.’ If war is itself a wrong act, how can it deserve moral support or blessings?
('79', 107, 11, 25, 224865) In the Mahabharata, was the help that Lord Krishna gave to Arjuna moral, or was it more destructive than the deadliest weapons of war?
('79', 107, 11, 26, 225000) I did explain in Harijan what I meant by moral support.
('79', 107, 11, 27, 225056) It is possible that the explanation did not appear in Harijanbandhu.
('79', 107, 11, 28, 225125) In my English writings things are often to be understood.
('79', 107, 11, 29, 225183) The ellipses need, however, to be brought out in translations.
('79', 107, 12, 30, 225246) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 17 8 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 108, 0, 1, 225374) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 109
('79', 108, 1, 2, 225420) Broadly speaking, Britain could have had moral support from the Congress, if only she had acted justly towards India.
('79', 108, 1, 3, 225538) There was no spirit of bargaining in my proposal because the help was not offered in exchange for anything.
('79', 108, 1, 4, 225646) Suppose my friend possesses moral strength which he has acquired through tapasya.
('79', 108, 1, 5, 225728) And suppose I am in need of this strength.
('79', 108, 1, 6, 225771) I shall not get it from him for the asking.
('79', 108, 1, 7, 225815) He may always be ready to give it to me, but if I have not the capacity within me to take it from him, how shall I ever obtain it?
('79', 108, 1, 8, 225946) Moral support cannot really be given in the sense of giving.
('79', 108, 1, 9, 226007) It automatically comes to him who is qualified to take it.
('79', 108, 1, 10, 226066) And such a one can take it in abundance.
('79', 108, 1, 11, 226107) The Congress has this moral reservoir.
('79', 108, 1, 12, 226146) The acceptance of the creed of truth and non violence has been its tapasya.
('79', 108, 1, 13, 226222) It has acquired world prestige through the acceptance of truth and non violence for the attainment of its goal.
('79', 108, 1, 14, 226334) If the Congress could have given its bles sings to Britain, the world would have adjudged Britain’s cause to be just.
('79', 108, 1, 15, 226452) The masses over whom the Congress holds sway would also have acknowledged justice to be on Britain’s side.
('79', 108, 1, 16, 226559) But in all this the Congress would have had nothing materiel to give.
('79', 108, 1, 17, 226629) The British Government would, by its own action, have acquired moral prestige or strength.
('79', 108, 1, 18, 226720) Though the Congress would not give one man or one piece as material aid, its moral support and blessings would definitely have turned the scales in favour of Britain.
('79', 108, 1, 19, 226887) This is my belief.
('79', 108, 1, 20, 226906) That my belief may be groundless and that the Congress never had any moral prestige is quite possible.
('79', 108, 1, 21, 227009) The determination of this question is unnecessary for my argument.
('79', 108, 1, 22, 227076) But the opportunity for rendering moral support now seems almost to have gone.
('79', 108, 1, 23, 227155) The Congress felt itself unable to adopt my course.
('79', 108, 1, 24, 227207) It cannot be taken mechanically.
('79', 108, 1, 25, 227240) It presupposes a living faith in truth and non violence.
('79', 108, 1, 26, 227297) The greatest quality in the Congress is this that it has never claimed to have what it really does not possess.
('79', 108, 1, 27, 227409) And therefore its resolutions are dignified and carry force with them.
('79', 108, 1, 28, 227480) The help that the Congress in its latest resolution promises to give is material and for a consideration, eminently just, no doubt, but it is not and cannot be unconditional.
('79', 108, 1, 29, 227655) I do not suggest that this posi tion is either untenable or morally wrong.
('79', 108, 1, 30, 227730) The resolution has dignity because it is the considered opinion of the majority.
('79', 108, 1, 31, 227811) But by passing it the Congress has, in my opinion, surrendered the prestige it had or was supposed to have.
('79', 108, 1, 32, 227919) Many Congressmen say that while they firmly
('79', 109, 0, 1, 227963) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 109, 1, 2, 228005) believed that they could attain swaraj through non violence, they had never meant it to be understood that they could retain it also through non violence.
('79', 109, 1, 3, 228160) The entire outside world, however, believed that the Congress was showing the golden way to the abolition of war.
('79', 109, 1, 4, 228274) No one outside India ever dreamed that, if the Congress could wrest indepen dence from a mighty power like Britain purely through non violence, it would not be able to defend it also by the same means.
('79', 109, 1, 5, 228476) In my opinion Lord Krishna’s help to Arjuna cannot be said to be moral, because he himself had an army and was an expert in the art of war.
('79', 109, 1, 6, 228616) Duryodhana acted foolishly in that he asked for krishna’s army, while Arjuna got what he wanted in the person of the expert in the science of war.
('79', 109, 1, 7, 228763) Therefore, if we interpret the Mahabharata literally, Lord Krishna’s strength was certainly more destructive than that of his army.
('79', 109, 1, 8, 228895) Because of his scientific skill Krishna was able with an army of seven divisions to destroy Duryodhana’s army of eleven.
('79', 109, 1, 9, 229016) But it is well known that I have never looked upon the Mahabharata as a mere record of earthly warfare.
('79', 109, 1, 10, 229120) In the garb of an epic the poet has described the eternal warfare within the individual as well as in society, between truth and Untruth, Violence and Non violence, Right and Wrong.
('79', 109, 1, 11, 229302) Looking at the epic even superficially one can understand how the great Vyasa has demonstrated that in this war the victor was no better off than the vanquished.
('79', 109, 1, 12, 229464) Out of that vast concourse of war riors only seven remained to tell the tale.
('79', 109, 1, 13, 229542) And the poet gives a true picture of the woeful state of mind also of these seven.
('79', 109, 1, 14, 229625) The author has shown clearly too that in armed warfare the contending parties are certain to stoop to meanness and trickery.
('79', 109, 1, 15, 229750) When occasion arose even the great Yadhishthira had to report to untruth to save the battle.
('79', 109, 1, 16, 229843) One more question of the writer remains to be answered.
('79', 109, 1, 17, 229899) If war is itself a wrong act, how can it be worthy or moral support or bles sings?
('79', 109, 1, 18, 229982) I believe all war to be wholly wrong.
('79', 109, 1, 19, 230020) But if we scrutinize the motives of two warring parties, we may find one to be in the right and the other in the wrong.
('79', 109, 1, 20, 230140) For instance, if A wishes to seize B’s cou ntry, B is obviously the wronged one.
('79', 109, 1, 21, 230221) Both fight with arms.
('79', 109, 1, 22, 230243) I do not believe in violent warfare, but all the same B, whose cause is just, deserves my moral help and blessings.
('79', 109, 1, 23, 230359) SEVAGRAM, August 12, 1940 Harijan, 18 8 1940

('79', 110, 6, 8, 230667) 122. IMPLICATIONS OF CONSTRUCTIVE PROGRAMME 1
('79', 110, 7, 9, 230713) A correspondent writes:
('79', 110, 8, 10, 230737) What are the qualities that you intend to inculcate in people by laying stress on the constructive programme?
('79', 110, 8, 11, 230847) What are the qualifications necessary for a constructive worker in order to make his work effective?
('79', 110, 8, 12, 230948) The constructive programme is a big undertaking including a number of items: (1) Hindu Muslim or communal unity; (2) Removal of untouchability; (3) Prohibition; (4) Khadi; (5) Other village indus tries; (6) Village sanitation; (7) New or basic education; (8) Adult education; (9) Uplift of women; (10) Education in hygiene and health; (11) Propagation of Rashtrabhasha; (12) Cultivating love of one’s own language; (13) Working for economic equality.
('79', 110, 8, 13, 231399) This list can be supplemented if necessary, but it is so comprehensive that I think it can be proved to include items appearing to have been omitted.
('79', 110, 8, 14, 231549) The reader will see that it is the want of all these things that is responsible for our bondage.
('79', 110, 8, 15, 231646) He will also see that the constructive programme of the Congress is not supposed to include all the items.
('79', 110, 8, 16, 231753) That is understood to include only four items, or rather six, now that the Congress has created the All India Village Industries Association and the Basic Education Board.
('79', 110, 8, 17, 231925) But we have to go further forward, we have to stabilize and perfect ahimsa, and so we have to make the cons tructive programme as comprehensive as possible.
('79', 110, 8, 18, 232082) There should be no room for doubt that, if we can win swaraj purely through non viole

('79', 111, 1, 2, 232339) nce, we can also retain it through the same means.
('79', 111, 1, 3, 232390) In the fulfilment of the constructive programme lies the non violent attainment of swaraj.
('79', 111, 1, 4, 232481) The items I have mentioned are not in order of importance.
('79', 111, 1, 5, 232540) I have put them down just as they came to my pen.
('79', 111, 1, 6, 232590) Generally I talk of khadi only nowadays, because millions of people can take their share in this work, and progress can be arithmetically measured.
('79', 111, 1, 7, 232738) Communal unity and the removal of untouchability cannot be thus assessed.

('79', 114, 4, 16, 240562) WHAT SHOULD A BRITON DO AND NOT DO?
('79', 114, 5, 17, 240598) Q. In your appeal to ‘Every Briton’ you say: “You will invite Herr Hitler and Signor Mussolini to take what they want.
('79', 114, 5, 18, 240717) You will give all your ‘earthly possessions’ but never your souls or your minds.
('79', 114, 5, 19, 240798) You will refuse to owe allegiance to them.” Please explain clearly what a Briton should or should not do.
('79', 114, 5, 20, 240904) I ask the question because your answer will have a bearing on the duty of every satyagrahi.
('79', 114, 6, 21, 240996) A. Not to yield your soul to the conqueror means that you will refuse to do that which your conscience forbids you to do.
('79', 114, 6, 22, 241118) Suppose the ‘enemy’ were to ask you to rub your nose on the ground or to pull your ears or to go through such humiliating performances, you would not submit to any of these humiliations.
('79', 114, 6, 23, 241305) But if he robs you of your possessions, you will yield them because as a votary of ahimsa you have from the beginning decided that earthly possessions have nothing to do with your soul.
('79', 114, 6, 24, 241491) That which you look upon as your own you may keep only so long as the world allows you to own it.
('79', 114, 6, 25, 241589) Not to yield your mind means that you will not give way to any temptation.

('79', 114, 6, 28, 241804) A weak minded man can never be a satyagrahi.

('79', 115, 1, 13, 243016) Therefore, when he is already thus dead why should he yearn to kill anyone?
('79', 115, 1, 14, 243092) To die in the act of killing is in essence to die defeated.
('79', 115, 1, 15, 243152) Because, if the enemy is unable to get what he wants from you alive, he will decide to get it after killing you.

('79', 120, 1, 2, 250570) 130. DISCUSSION WITH B. G. KHER AND OTHERS 1
('79', 120, 2, 3, 250615) [August 15, 1940] 2
('79', 120, 3, 4, 250635) You see that I am answering every one of your questions strai ghtway without the slightest hesitation.
('79', 120, 3, 5, 250738) That is because the great ques tion underlying your questions possesses me and I have rehearsed to myself every one of the situations arising out of the various implica tions of ahimsa.
('79', 120, 4, 6, 250924) Q. Should one stop with the human species or extend ahimsa to all creation?
('79', 120, 4, 7, 251000) GANDHI: I was not prepared for this question.
('79', 120, 4, 8, 251046) For the Congress ahimsa is naturally confined to the political field and therefore only to the human species.
('79', 120, 4, 9, 251156) Hence out and out non violence means for our purpose every variety of non violence in the political field.
('79', 120, 4, 10, 251263) In con crete terms it covers family relations, relations with constituted autho rity, internal disorders and external aggression.
('79', 120, 4, 11, 251393) Put in another way it covers all human relations.
('79', 120, 5, 12, 251443) Q. Then what about meat eating and egg eating?
('79', 120, 5, 13, 251490) Are they consistent with non violence?
('79', 120, 6, 14, 251529) G. They are.
('79', 120, 6, 15, 251542) Otherwise we should have to exclude Mussalmans and Christians and a vast number of Hindus as possible co workers in ahimsa.
('79', 120, 6, 16, 251666) I have known many meat eaters to be far more non violent than vegetarians.
('79', 120, 7, 17, 251741) Q. But what if we had to give them up for the sake of a principle?
('79', 120, 8, 18, 251808) G. Oh yes, we would, if we had to compromise our principle.
('79', 120, 8, 19, 251868) Our principle is defined as I have shown already.
('79', 120, 9, 20, 251918) Q. If, as you have said, Polish resistance to the German invasion was almost non violent, and you would thus seem to reconcile yourself with it, why do you object to the wardha resolution of the Working Committee?
('79', 120, 10, 21, 252132) G. Surely, there is no analogy between the two cases.
('79', 120, 10, 22, 252186) If a man fights with his sword single handed against a horde of dacoits armed to the teeth, I should say he is fighting almost non violently.
('79', 120, 10, 23, 252328) Haven’t I said to our women that, if in defence of their honour they used their nails and teeth and even a dagger, I should regard their conduct non violent?
('79', 120, 10, 24, 252486) She does know the distinction between himsa and ahimsa.
('79', 120, 10, 25, 252542) She acts spontaneously.
('79', 120, 10, 26, 252566) Supposing a mouse in fighting a cat tried to
('79', 120, 11, 27, 252611) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “An Interesting Discourse”.
('79', 120, 11, 28, 252672) B. G. Kher, a former Prime Minister of Bombay had come with a party from Poona “for the sole purpose of clearing their doubts on ahimsa”.
('79', 120, 12, 29, 252810) 2 The Date is from Bapu Smaran, “What the “Masnavi” Says
('79', 121, 0, 1, 252867) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 121, 1, 2, 252909) resist the cat with his sharp teeth, would you call that mouse violent?
('79', 121, 1, 3, 252981) In the same way, for the Poles to stand valiantly against the German hordes vastly superior in numbers, military equipment and strength, was almost non violence.
('79', 121, 1, 4, 253143) I should not mind repeating that statement over and over again.
('79', 121, 1, 5, 253207) You must give its full value to the word ‘almost’.
('79', 121, 1, 6, 253258) But we are 400 millions here.
('79', 121, 1, 7, 253288) If we were to organize a big army and prepare ourselves to fight foreign aggression, how could we by any stretch of imagination call ourselves almost non violent, let alone non violent?
('79', 121, 1, 8, 253474) The Poles were unprepared for the way in which the enemy swooped down upon them.
('79', 121, 1, 9, 253555) When we talk of armed preparation, we contemplate preparation to meet any violent combination with our superior violence.
('79', 121, 1, 10, 253677) If India ever prepared herself that way, she would constitute the greatest menace to world peace.
('79', 121, 1, 11, 253775) For if we take that path, we will also have to choose the path of exploitation like the European nations.
('79', 121, 1, 12, 253881) That is why I still regret the moment when my words lacked the power of convincing the Sardar and Rajaji.
('79', 121, 1, 13, 253987) By having passed that resolution we proclaimed to the world that the ahimsa we had subs cribed to all these years was not really ahimsa but a from of himsa.
('79', 121, 2, 14, 254144) Q. How will you run your administration non violently?
('79', 121, 2, 15, 254199) G. If you assume that we would have won independence by non violent means, it means that the bulk of the country had been organized non violently.
('79', 121, 2, 16, 254346) Without the vast majority of people having become non violent, we could not attain non violent swaraj.
('79', 121, 2, 17, 254449) If, therefore, we attain swaraj by purely non violent means, it should not be difficult for us to carry on the administration without the military.
('79', 121, 2, 18, 254597) The goondas too will then have come under our control.
('79', 121, 2, 19, 254652) If, for instance in Sevagram we have five or seven goondas in a population of seven hundred who are non violently organized, the five or seven well wither live under the discipline of the rest or leave the village.
('79', 121, 2, 20, 254867) But you will see that I am answering the question with the utmost caution, and my truth makes me admit that we might have to maintain a police force.
('79', 121, 2, 21, 255017) But the police will be after our pattern, and not the British pattern.
('79', 121, 2, 22, 255088) As we shall have adult suffrage, the voice of even the youngest of us will count.
('79', 121, 2, 23, 255170) That is why I have said that the ideally non violent State will be an ordered anarchy.
('79', 121, 2, 24, 255257) That State will be the best governed which is governed the least.
('79', 121, 2, 25, 255323) The pity is that no one trusts me with the reins of government!
('79', 121, 2, 26, 255387) Otherwise I would show how to govern non violently.
('79', 121, 2, 27, 255439) If I maintain a police force, it will be a body of reformers.
('79', 122, 0, 1, 255501) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 123
('79', 122, 1, 2, 255547) Q. But you had the power in the Congress?
('79', 122, 2, 3, 255589) G. That was a paper boat.
('79', 122, 2, 4, 255615) And then you must not forget that I never spared the Congress ministries.
('79', 122, 2, 5, 255689) Munshi and Pantji came in for a lot of strictures from me.
('79', 122, 2, 6, 255748) As I have said in another connection even the dirty water from the gutter.
('79', 122, 2, 7, 255823) When it mixes with the water of the Ganges, becomes as pure as the Ganges water; even so I had expected even the goondas would work under Congress discipline.
('79', 122, 2, 8, 255982) But evide ntly our ministers had not attained the purifying potency of the fabled Ganges.
('79', 122, 3, 9, 256072) B. G. KHER: But the Congress ministers had no non violent power with them.
('79', 122, 3, 10, 256147) Even if 500 goondas had run amuck and had been allowed to go unchecked, they would have dealt untold havoc.
('79', 122, 3, 11, 256255) I do not know how even you would have dealt with them.
('79', 122, 4, 12, 256310) G. Surely, surely, I had rehearsed such situations.
('79', 122, 4, 13, 256362) The ministers could on such occasions have gone out and allowed themselves to be done to death by the goondas.
('79', 122, 4, 14, 256473) But let us face the fact that we had not the requisite ahimsa.
('79', 122, 4, 15, 256536) We went in with our half baked ahimsa.
('79', 122, 4, 16, 256575) I do not mind it, inasmuch as we gave up power the moment we felt we should give it up.
('79', 122, 4, 17, 256663) I am sure that, if we had adhered to strictest non violence during these two or three years, the Congress would have made a tre mendous advance in the direction of ahimsa and also independence.
('79', 122, 5, 18, 256857) B. G. K. But four or five years ago when there was a riot, and I appealed to the leaders to go and throw themselves into the conflagration, no one was ready.
('79', 122, 6, 19, 257015) G. So you are supporting my argument.
('79', 122, 6, 20, 257053) You agree that our loyalty to ahimsa was lip loyalty and not heart loyalty.
('79', 122, 6, 21, 257129) And if even the half baked ahimsa carried us a long way, does it not follow that ahimsa would have carried us very far indeed, even if it had not already brought us to the goal?
('79', 122, 7, 22, 257307) Q. But we cannot visualize how you will stand non violently against a fore ign invasion.
('79', 122, 8, 23, 257396) G. I cannot draw the whole picture to you because we have no past experience to fall back upon and there is no reality facing us today.
('79', 122, 8, 24, 257532) We have got the Government army manned by the Sikhs, Pathans and Gurkhas.
('79', 122, 8, 25, 257606) What I can conceive is this that with my non violent army of, say, two thousand people I should put myself bet ween the two contending armies.
('79', 122, 8, 26, 257749) But this, I know, is no answer.
('79', 122, 8, 27, 257781) I can only say that we shall be able to reduce the invaders’ violence to a minimum.
('79', 122, 8, 28, 257865) The general of a non violent army has got to have greater
('79', 123, 0, 1, 257923) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 123, 1, 2, 257965) presence of mind than that of a violent army, and God would bless him with the necessary resourcefulness to meet situations as they arise.
('79', 123, 2, 3, 258104) B. G. K. The world is made up of pairs of opposites.
('79', 123, 2, 4, 258157) Where there is fear, there is courage too.
('79', 123, 2, 5, 258200) When we walk on the edge of a precipice we walk warily, for we have fear.
('79', 123, 2, 6, 258274) Fear is not a thing to despise.
('79', 123, 2, 7, 258306) Will your non violent army be above these pairs of opposites?
('79', 123, 2, 8, 258368) No, for the simple reason that my army will represent one of the pair—ahimsa—out of the pair of himsa and ahimsa.
('79', 123, 2, 9, 258482) Nei ther I nor my army is above the pair of opposites.
('79', 123, 2, 10, 258537) The state of gun atita 1 , in the language of the Gita, rises above himsa and ahimsa both.
('79', 123, 2, 11, 258628) Fear has its use, but cowardice has none.
('79', 123, 2, 12, 258670) I may not put my finger into the jaws of a snake, but the very sight of the snake need not strike terror into me.
('79', 123, 2, 13, 258784) The trouble is that we often die many times before death overtakes us.
('79', 123, 2, 14, 258855) But let me explain what my army will be like.
('79', 123, 2, 15, 258901) They need not and will not have the resourcefulness or understanding of the general, but they will have a perfect sense of discipline to carry out faithfully his order.
('79', 123, 2, 16, 259070) The general should have the quality which commands the unquestioning obedience of his army, and he will expect of them nothing more than this obedience.
('79', 123, 2, 17, 259223) The Dandi March was entirely my conception.
('79', 123, 2, 18, 259267) Pandit Motilalji first laughed at it, he thought it to be a quixotic adventure, and Jamnalalji suggested instead a march on the Viceroy’s House!
('79', 123, 2, 19, 259412) But I could not think of anything but the salt march as I had to think in terms of millions of our countrymen.
('79', 123, 2, 20, 259523) It was a conception that God gave me.
('79', 123, 2, 21, 259561) Pandit Motilalji argued for some time, and then he said he must not argue as after all I was the general, and he must have faith in me.
('79', 123, 2, 22, 259697) Later when he saw me in Jambusar, he was completely converted for he saw with his own eyes the awakening that had come over the masses.
('79', 123, 2, 23, 259833) And it was an almost magical awakening.
('79', 123, 2, 24, 259873) Where in history shall we find parallels of the cool courage that our women displayed in such large numbers?
('79', 123, 2, 25, 259982) And yet none of the thousands who took part in the movement were above the average.
('79', 123, 2, 26, 260066) They were erring, sinning mortals.
('79', 123, 2, 27, 260101) God has a way of making use of the most fragile instruments and remaining Himself untouched by everything.
('79', 123, 2, 28, 260208) Only He is gunatita.
('79', 123, 3, 29, 260229) 1 One who has transcended the three constituents of nature—Bhagavad Gita, xiv.
('79', 124, 0, 1, 260308) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 125
('79', 124, 1, 2, 260354) And then what after all is the army that wins?
('79', 124, 1, 3, 260401) You know Rama’s reply to Vibhishana when the latter wondered how Rama would be able to conquer a foe like Ravana, when he had no chariot, no amour, nor any shoes to his feet?
('79', 124, 1, 4, 260576) Rama says: 1
('79', 124, 2, 5, 260589) The chariot, my dear Vibhishana, that wins the victory for Rama is of a different sort from the usual one.
('79', 124, 2, 6, 260696) Manliness and courage are its wheels unflin ching truth and character its banners and standards; strength, discrimination, self restraint and benevolence its horses, with forgiveness, mercy, equani mity their reins; prayer to God is that conqueror’s unerring charioteer, dispas sion his shield, contentment his sword, charity his axe, intellect his spear, and perfect science his stout bow.
('79', 124, 2, 7, 261087) His pure and unwavering mind stands for a quiver, his mental quietude and his practice of yama and niyama stand for the sheaf of arrows, and the homage he pays to Brahmins and his guru is his impenetrable armour.
('79', 124, 2, 8, 261300) There is no other equipment for victory comparable to this; and, my dear friend, there is no enemy who can conquer the man who takes his stand on the chariot of dharma.
('79', 124, 2, 9, 261469) He who has a powerful chariot like this is a warrior who can conquer even that great and invincible enemy the world.
('79', 124, 2, 10, 261586) Hearken unto me and fear not.
('79', 124, 2, 11, 261616) That is the equipment that can lead us to victory.
('79', 124, 2, 12, 261667) I have not reti red from the world, nor do I mean to.
('79', 124, 2, 13, 261721) I am no recluse.
('79', 124, 2, 14, 261738) I am content to do what little work I can in Sevagram and give what guidance I can do those that come to me.
('79', 124, 2, 15, 261847) What we need is faith.
('79', 124, 2, 16, 261870) And what is there to be lost in following the right path?
('79', 124, 2, 17, 261928) The worst that can happen to us is that we shall be crushed.

('79', 131, 10, 20, 275974) 137. EQUAL DISTRIBUTION 3
('79', 131, 11, 21, 276000) In last week’s article on the Constructive Programme 4 I men tioned equal distribution of wealth as one of the 13 items.
('79', 131, 12, 22, 276121) 1Vide the preceding item.
('79', 131, 13, 23, 276147) 2 This was a postscript Gandhiji added to a letter Mahadev Desai wrote to the addresee.
('79', 131, 14, 24, 276235) 3 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 24 8 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 131, 15, 25, 276363) 4 Vide “Implications of Constructive Programme”
('79', 131, 16, 26, 276411) 5 The Gujarati adds: “Let us consider it here.”
('79', 132, 0, 1, 276459) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 133
('79', 132, 1, 2, 276505) The real implication of equal distribution is that each man shall have the wherewithal to supply all his natural needs and no more.
('79', 132, 1, 3, 276637) For example, if one man has a weak digestion and requires only a quarter of a pound of flour for his bread and another needs a pound, both should be in a position to satisfy their wants.
('79', 132, 1, 4, 276824) To bring this ideal into being the entire social order has got to be reconstructed.
('79', 132, 1, 5, 276908) A society based on non violence cannot nurture any other ideal.
('79', 132, 1, 6, 276972) We may not perhaps be able to realize the goal, but we must bear it in mind and work unceasingly to near it.
('79', 132, 1, 7, 277081) To the same extent as we progress to wards our goal we shall find contentment and happiness, and to that extent too shall we have contributed towards the bringing into being of a non violent society.
('79', 132, 1, 8, 277281) It is perfectly possible for an individual to adopt this way of life without having to wait for others to do so.
('79', 132, 1, 9, 277394) And if an individual can observe a certain rule of conduct, it follows that a group of individuals can do likewise.
('79', 132, 1, 10, 277510) It is necessary for me to emphasize the fact that no one need wait for anyone else in order to adopt a right course.
('79', 132, 1, 11, 277627) Men generally hesitate to make a beginning if they feel that the objective cannot be had in its entirely.
('79', 132, 1, 12, 277733) Such an attitude of mind is in reality a bar to progress.
('79', 132, 1, 13, 277791) Not let us consider how equal distribution can be brought about through non violence.
('79', 132, 1, 14, 277877) The first step towards it is for him who has made this ideal part of his being to bring about the necessary changes in his personal life.
('79', 132, 1, 15, 278015) He would reduce his wants to a minimum, bearing in mind the poverty of India.
('79', 132, 1, 16, 278093) His earnings would be free of dishon esty.
('79', 132, 1, 17, 278136) The desire for speculation would be renounced.
('79', 132, 1, 18, 278183) His habitation would be in keeping with the new mode of life.
('79', 132, 1, 19, 278245) There would be self restraint exercised in every sphere of life.
('79', 132, 1, 20, 278310) When he has done all that is possible in his own life, then only will he be in a position to preach this ideal among his associates and neighbours.
('79', 132, 1, 21, 278458) Indeed at the root of this doctrine of equal distribution must lie that of the trusteeship of the wealthy for the superfluous wealth pos sessed by them.
('79', 132, 1, 22, 278611) For according to the doctrine they may not possess a rupee more than their neighbours.
('79', 132, 1, 23, 278698) How is this to be brought about?
('79', 132, 1, 24, 278731) Non violently?
('79', 132, 1, 25, 278746) Or should the wealthy be dispossessed of their posse ssions?
('79', 132, 1, 26, 278807) To do this we would naturally have to resort to violence.
('79', 132, 1, 27, 278865) This violent action cannot benefit society.
('79', 132, 1, 28, 278909) Society will be the poorer, for it will lose the gifts of a man who knows how to accumulate wealth.
('79', 132, 1, 29, 279009) Therefore the non violent way is evidently superior.
('79', 132, 1, 30, 279062) The rich man will
('79', 133, 0, 1, 279080) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 133, 1, 2, 279122) be left in possession of his wealth, of which he will use what he rea sonably requires for his personal needs and will act as a trustee for the remainder to be used for the society.
('79', 133, 1, 3, 279304) In this argument honesty on the part of the trustee is assumed.
('79', 133, 1, 4, 279368) As soon as man looks upon himself as a servant of society, ear ns for its sake, spends for its benefit, then purity enters into his earni ngs and there is ahimsa in his venture.
('79', 133, 1, 5, 279546) Moreover, if men’s minds turn towards this way of life, there will come about a peaceful revolution in society, and that without any bitterness.
('79', 133, 1, 6, 279691) It may be asked whether history at any time records such a change in human nature.
('79', 133, 1, 7, 279774) Such changes have certainly taken place in individuals.
('79', 133, 1, 8, 279830) One may not perhaps be able to point to them in a whole society.
('79', 133, 1, 9, 279895) But this only means that up till now there has never been an experiment on a large scale in non violence.
('79', 133, 1, 10, 280001) Somehow or other the wrong belief has taken possession of us that ahimsa is pre eminently a weapon for individuals and its use should therefore be limited to that sphere.
('79', 133, 1, 11, 280172) In fact this is not the case.
('79', 133, 1, 12, 280202) Ahimsa is definitely an attri bute of society.
('79', 133, 1, 13, 280249) To convince people of this truth is at once my effort and my experiment.
('79', 133, 1, 14, 280322) In this age of wonders no one will say that a thing or idea is worthless because it is new.
('79', 133, 1, 15, 280414) To say it is impossible because it is difficult is again not in consonance with the spirit of the age.
('79', 133, 1, 16, 280517) Things undreamt of are daily being seen, the impossible is ever becoming possible.
('79', 133, 1, 17, 280600) We are constantly being astonished these days at the amazing discoveries in the field of violence.
('79', 133, 1, 18, 280699) But I maintain that far more undreamt of and seemingly impossible discoveries will be made in the field on non violence.
('79', 133, 1, 19, 280820) The history of religion is full of such examples.
('79', 133, 1, 20, 280870) To try to root out religion itself from society is a wild goose chase.
('79', 133, 1, 21, 280941) And were such an attempt to succeed, it would mean the destruction of society.
('79', 133, 1, 22, 281020) Superstition, evil customs and other imperfe ctions creep in from age to age and mar religion for the time being.
('79', 133, 1, 23, 281134) They come and go.
('79', 133, 1, 24, 281152) 1 But religion itself remains.
('79', 133, 1, 25, 281183) Because the existence of the world in a broad sense depends on religion.
('79', 133, 1, 26, 281256) The ultimate defi nition of religion may be said to be obedience to the law of God.
('79', 133, 1, 27, 281340) God and His law are synonymous terms.
('79', 133, 1, 28, 281378) Therefore God signifies an unchanging and living law.
('79', 133, 1, 29, 281432) No one has ever really found Him.
('79', 133, 2, 30, 281466) 1 The Gujarati version has: “Religion undergoes transformation.
('79', 133, 2, 31, 281530) The apparent superstitions, evil customs and imperfections can be removed—in fact they are and will be removed.”
('79', 134, 0, 1, 281643) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 135
('79', 134, 1, 2, 281689) avatars and prophets have, by means of their tapasya, given to man kind a faint glimpse of the eternal Law.
('79', 134, 1, 3, 281797) If, however, in spite of the utmost effort, the rich do not become guardians of the poor in the true sense of the term and the latter are more and more crushed and die of hunger, what is to be done?
('79', 134, 1, 4, 281996) In trying to find the solution to this riddle I have lighted on non violent non co operation and civil disobedience as the right and infallible means.
('79', 134, 1, 5, 282147) The rich cannot accumulate wealth without the co operation of the poor in society.
('79', 134, 1, 6, 282230) Man has been conversant with violence from the beginning, for he has inherited this strength from the animal in his nature.
('79', 134, 1, 7, 282354) It was only when he rose from the state of a quadruped (animal) to that of a biped (man) that the knowledge of the strength of ahimsa entered into his soul.
('79', 134, 1, 8, 282511) This knowledge has grown within him slowly but surely.
('79', 134, 1, 9, 282566) If this knowledge were to penetrate to and spread amongst the poor, they would become strong and would learn how to freethemselves by means of non violence from the crushing inequa lities [which have brought them to the verge of starvation] 1 .
('79', 134, 1, 10, 282811) I scarcely need to write anything about non co operation and civil disobedience, for the readers of Harijanbandhu are familiar with these and their working.
('79', 134, 2, 11, 282968) SEVAGRAM, August 19, 1940 Harijan, 25 8 1940

('79', 136, 4, 13, 285886) 141. MY IDEA OF A POLICE FORCE 1
('79', 136, 5, 14, 285919) A friend writes as follows: 2
('79', 136, 6, 15, 285949) The questions asked in this letter are of the utmost importance and deserve notice.
('79', 136, 6, 16, 286033) 3 If true ahimsa had come into being within us, and if our so called satyagraha movements had been truly non violent, these questions would not have arisen because they would have been solved.
('79', 136, 6, 17, 286226) For one who has never seen the arctic regions an imaginary description of them, however elaborate, can convey but an inadequate idea of the reality.
('79', 136, 6, 18, 286375) Even so is it with ahimsa.
('79', 136, 6, 19, 286402) If all Congressmen had been true to their creed, we would not be vacillating between violence and non violence as we are today.
('79', 136, 6, 20, 286530) The fruits of ahimsa would be in evidence everywhere.
('79', 136, 6, 21, 286584) There would be communal harmony, the demon of untouchability would have been cast out, and, generally speaking, we should have evolved an ordered society.
('79', 136, 6, 22, 286739) But the reverse is the case just now.
('79', 136, 6, 23, 286777) There is even definite hostility to the Congress in certain quarters.
('79', 136, 6, 24, 286847) The word of Congressmen is not always relied on.
('79', 136, 7, 25, 286896) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 31 8 1940. This translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 136, 8, 26, 287016) 2 Not reproduced here.
('79', 136, 8, 27, 287039) The correspondent, while conceding the effectiveness of non violence to meet external affression, had argued that so long as social injustice and poverty existed internal disturbances were bound to continue and hence also the need for a police force.
('79', 136, 8, 28, 287290) he had asked Gandhiji whether he envisaged such a police force to be maintained for all time.
('79', 136, 9, 29, 287384) 3 The Gujarati version has: “deserve consideration by all the responsible satya grahis.”
('79', 137, 0, 1, 287473) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 137, 1, 2, 287515) Muslim League and most of the Princes have no faith in the Congress and are in fact inimical to it.
('79', 137, 1, 3, 287615) If Congressmen had true ahimsa in them, there would be none of this distrust.
('79', 137, 1, 4, 287693) In fact the Congress would be the beloved of all.
('79', 137, 1, 5, 287743) Therefore I can only place an imaginary picture before the votaries of ahimsa.
('79', 137, 1, 6, 287822) So long as we are not saturated with pure ahimsa we cannot pos sibly win swaraj through non violence.
('79', 137, 1, 7, 287924) We can come into power only when we are in a majority or, in other words, when the large majority of people are willing to abide by the law of ahimsa.
('79', 137, 1, 8, 288075) When this happy state prevails, the spirit of violence will have all but vanished and internal disorder will have come under control.
('79', 137, 1, 9, 288209) Nevertheless I have conceded that even in a non violent State a police force may be necessary.
('79', 137, 1, 10, 288304) This, I admit, is a sign of my imperfect ahimsa.
('79', 137, 1, 11, 288353) I have not the courage to declare that we can carry on without a police force as I have in respect of an army.
('79', 137, 1, 12, 288464) Or course I can and do envisage a state where the police will not be necessary; but whether we shall succeed in realizing it, the future alone will show.
('79', 137, 1, 13, 288618) The police of my conception will, however, be of a wholly dif ferent pattern from the present day force.
('79', 137, 1, 14, 288723) Its ranks will be composed of believers in non violence.
('79', 137, 1, 15, 288780) They will be servants, not masters, of the people.
('79', 137, 1, 16, 288831) The people will instinctively render them every help, and thro ugh mutual co operation they will easily deal with the everdecreasing disturbances.
('79', 137, 1, 17, 288978) The police force will have some kind of arms, but they will be rarely used, if at all.
('79', 137, 1, 18, 289065) In fact the policemen will be reformers.
('79', 137, 1, 19, 289106) Their police work will be confined primarily to robbers and dacoits.
('79', 137, 1, 20, 289175) Quarrels between labour and capital and strikes will be few and far between in a non violent state, because the influence of the non violent majority will be so great as to command the respect of the principal elements in society.
('79', 137, 1, 21, 289406) Similarly there will be no room for communal disturbances.
('79', 137, 1, 22, 289465) Then we must remember that when such a Congress Government comes into power the large majority of men and women of 21 years and over will have been enfranchised.
('79', 137, 1, 23, 289627) The rigid and cramped Constitution of today has of course no place in this picture.
('79', 137, 1, 24, 289711) SEVAGRAM, August 20, 1940 Harijan, 1 9 1940

('79', 139, 0, 1, 291086) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 139, 1, 2, 291128) In all our activities we have to be non violent.
('79', 139, 1, 3, 291177) Non violence is dictated not only by the circumstances in our country but by considerations that operate throughout the world.
('79', 139, 1, 4, 291304) It is not only a practical necessity, it is an ethical desirability.
('79', 139, 1, 5, 291373) Whatever little confusion there might be on this point due to faulty reporting is set aside by the reporter himself.
('79', 139, 1, 6, 291490) I am reported to have said: ‘When we have recourse to weapons we become weak of hearts.
('79', 139, 1, 7, 291578) Those who rely on weapons do not rely on their hearts.
('79', 139, 1, 8, 291633) They turn into slaves of their own weapons.
('79', 139, 1, 9, 291677) They have no strength left in themselves.
('79', 139, 2, 10, 291719) I am an opponent of the old cult of the lathi, and its modern equivalent
('79', 139, 3, 11, 291792) the cult of the aeroplane.
('79', 139, 3, 12, 291819) There is an inner contradiction between these cults and the enduring of human life, a contradiction which is daily becoming more fierce.
('79', 139, 3, 13, 291956) The next twenty years will show which wins, and the dualism cannot last longer.Should human life endure, there can be only one from of organization.
('79', 139, 3, 14, 292105) Adult democracy must obtain throughout the world, and there will be no place in it for imperialism, nor for capitalism.
('79', 139, 3, 15, 292225) I have given an indication in my speech of this form of government as it will affect the Indian people.
('79', 139, 3, 16, 292329) It was with a view to bring into the foreground this principle of adult democracy that I suggested an immediate peace plan to Mahatma Gandhi.
('79', 139, 3, 17, 292471) I claim no origina lity for this plan whose items are:
('79', 139, 4, 18, 292526) 1. All peoples will be free.
('79', 139, 4, 19, 292555) Those newly acquiring freedom will determine their constitution through a constituent assembly.
('79', 139, 5, 20, 292651) 2. All races are equal, and there will be no racial privileges in any part of the world.
('79', 139, 5, 21, 292740) There will be no political bar to anyone settling wherever he likes.
('79', 139, 6, 22, 292809) 3. All credits and investments owned by the Government and nationals of one country in another will be scrapped or submitted for impartial review to international tribunals.
('79', 139, 6, 23, 292983) They will then be owned not by individuals but by the state.
('79', 139, 7, 24, 293044) When these three principles will have been accepted by the people of the world, a fourth will automatically come into operation.
('79', 139, 8, 25, 293173) 4. There will be total disarmament.
('79', 139, 9, 26, 293209) I am happy in the knowledge that Mahatma Gandhji has endorsed this peace plan.
('79', 139, 10, 27, 293288) Let me in conclusion state that I have no ill will towards any people.
('79', 139, 10, 28, 293359) I have lived among the German people and liked their thoroughness of enquiry, the scientific bent of their mind and their efficiency in action.
('79', 139, 10, 29, 293503) I am unhappy that they have today to carry on their shoulders a system which
('79', 140, 0, 1, 293580) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 141
('79', 140, 1, 2, 293626) results in war and conquest.
('79', 140, 1, 3, 293655) I have no intimate knowledge of the British people.
('79', 140, 1, 4, 293707) I dare say that they have their virtues.
('79', 140, 1, 5, 293748) I may be permitted to quote from my speech: ‘I do not want the destruction of Britain.
('79', 140, 1, 6, 293835) The British have done evil to us, but I do not want to do evil to them.’ Again, I am unhappy that the British people have to carry on their shoulders today a system which has enslaved the people of the world.
('79', 140, 2, 7, 294044) Of Dr. Lohia this is what the court has to say: The accused is a highly intellectual and cultured gentlemen, perhaps with a doctorate degree of some European University, a man of high princi ples and morals whose honesty of purpose nobody can doubt.
('79', 140, 2, 8, 294294) He does not mind suffering for his convictions and does not care much for his sentence or its duration.
('79', 140, 2, 9, 294398) We certainly do not punish him for holding certain political views about the present Government, for the very claim of the Government that it is democratic and run on public opinion entitles the public to criticize it according to his [sic] light by constitutional means, but we must protect such Government from embarrassment in her relations with the masses who are bound to be disaffected by a speech like the one the accused has delivered in Dostpur, and particularly when the British nation and Empire is in grip with the most unscrupulous enemy.
('79', 140, 2, 10, 294950) I, therefore, consider that his detention in jail for a long duration or until the present cloud is drifted away is very desirable and to that end in view I sentence him to two years R. I. He is recommended for B Class.
('79', 140, 2, 11, 295170) Then why has he been rewarded with rigorous imprisonment?
('79', 140, 2, 12, 295228) The duration of the term I understand.
('79', 140, 2, 13, 295267) He must be kept from the supposed mischief.
('79', 140, 2, 14, 295311) I wonder whether the fact of the imprisonment will not aggravate the mischief.
('79', 140, 2, 15, 295390) Of this, the Government must be the ju dge.
('79', 140, 2, 16, 295434) But the people will remember that love of one’s country and out spokenness are a crime in a country where the state is irresponsible to the people.
('79', 140, 2, 17, 295582) Dr. Lohia and other Congressmen’s imprisonments are so many hammer strokes that must weaken the chain that binds India.
('79', 140, 2, 18, 295702) The Government is inviting the Congress to start civil disobedience and deliver the last blow it would fain have reserved for a better day better for the British.
('79', 140, 2, 19, 295865) It is a pity.
('79', 140, 2, 20, 295879) SEVAGRAM, August 21, 1940 Harijan, 25 8 1940

('79', 141, 4, 11, 296696) 146. DRAFT RESOLUTION FOR CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE 3
('79', 141, 5, 12, 296751) WARDHA, August 21, 1940 The Working Committee have considered the Viceregal pro nouncement dated 8th inst., 4 on the Indian situation and the statement made by the Secretary of State in the House of Commons.
('79', 141, 5, 13, 296959) The W. C. are of opinion that both are highly unsatisfactory and provocative be cause they ignore patent facts.
('79', 141, 5, 14, 297071) They constitute one more among the many impositions on an unwilling India.
('79', 141, 5, 15, 297146) In spite of all repudiations the indisputable fact stands out that the Congress is the only national organization in the country that is non communal, non sectional and wholly democratic.
('79', 141, 5, 16, 297334) It is the one organization that has for fifty five years growingly represented the dumb millions of India, as has been repeatedly proved during its career.
('79', 141, 5, 17, 297490) The most convincing proof that can be understood by the world consists in the fact that barring four
('79', 141, 6, 18, 297591) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('79', 141, 6, 19, 297622) 2 Not reproduced here.
('79', 141, 6, 20, 297645) Kotak admitted in the notice that his action was hightly improper and wholly unauthorized.
('79', 141, 6, 21, 297736) 3 The Congress Working Committee met at Wardha from 18th to 22nd August.
('79', 141, 6, 22, 297809) The resolution was not accepted in too.
('79', 141, 6, 23, 297849) For the resolution as passed, vide “Resolution Passed at Congress Working Committee Meeting at Wardha”, 21 8 1940 4 Vide “Statement made by the viceroy on August 8, 1940”
('79', 142, 0, 1, 298020) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 143
('79', 142, 1, 2, 298066) out of the eleven provinces the Congress has a decisive majority given even by the limited electorate provided by the British Government in their Act imposed upon India.
('79', 142, 1, 3, 298236) If the electorate was not manipulated, as it has been under the said Act, and if representatives were elected under adult suffrage, it is admitted that the Congress would sweep the polls throughout India not excluding State India.
('79', 142, 1, 4, 298467) This claim has not been put forth by any other organization in India.
('79', 142, 1, 5, 298537) In the face of this the Secretary of State has misled the British public and world opinion by mentioning as ‘separate constituent factors the Muslim League, the Depressed Classes and the Princes.
('79', 142, 1, 6, 298733) The Muslim League is undou btedly a powerful organization demanding the greatest consideration.
('79', 142, 1, 7, 298829) It is the primary concern of the Congress to placate the Muslims of India.
('79', 142, 1, 8, 298904) What the British Government have done is to play the Muslims against the Hindus and vice versa in order to consolidate their power and to exploit the vast resources of India in their own interest.
('79', 142, 1, 9, 299101) It is they who finally cut the nation in twain by introducing the virus of separate electorates.
('79', 142, 1, 10, 299198) The Congress therefore repudiates the British claim specially to represent Muslim interests in so far as they may be in danger from the Hindu majority.
('79', 142, 1, 11, 299350) The Congress has claimed that the political and economic state of both is identical.
('79', 142, 1, 12, 299435) The Congress has undertaken to guarantee to the full the protection of the religious and the cultural rights of Muslims.
('79', 142, 1, 13, 299556) So far as the depressed classes are con cerned the indisputable fact is that the British Government is incapable of protecting them.
('79', 142, 1, 14, 299689) It is admitted that they have suffered and are suffering from wrongs which no other part of the nation has suffered.
('79', 142, 1, 15, 299806) But their disabilities are social and religious.
('79', 142, 1, 16, 299855) They are beyond the power of any foreign Government to redress.
('79', 142, 1, 17, 299919) All that the British Government have done is to sow seeds of dissension among the Hindus themselves of whom the depressed classes are an inseparable part.
('79', 142, 1, 18, 300074) There is no such thing as a class known as depressed.
('79', 142, 1, 19, 300128) No single organization specially devoted to their interest can represent the whole of them.
('79', 142, 1, 20, 300220) They have no class consciousness.
('79', 142, 1, 21, 300254) If the British Government could have helped it, they would have vivisected the Hindus by crea ting separate electorates for them as they have for Muslims and dest royed both the caste Hindus and the non caste Hindus which the dep ressed classes are.
('79', 142, 1, 22, 300504) The British Government know very well that the legal status of these classes was improved under Congress ministries as never before.
('79', 142, 1, 23, 300637) They know that removal of untouchability is a plank in the Congress programme.
('79', 142, 1, 24, 300716) They know that the Congress has worked ceaselessly for the social amelioration of their lot.
('79', 142, 1, 25, 300809) It is therefore false
('79', 143, 0, 1, 300831) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 143, 1, 2, 300873) and hypocritical for the British Government to pose as their protectors as against the Congress.
('79', 143, 1, 3, 300970) Equally false is their claim to protect the Princes against the Congress.
('79', 143, 1, 4, 301044) The British Government know that the Princes are their creation sustained to secure the British hold on the whole of India.
('79', 143, 1, 5, 301168) They cannot be played against the Indian claim for independence.
('79', 143, 1, 6, 301233) Rejection by the British Government of the Congress resolution 1
('79', 143, 2, 7, 301298) is proof of their determination to hold India by the sword against her will.
('79', 143, 2, 8, 301375) In order to compass this they have been gradually undermining the power of the Congress by picking out some of the best workers of the Congress under and Defence of India Act which has no popular sanction whatsoever.
('79', 143, 2, 9, 301592) It was to this Government that the Congress resolution was addr essed in the hope that the congress goodwill and the hand of friend ship will be recognized, appreciated and reciprocated.
('79', 143, 2, 10, 301779) Instead it has been rejected on grounds which have been shown to be false and hyp ocritical.
('79', 143, 2, 11, 301872) It is well known that the offer was made against Gandhji’s ad vice.
('79', 143, 2, 12, 301940) He had warned the members of the W. C. that the Congress was abdicating its moral position by promising to associate itself actively with the War as against declaration of independence and immediate composition of a national executive responsible to the elected legis lature.
('79', 143, 2, 13, 302216) It would be no answer to this proposition that under the existing Act this could not be done.
('79', 143, 2, 14, 302310) The desired change could have been made in one hour as a peremptory war measure.
('79', 143, 2, 15, 302391) But the British Government did not and do not wish to part with their possession of India.
('79', 143, 2, 16, 302482) Events that have happened compel the W. C. To recognize the soundness of Gandhiji’s advice from the purely political platform if not from his ethical standpoint.
('79', 143, 2, 17, 302644) The Congress which has inculcated non violence for the past 20 years for ousting the British Power could not be turned into a war machine without losing its fibre and without doing violence to the dumb masses which have hitherto responded to the Congress call.
('79', 143, 2, 18, 302905) The W. C. therefore consider the British Govern ment’s rejection of the Congress resolution as a God sent escape from a false and untenable position.
('79', 143, 2, 19, 303055) The W. C. therefore wish it to be known that the effect of the resolution must be regarded as exhausted.
('79', 143, 3, 20, 303160) 1 Promising co operation in the war effort if Britain acknowledged the ind ependence of India and formed a national government at the Center.
('79', 143, 3, 21, 303302) The resolution was passed at the A. I. C. C. session held at aPoona on 27th and 28th July.
('79', 144, 0, 1, 303393) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 145
('79', 144, 1, 2, 303439) It has not further currency.
('79', 144, 1, 3, 303468) The W. C. must revert to Gandhiji’s position and so far as the congress is concerned it must strive to build up a non violent society and believe with Gandhiji in the possibility of building up a State able to defend its liberty against the whole world by its own sheer goodwill towards the whole of mankind working under a democratic system which will eschew all violence and which by its simple code will afford no temptation to an invader.
('79', 144, 1, 4, 303911) It follows from this that the Congress must now vindicate its position and seek to protect itself against a slow death by the means that the British Government have chosen to adopt for the purpose.
('79', 144, 1, 5, 304109) The W. C. cannot but put on record its deep sorrow that the desire of the Congress not to embarrass the British Government has been despised by them and they have thus driven the Congress to defend itself against political extinction.
('79', 144, 1, 6, 304344) It therefore invites and appoints Gandhiji to devise such measures as he may think necessary for the protection of the congress and national honour and calls upon all Congress organizations and Congressmen to carry out such instru ctions as he may issue himself and through the W. C. or otherwise.
('79', 144, 1, 7, 304642) The W. C. wish it to be known that they have no quarrel with the Muslim League or the Muslims or any other organization or per sons.
('79', 144, 1, 8, 304775) Nor have they anything but goodwill towards the Princes.
('79', 144, 1, 9, 304832) Their non violence, if it is worth the name, precludes any ill will towards any part of the nation of which the Congress is proud to be known as servant.
('79', 144, 1, 10, 304986) Nor has the Congress anything but goodwill towards the Bri tish people.

('79', 144, 1, 12, 305280) In seeking that good, Congress has chosen the most harmless and the most powerful method of unadult erated non violence.
('79', 144, 1, 13, 305401) The W. C. seek the co operation in their task of all the forces of good throughout the world.

('79', 151, 6, 19, 317724) 156. NON VIOLENCE OF THE BRAVE 1
('79', 151, 7, 20, 317757) A correspondent writes:
('79', 151, 8, 21, 317781) You say non violence is for the brave, not for cowards.
('79', 151, 8, 22, 317837) But, in my opinion, in India the brave are conspicuous by their absence.
('79', 151, 8, 23, 317910) Even if we claim to be brave, how is the world to believe us when it knows that India has no arms and is therefore incapable of defending herself?
('79', 151, 8, 24, 318057) What then should we do to cultivate non violence of the brave?
('79', 151, 8, 25, 318120) The correspondent is wrong in thinking that in India the brave are conspicuous by their absence.
('79', 151, 8, 26, 318217) It is a matter for shame that because foreigners once labelled us as cowards we should accept the label.
('79', 151, 8, 27, 318322) Man often becomes what he believes himself to be.
('79', 151, 8, 28, 318372) If I keep on say ing to myself that I cannot do a certain thing, it is possible that I may end by really becoming incapable of doing it.
('79', 151, 8, 29, 318509) On the contrary, if I have the belief that I can do it, I shall surely acquire the capacity to do it even if I may not have it at the beginning.
('79', 151, 8, 30, 318654) Again it is wrong to say that the world today believes us to be cowards.
('79', 151, 8, 31, 318727) It has ceased to
('79', 151, 9, 32, 318744) 1 The Gujarati original of this was published in Harijanbandhu, 31 8 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 152, 0, 1, 318872) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 153
('79', 152, 1, 2, 318918) think so since the satyagraha campaign.
('79', 152, 1, 3, 318958) The Congress prestige has risen very high in the West during the past twenty years.
('79', 152, 1, 4, 319042) The world is watching with astonished interest the fact that although we have no arms we are hoping to win swaraj, and have indeed come very near it.
('79', 152, 1, 5, 319192) Moreover, it sees in our non violent movement rays of hope for peace in the world and its salvation from the hell of carnage.
('79', 152, 1, 6, 319318) The bulk of mankind has come to believe that, if ever the spirit of revenge is to vanish and bloody wars are to cease, the happy event can happen only through the policy of non violence adopted by the Congress.
('79', 152, 1, 7, 319529) The correspondent’s fear and suspicion are, therefore, unfounded.
('79', 152, 1, 8, 319595) It will now be seen that the fact that India is unarmed is no obs tacle in the path of ahimsa.
('79', 152, 1, 9, 319690) The forcible disarmament of India by the British Government was indeed a grave wrong and a cruel injustice.
('79', 152, 1, 10, 319798) But we can turn even injustice to our advantage if God be with us, or if you prefer, we have the skill to do so.
('79', 152, 1, 11, 319911) And such a thing has happened in India.
('79', 152, 1, 12, 319951) Arms are surely unnecessary for a training in ahimsa.
('79', 152, 1, 13, 320005) In fact the arms, if any, have to be thrown away, as the Khan Saheb did in the Frontier Province.
('79', 152, 1, 14, 320103) Those who hold that it is essential to learn violence before we can learn non violence, would hold that only sinners can be saints.
('79', 152, 1, 15, 320235) Just as one must learn the art to killing in the training for viol ence, so one must learn the art of dying in the training for non viol ence.
('79', 152, 1, 16, 320378) Violence does not mean emancipation from fear, but discover ing the means of combating the cause of fear.
('79', 152, 1, 17, 320484) Non violence, on the other hand, has no cause for fear.
('79', 152, 1, 18, 320540) The votary of non violence has to cultivate the capacity for sacrifice of the highest type in order to be free from fear.
('79', 152, 1, 19, 320662) He recks not if he should lose his land, his wealth, his life.
('79', 152, 1, 20, 320725) He who has not overcome all fear cannot practise ahimsa to per fection.
('79', 152, 1, 21, 320797) The votary of ahimsa has only one fear, that is of God.
('79', 152, 1, 22, 320853) He who seeks refuse in God ought to have a glimpse of the atman that transcends the body; and the moment one has a glimpse of the imp erishable atman one sheds the love of the perishable body.
('79', 152, 1, 23, 321046) Training in non violence is thus diametrically opposed to training in violence.
('79', 152, 1, 24, 321126) Violence is needed for the protection of things external, non violence is needed for the protection of the atman, for the protection of one’s honour.
('79', 152, 1, 25, 321276) The non violence cannot be learnt by staying at home.
('79', 152, 1, 26, 321330) It needs enterprise.
('79', 152, 1, 27, 321351) In order to test ourselves we should learn to dare danger
('79', 153, 0, 1, 321409) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 153, 1, 2, 321451) and death, mortify the flesh and acquire the capacity to endure all manner of hardships.
('79', 153, 1, 3, 321540) He who trembles or takes to his heels the moment he sees two people fighting is not non violent, but a coward.
('79', 153, 1, 4, 321651) A non violent person will lay down his life in preventing such quar rels.
('79', 153, 1, 5, 321725) The bravery of the non violent is vastly superior to that of the violent.
('79', 153, 1, 6, 321799) The badge of the violent is his weapon spear, or sword, or rifle.
('79', 153, 1, 7, 321865) God is the shield of the non violent.
('79', 153, 1, 8, 321903) This is not a course of training for one intending to learn non violence.
('79', 153, 1, 9, 321977) But it is easy to evolve one from the principles I have laid down.
('79', 153, 1, 10, 322044) It will be evident from the foregoing that there is no compa rison between the two types of bravery.
('79', 153, 1, 11, 322145) The one is limited, the other is limitless.
('79', 153, 1, 12, 322189) There is no such thing as out daring or out fighting non violence.
('79', 153, 1, 13, 322256) Non violence is invincible.
('79', 153, 1, 14, 322284) There need be no doubt that this non violence can be achieved.
('79', 153, 1, 15, 322347) The history of the past twenty years should be enough to reassure us.

('79', 154, 4, 9, 324245) HOW TO CONVERT ATHEISTS
('79', 154, 5, 10, 324269) Q. How can one convert atheists to belief in God and religion?
('79', 154, 6, 11, 324332) A. There is only one way.
('79', 154, 6, 12, 324358) The true servant of God can convert the atheist by means of his own purity and good conduct.
('79', 154, 6, 13, 324451) It can never be done by argument.
('79', 154, 6, 14, 324485) Innumerable books have been written to prove the existence of God, and if argument could have prevailed, there would not be a single atheist in the world today.
('79', 154, 6, 15, 324646) But the opposite is the case.
('79', 154, 6, 16, 324676) In spite of all the literature on the subject, atheism is on the increase.
('79', 154, 6, 17, 324751) Often, however, the man who calls himself an atheist is not one in reality; and the converse also is equally true.
('79', 154, 6, 18, 324866) Atheists some times say, “ If you are believers, then we are unbelievers.” And they have a right to say so, far self styled believers are often not so in reality.
('79', 154, 6, 19, 325029) Many worship God because it is the fashion to do so or in order to deceive the world.
('79', 154, 6, 20, 325115) How can such persons have any influence on atheists?
('79', 154, 6, 21, 325168) Therefore let the believer realize and have the faith that, if he is true to God, his neighbours will instinctively not be atheists.
('79', 154, 6, 22, 325301) Do not let him be troubled about the whole world.
('79', 154, 6, 23, 325351) Let us remember that atheists exist by the sufferance of God.
('79', 154, 6, 24, 325413) How truly has it been said that those who worship God in name only are not believers but those who do His will!
('79', 154, 7, 25, 325525) LIVING WAGE
('79', 154, 8, 26, 325537) Q. You once wrote in Harijan to the effect that villagers are at liberty to buy yarn spun in their own villages without reference to the living wage, and that the A. I. S. A. should let them go their way in this matter.

('79', 155, 2, 4, 326332) A. If we were always careful enough not to read into a writer’s sentences a meaning which defeats his very purpose, such questions would rarely arise.

('79', 155, 2, 6, 326569) It is of course assumed that the A. I. S. A. rule is not broken on a false plea of self sufficiency.

('79', 155, 3, 20, 327736) WILL IT FAIL ?

('79', 156, 1, 2, 328433) 158. ANDREWS MEMORIAL
('79', 156, 2, 3, 328455) A friend, who is himself trying to collect for the Andrews Memorial, has written a letter from which I take the following relevant paragraphs:
('79', 156, 3, 4, 328598) As I read it there are four objects of the appeal 1 (you will kindly correct me, if I am wrong):
('79', 156, 4, 5, 328695) (i) Ensuring the permanence of the present established work by an endowment to enable Santiniketan to fulfil Andrew’s high hopes for it, unhampered by the constant financial anxiety with which it is now burdened.
('79', 156, 5, 6, 328908) This is obviously the first need, for it would be doubtful wisdom to add new developments to an institution which itself is insecure.
('79', 156, 5, 7, 329042) At the same time the amount required for this purpose is nowhere specified.
('79', 156, 6, 8, 329118) If there is a sufficiently generous response to the appeal, providing more than is required for this first need, then it will be possible to go on to the other three parts of the scheme, viz.,
('79', 156, 7, 9, 329311) (ii) a small but properly equipped hospital;
('79', 156, 8, 10, 329356) (iii) the provision of ‘Deenabandhu wells’ in the district;
('79', 156, 9, 11, 329416) (iv) the provision of the Hall of Christian culture.
('79', 156, 9, 12, 329469) Now, if I am right in this, it must surely occur to the reader of the appeal that, if, as seems likely, the institution requires a considerable sum for its endowment fund, the chances that any contributions made now will actually be available for either of the second, third or fourth part of the scheme are somewhat remote.
('79', 156, 9, 13, 329794) It is not stated whether contributors are allowed to earmark their gifts for any of the special objects in the scheme; and obviously, if a large proportion of contributors did so, the primary object of the appeal— the placing of Santiniketan on a sound basis financially—may be defeated.
('79', 156, 10, 14, 330082) My second difficulty was about the statement of the aims, and I had in view particularly those of the proposed hall of Christian culture, in which I am naturally interested.
('79', 156, 11, 15, 330256) That is first described as providing for India’s thought contact with the Western world, on the analogy of the ‘Cheena Bhavan’ and China.
('79', 156, 11, 16, 330394) This suggests a doubtful identification of ‘Christian culture’ and ‘Western culture’.
('79', 156, 12, 17, 330480) That statement then goes on to speak of (a) the application of the teaching and character of Christ to international problems, and (b) the task of interpreting in Eastern modes of thought the spirit and mind of Christ.
('79', 156, 13, 18, 330699) 1 For the text of the appeal, vide “Deenabandhu Memorial”
('79', 157, 0, 1, 330757) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 157, 1, 2, 330799) What we have, therefore, seem to be three rather different aims, all very important and relevant.
('79', 157, 1, 3, 330897) Perhaps it may be necessary to leave it in this rather wide from; and yet I cannot help thinking that a more careful wording might make clear the relation of the other two aspects of the aim to that which is described as the ‘central purpose’.
('79', 157, 2, 4, 331141) Thirdly, I raised the question of trustees and a sound basis for confi dence in the future running of the scheme.

('79', 157, 4, 20, 333126) The Poet is a host in himself.

('79', 160, 7, 14, 338147) 161. NOTES
('79', 160, 8, 15, 338158) SIND The position of Congressmen in Sind is by no means enviable.
('79', 160, 8, 16, 338224) They have a most difficult time before them.
('79', 160, 8, 17, 338269) Their non violence, if they have it in them, has not benefited those who live in fear of their lives.
('79', 160, 8, 18, 338371) It is true that no one else has helped them.
('79', 160, 8, 19, 338416) I warned them at the very outset that they must learn the art of helping themselves as others do, or by non violence as Congressmen are supposed or expected to do.
('79', 160, 8, 20, 338580) In some places they are organizing national guards.
('79', 160, 8, 21, 338632) Those who do, look up to Congressmen for help and guidance.
('79', 160, 8, 22, 338692) For the latter have been their helpers and guides hitherto.
('79', 160, 8, 23, 338752) Some Congressmen feel that without any intention themselves of taking up arms they can put courage into the people, if they train them in the art of self defence
('79', 160, 9, 24, 338914) 1 Not traceable 2 Sarojini Naidu 3 On September 13, the Congress Working Committee was to meet at Bombay.
('79', 160, 9, 25, 339020) 4 Eldest daughter fo the addressee
('79', 161, 0, 1, 339055) 162 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 161, 1, 2, 339097) whether with or without arms.
('79', 161, 1, 3, 339127) The question has attained importance and demands immediate answer in view of the unequivocal resolution of the A. I. C. C. recently held at Poona.
('79', 161, 1, 4, 339274) I am quite clear that no Congressman, so long as he is even a four anna member of the Congress, can take part in organizing or aiding self defence groups without committing a breach of the Poona resolution.
('79', 161, 1, 5, 339481) But I am equally clear that it is the duty of those Congressmen who feel the need for helping self defence groups and have the capacity for doing so, to go to the rescue of the terror stricken men.
('79', 161, 1, 6, 339679) This they can do by resigning their membership of the Congress.
('79', 161, 1, 7, 339743) By doing so they will enhance the prestige of the Congress and their own usefulness.
('79', 161, 1, 8, 339828) The fact that they feel the call to help is the decisive factor in determining their course of action.
('79', 161, 2, 9, 339931) PEACEFUL METHODS ?
('79', 161, 2, 10, 339950) A correspondent sends a leaflet published by the Madras Provincial War Committee and printed at the Government Press, which enume rates the seven “great ideals” for which “War is being waged” today by England.
('79', 161, 2, 11, 340160) The second of the ideals runs thus:
('79', 161, 3, 12, 340196) The ideals for which England is fighting are the ideals of India.
('79', 161, 3, 13, 340262) Our philosophy of life, our traditions of domestic and international policy have had:

('79', 175, 3, 8, 366922) 176. HOW TO QUENCH IT?
('79', 175, 4, 9, 366945) Elsewhere in these columns the reader will see “A Seeker’s” letter in which he has asked a question which must have occurred to everyone.
('79', 175, 4, 10, 367083) The beauty lies in the way in which he has introduced the question.
('79', 175, 4, 11, 367151) He has depicted the present conflagration in such lurid colours that violence cannot but stink in our nostrils.
('79', 175, 4, 12, 367263) The reader is sure instinctively to exclaim: “Even if it were possible to win the king dom of the world by means of such violence, I would not have it.” But this exclamation will be of no avail to quench the confla gration.
('79', 175, 4, 13, 367487) No doubt it will some day quench itself, but it means mutual fratricidal slaughter like that of the Yadavas of old who destroyed themselves and relieved the earth of so much burden.
('79', 175, 4, 14, 367669) And such a consummation would any day be preferable to a perpetual confla gration.
('79', 175, 4, 15, 367752) But no one would wish for this.
('79', 175, 4, 16, 367784) What one would devoutly wish for is some brave step to stop the conflagration before there is total destruction.
('79', 175, 4, 17, 367897) This can only be a non violent step.
('79', 175, 4, 18, 367934) How and when it can be taken has to be discovered.
('79', 175, 4, 19, 367985) The “Seeker” will be satisfied when the discovery is made.
('79', 175, 4, 20, 368044) In my opinion the discovery has already been made.
('79', 175, 4, 21, 368095) If India can win swaraj non violently even while this conflagration is going on, the latter is bound to be extinguished by that one event.

('79', 178, 4, 25, 375031) Now I come to what you write about Sushila.
('79', 178, 4, 26, 375075) Your defence has no basis.
('79', 178, 4, 27, 375102) Why do you not understand that the reason that Sushila has for staying with me is that she is a doctor.
('79', 178, 4, 28, 375206) But her medical knowledge could be my undoing, because, if I acknowledged it I would pass from God’s hands into Sushila’s.
('79', 178, 4, 29, 375329) As for her affection, what shall I say?
('79', 178, 4, 30, 375369) She would probably work on my conditions for 359 days, but if on one day her own conditions are not met, she would not serve me, she would not work for me.
('79', 178, 4, 31, 375525) What does she care how much I have to involve myself with the patients while she is away?
('79', 178, 4, 32, 375615) But what is the use of bemoaning my lot before my own sons and daughters?
('79', 178, 4, 33, 375689) I shall endure what comes.
('79', 178, 4, 34, 375716) I see that she even resents my guiding her.
('79', 178, 4, 35, 375760) I wish you would yourself guide her.
('79', 178, 4, 36, 375797) She has infinite faith m you.
('79', 178, 4, 37, 375827) Her good
('79', 179, 0, 1, 375836) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
