('79', 179, 4, 8, 376209) 179. BISWA MISCARRIAGE AGAIN
('79', 179, 5, 9, 376238) Moulvi Saheb Fazlul Haq, the Premier of the largest Province in all India has done me the honour of addressing an open letter holding the National Congress, of which he was at one time an ardent followers and admirer, to public ridicule.
('79', 179, 5, 10, 376476) In his opinion the Congress has done everything to wound Muslim feeling.
('79', 179, 5, 11, 376549) Says the Moulvi Saheb:
('79', 179, 6, 12, 376572) On several occasions I have published instances of the manner in which the Congress chariot wheels of democracy have ridden roughshod over the feelings and sentiments of countless Muslims and other minorities, and in many cases with our connivance, approbation and consent.
('79', 179, 6, 13, 376846) I must plead not guilty so far as the indictment concerns me.
('79', 179, 6, 14, 376908) I have claimed to have inquired into every case of alleged injustice brought to my notice.
('79', 179, 6, 15, 376999) I have never hesitated to condemn Congress acts when facts have demanded condemnation.
('79', 179, 6, 16, 377086) Let us, however, examine the latest illustration quoted by the Bengal Premier in support of his charge.
('79', 179, 6, 17, 377190) He deals at length with the notorious Biswa miscarriage of justice.
('79', 179, 6, 18, 377258) I am invited to give my opin ion on it.
('79', 179, 6, 19, 377298) The Moulvi Saheb evidently had not my opinion before him when he penned the open letter.
('79', 179, 6, 20, 377387) I refer him to Harijan dated 11th ultimo (p.
('79', 179, 6, 21, 377432) 244) wherein he will find my opinion.
('79', 179, 6, 22, 377470) I adhere to every word of that opinion.
('79', 179, 6, 23, 377510) If the cases of injustice quoted by him are on a par with the Biswa case, his indictment singularly fails.
('79', 179, 6, 24, 377617) The Congress Ministry had as much to do with the miscarriage of justice as the Moulvi Saheb.
('79', 179, 6, 25, 377710) No judge has suggested that the police were under the influence of the Congress Ministry and that the latter used it to procure the miscar riage.
('79', 179, 6, 26, 377856) The fact is that the ministers were in no way responsible for the conduct of the police or the prosecution.
('79', 179, 6, 27, 377964) Miscarriages, like the one under examinations, have occurred before now in India.
('79', 179, 6, 28, 378046) But in every
('79', 180, 0, 1, 378059) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 181
('79', 180, 1, 2, 378105) case the police were held blameworthy, not the Government, except when a clear case of Government complicity was made out.
('79', 180, 1, 3, 378228) The Mou lvi Saheb has produced no evidence whatsoever in support of his state ment that the ministers had in any way interfered with the conduct of the prosecution.
('79', 180, 1, 4, 378393) He has produced certain remarks of the court on Pandit Shukla’s speech in the C. P. Assembly.
('79', 180, 1, 5, 378487) It amounts to no more than a reflection on the political unwisdom of making a speech which would seem to prejudge the case.
('79', 180, 1, 6, 378611) The court’s stricture in no way connects Pandit Shukla with the police or the prosecution.
('79', 180, 1, 7, 378702) Moreover it is an obiter dictum which has no judicial value.
('79', 180, 1, 8, 378763) I doubt if the court was wise in making the stricture without having called upon Pandit Shukla to explain his speech.
('79', 180, 1, 9, 378881) This explanation, however, Pandit Shukla has given in his letter to the President of the Congress.
('79', 180, 1, 10, 378980) The Moulvi Saheb has omitted to notice the outstanding fact that the appellate court has found as a matter of fact that Jagdervao was killed and that many person were seriously injured.
('79', 180, 1, 11, 379166) Their regret is that the guilty ones got off scot free.
('79', 180, 1, 12, 379222) Surely the ministers cannot be blamed for this untoward result by the Muslims.
('79', 180, 1, 13, 379301) If a complaint can be legitimately made by anybody, it is the Hindus who can make it.
('79', 180, 1, 14, 379387) So far as I am aware there were no Hindus tried, and there were no seri ous injuries sustained by the Muslims.
('79', 180, 1, 15, 379498) The Sessions Judge may have erred in weighing evidence.
('79', 180, 1, 16, 379554) But the fact that he condemned six Mus lims to the gallows is a matter that demands serious thinking by all right minded men.
('79', 180, 1, 17, 379680) For if the ones condemned were not guilty, some other Muslims were.
('79', 180, 1, 18, 379748) I miss in the Moulvi Saheb’s open letter any regret for the murder of a Hindu leader and for serious injury to other Hindus, and the fact that the culprits who were responsible for the murder and injuries had gone unpunished.
('79', 180, 1, 19, 379974) Pandit Shukla was a fellow Premier in a neighbouring Province.
('79', 180, 1, 20, 380037) I suggest to the Bengal Premier that cour tesy required him to ask for Pandit Shukla’s explanation before cond emning him.
('79', 180, 1, 21, 380160) SEVAGRAM, September 3, 1940 Harijan, 8 9 1940

('79', 188, 1, 2, 390858) 192. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('79', 188, 2, 3, 390882) Unrevised SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, C. P., September 7, 1940
('79', 188, 3, 4, 390935) MIRA, I have your long letter.
('79', 188, 3, 5, 390966) It enables me to follow the struggle that is going on within you.
('79', 188, 3, 6, 391032) You have not yet acquired the art of looking within for everything.
('79', 188, 3, 7, 391100) Carding should soothe just as much as spinning once you connect the process with God.
('79', 188, 3, 8, 391186) Farhad saw his God through breaking a mountain.
('79', 188, 3, 9, 391234) He is represented as one incessantly delivering heavy blows with God given strength.
('79', 188, 3, 10, 391319) He broke the mountain and found his God who is represented as a fair bride.
('79', 188, 3, 11, 391395) It will be an indul gence if you spin with slivers supplied from Sabarmati or elsewhere.
('79', 188, 3, 12, 391484) But your arms may be too weak to card heavily.
('79', 188, 3, 13, 391531) The body may be too weak to respond to the routine involved in all the processes involved in attaining speed and quantity.
('79', 188, 3, 14, 391654) But, for you neither of these two things is essential.
('79', 188, 3, 15, 391709) What is essential is the spirit of dedications to God.
('79', 188, 3, 16, 391764) Whatever your outward activity it must be all for God.
('79', 188, 3, 17, 391819) In order to avoid self deception we have devised spinning including all the anterior processes.
('79', 188, 3, 18, 391915) If this much is clear to you, you should have a small quantity of unginned cotton.
('79', 188, 3, 19, 391998) This you will gin with the hand roller.
('79', 188, 3, 20, 392038) You know the process.
('79', 188, 3, 21, 392060) You can devise these there.
('79', 188, 3, 22, 392088) Instead of an iron rod you can have a wooden roller.
('79', 188, 3, 23, 392141) You will gin enough for your purpose.
('79', 188, 3, 24, 392179) To card this cotton would be child’s play.

('79', 190, 1, 2, 393931) 196. TO THE READERS
('79', 190, 2, 3, 393951) The first issue of Harijan Sevak published from Poona has many printer’s errors.
('79', 190, 2, 4, 394032) Readers will excuse me for that.
('79', 190, 2, 5, 394065) There are very few people knowing Hindustani in Poona.
('79', 190, 2, 6, 394120) For that matter, those kno wing Gujarati are also few in number.
('79', 190, 2, 7, 394185) Readers know under what con ditions Harijan was started.
('79', 190, 2, 8, 394242) It did not prove so difficult to bring out Harijanbandhu from Poona because I had with me workers who knew Gujarati while those who know Hindustani are scattered everywhere.
('79', 190, 2, 9, 394416) I hope the printing of Harijan Sevak will improve soon and the mist akes will gradually become fewer.
('79', 190, 2, 10, 394518) If those who take interest in the lan guage of Harijan Sevak send me their criticism I shall be grateful.
('79', 190, 2, 11, 394624) Although Viyogiji had wired his willingness to continue as editor he writes to say that he would be happy if he was relieved.
('79', 190, 2, 12, 394750) He believes that it is morally wrong to continue as editor without any responsibility.
('79', 190, 2, 13, 394837) He also says that he will hardly get any time to write.
('79', 190, 2, 14, 394893) I understand his viewpoint and I appreciate it.
('79', 190, 2, 15, 394941) I have therefore relieved him.
('79', 190, 2, 16, 394972) Pyarelal consented to my proposal and has agreed to become the editor.
('79', 190, 2, 17, 395043) Knowing his temperament, I wanted to keep him free.
('79', 190, 2, 18, 395095) But he is the only person among my associates who is fit to be editor.
('79', 190, 2, 19, 395166) He is well versed in Urdu and he has also a knowledge of Hindi.
('79', 190, 2, 20, 395230) He can there fore carry the responsibility of editing a Hindustani paper.
('79', 190, 2, 21, 395304) He was at once time editor of young India.
('79', 190, 2, 22, 395347) Notwithstanding all this I would need the generosity of the readers and their help by way of comment and criticism.
('79', 190, 2, 23, 395463) The main thing is the realization of the purpose.
('79', 190, 2, 24, 395513) The purpose of publishing Harijan Sevak is to lay before the Hindustani knowing people all aspects of satyagraha.
('79', 190, 2, 25, 395627) Satyagraha does not mean only civil disobedience.
('79', 190, 2, 26, 395677) Of much greater importance are the various construc tive activities.
('79', 190, 2, 27, 395746) Without these civil disobedience is nothing.
('79', 190, 2, 28, 395791) Harijan Sevak will strive to explain to the people what this thirteen point pro gramme is, how it can be conducted and what progress is has made.
('79', 190, 2, 29, 395937) The work was the same even before, but it was not done under my direct supervision.
('79', 190, 2, 30, 396021) Now I will look after it to the extent I can.
('79', 190, 2, 31, 396067) We shall never forget the aim of Harijan Sevak, which is the service of the Harijan.
('79', 190, 2, 32, 396152) For so long as the incubus of untouchability remains our efforts to win swaraj will be like looking for flowers in the sky.
('79', 190, 2, 33, 396276) Now the readers will understand why I have given a secondary place to the language.
('79', 190, 2, 34, 396360) The language is not an end in itself.
('79', 190, 2, 35, 396398) It is neither jugglery of words nor bombast.
('79', 190, 2, 36, 396443) It is certainly an important means of
('79', 191, 0, 1, 396481) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 191, 1, 2, 396523) expressing thought.
('79', 191, 1, 3, 396543) However poor the language of the writer may be, if his ideas have any force, if he has something worth saying or some information useful to the reader, it is sure to find its way to his heart.
('79', 191, 2, 4, 396736) THE THIRTEEN POINT PROGRAMME The above programme is as follows: 1. Hindi Muslim or communal unity 2. Removal of untouchability 3. Prohibition 4. Charkha and khadi 5. Other village industries 6. Village sanitation 7. Nayee Taleem or Basic Education 8. Adult education 9. Uplift of women 10. Education in health and hygiene 11. Propagation of the national language (Hindustani) 12. Cultivating love for mother tongue 13. Working for economic equality.
('79', 191, 2, 5, 397186) SEVAGRAM, September 8, 1940 Harijan Sevak, 14 9 1940

('79', 193, 2, 3, 399034) September 8, 1940
('79', 193, 3, 4, 399052) SUSHILA, Pyarelal gave me your letter only yesterday.
('79', 193, 3, 5, 399106) You did we to write it.
('79', 193, 3, 6, 399130) What you say is all in your hands today.
('79', 193, 3, 7, 399171) Only one thing which is behind it all is absolutely wrong.
('79', 193, 3, 8, 399230) Even though unconsciously, you believe that strength is your right.
('79', 193, 3, 9, 399298) Doing one’s duty is not a right, it is an obligation.
('79', 193, 3, 10, 399352) You must be content to do whatever it is given to you to do.
('79', 193, 3, 11, 399413) If I were on my death bed, would you say that you would take up my case only if I accepted your conditions and not otherwise?
('79', 193, 3, 12, 399539) If that be not so and if, as you have said, I should not be without a doctor even for a moment, because one can never say what may happen to me at what time, however much I may refuse you should never leave my side.
('79', 193, 3, 13, 399755) But this is only an argument.
('79', 193, 3, 14, 399785) I put forward this argument because you have advanced an argument.
('79', 193, 3, 15, 399852) But what really counts is God.
('79', 193, 3, 16, 399883) We must let ourselves be guided by Him.
('79', 193, 3, 17, 399923) In my eyes, you are always with me.
('79', 193, 3, 18, 399959) I never left you and I do not want to leave you.
('79', 193, 3, 19, 400008) Your absense irks me, but I would not bargain even for your presence at the cost of duty.
('79', 193, 3, 20, 400098) You have committed a grave blunder by writing about the fast to your superior.
('79', 193, 3, 21, 400177) Such naivete in you is a new thing for me.
('79', 193, 3, 22, 400220) I informed you about it to convince you that I have concealed nothing from you.
('79', 193, 3, 23, 400300) But you should not have mentioned it even to Mother or Mohan.
('79', 193, 3, 24, 400362) It should have remained buried in your heart.
('79', 193, 3, 25, 400408) I have not written about it even to Devdas.
('79', 193, 3, 26, 400452) I hope this does not lead to any trouble.
('79', 193, 3, 27, 400494) You do not have to do anything.
('79', 193, 3, 28, 400526) You do not even have to feel sorry.
('79', 193, 3, 29, 400562) There is no doubt that it has been a grave mistake.
('79', 193, 3, 30, 400614) But now there is nothing to be done about it.
('79', 193, 3, 31, 400660) You must face the consequences.
('79', 193, 3, 32, 400692) This is no rebuke, only a warning to you.

('79', 194, 1, 2, 400917) 199. ADVICE TO PRABHAKAR 1
('79', 194, 2, 3, 400944) [Before September 9, 1940] 2
('79', 194, 3, 4, 400973) I am prepared to go one better than you.
('79', 194, 3, 5, 401014) Mother cow is in many ways better than the mother who gave us birth.
('79', 194, 3, 6, 401083) Our mother gives us milk for a couple of years and then expects us to serve for when we grow up.
('79', 194, 3, 7, 401180) Mother cow expects from us nothing but grass and grain.
('79', 194, 3, 8, 401236) Our mother often falls ill and expects service from us.
('79', 194, 3, 9, 401292) Mother cow rarely falls ill.
('79', 194, 3, 10, 401321) Hers is an unbroken record of service which does not end with her death.
('79', 194, 3, 11, 401394) Our mother when she dies means expenses of burial or cremation.
('79', 194, 3, 12, 401458) Mother cow is as useful dead as when she is alive.
('79', 194, 3, 13, 401509) We can make use of every part of her bodyher flesh, her bones, her intestines, her horns and her skin.
('79', 194, 3, 14, 401613) Well, I say this not to disparage the mother who gives us birth but in order to show you the substantial reasons for my worshipping the cow.
('79', 194, 3, 15, 401754) Although I am such a cow wor shipper, I ask you to take milk.
('79', 194, 3, 16, 401816) I don’t take cow’s milk as I took a vow about it.
('79', 194, 3, 17, 401866) But yours is not a vow.
('79', 194, 3, 18, 401890) You see what I am doing to expand the dairy here.
('79', 194, 3, 19, 401940) If you feel so much for the cow, you can dedi cate yourself to her service.

('79', 194, 4, 21, 402035) 200. QUESTION BOX 3
('79', 194, 5, 22, 402055) INDIANS STATES AND CONGRESS ACTIVITY
('79', 194, 6, 23, 402092) Q. Should Congress members be enrolled in Indian States?
('79', 194, 7, 24, 402149) A. This question has been frequently put and answered by me.
('79', 194, 7, 25, 402210) I have always held that it would be inadvisable to enrol Congress members in the States.
('79', 194, 7, 26, 402299) There is danger fo friction and clash with auth ority, and the latter interfering with this work of organization.
('79', 194, 7, 27, 402413) Indian States subjects who may be anxious to become Congress members can enrol themselves on the register of the nearest Congress office of their Province in British India.
('79', 194, 7, 28, 402586) But it would be better for them not to bother about membership and to confine themselves to such activity
('79', 194, 8, 29, 402692) 1 Extracted from Mahadev Desai's “Sevagram Notes”, 9 9 1940. Prabha kar, a Harijan worker from Andhra, had given up cow's milk in expiation for the sin he had committed against here in eating carrion.
('79', 194, 9, 30, 402893) 2 ibid 3 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 14 9 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 195, 0, 1, 403020) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 195, 1, 2, 403062) as is possible within their own States.
('79', 195, 1, 3, 403102) This can be largely only cons tructive work.
('79', 195, 1, 4, 403147) It will arouse self consciousness and solidarity among the masses.
('79', 195, 1, 5, 403214) In fact it may on the whole be better to make people Congress minded in the true sense of the term than to enrol them as Congress members.
('79', 195, 2, 6, 403353) A. I. S. A. WORKERS
('79', 195, 3, 7, 403373) Q. Supposing members are enrolled in the State for the Congress, should not workers of the Charkha Sangh or the Praja Mandals participate or co operate in Congress political work?
('79', 195, 4, 8, 403553) A. Neither of these organizations may go outside its allotted field.
('79', 195, 4, 9, 403622) The Charkha Sangh workers are already precluded from doing so by the existing rules.
('79', 195, 4, 10, 403707) Although it is a creation of the Congress, it has no connection with Congress politics.
('79', 195, 4, 11, 403795) It is purely an economic and philanthropic organization and cannot be made to subserve a dual purpose.
('79', 195, 4, 12, 403898) The Praja Mandals should be ruled by their peculiar position.
('79', 195, 4, 13, 403960) They are functioning under heavy odds.
('79', 195, 4, 14, 403999) [ It would not be fair or proper ] 1 to burden them with Congress work.
('79', 195, 4, 15, 404071) It follows from this they cannot be asked to lend co operation to the Congress orga nization, unless it be in the sense of [silent homage expressed in the constructive work.] 2 All these organizations can help one another by each rendering true service within its well defined ambit.
('79', 195, 4, 16, 404355) Thus if the Congress is successful in the political field, the Charkha Sangh and the Praja Mandals would profit thereby.
('79', 195, 4, 17, 404476) Similarly the success of the Charkha Sangh equally serves the Congress.
('79', 195, 4, 18, 404548) Any single Praja Mandal that achieves success in its mission strengthens the Congress to that extent.
('79', 195, 4, 19, 404650) By straying from our allotted fields we are likely to do more harm than good.
('79', 195, 5, 20, 404728) SEVAGRAM, September 9, 1940 Harijan, 15 9 1940

('79', 196, 2, 23, 407081) 202. NOTES 1
('79', 196, 3, 24, 407094) CONGRESS AHIMSA I am being inundated with letters 2 complaining that by giving my definition of ahimsa before the Poona Congressmen, who saw me
('79', 196, 4, 25, 407238) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 14 9 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 196, 4, 26, 407361) 2 The Gujarati adds: “Some sent by registered post”.
('79', 197, 0, 1, 407414) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 197, 1, 2, 407456) recently at Wardha, 1 I have seriously circumscribed the scope of ahi msa.
('79', 197, 1, 3, 407531) These friends forget that my remarks were confined to Congress ahimsa only.
('79', 197, 1, 4, 407607) Personally I would not kill insects, scorpions or even snakes.
('79', 197, 1, 5, 407670) Nor would I under any circumstance take meat.
('79', 197, 1, 6, 407716) But I may not impose the creed of such ahimsa on the Congress.
('79', 197, 1, 7, 407779) The Congress is not a religious institution, it is a political organization.
('79', 197, 1, 8, 407856) Its non violence is limited to human beings.
('79', 197, 1, 9, 407901) If it were to be further extended, only Hindus, and among even them only Vaishnavas and Jains, would be left to participate in it.
('79', 197, 1, 10, 408032) Millions of Hindus who eat fish and meat would be excluded.
('79', 197, 1, 11, 408092) My proposition, to my mind, is so simple and straight that I never thought that anybody could object to it.
('79', 197, 1, 12, 408200) My critics should further understand that many Mussalmans have not accepted even the limited ahimsa of the Congress as their creed, and that the Congress, itself has by its Wardha and Poona reso lutions, so cramped its scope as to render it almost meaningless.
('79', 197, 1, 13, 408461) It follows, therefore, that any attempt to widen its scope to include the sub human species will defeat its purpose.
('79', 197, 1, 14, 408578) Unlimited ahimsa will take time to be universalized.
('79', 197, 1, 15, 408631) 2 we will have ample cause to congratulate ourselves if we learn to substitute the law of love in society for that of the jungle, and if instead of harbouring ill will and enmity in our bosoms against those whom we regard as our enemies we learn to love them as actual and potential friends.
('79', 197, 1, 16, 408923) It should be remembered too that mere jivadaya (kindness to animals) does not enable us to overcome the‘six deadly enemies’ within us, namely, lust, anger, greed, infatua tion, pride and falsehood.
('79', 197, 1, 17, 409121) 3 Give me the man who has completely conquered self and is full of goodwill and love towards all, and is ruled by the law of love in all his actions, and I for one will offer him my respectful homage even though he be a meat eater.
('79', 197, 1, 18, 409353) On the other hand the jivadaya of a person who is steeped in anger and lust but daily feeds the ants and insects and refrains from killing has hardly anything in it to recommend itself.
('79', 197, 1, 19, 409539) It is a mechanical performance without any spiritual value.
('79', 197, 1, 20, 409599) It may even be worse—a hypocritical screen for hiding the corruption within.
('79', 197, 2, 21, 409676) 1 Vide “Discussion with B. G. Kher and Others”, 15 8 1940
('79', 197, 3, 22, 409734) 2 The Gujarati adds here: “It certainly has its uses for the devotees.” 3 The Gujarati has here: “Only non violent behaviour towards other human beings will help us to overcome these six enemies.”
('79', 198, 0, 1, 409931) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 199
('79', 198, 1, 2, 409977) NON VIOLENCE DURING RIOTS A friends writes:
('79', 198, 2, 3, 410021) How can non violence be efficacious during riots?
('79', 198, 2, 4, 410071) By self immolation we can influence only those with whom we have already established living contacts.
('79', 198, 2, 5, 410173) But the hooligans who perpetrate violence during riots are, as a rule, hirelings imported from outside.
('79', 198, 2, 6, 410277) How can they have any scruples about hurting those whom they have never known before and for whom they can have no regard or consideration?
('79', 198, 2, 7, 410417) The question deserves careful consideration.
('79', 198, 2, 8, 410462) The friend who has put it is a valiant worker who nearly lost his life in trying to do his duty during a riot.
('79', 198, 2, 9, 410573) I have often written on this question before.
('79', 198, 2, 10, 410619) The pity of it is that Congressmen have never seriously thought over the question of finding a non violent way of quelling riots.
('79', 198, 2, 11, 410749) Their non violence was restricted to the sole purpose of offering civil resistance to the autho rities.
('79', 198, 2, 12, 410853) In my opinion the non violence that goes so far and no further scarcely deserves the name ‘ahimsa’.
('79', 198, 2, 13, 410953) You may, if you like, call it unarmed resistance.
('79', 198, 2, 14, 411003) So far as it is a device for embarrassing the Government it is a species of himsa.
('79', 198, 2, 15, 411086) To quell riots non violently, there must be true ahimsa in one’s heart, an ahimsa that takes even the erring hooligan in its warm embrace.
('79', 198, 2, 16, 411225) Such an attitude has to be culti vated.
('79', 198, 2, 17, 411265) It can only come as a prolonged and patient effort which must be made during peaceful times.
('79', 198, 2, 18, 411358) The would be members of a peace brigade should come into close touch and cultivate acquaintance with the so called goonda element in his vicinity.
('79', 198, 2, 19, 411505) He should know all and be known to all and win the hearts of all by his living and selfless service.
('79', 198, 2, 20, 411606) No section should be regarded as too contemptible or mean to mix with.
('79', 198, 2, 21, 411677) Goondas do not drop from the sky, nor do they spring from the earth like evil spirits.
('79', 198, 2, 22, 411764) They are the product of social disorganiza tion, and society is therefore responsible for their existence.
('79', 198, 2, 23, 411871) In other words, they should be looked upon as a symptom of corruption in our body politic.
('79', 198, 2, 24, 411962) To remove the disease we must first discover the under lying cause.
('79', 198, 2, 25, 412030) To find the remedy will then be a comparatively easy task.
('79', 198, 2, 26, 412089) So far we have not even attempted a proper beginning.
('79', 198, 2, 27, 412143) But it is never too late to mend.
('79', 198, 2, 28, 412177) It is enough that we are at last alive to the nec essity of it.
('79', 198, 2, 29, 412241) We have now to follow it up with prompt action.
('79', 198, 2, 30, 412289) Let every one who is interested make a prompt beginning in his own neigh bourhood.
('79', 198, 2, 31, 412372) The difficulty mentioned by my correspondent will auto matically resolve itself if we proceed with our effort in the right spirit.

('79', 199, 1, 2, 412545) HOW TO UNIVERSALIZE KHADI A correspondent 1 writes:
('79', 199, 2, 3, 412597) 1. The spinning propaganda is going on in every part of India; but I wish the A. I. S. A. would simultaneously open khadi production centres where people could send or take their yarn, without much expense, for weaying, and where they could sell their yarn if they wished.
('79', 199, 3, 4, 412870) 2. The A. I. S. A. should allow every spinner to have his or her yarn woven locally and also to sell it locally.
('79', 199, 4, 5, 412983) 3. Khadi bhandars in big towns and cities mean heavy overhead charges due to house rent, electric lighting , management, and other office expenses, and that makes khadi too dear.
('79', 199, 4, 6, 413162) It ought to be possible for people to purchase cheap khadi in villages or taluka centres.
('79', 199, 4, 7, 413252) All the three suggestions are good.
('79', 199, 4, 8, 413288) But the great difficulty in carrying them out is that we have not enough workers.
('79', 199, 4, 9, 413370) There is no doubt that all the yarn should be woven where it is spun, and that the khadi should be disposed of there and then.
('79', 199, 4, 10, 413497) Therein lies the beauty of khadi.
('79', 199, 4, 11, 413531) The economics of khadi are to a great extent contrary to those of mill cloth.
('79', 199, 4, 12, 413609) Cloth manufactured in Manchester is meant for use not in Manchester or England or Europe, but to be exported to Asia or Africa for the use of the people there.
('79', 199, 4, 13, 413769) On the contrary khadi is meant to be made for the millions by the millions living in villages.
('79', 199, 4, 14, 413864) Mills use cotton imported from all parts of the world.
('79', 199, 4, 15, 413919) Cotton for khadi should be produced where it is turned into khadi.
('79', 199, 4, 16, 413986) We have not yet attained the ideal of the science of khadi, and to that extent the foundation of khadi must be regarded as weak.
('79', 199, 4, 17, 414115) There was no science of khadi when we began to use khadi.
('79', 199, 4, 18, 414173) It has evolved with the progress of khadi, and even now it is far from being perfect.
('79', 199, 4, 19, 414259) But ever watchful khadi servants are constantly thinking about it and going on perfecting it in the light of experience.
('79', 199, 4, 20, 414380) I am afraid it will be some time before we can reach the ideal pictured by the correspondent.
('79', 199, 4, 21, 414474) The A. I. S. A. is not slack in its effort, but it is faced with difficulties at every step.
('79', 199, 4, 22, 414567) The main thing needed for the universalization of khadi is the co operation of the people.
('79', 199, 4, 23, 414658) Machine manufacture can be planned in an office and can be carried out according to plan.
('79', 199, 4, 24, 414748) Where people have to be converted to an idea it does take time.
('79', 199, 4, 25, 414812) We have therefore, for the time being, to put with khadi bhandars in towns and cities.
('79', 199, 4, 26, 414899) Most of these are self supporting.
('79', 199, 4, 27, 414934) But for them there would not be the demand for khadi
('79', 199, 5, 28, 414987) 1 The Gujarati version has “from Dabhoi”.
('79', 200, 0, 1, 415029) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 201
('79', 200, 1, 2, 415075) that there is today.
('79', 200, 1, 3, 415096) While, therefore, we should make every attempt to teach the ideal, we cannot jump to it at one bound.

('79', 200, 3, 5, 415245) 203. QUESTION BOX 2
('79', 200, 4, 6, 415265) STUDENT AND SATYAGRAHA
('79', 200, 5, 7, 415288) Q. Why do you object to students participating in the satyagraha campaign, if it is launched?
('79', 200, 5, 8, 415382) And why must they leave school or college for good, in case they are permitted?
('79', 200, 5, 9, 415462) Surely students in England are not silently looking on when their country is engaged in a war.
('79', 200, 6, 10, 415557) A. To withdraw students from schools and colleges is to encourage them in a programme of non co operation.
('79', 200, 6, 11, 415664) It is not on our programme today.
('79', 200, 6, 12, 415698) If I were in charge of the satyagraha campaign, I should neither invite nor encourage the stud ents to leave their schools and colleges.
('79', 200, 6, 13, 415835) We have seen by experience that the students have not yet got over their passion for Government schools and colleges.
('79', 200, 6, 14, 415953) That these institutions have lost their glamour is a gain, but I do not set much store by it.
('79', 200, 6, 15, 416047) And if the institutions are to continue, withdrawal of students for satyagraha will do them no good and will be of little help to the cause.
('79', 200, 6, 16, 416188) Such withdrawal will not be non violent.
('79', 200, 6, 17, 416229) I have said that those who intend to join the campaign should leave their schools or colleges for good and resolve to devote them selves to the nation’s service even after the struggle is over.
('79', 200, 6, 18, 416423) There is no comparison between the students here and those in England.
('79', 200, 6, 19, 416494) There the whole nation is involved in the war.
('79', 200, 6, 20, 416541) The institutions have been closed down by the managers.
('79', 200, 6, 21, 416597) Here, on the contrary, students leaving their schools and colleges would do so in spite of the heads of those institutions.
('79', 200, 7, 22, 416721) ARE NOT ALL FASTS VIOLENT?
('79', 200, 8, 23, 416748) Q. Are not all fasts violent?
('79', 200, 8, 24, 416778) Do I not coerce a friend when I try to prevent him, by means of my fast, from doing a wrong act?
('79', 200, 9, 25, 416875) 1 The Gujarati version has: “and as long as we do not reach the ideal we should not underestimate the existing arrangement.” 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 14 9 1940. This English translation is reproduced from Harijan.
('79', 201, 0, 1, 417123) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 201, 1, 2, 417165) A. Fasts undertaken according to the rules governing them are truly non violent.
('79', 201, 1, 3, 417246) There is no room there for coercion.
('79', 201, 1, 4, 417283) If a friend of mine is going astray, and if I impose suffering on myself by fasting in order to awaken his better instincts, it can be only out of love.
('79', 201, 1, 5, 417436) If the friend for whom I fast has no love in him, he will not respond.
('79', 201, 1, 6, 417507) If he has it and responds, it is all to the good.
('79', 201, 1, 7, 417557) This is how I would analyse his act: He valued his love for me more than his bad ways.
('79', 201, 1, 8, 417644) There is a possible risk, I admit, namely that as soon as the effect of the fast is over he would be tempted to go back to his old ways.
('79', 201, 1, 9, 417781) But then I can fast again.
('79', 201, 1, 10, 417808) Ultimately the increasing influence of my love will either convert the friend to the extent of weaning him completely from his evil ways, or repeated fasts may lose their novelty, blunt his mind, and make it impervious to my fasting.
('79', 201, 1, 11, 418042) It is my conviction that a fast undertaken out of genuine love cannot have such an untoward result.
('79', 201, 1, 12, 418142) But because such a result is not impossible we cannot afford to dis regard this pure instrument of moral reform.
('79', 201, 1, 13, 418255) The risk, however, makes it clear that he who fasts should to properly qualified, and that it should not be lightly undertaken.
('79', 201, 2, 14, 418383) PENANCE
('79', 201, 3, 15, 418391) Q. Is not the realization of one error and the resolve never to repeat it a penance in itself?
('79', 201, 3, 16, 418486) Is any further penance necessary?
('79', 201, 3, 17, 418520) A. Realization of an error, which amounts to a fixed resolve never to repeat it, is enough penance.
('79', 201, 3, 18, 418620) One casts away one’s evil habits as a snake casts off its skin, and thus purifies oneself.
('79', 201, 3, 19, 418711) Such self purifi cation is itself complete penance.
('79', 201, 3, 20, 418763) But he who gets into the habit of committing errors cannot easily shed it.
('79', 201, 3, 21, 418838) For all such penance in its accepted sense, if undertaken with discrimination, is likely to be a great help.

('79', 203, 2, 9, 421230) The peasantry, whose only property and means of sustenance are the bulls and the milch cattle, find themselves without both on account of depredations by thieves, as thefts of cattle have risen to abnormal propor tions.

('79', 203, 5, 24, 422911) Even the Sukkur district, which witnessed the recent abominable atrocities, is far distant from Hyderabad.

('79', 205, 1, 2, 425370) 208. ALL INDIA CONGRESS COMMITTEE RESOLUTION
('79', 205, 2, 3, 425415) [September 15, 1940] 1
('79', 205, 3, 4, 425438) The All India Congress Committee has given its careful attention to the events that have taken place since its last meeting held in Poona on July 27, 1940, and to the resolutions passed by the Working Committee at Wardha in August last.
('79', 205, 3, 5, 425675) 2 The Committee approves of and endorses these resolutions.
('79', 205, 3, 6, 425735) In order to end the deadlock in India and to promote the national cause, in co operation with the British people, the Working Committee, even at the sacrifice of Mahatma Gandhi’s co operation, made a proposal to the British Government in their Delhi resolution of July 7, which was subsequently approved by the A. I. C. C. 3 at Poona.
('79', 205, 3, 7, 426070) This proposal was rejected by the British Government in a manner which left no doubt that they had no intention to recognize India’s independence, and would, if they could, continue to hold this country indefinitely in bondage for British exploitation.
('79', 205, 3, 8, 426323) This decision of the British Government shows that they will impose their will upon India, and their recent policy has further shown that they will not even tolerate free expression of public opinion in condemnation of their
('79', 205, 4, 9, 426548) 1 The resolution, drafted by Gandhiji (vide”Speech at A.I.C.C. Meeting, Bombay) and moved by Jawaharlal Nehru on this date, was passed on September 16. 2 On August 21, the Congress Working Committee passed a resolution (vide “Resolution Passed at Congress Working Committee Meeting at Wardha”, 21 8 1940) on the Viceroy’s declaration (vide “Statement made by the Viceroy on August 8, 1940”) of August 8, suggesting expansion of Governor’s Executive Council and establishment of a War Advisory Council.
('79', 205, 4, 10, 427050) The Viceroy also stated that soon after the war they would set up “a body of representatives of principal elements in India’s national life” to frame the new Constitution.
('79', 205, 4, 11, 427222) He added that “they could not contemplate the transfer of their present responsibilities for the peace and welfare of India to any system of government whose authority is directly denied by large and powerful elements in India’s national life.” The Working Committee resolved that the Viceroy’s offer not only did not fulfil the Congress demand but also blocked the way of achieving freedom.
('79', 205, 4, 12, 427614) 3 The A.I.C.C., which met at Poona from July 25 to 28, ratified the Working Committee resolution demanding independence and a national ministry at the Centre and explained, “how, while the Congress must continue to adhere strictly to the principle of non violence in the struggle for independence, it was unable, in the present circumstances, to declare that the principle should be extended to India’s national defence”.
('79', 205, 4, 13, 428036) For the text of the Delhi resolution and Gandhiji’s comments on it, vide “The Delhi Resolution”
('79', 206, 0, 1, 428132) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 207
('79', 206, 1, 2, 428178) associating India in the war against Germany, against the will of a vast body of the people of India, and of exploiting her national resources and manpower for this purpose.
('79', 206, 1, 3, 428352) The All India Congress Committee cannot submit to a policy which is a denial of India’s natural right to freedom, which suppresses the free expression of public opinion and which could lead to the degradation of her people and their continued enslavement.
('79', 206, 1, 4, 428608) By following this policy the British Government have created an intolerable situation, and are imposing upon the Congress a struggle for the preservation of the honour and the elementary rights of the people.
('79', 206, 1, 5, 428817) The Congress is pledged under Gandhiji’s leadership to non violence for the vindication of India’s freedom.
('79', 206, 1, 6, 428925) At this grave crisis in the movement for national freedom, the All India Congress Committee, therefore, requests him to guide the Congress in the action that should be taken.
('79', 206, 1, 7, 429100) The Delhi resolution, confirmed by the A.I.C.C. at Poona, which prevented him from so doing, no longer applies.
('79', 206, 1, 8, 429212) It has lapsed.
('79', 206, 1, 9, 429227) The A.I.C.C. sympathizes with the British people as well as the peoples of all other countries involved in the war.
('79', 206, 1, 10, 429343) Congressmen cannot withhold their admiration for the bravery and endurance shown by the British nation in the face of danger and peril.
('79', 206, 1, 11, 429479) They can have no ill will against them, and the spirit of satyagraha forbids the Congress from doing anything with a view to embarrass them.
('79', 206, 1, 12, 429620) But this self imposed restraint cannot be taken to the extent of self extinction.
('79', 206, 1, 13, 429702) The Congress must insist on the fullest freedom to pursue its policy based on non violence.
('79', 206, 1, 14, 429794) The Congress has, however, no desire at the present moment to extend non violent resistance, should this become necessary, beyond what is required for the preservation of the liberties of the people.
('79', 206, 1, 15, 429994) In view of certain misapprehensions that have arisen in regard to the Congress policy of non violence, the A.I.C.C. desires to state this afresh and to make it clear that this policy continues, notwithstanding anything contained in previous resolutions which may have led to these misapprehensions.
('79', 206, 1, 16, 430293) This Committee firmly believes in the policy and practice of non violence not only in the struggle for swaraj but also in so far as this may be possible of application in free India.
('79', 206, 1, 17, 430476) The Committee is convinced, and recent world events have demonstrated, that complete world disarmament is necessary, and the establishment
('79', 207, 0, 1, 430615) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 207, 1, 2, 430657) of a new and juster political and economic order, if the world is not to destroy itself and revert to barbarism.
('79', 207, 1, 3, 430770) A free India will, therefore, throw all her weight in favour of world disarmament and should herself be prepared to give a lead in this to the world.
('79', 207, 1, 4, 430920) Such lead will inevitably depend on external factors and internal conditions, but the State would do its utmost to give effect to this policy of disarmament.
('79', 207, 1, 5, 431078) Effective disarmament and the establishment of world peace by the ending of national wars, depend ultimately on the removal of the causes of wars and national conflicts.
('79', 207, 1, 6, 431248) These causes must be rooted out by the ending of the domination of one country over another and the exploitation of one people or group by another.
('79', 207, 1, 7, 431396) To that end India will peacefully labour, and it is with this objective in view that the people of India desire to attain the status of a free and independent nation.
('79', 207, 1, 8, 431563) Such freedom will be the prelude to the close association with other countries within a comity of free nations for the peace and progress of the world.

('79', 207, 3, 10, 431734) 209. LETTER TO AMRIT KAUR
('79', 207, 4, 11, 431760) BOMBAY, September 15, 1940
('79', 207, 5, 12, 431787) MY DEAR AMRIT, I am writing this in the A.I.C.C. meeting.
('79', 207, 5, 13, 431845) My heart is there, though the body is here.

('79', 209, 3, 4, 434260) I told Maulana Saheb 1 that the resolution 2 before you was of such a nature that he would have to let me speak on it right away, so that before anyone else spoke on it I could explain in my own words how I interpreted it, why at death’s door as I was I had taken upon myself this responsibility and what I expected of you.
('79', 209, 3, 5, 434584) A general discussion could come afterwards.
('79', 209, 3, 6, 434628) Maulana Saheb and the other members of the Working Committee acceded to my request.
('79', 209, 3, 7, 434712) I have had to bear many heavy responsibilities in my life but I feel that the responsibility I am today called upon to bear is the heaviest.
('79', 209, 3, 8, 434853) I have assumed this responsibility with due deliberation.
('79', 209, 3, 9, 434911) But I must confess that I am besieged by a doubt, I cannot say why, as to how far I shall be able to carry you with me.
('79', 209, 3, 10, 435031) As to what the upshot will be is quite beyond my telling.
('79', 209, 3, 11, 435089) Still it is good.
('79', 209, 3, 12, 435107) It is a lesson I have learnt during fifty years and more that a man should not worry about the end but should address himself only to the means.
('79', 209, 3, 13, 435252) Herein lies the key to success.
('79', 209, 3, 14, 435284) Truly we can think only of the means, which is the only thing in our hands.
('79', 209, 3, 15, 435360) Nothing can interpose itself between us and our means.
('79', 209, 3, 16, 435415) But who knows about the result?
('79', 209, 3, 17, 435447) Who can tell whether I shall be able to go where I intend to go.
('79', 209, 3, 18, 435512) So many obstructions in the way can frustrate me.
('79', 209, 3, 19, 435562) There are hidden enemies inside myself, too.
('79', 209, 3, 20, 435607) I shudder even when I think of all this.
('79', 209, 3, 21, 435648) But it is enough for me that I know where I want to go and by which way.
('79', 209, 3, 22, 435721) So I set out in the faith that if the path I have chosen is right, straight and true, my quest will lead me to the end I desire and no other.
('79', 209, 3, 23, 435863) Behind this belief of mine is not only faith but also the accumulated experience of fifty years.
('79', 209, 3, 24, 435960) Therefore, in assuming this responsibility, I am neither hampered by my hesitation nor subdued by my fear.
('79', 209, 3, 25, 436067) Before getting into a boat there is scope for a thousand hesitations, fears and reflection.
('79', 209, 3, 26, 436159) There is none after one is in the boat and the boat is in the stream.
('79', 209, 3, 27, 436229) Why then this fear in me ?
('79', 209, 3, 28, 436256) Why this hesitation ?
('79', 209, 3, 29, 436278) I have not the least bit of doubt as to the rightness of the way.
('79', 209, 3, 30, 436344) What I am not so sure about is whether I shall be able to carry you with me, heart and soul.

('79', 210, 1, 20, 437930) In the meanwhile came the Delhi resolution.
('79', 210, 1, 21, 437974) The Congress made a simple and straightforward proposal to the Government.
('79', 210, 1, 22, 438049) The Government refused to countenance it.
('79', 210, 1, 23, 438091) I must confess that this rather pleased me.
('79', 210, 1, 24, 438135) For I trembled at the very thought that the Congress which had been swearing by ahimsa for the last twenty years, the Congress which had given the call of ahimsa from thousands of platforms to the millions in the country, could take it upon itself to make the people give up ahimsa and cultivate war mindedness.
('79', 210, 1, 25, 438447) Has not the Congress, ever since the days of Khilafat and the Ali Brothers, repeated in season and out of season, with the beat of drums, that we seek to solve all questions—whether of the Khilafat or swaraj, whether national or international—only through non violence and that if we have to resort to civil disobedience it will be purely non violent?
('79', 210, 1, 26, 438799) And notwithstanding the fact that our opponent is a Government that spends ten crores of rupees a day on arms and ammunition, we chose the path of peace and Muslims as well as Hindus all resorted only to non violent action.
('79', 210, 1, 27, 439023) You must remember that in the special session of the Congress at Calcutta the main resolution 1 was moved by me and it mentioned only the Khilafat and the Punjab murders and brutalities.

('79', 214, 1, 2, 447446) circumstances I feel we have to tell them, ‘No, we cannot go along with you.

('79', 214, 1, 8, 447998) He will say, ‘Why fight against an opponent in trouble?’ We cannot start the battle of swaraj now on the assumption that they will give us nothing after they have won the war.
('79', 214, 1, 9, 448174) It is not the way of satyagrahis to take advantage of the opponent’s weak position to wrest political power from him.

('79', 214, 1, 12, 448488) For, whatever we may do in pursuance of the resolution is bound to create difficulties for them.
('79', 214, 1, 13, 448585) The answer is that the position today is such that if we do nothing, our very existence will be imperilled.

('79', 231, 4, 10, 490388) 214. INTERVIEW TO STIMSON 1
('79', 231, 5, 11, 490416) [September 17, 1940] 2
('79', 231, 6, 12, 490439) STIMSON: How do you desire not to embarrass Britain with your demand to preach anti war propaganda in a non violent way?
('79', 231, 7, 13, 490560) GANDHIJI: Because non violence is the Congress creed which involved Congress hostility to all war.
('79', 231, 7, 14, 490659) Hence it is a vital necessity for the Congress to dissociate itself from identifying itself with any war.
('79', 231, 7, 15, 490765) Hence my desire not to embarrass Britain was necessarily limited and conditioned by the counter necessity of preserving the Congress existence, and therefore civil disobedience is definitely restricted to freedom of speech and action, provided they are absolutely non violent.
('79', 231, 7, 16, 491042) Therefore I have claimed in my speech that, if the full import of Congress action is understood, it must in the end help Britain and the world.
('79', 231, 8, 17, 491186) Because in the midst of the conflagration all round there is one powerful body pinning its faith to uttermost non violence.
('79', 231, 8, 18, 491310) If it succeeds, then the groaning world can heave a sigh of relief and find a way out of these monstrous armaments.
('79', 231, 9, 19, 491426) How do you visualize the future of India in the event of a Nazi victory?
('79', 231, 9, 20, 491499) All I can say is I am not dismayed by the prospect, if my country remains true to the cult of non violence.
('79', 231, 9, 21, 491607) But that does not mean that I should be in any way pleased with the prospect of a Nazi victory.

('79', 232, 3, 7, 492840) Does your policy mean disapproval of America’s help to Britain in the shape of planes and munitions?

('79', 233, 1, 2, 494377) Hitlerism and all such ‘isms’ will go as a matter of course.
('79', 233, 2, 3, 494438) Don’t you think India should do something to make facts better known in America and thus promote the interchange of goods and ideas?
('79', 233, 2, 4, 494571) What do you think should be done in this connection?
('79', 233, 2, 5, 494624) First let us take up goods.
('79', 233, 2, 6, 494652) America has had her bit, irrespective of Indian conditions and India’s wishes.
('79', 233, 2, 7, 494731) So far as ideas are concerned, my unhappy experience is that anti Indian propaganda carried on in America has held undisputed sway, so much so that even the visit of an outstanding personality like Tagore produced little impression on the American mind.
('79', 233, 3, 8, 494985) But why does not India endeavour to make herself better known in America ?
('79', 233, 3, 9, 495060) If America really wanted to know what Indian opinion is at a given time, there is ample literature which is growing from day to day to which they have access.
('79', 233, 3, 10, 495219) If you have in mind an Indian agency which should do propagandist work on behalf of India, again our bitter experience has been that imperialist propaganda that is carried on with much ability and perseverance and at a lavish expenditure is such that we can never overtake it, and the work of any such agency has up to now proved fruitless.
('79', 233, 4, 11, 495560) Why not have Indian people use Indian hand spun cloth and keep her mills busy for the export of manufactured cloth and yarn?
('79', 233, 4, 12, 495685) Don’t you think that this would help the cotton grower?
('79', 233, 4, 13, 495741) I would not mind such a thing but it must be in order to supply the felt needs of the country which received our cloth.
('79', 233, 4, 14, 495861) I have no idea of exploiting other countries for the benefit of India.
('79', 233, 4, 15, 495932) We are suffering from the poisonous disease of exploitation ourselves, and I would not like my country to be guilty of any such thing.
('79', 233, 4, 16, 496067) If Japan, say, as a free country wanted India’s help, and said we could produce certain goods cheaper, and we might export them to Japan, we would gladly do so.
('79', 233, 4, 17, 496228) But under my scheme of things all dumping of goods by one country on another, supported by her army and her navy, has to cease.
('79', 233, 5, 18, 496356) Apart from export of merchandise what has India to give America, and turn what does India expect from America?
('79', 233, 5, 19, 496467) I must correct your question for you.
('79', 233, 5, 20, 496505) India sends no merchandise to America; she sends only raw material, and that is a matter or serious consideration for every nationalist.
('79', 233, 5, 21, 496642) For we cannot suffer our country remaining an exporter of raw produce, for it means (as it has meant) extinction of handicrafts and art itself.
('79', 233, 5, 22, 496786) I would expect America to treat India not as though India was a country for American exploitation but as if India was a free country, although unarmed, and deserving, therefore, the same treatment that America
('79', 234, 0, 1, 496996) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 235
('79', 234, 1, 2, 497042) would wish at the hands of India.
('79', 234, 2, 3, 497076) You are repeating, Sir, the message of Jesus.
('79', 234, 2, 4, 497122) I agree.
('79', 234, 2, 5, 497131) We are poor in technical skill, but as soon as you accept and consent to follow Jesus’s teaching, I would not have to complain of all the skill being monopolized by America.
('79', 234, 2, 6, 497305) You will then say, ‘Here is a sister country poor in technical skill, let us offer our skilled assistance not for exploitation, not for a terrific price, but for its benefit, and so for nothing.’ And here let me say a word about your missionaries.

('79', 234, 3, 25, 499094) You might have supplied other countries the sugar and the wheat or fed America’s own unemployed.

('79', 234, 4, 27, 499230) I know.
('79', 234, 4, 28, 499238) But all do not think like me.
('79', 234, 4, 29, 499268) Pandit Nehru wants industrialization because he thinks that, if it is socialized, it would be free from the evils of capitalism.
('79', 234, 4, 30, 499397) My own view is that evils are inherent in industrialism, and no amount of socialization can eradicate them.
('79', 234, 5, 31, 499505) We have seen what Germany has done to Belgium and to the other countries.

('79', 236, 1, 2, 501373) 216. I WAS UNJUST BECAUSE WEAK
('79', 236, 2, 3, 501404) I know Rajaji enough to understand that he is too brave to need any support from anybody, he is too philosophic to harbour an injury for many hours, if not minutes.
('79', 236, 2, 4, 501569) I know also that his fine sense of humour enables him to enjoy a joke at his expense.
('79', 236, 2, 5, 501655) Therefore this confession must be taken as one for my own satisfaction only.
('79', 236, 2, 6, 501732) I have told 1 the public that, had, I not egged him on, Rajaji would never have brought forward his resolution at New Delhi.
('79', 236, 2, 7, 501857) Having great regard for his judgment and his honesty, when he asserted with amazing assurance that I was wrong and he was right in the implications and application of non violence, I allowed myself to doubt the correctness of my interpretation to the point of allowing and encouraging him to act on his.
('79', 236, 2, 8, 502161) I showed weakness and became unjust to him.
('79', 236, 2, 9, 502205) A weak man is just by accident.
('79', 236, 2, 10, 502237) A strong but non violent man is unjust by accident.
('79', 236, 2, 11, 502289) I was unjust to Rajaji because I exposed him to ridicule and unkind attacks.
('79', 236, 2, 12, 502366) Though no ultimate harm has come to the Congress because what I still consider was an error has been rectified, it is not a good thing for a great leader to have his work undone all of a sudden, for I know that Rajaji still feels that he was right.
('79', 236, 2, 13, 502615) If his view had prevailed, the resolution that now holds sway would not have taken the shape it has.
('79', 236, 2, 14, 502716) I would still have been out of the Congress.
('79', 236, 2, 15, 502761) For I was out of it at Wardha before the Delhi resolution was taken as the natural outcome of Wardha.
('79', 236, 2, 16, 502863) If I was unjust to Rajaji, I was also unjust to the Working Committee.
('79', 236, 2, 17, 502934) For, had I remained firm, the Wardha resolution too would not have been passed.
('79', 236, 2, 18, 503014) I hold that, so long as I am accepted as the sole authority on satyagraha and its implications, they must not be a matter of vote.
('79', 236, 2, 19, 503145) My colleagues may debate the pros and cons with me and try to convince me that their interpretation is right.
('79', 236, 2, 20, 503255) If I cannot accept it, my judgment should prevail because I am both the author of satyagraha and general in satyagraha action.
('79', 236, 2, 21, 503382) The only way the colleagues can avoid my judgment is by absolving me from guidance.
('79', 236, 2, 22, 503466) They did in so many words at Wardha.

('79', 236, 2, 24, 503568) They were most unwilling to give me absolution.
('79', 236, 2, 25, 503616) It was given because I wrung it from them.

('79', 239, 1, 2, 507828) 218. INTERVIEW TO “THE NEWS CHRONICLE” 1
('79', 239, 2, 3, 507869) BOMBAY, September 18, 1940
('79', 239, 3, 4, 507896) CORRESPONDENT: While expressing your sympathy with the British people in their plight, don’t you think there is an inconsistency between your earlier decisions and your latest decision?
('79', 239, 3, 5, 508082) GANDHIJI: I thought that I had clearly and sufficiently explained my position in my speech 2, in anticipation of the charge of inconsistency.
('79', 239, 3, 6, 508224) If there is any inconsistency, it is due in this particular instance to changed circumstances.
('79', 239, 3, 7, 508319) My sympathy is not only the same as it had been expressed 3 in Simla on the declaration of war; it has become deeper because what was imaginary has become vividly real.
('79', 239, 3, 8, 508488) In Simla almost a year ago I had expressed my grief over what might befall Britain.
('79', 239, 3, 9, 508572) Today the dreaded thing has happened and is still going on.
('79', 239, 3, 10, 508632) By nature I am so framed that every calamity moves me irrespective of the people whom it may overtake.
('79', 239, 3, 11, 508735) But my sympathy, even though it is deeper today than a year ago, has undoubtedly changed in form.
('79', 239, 3, 12, 508833) I was unprepared for the recent Government declarations, and I claim that it is the genuineness of my sympathy which has made me single out the one fact which Britain can easily recognize and yield without any hitch in her prosecution of war.
('79', 239, 3, 13, 509076) I readily grant that there might be some reason for not dividing the responsibility for the conduct of the war with those who are the determined opponents of British imperialism and all it implies, and therefore I felt that, if the Congress continued to abide by its policy of non embarrassment which is inherent in its non violence, the Congress should for the moment abate agitation by way of direct action for independence.
('79', 239, 3, 14, 509503) But freedom of speech and corresponding action is the breath of democratic life.
('79', 239, 3, 15, 509584) Freedom of propagating non violence as substitute for war is the most relevant when indecent savagery is being perpetrated by the warring nations of Europe.
('79', 239, 3, 16, 509741) The Congress will forfeit all its right to be considered a non violent organization if out of false sympathy or—what would be worse—fear of consequences, it
('79', 239, 4, 17, 509898) 1Extracted from “Seven Days in Bombay”.
('79', 239, 4, 18, 509938) Mahadev Desai explains: “The correspondent .
('79', 239, 4, 19, 509983) saw Gandhiji when he had already had a heavy day on top of a night of insufficient sleep, and when he had heavy engagements yet to fulfil.” 2 Vide “Speech At A.I.C.C. Meeting, Bombay”, 15 9 1940 3 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 5 9 1939.

('79', 240, 1, 2, 510267) ceased to agitate against the inhumanity that is being perpetrated in Europe and which, if not checked by somebody or some organization, may overtake the whole world.
('79', 240, 1, 3, 510434) I hope this statement of Congress policy as I interpret it, as its sole guide, will not only satisfy the British public opinion, but will make it range itself on the side of the Congress, so as to enable the Viceroy to recognize the justice of the Congress claim which is a claim not for itself but which is a claim for freedom of speech no matter by whom exercised so long as it does not promote violence in any shape or form.

('79', 240, 2, 5, 510881) 219. FRAGMENT OF LETTER TO ABDUL GHAFFAR KHAN 1
('79', 240, 3, 6, 510929) [After September 18, 1940] 2
('79', 240, 4, 7, 510958) I hope that all the conversation we had in Bombay has soaked into you.
('79', 240, 4, 8, 511029) If it has, every problem could be solved by reference to those fundamentals which I tried to put before you.
('79', 240, 4, 9, 511138) Our non violence has to begin at home with our children, elders, neighbours and friends.
('79', 240, 4, 10, 511227) We have to overlook the so called blemishes of our friends and neighbours and never forgive our own.
('79', 240, 4, 11, 511328) Then only shall we be able to right ourselves, and as we ascend higher, our non violence has to be practised among our political associates.
('79', 240, 4, 12, 511469) We have to see and approach the viewpoints of those who differ from us.
('79', 240, 4, 13, 511541) We have to be patient with them and convince them of their errors and be convinced of our own.
('79', 240, 4, 14, 511636) Then proceeding further we have to deal patiently and gently with political parties that have different policies and different principles.
('79', 240, 4, 15, 511775) We have to look at their criticism from their own standpoint, always remembering that the greater the distance between ourselves and others, the greater the scope for the play of our non violence; and it is only when we have passed our examination or test in these fields that we can deal with those against whom we are fighting and who have grievously wronged us.
('79', 240, 4, 16, 512140) This was one thing we talked about.
('79', 240, 4, 17, 512176) The other thing I said was that a non violent man has to keep himself engaged usefully during all waking hours and, therefore, constructive work is for him what arms are for the violent men.
('79', 240, 5, 18, 512367) Harijan, 18 1 1942

('79', 242, 3, 5, 514078) 222. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('79', 242, 4, 6, 514106) WARDHA, September 20, 1940
('79', 242, 5, 7, 514133) I see from Press comments that the main purpose of my contemplated visit to H.E. the Viceroy is being missed.
('79', 242, 5, 8, 514243) It is well that I should not be misunderstood as to the purpose of my visit.
('79', 242, 5, 9, 514320) Assuming that the interview is granted, I do not go to hold a pistol at the Viceroy’s head if the contemplated civil disobedience is to be taken as such.
('79', 242, 5, 10, 514474) But I go, as I explained 1 in my speech before the All India Congress Committee, in order to make sure I am right in the inferences I have drawn from the acts of the Government, commencing from the declaration of His Excellency the Viceroy.
('79', 242, 5, 11, 514715) If the premises on which the Congress case is built are wrong, there is no case for civil disobedience.
('79', 242, 5, 12, 514819) I would not be able to approach my task with confidence and firmness unless I made myself sure of my facts and the conclusions to be deduced therefrom.

('79', 248, 3, 6, 523447) 234. ANSWER TO A QUESTION 1
('79', 248, 4, 7, 523475) [Before September 23, 1940] 2
('79', 248, 5, 8, 523505) I agree.
('79', 248, 5, 9, 523514) The resolution is the result of several days’ full fledged debate among the members of the Working Committee.
('79', 248, 5, 10, 523624) I may confess that many of the members have no independent faith in non violence but they are trying to imbibe it.
('79', 248, 5, 11, 523739) But you must know that the Congress is not merely the Working Committee, nor the A.I.C.C., nor the members on the Congress registers, but the dumb millions.
('79', 248, 5, 12, 523896) They are all peace loving, and we have to represent them truly.
('79', 248, 5, 13, 523960) These millions, before the Congress identified itself with them in 1919, had taken no part in any violent or non violent or even a so called constitutional fight.
('79', 248, 5, 14, 524123) But they rose like one man on the 6th of April 1919 3. They took up peaceful rebellion as their mantra, and without any organization, without any country wide tour—for I had not then toured in the interior—they instinctively took up the call, and the Congress organization became a peaceful rebel organization.
('79', 248, 5, 15, 524434) The Bombay resolution had these masses in mind.
('79', 248, 5, 16, 524482) Harijan, 29 9 1940

('79', 248, 7, 19, 524565) ASHRAM YOUNGSTER: If the Congress demand is complete, it means that we do not need swaraj, and that we shall be content with the liberty of speech and the Press.

('79', 249, 0, 1, 525509) 250 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 249, 1, 2, 525551) GANDHIJI: Our objective is complete independence, as you know.
('79', 249, 1, 3, 525614) But do you know the means to attain it?
('79', 249, 2, 4, 525654) Carrying out the constructive programme.
('79', 249, 2, 5, 525695) That is one of the principal branches of the tree.
('79', 249, 2, 6, 525746) But what is the root?
('79', 249, 3, 7, 525768) Truth and non violence.
('79', 249, 3, 8, 525792) Well, then, we want the right to preach truth and non violence.
('79', 249, 4, 9, 525856) But will newspaper articles and speeches be enough for the propagation of truth and non violence?
('79', 249, 4, 10, 525954) No, we have to do much more.
('79', 249, 4, 11, 525983) But the right to preach truth and non violence is threatened.
('79', 249, 4, 12, 526045) The law seems to say that we may not tell people that they have every right not to co operate in the war effort and that it is their duty as a non violent people not to co operate thus.
('79', 249, 5, 13, 526231) But you have yourself said that we can get swaraj if we fulfil the constructive programme.
('79', 249, 5, 14, 526322) Why then this trivial issue?
('79', 249, 5, 15, 526351) It is not a trivial issue; it is a concrete and all important issue.
('79', 249, 5, 16, 526420) If we surrender it, a time will come when we may have to surrender all, when we may have to forget even the name of truth and non violence.
('79', 249, 5, 17, 526560) To preach these is our birthright, and to forfeit it is to forfeit our existence.
('79', 249, 6, 18, 526642) But what I am troubled about is the emphasis on mere speech and writing.
('79', 249, 6, 19, 526715) It is the liberty we claim.
('79', 249, 6, 20, 526743) How and when to use it and whether to use it or no is our concern.
('79', 249, 6, 21, 526810) If we cannot stand a strong breeze, we shut the windows and even the doors.
('79', 249, 6, 22, 526886) But how should we feel if someone were to shut us up?
('79', 249, 7, 23, 526940) But may it not be imaginary?
('79', 249, 7, 24, 526969) If you ask a little child not to eat earth, it will eat it.
('79', 249, 7, 25, 527029) It is the inhibition that is galling.
('79', 249, 7, 26, 527067) Do you want to remove the inhibitions?
('79', 249, 7, 27, 527106) The analogy is wrong, for the little child has no right to eat earth, whereas no one has a right to prevent us from enjoying free air.
('79', 249, 7, 28, 527241) But let me take another example for you as you are a child.
('79', 249, 7, 29, 527301) Prahlad was ordered by his father not to take the name of Rama.
('79', 249, 7, 30, 527365) He might have argued with himself, ‘I lose nothing by not repeating the name of Rama, for Rama is in my heart.’ But if he had resorted to this argument, he would have deceived himself.
('79', 249, 7, 31, 527550) He did not do so, and he defied his father to do his worst; he was not going to give up repeating Ramanama.
('79', 249, 7, 32, 527658) And because he braved the most fearful hardships and dared even death for that sacred right, we have today a living faith in Ramanama.
('79', 249, 7, 33, 527793) If he had yielded, that faith would have vanished from the earth.
('79', 249, 7, 34, 527859) Even so, if we give up our right to preach truth and
('79', 250, 0, 1, 527912) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 251
('79', 250, 1, 2, 527958) non violence, we give it up for ever.
('79', 250, 2, 3, 527996) But abstract truth and non violence no one prevents us from preaching.
('79', 250, 2, 4, 528067) No principle exists in the abstract.
('79', 250, 2, 5, 528104) Without its concrete application it has no meaning.
('79', 250, 2, 6, 528156) And when I want to preach non violence I want to preach it as an effective substitute for war, and thereby to be able to wean Britain and other warring countries from violence and barbarism.
('79', 250, 3, 7, 528347) But why do you claim that right for all?
('79', 250, 3, 8, 528388) In your speech 1 you said that you would speak as a conscientious objector, but that others might use any reasoning they liked, e.g., the financial or the imperialistic argument.
('79', 250, 4, 9, 528567) I have no business to claim the right only for myself and for those who are conscientious objectors.
('79', 250, 4, 10, 528668) For, some other grounds may be as important as, if not more than, conscientious grounds; and if I may not be smothered, how can I suffer those others to be smothered?
('79', 250, 4, 11, 528835) If, moreover, the freedom was restricted to conscientious objectors, we should compel a number of our people to be hypocrites, for they would take shelter under the conscientious argument.
('79', 250, 4, 12, 529024) All that is necessary is the acceptance by all of the condition of non violence.
('79', 250, 4, 13, 529105) That cannot be relaxed.
('79', 250, 4, 14, 529129) Harijan, 29 9 1940
('79', 250, 5, 15, 529148) 236. KHADI WEEK
('79', 250, 6, 16, 529164) It is a happy thing that the khadi week coincides with my pending visit to H. E. the Viceroy.
('79', 250, 6, 17, 529258) I want the prayers of all who believe in the efficacy of prayer that the result of my visit may prove fruitful to India, the British people, and ultimately conduce to peace between the warring nations.
('79', 250, 6, 18, 529460) I feel that though the issue raised by the A.I.C.C. resolution seems small, it has in it great potency for the good of mankind.
('79', 250, 6, 19, 529588) ‘Khadi Week’ is the name given by me to my birthday celebration.
('79', 250, 6, 20, 529653) Birth and death are twins.
('79', 250, 6, 21, 529680) I should be sorry if the annual celebration was forgotten with my death.
('79', 250, 6, 22, 529753) Therefore, I have popularized the birthday celebration as Khadi Week.
('79', 250, 6, 23, 529823) It enables me to deal with the event impersonally.
('79', 250, 6, 24, 529874) I shall strain every nerve to avoid a civil disobedience struggle.
('79', 250, 6, 25, 529941) But it would be wrong for Congressmen to go to sleep while an effort for peace is being made.
('79', 250, 6, 26, 530035) I hope no Congressman thinks that because I have undertaken command of the struggle, if it comes, the spinning

('79', 255, 4, 11, 539684) 241. SOME CRITICISM ANSWERED
('79', 255, 5, 12, 539713) The recent resolution of the A.I.C.C. and my speeches before the meeting have come in for much criticism, if they have earned some praise.
('79', 255, 5, 13, 539852) Of the criticism there are two items which I must attempt to answer.
('79', 255, 5, 14, 539921) For they are of permanent interest.
('79', 255, 5, 15, 539957) The Times of India of the 17th instant in its temperate criticism 1 takes me to task for my statement 2 that ‘the peoples of Europe do not know what they are fighting for’.
('79', 255, 5, 16, 540130) It was bound to be resented.
('79', 255, 5, 17, 540159) But truth, though seemingly harsh, has to be uttered when utterance becomes relevant, indeed imperative.
('79', 255, 5, 18, 540264) I believe that the utterance had become overdue.
('79', 255, 5, 19, 540313) I must say why I think that the warring nations do not know what they are fighting for.
('79', 255, 5, 20, 540401) I had used the expression ‘warring nations’, not ‘peoples of Europe’.
('79', 255, 5, 21, 540471) This is not a distinction without a difference.
('79', 255, 5, 22, 540519) I have distinguished between the nations and their leaders.
('79', 255, 5, 23, 540579) The leaders of course know what they are fighting for.
('79', 255, 5, 24, 540634) I make no admission that they are right.
('79', 255, 5, 25, 540675) But neither the English nor the Germans nor the Italians know what they are fighting for except that they trust their leaders and therefore follow them.

('79', 255, 5, 28, 541102) But The Time’s claim probably is that the British people know what they are fighting for.
('79', 255, 5, 29, 541192) When I asked the British soldiers in South Africa during the Boer War they could not tell me what they were fighting for.

('79', 258, 3, 8, 546275) I flatter myself with the belief that on occasions I have saved the community against itself.
('79', 258, 3, 9, 546369) But Master Tara Singh asked me for permission to publish the correspondence which I readily gave.

('79', 258, 4, 17, 547265) It applies only to Master Tara Singh and those whom he represents.
('79', 258, 4, 18, 547332) It can apply to the whole of the Sikh community only if they accept Master Tara Singh as their undisputed leader.

('79', 259, 2, 13, 549584) 243. RAJAJI’S POSTSCRIPT
('79', 259, 3, 14, 549609) MY DEAR GANDHIJI, I had the advantage of reading the leading article 2 of September 22 in manuscript at Poona through the courtesy of Shri Chandrashanker 3. I quite understand why you wrote the article, but I wished I could stop its publication or add my remarks to it.
('79', 259, 3, 15, 549879) Reading the article in print now I think I had better explain my position.
('79', 259, 3, 16, 549954) I do not feel that you exposed me to any ridicule.
('79', 259, 3, 17, 550005) I was not worried over the attacks made at Bombay on the Poona resolution.
('79', 259, 3, 18, 550080) I am not the least bit sorry for the Poona resolution.
('79', 259, 3, 19, 550135) It expressed what we felt was the right thing to do under the circumstances.
('79', 259, 3, 20, 550212) The British Government did not agree, and in consequence the proposal has failed.
('79', 259, 3, 21, 550294) That, however, does not make any difference as to the validity of the reasons that led to it.
('79', 259, 3, 22, 550388) Almost the entire body of intelligent public opinion in India welcomed the Poona resolution.
('79', 259, 3, 23, 550481) You, of course, considered it wrong because it involved participation in war,

('79', 260, 1, 2, 550721) be it even for the defence of India.
('79', 260, 1, 3, 550758) There were some who feared that the resolution might be accepted by the British Government and involve us in co operation with Britain which was distasteful to them.
('79', 260, 1, 4, 550924) There are some people for whom the deciding consideration is success.
('79', 260, 1, 5, 550994) They feel it a disgrace to make a proposal which is turned down.
('79', 260, 1, 6, 551059) There are again some who desire the maturing of chaos in which alone they see hope for the future of our country, and they would oppose anything that would retard the progress of this fermentation of chaos.
('79', 260, 1, 7, 551266) Barring these groups the vast body of enlightened opinion in the country enthusiastically approved of the proposal made at Poona, namely, that if Britain acknowledged the right of India to the status of an independent nation and set up a truly national government composed of leaders of the various groups among the present elected legislators in the Central Assembly, the deadlock should stand resolved.
('79', 260, 1, 8, 551671) You hold the view that the Congress should as from now work for the abolition of war.
('79', 260, 1, 9, 551757) The fulfilment of our national goal is inextricably connected, according to you, with that mission.
('79', 260, 1, 10, 551857) You are, therefore, of opinion that it is a grievous error to participate in the present war effort under any conditions.
('79', 260, 1, 11, 551979) I believe also that the world should reach peace and abolish wars as soon as possible.

('79', 260, 1, 13, 552256) Unlike you, I do not feel glad that the British rejected our offer on the ground that it has saved us our pacifism.
('79', 260, 1, 14, 552372) I do not support the Bombay resolution 1 because the Poona resolution was wrong.
('79', 260, 1, 15, 552453) My support is based on the following grounds.
('79', 260, 1, 16, 552499) It is wrong for the British to declare that the Indian people were in a state of war against any other nation without asking them about it.
('79', 260, 1, 17, 552639) War does not mean only payment of some money and manufacturing munitions.
('79', 260, 1, 18, 552713) It can easily lead up to all that is happening in London, and should be dealt with on that footing.
('79', 260, 1, 19, 552813) Four hundred millions of human beings cannot be thrown into such a condition against their own will or without asking them.
('79', 260, 1, 20, 552937) It is possible for us to recognize the justice of Britain’s case against Germany without having to join in it and extend the tragedy beyond the necessary limits.
('79', 260, 1, 21, 553099) America refuses to enter the war though it may give judgment in favour of Britain.
('79', 260, 1, 22, 553182) We have not entered the Sino Japanese war in spite of the justice of China’s cause.
('79', 260, 1, 23, 553266) The Poona proposal sought to make participation consistent with self respect and fruitful.
('79', 260, 1, 24, 553357) But the proposal was rejected by the British Government.
('79', 260, 1, 25, 553414) India is, therefore, entitled to refuse to participate in the war.
('79', 260, 1, 26, 553481) But she is forced to contribute and participate on the basis that India is an imperial possession without any independent status or the right to choose between war and neutrality.
