('79', 264, 3, 13, 559326) 249. INTERESTING PARALLEL
('79', 264, 4, 14, 559352) Shri A. Choudhary, who has come to non violence after much travail, sends the following interesting letter:
('79', 264, 5, 15, 559460) Looking through some Press articles about Trotsky 1 after his recent murder, I came across the following remarkable fact: When the Bolsheviks captured power after the October revolution in 1917, the Soviet Government negotiated for peace with Germany.
('79', 264, 5, 16, 559712) The German Government offered very severe terms.
('79', 264, 5, 17, 559761) Trotsky thought that the moral effect of the revolution was so great that the German Government would find it impossible to move their armies against Russia.
('79', 264, 5, 18, 559919) So, rather than submit to those terms, he declared that the Soviet Government considered war to be at an end and so would demobilize their armies, and actually proceeded to do so.
('79', 264, 5, 19, 560099) The Germans continued to advance and later on they concluded a severer treaty.
('79', 264, 6, 20, 560178) Do you not think this to be an unconscious and partial realization by the revolutionary leader of the possibility of resisting foreign aggression without an army?
('79', 264, 6, 21, 560341) The cause of the failure is obvious.
('79', 264, 6, 22, 560378) They had never
('79', 264, 7, 23, 560393) 1 Lev Davidovich Trotsky (1879 1940), Russian politician, whose real name was Bronstein, escaped to England in 1902 under the name Trotsky.
('79', 264, 7, 24, 560533) Opposed to war, he played important part in organizing the 1917 Bolshevik revolution.
('79', 264, 7, 25, 560619) In 1936, he was accused of joining a plot to murder Stalin but repudiated the charge.
('79', 264, 7, 26, 560705) On August 20, 1940, Trotsky was attacked by a ‘friend’, described as a Stalinist agent.
('79', 264, 7, 27, 560793) He died the next day.
('79', 265, 0, 1, 560815) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 265, 1, 2, 560857) consciously accepted non violence or prepared for it.
('79', 265, 1, 3, 560911) Trotsky’s action amounted to non resistance, not active non violent appeal.
('79', 265, 2, 4, 560987) There are instances in the history of the Russian Revolution of unarmed masses or workers facing the military forces in face of rifle fire in the hope of winning them over and actually doing so.
('79', 265, 2, 5, 561182) These I hold to be an unorganized and unconscious adoption of the non violent technique, by the masses in the streets.
('79', 265, 2, 6, 561301) But Trotsky’s instance shows that a responsible revolutionary statesman, having nothing to do with non violence, could, in the light of revolutionary experience, think the ‘silly’ course now advocated by you to be a possible one, and actually experiment with it.
('79', 265, 3, 7, 561564) Why should not we, with twenty years’ tradition of non violent action, not only experiment with it, but hope for certain success?
('79', 265, 3, 8, 561694) I for myself have begun to believe that of all forms of non violent action, resistance to foreign aggression is the easiest one, and the first one likely to be completely successful.
('79', 265, 3, 9, 561877) SIMLA, September 28, 1940

('79', 267, 1, 2, 564266) 253. DISGRACEFUL IF TRUE
('79', 267, 2, 3, 564291) A correspondent sends me a bitter letter which I reproduce after removing some choice adjectives which he has used: 1
('79', 267, 3, 4, 564409) I have several letters in confirmation of the general charge of indecent behaviour of these ‘soldiers’.
('79', 267, 3, 5, 564513) One letter says that a philanthropic lady had invited these and Indian soldiers to tea.
('79', 267, 3, 6, 564601) The Indians responded.
('79', 267, 3, 7, 564624) Of over 250 Australians invited about eight responded.
('79', 267, 3, 8, 564679) The poor lady, it is said, was frantic with grief, and phoned to know why her Australian guests had not turned up.
('79', 267, 3, 9, 564794) ‘They have gone out, they are not ready,’ was the answer.
('79', 267, 3, 10, 564852) When I was in Bombay I had heard of this wild behaviour.
('79', 267, 3, 11, 564909) I was inclined to discount the stories that came to me of their alleged misbehaviour.
('79', 267, 3, 12, 564995) Some of them were at the station when I took the train for Wardha.
('79', 267, 3, 13, 565062) I mentioned to them the complaints that were brought to my notice.
('79', 267, 3, 14, 565129) They promised to set things right.
('79', 267, 3, 15, 565164) Evidently they had no influence over their companions.
('79', 267, 3, 16, 565219) They did say to me, they had not been in touch with one another before their enlistment.
('79', 267, 3, 17, 565308) Be that as it may, the menace should be sternly dealt with.
('79', 267, 3, 18, 565368) I did mention the matter to H.E. the Viceroy.
('79', 267, 3, 19, 565414) He promised to investigate.
('79', 267, 3, 20, 565442) He admitted that the thing was serious if it was true.
('79', 267, 3, 21, 565497) I suppose colour prejudice is as strong in Australia as in South Africa.
('79', 267, 3, 22, 565570) The coloured man is dirt.
('79', 267, 3, 23, 565596) There shall be no equality between the whites and the coloured races.
('79', 267, 3, 24, 565666) Thus runs the South African constitution.
('79', 267, 3, 25, 565708) The white man thinks that a nation containing forty crores of people and ruled by one hundred thousand white men can only be treated as the Australian soldiers are reported to have regarded our girls, the victoriawallas and even the Indian police.
('79', 267, 3, 26, 565956) The war has made no difference in the behaviour of the white man.
('79', 267, 3, 27, 566022) Two questions emerge from the incidents, assuming them to have happened as reported.
('79', 267, 3, 28, 566107) All the letters received by me cannot be inventions of fertile brains.
('79', 267, 3, 29, 566178) What notice have the immediate authorities taken of the allegations?
('79', 267, 3, 30, 566247) The Viceroy is but one man.
('79', 267, 3, 31, 566275) If every ugly incident has to go up to him for redress, the system under which this has to happen is bad.
('79', 267, 3, 32, 566381) There is gross indiscipline among the subordinates in so far as justice to the people is concerned.
('79', 267, 3, 33, 566481) It is plain sailing when the power of the bayonet is to be exhibited.
('79', 267, 3, 34, 566551) Then the Viceroy and the subordinate service can act as one man.
('79', 267, 3, 35, 566616) The sinister
('79', 267, 4, 36, 566629) 1 The letter, not reproduced here, gave an account of the rowdy and indecent behaviour of Australian soldiers in Bombay.
('79', 268, 0, 1, 566750) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 269
('79', 268, 1, 2, 566796) inference from this phenomenon is that the subordinate service is the supreme authority and the Viceroy a mere figure head.
('79', 268, 1, 3, 566920) The most striking though painful illustration of the truth was furnished by the subordinate authority combining to break to pieces the Gandhi Irwin pact 1. Had it not been wantonly disregarded by the subordinate service, history would certainly have been written differently.
('79', 268, 1, 4, 567196) But there was no Irwin spirit behind the service.
('79', 268, 1, 5, 567246) The question, therefore, is, in the present instance, what has the G.O.C. Of the Australian contingent done with his men?
('79', 268, 1, 6, 567368) Had he issued instructions to them as to their behaviour in the midst of a mild population?
('79', 268, 1, 7, 567460) What did the Commissioner of Police do?
('79', 268, 1, 8, 567500) What did the Collector do?
('79', 268, 1, 9, 567527) And what did H.E. the Governor do?
('79', 268, 1, 10, 567562) The second question is equally important—what have the people done to protect girls from the barbarity to which they were exposed ?
('79', 268, 1, 11, 567694) What has the Mayor 2 done to vindicate the honour of the women living within his jurisdiction?
('79', 268, 1, 12, 567789) True, he has no executive authority.
('79', 268, 1, 13, 567826) But he is not the mere chairman of the Corporation.
('79', 268, 1, 14, 567878) His status carries with it a dignity and prestige which should enable him to move the authorities concerned in the right direction.
('79', 268, 1, 15, 568010) What has the Bombay Congress Committee done?
('79', 268, 1, 16, 568055) What has the man in the street done?
('79', 268, 1, 17, 568092) If the facts are correctly represented, they constitute a serious blot on everyone concerned.
('79', 268, 1, 18, 568186) If there was public spirit, violent or non violent, no one, white or brown, would dare to touch a girl against her will.

('79', 268, 2, 21, 568395) 254. NOTES
('79', 268, 3, 22, 568406) ILLEGAL LEVY?
('79', 268, 4, 23, 568420) This is a typical letter 3. In some shape or other things go on like this.
('79', 268, 4, 24, 568495) I call it an illegal levy.
('79', 268, 4, 25, 568522) Any passenger who will take the trouble can decline to pay the levy and tender the scheduled fare and demand a seat in the bus.
('79', 268, 4, 26, 568650) If he is rejected, he has a cause of action.
('79', 268, 4, 27, 568695) So far as I know, it is not the Government policy to compel people to give
('79', 268, 5, 28, 568770) 1 Of March 5, 1931; vide “Provisional Settlement” 2 Mathuradas Trikumji; vide also “Letter to Mathuradas Trikumji”, 7 10 1940. 3 The letter, not reproduced here, described how the police forced bus owners at Alibag, Kolaba, to contribute half anna on every ticket sold as war gift and how they were charging it to the passengers.
('79', 269, 0, 1, 569100) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 269, 1, 2, 569142) donations.
('79', 269, 1, 3, 569153) There is legal compulsion enough for the purposes of the war.
('79', 269, 1, 4, 569215) Even that is being carried too far and is causing resentment.
('79', 269, 1, 5, 569277) But it becomes intense when to this legal levy is added the illegal one miscalled donations.
('79', 269, 1, 6, 569370) It is indecent to legalize arbitrary exactions.
('79', 269, 1, 7, 569418) It is doubly indecent to connive at illegalities.
('79', 269, 1, 8, 569468) I can only hope that these will be stopped altogether.

('79', 269, 6, 25, 570668) 255. PHYSICAL TRAINING AND AHIMSA 2
('79', 269, 7, 26, 570704) Part of the course in physical training schools and gymnasia is a training in the use of the sword, the spear and similar weapons.
('79', 269, 7, 27, 570835) The Congress volunteers are taught various kinds of drill, and in many places are given also the training I have mentioned.
('79', 269, 7, 28, 570959) I have received a
('79', 269, 8, 29, 570977) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('79', 269, 8, 30, 571014) The correspondent said that the students of the college had called a strike in protest against the Principal objecting to the singing of Vandemataram in a programme.

('79', 270, 0, 1, 571277) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 271
('79', 270, 1, 2, 571323) number of letters asking for my views on the subject from the point of view of ahimsa.
('79', 270, 1, 3, 571410) Before I proceed to state my views, it is necessary to mention an important fact, viz., that physical fitness is the only thing examined in case of candidates intending to be recruited for a violent army.
('79', 270, 1, 4, 571615) Old men, women, and raw youth are not regarded as eligible.
('79', 270, 1, 5, 571675) Nor are those suffering from disease fit to be chosen.
('79', 270, 1, 6, 571730) And it is necessary to insist on this rule in selecting these recruits.
('79', 270, 1, 7, 571802) But the standard is quite the contrary for selecting recruits for a non violent body.
('79', 270, 1, 8, 571888) The chief thing to test is the candidate’s mental fitness.
('79', 270, 1, 9, 571947) And so such a body may have old men, women, raw youth, the blind and the lame, and even lepers, and it would bid fare to win.
('79', 270, 1, 10, 572073) The ability to kill requires training.
('79', 270, 1, 11, 572112) The ability to die is there in him who has the will for it.
('79', 270, 1, 12, 572172) One can conceive of a child of ten or twelve being a perfect satyagrahi; indeed we come across such in daily life.
('79', 270, 1, 13, 572287) But for such a child to be recruited for a violent army is out of the question.
('79', 270, 1, 14, 572367) In spite of the best will in the world he cannot have the physical fitness.
('79', 270, 1, 15, 572443) But to say that lepers and children are eligible for a non violent army is not to say that a non violent person need have no regard for physical fitness.
('79', 270, 1, 16, 572597) Ahimsa requires certain duties which can be done only by those with a trained physique.
('79', 270, 1, 17, 572685) It is therefore most necessary to consider what kind of physical training a non violent person should receive.
('79', 270, 1, 18, 572796) Very few of the rules applying to a violent army will apply to a non violent body.
('79', 270, 1, 19, 572879) A violent army will not have its arms for show but definitely for destructive purposes.
('79', 270, 1, 20, 572967) A non violent body will have no use for such weapons and will therefore beat its swords into plough shares and spears into pruning hooks, and will shrink from the thought of using them as lethal weapons.
('79', 270, 1, 21, 573171) The violent soldier will be trained in the use of violence by being taught to shoot.
('79', 270, 1, 22, 573256) The non violent soldier will have no time for this pastime.
('79', 270, 1, 23, 573316) He will get all his training through nursing the sick, saving those in danger at the risk of his own life, patrolling places which may be in fear of thieves and dacoits, and in laying down his life, if necessary, in dissuading them from their purpose.
('79', 270, 1, 24, 573568) Even the uniforms of the two will differ.
('79', 270, 1, 25, 573610) The violent man will wear a coat of mail for his protection, and his uniform will be such as can dazzle people.
('79', 270, 1, 26, 573722) The uniform of the non violent man will be simple, in conformity with the dress of the poor, and betokening humility.
('79', 270, 1, 27, 573840) Its purpose will be just to keep him
('79', 271, 0, 1, 573877) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 271, 1, 2, 573919) from heat and cold and rain.
('79', 271, 1, 3, 573948) A violent soldier’s protection will be his arms, no matter how much he takes God’s name.
('79', 271, 1, 4, 574037) He will not shrink from spending millions on armaments.
('79', 271, 1, 5, 574093) The first and last shield and buckler of the non violent person will be his unwavering faith in God.
('79', 271, 1, 6, 574194) And the minds of the two will be as poles asunder.
('79', 271, 1, 7, 574245) The violent man will always be casting about for plans to work the destruction of his enemy and will pray to God to fulfil his purpose.
('79', 271, 1, 8, 574381) The national anthem of the British people is worth considering in this connection.
('79', 271, 1, 9, 574464) It prays to God to save the King, to frustrate the enemy’s knavish tricks, and to destroy him.
('79', 271, 1, 10, 574559) Millions of Englishmen sing this anthem aloud with one voice standing respectfully.
('79', 271, 1, 11, 574643) If God is the Incarnation of Mercy, He is not likely to listen to such prayer, but it cannot but affect the minds of those who sing it, and in times of war it simply kindles their hatred and anger to white heat.
('79', 271, 1, 12, 574855) The one condition of winning a violent war is to keep the indignation against the enemy burning fiercely.
('79', 271, 1, 13, 574961) In the dictionary of the non violent there is no such word as an external enemy.
('79', 271, 1, 14, 575042) But even for the supposed enemy he will have nothing but compassion in his heart.
('79', 271, 1, 15, 575124) He will believe that no man is intentionally wicked, that there is no man but is gifted with the faculty to discriminate between right and wrong, and that if that faculty were to be fully developed, it would surely mature into non violence.
('79', 271, 1, 16, 575365) He will therefore pray to God that He may give the supposed enemy a sense of right and bless him.
('79', 271, 1, 17, 575463) His prayer for himself will always be that the spring of compassion in him may ever be flowing and that he may ever grow in moral strength so that he may face death fearlessly.
('79', 271, 1, 18, 575640) Thus since the minds of both will differ as the poles, their physical training will also differ in the same degree.
('79', 271, 1, 19, 575756) We all know more or less what military training is like.
('79', 271, 1, 20, 575813) But we have hardly ever thought that non violent training must be of a different kind.
('79', 271, 1, 21, 575900) Nor have we ever cared to discover whether in the past such training was given anywhere in the world.
('79', 271, 1, 22, 576002) I am of opinion that it used to be given in the past and is even now being given in a haphazard way.
('79', 271, 1, 23, 576103) The various exercises of Hatha Yoga are in this direction.
('79', 271, 1, 24, 576162) The physical training given by means of these imparts among other things physical health, strength, agility, and the capacity to bear heat and cold.
('79', 271, 1, 25, 576311) Shri Kuvalayanandji is making scientific researches in the technique and benefits of these exercises.
('79', 271, 1, 26, 576413) I have no knowledge of the progress he has made, nor do I know whether he is making his experiments with ahimsa as his goal.
('79', 271, 1, 27, 576538) My reference to Hatha Yoga is meant only with a view to showing that this ancient type of non violent training still exists, though I know that there is room in it for improvement.
('79', 271, 1, 28, 576719) I do not know either that the author of this science had any idea of mass non violence.
('79', 271, 1, 29, 576807) The exercises had at their
('79', 272, 0, 1, 576834) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 273
('79', 272, 1, 2, 576880) back the desire for individual salvation.
('79', 272, 1, 3, 576922) The object of the various exercises was to strengthen and purify the body in order to secure control of the mind.
('79', 272, 1, 4, 577036) The mass non violence we are now thinking of applies to people of all religions, and therefore the rules that may be framed must be such as can be accepted by all believers in ahimsa.
('79', 272, 1, 5, 577220) And then as we are thinking of a non violent army, that is to say of bringing into being a Satyagraha Sangh, we can but build anew accepting the old as our foundation.
('79', 272, 1, 6, 577388) Let us then think of the physical training required by a satyagrahi.
('79', 272, 1, 7, 577457) If the satyagrahi is not healthy in mind and body, he may perhaps fail in mustering complete fearlessness.
('79', 272, 1, 8, 577564) He should have the capacity to stand guard at a single spot day and night; he must not fall ill even if he has to bear cold and heat and rain; he must have the strength to go to places of peril, to rush to scenes of fire, and the courage to wander about alone in desolate jungles and haunts of death; he will bear, without a grumble, severe beatings, starvation and worse, and will keep to his post of duty without flinching; he will have the resourcefulness and capacity to plunge into a seemingly impenetrable scene of rioting; he will have the longing and capacity to run with the name of God on his lips to the rescue of men living on the top storeys of buildings enveloped in flames; he will have the fearlessness to plunge into a flood in order to rescue people being carried off by it or to jump down a well to save a drowning person.
('79', 272, 1, 9, 578406) This list can be extended ad libitum.
('79', 272, 1, 10, 578444) The substance of it all is that we should cultivate the capacity to run to the rescue of people in danger and distress, and to suffer cheerfully any amount of hardship that may be inflicted upon us.
('79', 272, 1, 11, 578643) He who accepts this fundamental principle will easily be able to frame rules of physical training for satyagrahis.
('79', 272, 1, 12, 578758) I have a firm conviction that the very foundation of this training is faith in God.
('79', 272, 1, 13, 578842) If that is absent, all the training one may have received is likely to fail at the critical moment.
('79', 272, 1, 14, 578942) Let no one pooh pooh my statement by saying that the Congress has many people who are ashamed to take the name of God.
('79', 272, 1, 15, 579061) I am simply trying to state the view in terms of the science of satyagraha as I have known and developed it.
('79', 272, 1, 16, 579170) The only weapon of the satyagrahi is God, by whatsoever name one knows Him.
('79', 272, 1, 17, 579246) Without Him the satyagrahi is devoid of strength before an opponent armed with monstrous weapons.
('79', 272, 1, 18, 579344) Most people lie prostrate before physical might.
('79', 272, 1, 19, 579393) But he who accepts God as his only Protector will remain unbent before the mightiest earthly power.
('79', 272, 1, 20, 579493) As faith in God is essential in a satyagrahi, even so is brahmacharya.
('79', 272, 1, 21, 579564) Without brahmacharya the
('79', 273, 0, 1, 579589) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 273, 1, 2, 579631) satyagrahi will have no lustre, no inner strength to stand unarmed against the whole world.
('79', 273, 1, 3, 579723) Brahmacharya may have here the restricted meaning of conservation of the vital energy brought about by sexual restraint, and not the comprehensive definition I have given of it.
('79', 273, 1, 4, 579901) He who intends to live on spare diet, and without any external remedies, and still wants to have physical strength, has need to conserve his vital energy.
('79', 273, 1, 5, 580056) It is the richest capital man can ever possess.
('79', 273, 1, 6, 580104) He who can preserve it ever gains renewed strength out of it.
('79', 273, 1, 7, 580166) He who uses it up, consciously or unconsciously, will ultimately be impotent.
('79', 273, 1, 8, 580244) His strength will fail him at the right moment.
('79', 273, 1, 9, 580292) I have often written about the ways and means of conserving this energy.
('79', 273, 1, 10, 580365) Let the reader turn to my writings and carry out the instructions.
('79', 273, 1, 11, 580432) He who lusts with the eye or the touch can never conserve his vital energy, nor the man who lusts after flesh pots.
('79', 273, 1, 12, 580548) Those who hope to conserve this energy without strict observance of the rules will no more succeed than those who hope to swim against the current without being exhausted.
('79', 273, 1, 13, 580720) He who restrains himself physically and sins with his thoughts will fare worse than he who, without professing to observe brahmacharya, lives the life of a restrained householder.
('79', 273, 1, 14, 580900) For he who lusts with the thought will ever remain unsated and will end his life a moral wreck and burden on the earth.
('79', 273, 1, 15, 581020) Such a one can never be a full satyagrahi.
('79', 273, 1, 16, 581063) Nor can one who hankers after wealth and fame.
('79', 273, 1, 17, 581110) This is the foundation of the physical training for a satyagrahi.
('79', 273, 1, 18, 581176) The detailed structure of the course can easily be built in consonance with this foundation.
('79', 273, 1, 19, 581269) It should now be clear that in the physical training of a satyagrahi there is no room for lethal weapons like the sword or the spear.
('79', 273, 1, 20, 581403) For far more terrible weapons than we have seen are in existence today, and newer ones are being invented every day.
('79', 273, 1, 21, 581520) Of what fear will a sword rid him who has to cultivate the capacity to overcome all fear—real or imaginary?
('79', 273, 1, 22, 581628) I have not yet heard of a man having shed all fear by learning sword play.
('79', 273, 1, 23, 581703) Mahavir and others who imbibed ahimsa did not do so because they knew the use of weapons, but because in spite of the knowledge of their use they shed all fear.
('79', 273, 1, 24, 581864) A slight introspection will show that he who has always depended on the sword will find it difficult to throw it away.
('79', 273, 1, 25, 581983) But having deliberately discarded it he is likely to find his ahimsa more lasting than that of him who, not knowing its use, fancies he will not fear it.
('79', 273, 1, 26, 582137) But that does not mean that in order to be truly non violent
('79', 274, 0, 1, 582198) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 275
('79', 274, 1, 2, 582244) one must beforehand possess and know the use of arms.
('79', 274, 1, 3, 582298) By parity of reasoning, one might say that only a thief can be honest, only a diseased person can be healthy, and only a dissolute person can be a brahmachari.
('79', 274, 1, 4, 582458) The fact is that we have formed the habit of thinking along traditional grooves and will not get out of them.
('79', 274, 1, 5, 582568) And as we cannot take a detached view, we cannot draw the right conclusions, and get caught in delusive snares.
('79', 274, 1, 6, 582680) If I have the time, I hope to present the reader with a model course of training.

('79', 278, 3, 4, 589609) 261. THE BREACH 1
('79', 278, 4, 5, 589627) It is my firm conviction that British statesmen have failed to do the right thing when it was easy to do it.
('79', 278, 4, 6, 589736) If India is wholly in favour of participation in the war, they could have easily disregarded any hostile propaganda.
('79', 278, 4, 7, 589853) But the determination to gag free expression of opinion, provided it was not in the least tainted with violence, shatters Britain’s claim that India’s participation is voluntary.
('79', 278, 4, 8, 590032) Had the Congress proposal been accepted, such aid as Britain would have got from India would have been an asset of inestimable value.
('79', 278, 4, 9, 590166) The non violent party would have played an effective part for honourable peace when the proper time for it was in sight, as it must be some day.
('79', 278, 4, 10, 590311) I have been shown The Times comment on the breach.
('79', 278, 4, 11, 590362) I accept the compliment about my resourcefulness.
('79', 278, 4, 12, 590412) But great as I believe it to be, I own that it has its limitations.
('79', 278, 4, 13, 590480) There must be willingness on the other side.
('79', 278, 4, 14, 590525) I regret to have to say, I wholly missed it at the interview.
('79', 278, 4, 15, 590587) The Viceroy was all courtesy, but he was unbending, and believed in the correctness of his judgment, and as usual had no faith in that of nationalist India.
('79', 278, 4, 16, 590744) The Britisher is showing extraordinary bravery on the battle field in a marvellous manner.
('79', 278, 4, 17, 590835) But he lacks bravery to take risks in the moral domain.
('79', 278, 4, 18, 590891) I often wonder whether the latter has any place in British politics.
('79', 278, 4, 19, 590960) SEVAGRAM, October 3, 1940
('79', 278, 5, 20, 590986) Harijan, 6 10 1940

('79', 281, 0, 1, 593791) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 281, 1, 2, 593833) 266. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('79', 281, 2, 3, 593863) SEVAGRAM, October 5, 1940
('79', 281, 3, 4, 593889) In the correspondence between H.E. the Viceroy and myself announcing the breakdown in the talks, I have said in my letter 2 that I would make a public statement covering matters not referred to in my letter.
('79', 281, 3, 5, 594097) Before I do so, I think it is necessary for my purpose to say a few words regarding Lord Linlithgow.
('79', 281, 3, 6, 594198) He is straight in his talk, always deliberate, and economical in his language.
('79', 281, 3, 7, 594277) He is never equivocal, never leaves you in doubt as to his meaning.
('79', 281, 3, 8, 594345) He conveys the most unpalatable decisions with a calmness and courtesy which, for the moment, make you think that you have heard no harsh or hard decision.
('79', 281, 3, 9, 594501) He listens to your argument with a patience and attention I have never known any other Viceroy or high functionary to show in an equal measure.
('79', 281, 3, 10, 594645) He is never ruffled and never discourteous.
('79', 281, 3, 11, 594689) With all this, however, he is not to be easily moved from his position.
('79', 281, 3, 12, 594761) He meets you with his decision on the matter under discussion already made.
('79', 281, 3, 13, 594837) He takes care not to let you think that it is so, but there is no doubt about it that his decision is unchangeable.
('79', 281, 3, 14, 594953) He is not receptive.
('79', 281, 3, 15, 594974) He has amazing confidence in the correctness of his judgment.
('79', 281, 3, 16, 595036) He does not believe in a gentleman’s or any other agreement.
('79', 281, 3, 17, 595097) I have always felt that after the Gandhi Irwin pact, British satraps decided that there should be no more such pacts.
('79', 281, 3, 18, 595215) Whatever they wanted to do, they should do independently.
('79', 281, 3, 19, 595273) It shows either a high sense of justice or boundless self assurance.
('79', 281, 3, 20, 595342) I think it is the latter.
('79', 281, 3, 21, 595368) He and I have become friends never to be parted, be the differences between us as great as they can be.
('79', 281, 3, 22, 595472) Holding such an opinion about the Viceroy, it pains me to have to relate what I must of my impression of the talks which have ended in a divergence which, in my opinion, was wholly avoidable.
('79', 281, 3, 23, 595664) Acceptance of my proposal would have been no less beneficial to England than to India.
('79', 281, 4, 24, 595751) 1 This appeared under the title “More about Simla Visit”.
('79', 281, 4, 25, 595809) 2 Vide “Letter to Lord Linthgow”, 30 9 1940
('79', 282, 0, 1, 595853) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 283
('79', 282, 1, 2, 595899) I went to Simla in the capacity of a representative and as a friend.
('79', 282, 1, 3, 595968) As a friend I presented him with my doubts as to certain acts of the British Government.
('79', 282, 1, 4, 596057) To have them dissolved was necessary to enable me to determine my mental attitude which to me is more than any visible act.
('79', 282, 1, 5, 596181) I felt that the putting up by the Viceroy, and then the Secretary of State, of want of agreement by the Congress with the Princes, the Muslim League and even the Scheduled Classes as a barrier to the British recognition of India’s right to freedom was more than unjust to the Congress and the Indian people.
('79', 282, 1, 6, 596489) I told the Viceroy that these three represented class or communal interests, whereas the Congress represented no particular class.
('79', 282, 1, 7, 596620) It was a purely national organization striving to represent India as a whole; and therefore the Congress had always maintained that it would abide by the verdict of a national assembly elected on the basis of the broadest franchise.
('79', 282, 1, 8, 596853) It had further declared its intention to abide by the vote of the separate Muslim electorate, so far as special Muslim rights were concerned.
('79', 282, 1, 9, 596995) Therefore it was wrong to speak as if Muslim rights needed special safeguards as against the Congress.
('79', 282, 1, 10, 597098) The same thing applied to the Sikhs.
('79', 282, 1, 11, 597135) The Princes of the present day were a creation of the British Government to subserve British interest.
('79', 282, 1, 12, 597238) As against the plea that the British were bound by special treaty obligations, I contended that the Congress did not ask the British Government to disregard them.
('79', 282, 1, 13, 597401) Only they could not be used to bar Indian progress, and it was wholly wrong to expect the Congress to produce an agreement with them.
('79', 282, 1, 14, 597535) The Princes were not like other parties free to conclude any agreement with the Congress even if they wished.
('79', 282, 1, 15, 597645) Moreover, the treaties, if they oblige the British Government to protect the Princes, equally compel them to protect the rights of the people.
('79', 282, 1, 16, 597788) But it has been abundantly proved that the British had rarely interfered with the Princes purely on behalf of the people.
('79', 282, 1, 17, 597910) If they had been as careful of the people’s right as they were bound by the treaties to be, the people’s condition would not have been as miserable as it is today.
('79', 282, 1, 18, 598074) Had they been true to the treaties of their own making, the people of States India should be more advanced than those of British India.
('79', 282, 1, 19, 598210) I cited some telling illustrations of this neglect of duty.
('79', 282, 1, 20, 598270) The introduction of the Scheduled Classes in the controversy has made the unreality of the case of the British Government doubly unreal.
('79', 282, 1, 21, 598407) They know that these are the special care of the Congress, and
('79', 283, 0, 1, 598470) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 283, 1, 2, 598512) that the Congress is infinitely more capable of guarding their interests than the British Government.
('79', 283, 1, 3, 598614) Moreover, the Scheduled Classes are divided into as many castes as the caste Hindu society.
('79', 283, 1, 4, 598706) No single Scheduled Class member could possibly and truthfully represent the innumerable castes.
('79', 283, 1, 5, 598803) I had sought the interview with the Viceroy to see if my interpretation of the British argument had any flaw.
('79', 283, 1, 6, 598913) I failed to get any satisfaction on the points raised.
('79', 283, 1, 7, 598968) The Viceroy would not be drawn into a discussion.
('79', 283, 1, 8, 599018) I can have no grievance about his disinclination to enter into any argument.
('79', 283, 1, 9, 599095) He had every right to rely upon the fact that that was a matter of high policy not admitting of argument.
('79', 283, 1, 10, 599201) There is a certain cold reserve about the British official world which gives them their strength and isolation from surroundings and facts.
('79', 283, 1, 11, 599341) They do not want to be too frank.
('79', 283, 1, 12, 599375) They politely refuse to enter into embarrassing argument.
('79', 283, 1, 13, 599433) They leave you to draw what inferences you like while they continue to maintain their inflexible attitude.
('79', 283, 1, 14, 599540) I suppose that is what is meant by the steel frame.
('79', 283, 1, 15, 599592) For me, this side of British policy has been the least attractive.
('79', 283, 1, 16, 599659) I had hoped, against the warning of friends, that I might be able to break through this steel wall of reserve and get at the naked truth.
('79', 283, 1, 17, 599797) But the imperialist Britisher is firmly fixed in his saddle.
('79', 283, 1, 18, 599858) Nevertheless, I will not accept defeat.
('79', 283, 1, 19, 599898) I must strive to have the truth admitted by the British people that the bar to India’s freedom lies not in the Congress or any other party’s inability to produce an agreement which is in its nature impossible, but that it undoubtedly lies in the British disinclination to do the obviously right thing.
('79', 283, 1, 20, 600200) The unreality of the British reasons for refusal to treat India as a free country was not my only grouse.
('79', 283, 1, 21, 600306) I drew the Viceroy’s attention to certain irregularities in the prosecution of the war policy.
('79', 283, 1, 22, 600401) There was agreement between us that there should be no compulsion as to war contributions.
('79', 283, 1, 23, 600492) He has promised to examine all cases of hardship and all other difficulties.
('79', 283, 1, 24, 600569) My purpose was to leave no ground for misunderstanding and to fight, if there was to be a fight, only on well defined issues and without bitterness.
('79', 283, 1, 25, 600718) I want to enter upon the fight with the hope that its very fairness will compel the recognition that India deserves better treatment, not merely from the British but from all the nations of the earth.
('79', 283, 1, 26, 600919) Lest it might be said that the Congress fights because it has failed to get power, I told His Excellency in the plainest words possible that the Congress had no desire to mount to power at the
('79', 284, 0, 1, 601112) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 285
('79', 284, 1, 2, 601158) expense of a single national interest.
('79', 284, 1, 3, 601197) It seeks no power save for the whole nation.
('79', 284, 1, 4, 601242) Therefore he will have no opposition from the Congress if he forms a Cabinet composed of representatives of different parties.
('79', 284, 1, 5, 601369) The Congress would be content to be in opposition so far as the war effort is concerned and so long as the machinery of Government has to subserve imperialist ends.
('79', 284, 1, 6, 601534) The immediate issue is not independence.
('79', 284, 1, 7, 601575) The immediate issue is the right of existence, i.e., the right of self expression which, broadly put, means free speech.
('79', 284, 1, 8, 601696) This the Congress wants not merely for itself, but for all, the only restraint being complete observance of non violence.
('79', 284, 1, 9, 601818) I hold that that condition answers all the difficulties by whomsoever raised.
('79', 284, 2, 10, 601896) Harijan, 13 10 1940

('79', 287, 1, 2, 605140) 273. LETTER TO H. L. SHARMA
('79', 287, 2, 3, 605168) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, October 6, 1940
('79', 287, 3, 4, 605202) SHARMA, I got your letter.
('79', 287, 3, 5, 605229) I want to call you to the battle.
('79', 287, 3, 6, 605263) At least now improve your health.

('79', 287, 6, 9, 605376) 274. TWO THOUGHT PROVOKING LETTERS 1
('79', 287, 7, 10, 605413) A friend writes thus:
('79', 287, 8, 11, 605435) When you asked for the names of out and out believers in non violence I wanted very much to send in mine, but something within compelled me to refrain.
('79', 287, 8, 12, 605587) First because I felt there was lack of ahimsa in my personal conduct, and secondly because there was the opposite of love for the English in my heart.
('79', 287, 8, 13, 605738) I rejoice when I read in the papers of the destruction wrought on London and Britain, and I inwardly want the British to be defeated in the war.
('79', 287, 8, 14, 605883) I am impelled to confess this, for I could not deceive you.
('79', 287, 8, 15, 605943) The second letter is from South Africa.
('79', 287, 8, 16, 605983) I take a few sentences from it:
('79', 287, 9, 17, 606015) I am puzzled as to what should be the attitude of Indians at the present juncture.
('79', 287, 9, 18, 606098) The ‘White’ races are so utterly callous in regard to ‘Coloured’ people, and in spite of the war colour prejudice continues unabated.
('79', 287, 9, 19, 606232) Why then should we give our lives for them ?
('79', 287, 9, 20, 606277) Quite recently an Indian student who returned here from Europe was telling us that in spite of the fact that the steamer was not crowded the British company hesitated to give accommodation to Indians.
('79', 287, 9, 21, 606478) Such treatment leads us and also the African people to believe that there is no difference between the Nazis, the Boers and the British, so far as we are concerned.
('79', 287, 9, 22, 606643) If there were Nazi rule in South Africa, we could not be treated worse than we are today.
('79', 287, 9, 23, 606733) Many of us think that the British
('79', 287, 10, 24, 606767) 1 This appeared as “translated from Gujarati”, originally published in Harijanbandhu, 12 10 1940.
('79', 288, 0, 1, 606865) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 289
('79', 288, 1, 2, 606911) are sweet tongued but they pursue their own ruthless policy in spite of honeyed words, whereas Hitler would be more frank.
('79', 288, 1, 3, 607034) He at any rate says exactly what he feels.
('79', 288, 1, 4, 607077) Is there not truth in this?
('79', 288, 1, 5, 607105) Anyhow we ought to know where we stand.
('79', 288, 1, 6, 607145) Please tell us.
('79', 288, 1, 7, 607161) Though differently worded the two letters betray the same thought.
('79', 288, 1, 8, 607228) It is difficult for those who suffer at British hands to shed either their dislike of or a disinclination to help them.
('79', 288, 1, 9, 607348) But the present is a real testing time for ahimsa which alone can throw light on our path.
('79', 288, 1, 10, 607439) First of all we must distinguish between the British people and their policy.
('79', 288, 1, 11, 607517) We must have full liberty thoughtfully and with reason to criticize the latter, but we may not dislike them.
('79', 288, 1, 12, 607626) To err is human.
('79', 288, 1, 13, 607643) All have their good as well as bad points.
('79', 288, 1, 14, 607686) It is in human nature, even if we are in the wrong, to resent bitter, often unjust, criticism.
('79', 288, 1, 15, 607781) But if we were lovingly shown our faults, we would perhaps be willing to listen.
('79', 288, 1, 16, 607862) We must behave thus towards the British.
('79', 288, 1, 17, 607903) Let us tell them where they are in the wrong, but let us not wish them any harm.
('79', 288, 1, 18, 607984) We may demand a mental and heart change in their outlook, but we may not pray for their downfall.
('79', 288, 1, 19, 608082) Such an attitude is indispensable in satyagraha which demands that, while we may neither speak evil of wrongdoers nor wish them ill, we must at the same time show them the error of their ways and non co operate with them in their wrongdoing.
('79', 288, 1, 20, 608324) The Congress has been trying to follow this great principle for the last twenty years.
('79', 288, 1, 21, 608411) I believe that we have benefited greatly therefrom.
('79', 288, 1, 22, 608463) Moreover there is no reason why we should wish the British to be defeated in this war.
('79', 288, 1, 23, 608550) The writer from South Africa rightly says that there is not much to choose between the British and the Nazis.
('79', 288, 1, 24, 608660) This is as clear as daylight in South Africa, in particular, where Coloured races are treated as definitely inferior in every way.
('79', 288, 1, 25, 608791) What more than this could the Nazis say or do?
('79', 288, 1, 26, 608838) The defeat of the British would connote the victory of the Nazis, which, again, we do not and must not desire.
('79', 288, 1, 27, 608949) Therefore, we should be impartial.
('79', 288, 1, 28, 608984) We are desirous of our own independence.
('79', 288, 1, 29, 609025) For that there is no reason why we should want the destruction of Germany.
('79', 288, 1, 30, 609100) We have to achieve as well as maintain our freedom through our own strength.
('79', 288, 1, 31, 609177) We do not need British or any outside help for it.
('79', 288, 1, 32, 609228) Those of us who have full faith in ahimsa believe that we can win it through non violence and keep it thereby also.
('79', 289, 0, 1, 609344) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 289, 1, 2, 609386) There is, however, a section amongst us who believe in winning and maintaining our independence through force of arms.
('79', 289, 1, 3, 609505) Their position is a difficult one.
('79', 289, 1, 4, 609540) As a matter of fact we have still to gain our freedom.
('79', 289, 1, 5, 609595) If we win it through violence, we will not do so by helping Britain in the war.
('79', 289, 1, 6, 609675) For if we help the war effort, we really come more under their sway than we are today.
('79', 289, 1, 7, 609762) And if in spite of our help they lose, we would then come under the rule of another foreign power.
('79', 289, 1, 8, 609861) So that, if Britain and India were jointly defeated, we would, so to speak, be jumping from the frying pan into the fire.
('79', 289, 1, 9, 609983) Moreover India has no enmity towards any nation.
('79', 289, 1, 10, 610032) Hitler and others have no illusions.
('79', 289, 1, 11, 610069) They know full well that India is not a willing partner in the war, that we are a slave country and that our wishes do not count.
('79', 289, 1, 12, 610199) It was really the Congress who raised this question because the Congress has adopted non violence as its weapon.
('79', 289, 1, 13, 610312) At the same time we have no quarrel with those who do not believe in non violence.
('79', 289, 1, 14, 610395) Each of us must go his own way.
('79', 289, 1, 15, 610427) By doing so we shall know where India stands.
('79', 289, 1, 16, 610473) If the Congress had not spoken out its mind, it would have committed suicide, that is to say, it would have given up its right to follow out its policy of non violence.
('79', 289, 1, 17, 610642) It is its duty to keep itself alive.
('79', 289, 1, 18, 610679) Therefore the Congress has to take some action.
('79', 289, 1, 19, 610727) What that action will be will shortly become known.
('79', 289, 1, 20, 610779) I suggest to the two writers that they should try to rid their hearts of all anger and hatred.
('79', 289, 1, 21, 610874) These are in reality signs of weakness.
('79', 289, 1, 22, 610914) Non violence is an active force.
('79', 289, 1, 23, 610947) If they were to follow it, they would be active and they would be spreading the leaven of ahimsa.
('79', 289, 1, 24, 611045) The Congress demand is not for itself only.
('79', 289, 1, 25, 611089) It extends far beyond even India and embraces the world.
('79', 289, 1, 26, 611146) Let us therefore wish well from the bottom of our hearts to all the warring nations.
('79', 289, 1, 27, 611231) SEVAGRAM, October 7, 1940

('79', 290, 11, 22, 612707) This question demands an answer.
('79', 290, 11, 23, 612740) So far as they have been taken away by the English the right accrues against the English.

('79', 291, 0, 1, 613200) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 291, 1, 2, 613242) am asked as a matter of equity, I can only say that the people of the respective parts should be asked to make their choice.
('79', 291, 1, 3, 613367) That is the only equity I know.
('79', 291, 1, 4, 613399) But I suggest that all such discussion is academic.
('79', 291, 1, 5, 613451) If India, the geographical unit, gets independence, as it must some day, it means that every component part has its independence.
('79', 291, 1, 6, 613581) If independence is won non violently, all the component parts will be voluntarily interdependent, working in perfect harmony under a representative central authority which will derive its sanction from the confidence reposed in it by the component parts.
('79', 291, 1, 7, 613836) If independence is taken by force of arms, then the strongest power will hold sway over all India.
('79', 291, 1, 8, 613935) And this may be Hyderabad for ought I know.
('79', 291, 1, 9, 613979) All the big and the petty States will be free willy nilly from the British yoke.
('79', 291, 1, 10, 614060) They will each fight for their existence and succumb to the strongest who will be the emperor of India.
('79', 291, 1, 11, 614164) This presupposes unarmed millions lying prostrate at the feet of the combination of armed States.
('79', 291, 1, 12, 614262) Many other things are, however, conceivable.
('79', 291, 1, 13, 614307) The Indian part of the British army will probably have consciousness of strength and an independent existence.
('79', 291, 1, 14, 614418) There may be Muslim arms, Sikh arms, Gurkha arms, Rajput arms and what not.
('79', 291, 1, 15, 614494) They may fight among themselves or, having allied themselves to some nationalist party, may present a united front to the Princes.
('79', 291, 1, 16, 614625) There may also be the descent upon India of the warring tribes from the Frontier to share the spoils or the sovereignty itself.
('79', 291, 1, 17, 614753) The Congress, if it still has anything of its non violence left in it, will die in the attempt to establish universal peace in India.
('79', 291, 1, 18, 614887) It is not impossible that all the warring elements will find it profitable in more ways than one voluntarily to surrender themselves to the moral authority of a central power.
('79', 291, 1, 19, 615063) This means universal suffrage exer cised by a disciplined and politically intelligent electorate.
('79', 291, 1, 20, 615161) It also means a decent and permanent burial to communal and other discord.
('79', 291, 1, 21, 615236) But this may not happen.
('79', 291, 1, 22, 615261) The existing state of things does not warrant an optimistic outlook.
('79', 291, 1, 23, 615330) But I am a man of faith.
('79', 291, 1, 24, 615355) And to faith all things are possible.
('79', 291, 1, 25, 615393) But supposing the worst happens and there is anarchy in the land, if there is God upon earth as He is in heaven, then you may depend upon it that, I shall not live to make any choice.
('79', 291, 1, 26, 615577) I shall die in the anarchic flame whilst I am vainly attempting to still it with my tiny, shaky hands.
('79', 291, 1, 27, 615680) But if you ask me in advance whether I would face anarchy in preference to foreign orderly rule, either
('79', 292, 0, 1, 615784) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 293
('79', 292, 1, 2, 615830) British or any other, I would unhesitatingly plump for anarchy, say, the rule of the Nizam supported by Chiefs become feudatory to him or supported by the border Muslim tribes.
('79', 292, 1, 3, 616007) In my estimation it will be cent per cent domestic.
('79', 292, 1, 4, 616059) It will be home rule though far, far from self rule or swa raj ( ).
('79', 292, 1, 5, 616127) But you must let me repeat that, while I can write thus academically, if the reality faces me, my choice will be death or the rule of the people by the people for the people.
('79', 292, 1, 6, 616302) This means the rule of unadulterated non violence.
('79', 292, 1, 7, 616353) So you see my non violence is made not of cotton wool but of a metal much harder than steel and yet softer than cotton wool.
('79', 292, 1, 8, 616478) You can compare it only with itself.
('79', 292, 1, 9, 616515) You will naturally then ask what place have the Princes in my scheme of things.
('79', 292, 1, 10, 616595) Such a question should not arise if you had fully realized the implications of non violence.
('79', 292, 1, 11, 616688) For the Princes obeying the moral authority of a central body not sustained by arms will find an honourable place as servants of the people.
('79', 292, 1, 12, 616829) No one will have any rights but what are inherent in a willing performance of one’s duties.
('79', 292, 1, 13, 616921) Thus H. E. H. the Nizam will then be the chosen servant of people.
('79', 292, 1, 14, 616988) Only then his people will not be merely those confined willy nilly within his present borders but may be all India.
('79', 292, 1, 15, 617104) You must not dismiss this as a utopian scheme.
('79', 292, 1, 16, 617151) I claim to be a practical man.
('79', 292, 1, 17, 617182) If the Congress proves true to its policy, what may seem today to be an airy nothing may tomorrow become an agreeable reality.
('79', 292, 1, 18, 617309) In my scheme there is no waste of either human talent or creative effort.
('79', 292, 1, 19, 617383) Let me quote here my cable to H. G. Wells in reply to his on the rights of man: Received your cable.
('79', 292, 1, 20, 617484) Have carefully read your five articles.
('79', 292, 1, 21, 617524) You will permit me to say, you are on the wrong track.
('79', 292, 1, 22, 617579) I feel sure that I can draw up a better charter of rights than you have drawn up.
('79', 292, 1, 23, 617661) But what good will it be?
('79', 292, 1, 24, 617687) Who will become its guardian?
('79', 292, 1, 25, 617717) If you mean propaganda or populareducation, you have begun at the wrong end.
('79', 292, 1, 26, 617794) I suggest the right way.
('79', 292, 1, 27, 617819) Begin with a charter of duties of man, and I promise the rights will follow as spring follows winter.
('79', 292, 1, 28, 617921) I write from experience.
('79', 292, 1, 29, 617946) As a young man I began life by seeking to assert my rights, and I soon discovered I had none—not even over my wife.
('79', 292, 1, 30, 618062) So I began by discovering and performing my duty by my wife, my children, friends, companions and society, and I find today that I have greater rights, perhaps, than any living man I know.
('79', 292, 1, 31, 618251) If this is too tall a claim, then I say I do not know anyone who possesses greater rights than I. SEVAGRAM, October 8, 1940

('79', 293, 4, 9, 618968) 279. FASTING IN SATYAGRAHA 2
('79', 293, 5, 10, 618997) I note that in connection with the imminent satyagraha the possibility of my fasting has been hinted at in the papers.
('79', 293, 5, 11, 619116) Pandit Malaviyaji has a soft corner for me.
('79', 293, 5, 12, 619160) He is always deeply concerned about my health, my politics, and my morals.
('79', 293, 5, 13, 619235) We have differences of opinion, but our love cheerfully stands the strain.
('79', 293, 5, 14, 619310) The day before I left Sevagram for Simla I received a letter from him, urging me to avoid at all cost the reported fast.
('79', 293, 6, 15, 619431) I have to admit that there is a certain measure of truth in the report.
('79', 293, 6, 16, 619503) I have told my friends of the Working Committee of my premonition that I may have to undertake one more fast during my life, and that this may even take place sooner than I had thought.
('79', 293, 6, 17, 619689) But the fact is that so far as I can remember I have never undertaken a single one of my public fasts with any premeditation on my part.
('79', 293, 6, 18, 619826) All my fasts have come to me on the spur of the moment, gifts from God as I have called them.
('79', 293, 6, 19, 619920) Their results have been invariably good.
('79', 293, 6, 20, 619961) And in any event I have no regrets regarding them.
('79', 293, 6, 21, 620012) I hope, therefore, that readers will entertain no anxiety on reading these lines.
('79', 293, 6, 22, 620094) If God has a fast in store for me, it will surely come and it will bring good in its wake.
('79', 293, 6, 23, 620185) In all things His will be done.
('79', 293, 7, 24, 620217) 1 This appeared under “Notes”.
('79', 293, 7, 25, 620248) 2 This appeared as “translated from Hindustani”, originally published in Harijan Sevak, 12 10 1940. 3 For Gandhiji’s reply to M. M. Malaviya, vide “Letter to M. M. Malaviya”, 25 9 1940
('79', 294, 0, 1, 620433) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 295
('79', 294, 1, 2, 620479) Now what is the place of fasting in satyagraha ?
('79', 294, 1, 3, 620528) Nowadays quite a number of fasts are undertaken in the name of satyagraha.
('79', 294, 1, 4, 620603) Many of the known fasts have been meaningless, many may be said to have been impure.
('79', 294, 1, 5, 620688) Fasting is a fiery weapon.
('79', 294, 1, 6, 620715) It has its own science.
('79', 294, 1, 7, 620739) No one, as far as I am aware, has a perfect knowledge of it.
('79', 294, 1, 8, 620800) Unscientific experimentation with it is bound to be harmful to the one who fasts, and it may even harm the cause espoused.
('79', 294, 1, 9, 620923) 1 No one who has not earned the right to do so should, therefore, use this weapon.
('79', 294, 1, 10, 621006) A fast may only be undertaken by him who is associated with the person against whom he fasts.
('79', 294, 1, 11, 621100) The latter must be directly connected with the purpose for which the fast is being undertaken.
('79', 294, 1, 12, 621195) Bhagat Fulsinghji’s recent fast was such a one.
('79', 294, 1, 13, 621243) He was closely connected with the people of Moth village; he had served the Harijans of the place, too.
('79', 294, 1, 14, 621347) The wrong that was being enacted was done by the villagers to the Harijans.
('79', 294, 1, 15, 621423) When every means of obtaining justice had failed, there was no option left for a man like Fulsinghji except to resort to fasting.
('79', 294, 1, 16, 621553) He did and succeeded.
('79', 294, 1, 17, 621575) 2 Success or failure depends entirely on the will of God and is not relevant to the issue under discussion.
('79', 294, 1, 18, 621683) All my public fasts have been of this category.
('79', 294, 1, 19, 621731) Out of all of them perhaps there is most to be learnt from the Rajkot one.
('79', 294, 1, 20, 621806) It has been roundly condemned by many people.
('79', 294, 1, 21, 621852) Originally it was pure and necessary.
('79', 294, 1, 22, 621890) The blemish crept in when I asked the Viceroy to intervene.
('79', 294, 1, 23, 621950) Had I not done so, I am convinced that its result would have been brilliant.
('79', 294, 1, 24, 622027) Even as it was, the result was a victory for the cause.
('79', 294, 1, 25, 622083) Because God wanted to open my eyes, he took the bread out of my mouth, so to speak.
('79', 294, 1, 26, 622167) The Rajkot fast is thus a useful study for the satyagrahi.
('79', 294, 1, 27, 622226) In regard to its necessity there is no doubt, assuming that the principles for fasting which I have laid down are accepted.
('79', 294, 1, 28, 622350) The important thing to note about it is how a pure undertaking can become tainted owing to lack of watchfulness on the part of the doer.
('79', 294, 1, 29, 622487) There can be no room for selfishness, anger, lack of faith, or impatience in a pure fast.
('79', 294, 1, 30, 622577) It is no exaggeration to admit that all these defects crept into my Rajkot fast.
('79', 294, 1, 31, 622658) My selfishness lay in the fact that, inasmuch as its being given up depended on certain conditions being fulfilled by the late Thakore Saheb, I had in me the selfish desire for the realization of the fruits of my labour.
('79', 294, 1, 32, 622879) If there had been no anger in me, I would not have looked to the Viceroy for assistance.
('79', 294, 1, 33, 622968) My love should have deterred me from
('79', 294, 2, 34, 623005) 1 The Hindi version has: “ .
('79', 294, 2, 35, 623034) and it may harm even other people.” 2 Vide also “Telegram to G. D. Birla”, 21 9 1940
('79', 295, 0, 1, 623119) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 295, 1, 2, 623161) doing so.
('79', 295, 1, 3, 623171) For if he was really as a son to me, why should I have complained about him to his overlord?
('79', 295, 1, 4, 623264) I betrayed want of faith in that I thought the Thakore Saheb would not be melted by my love and I was impatient to break the fast.
('79', 295, 1, 5, 623395) All these shortcomings were bound to make my fast impure.
('79', 295, 1, 6, 623453) It would be irrelevant here to ponder over the many results of the Rajkot fast, and I therefore refrain from doing so.
('79', 295, 1, 7, 623572) But we have learnt how infinietly watchful and prayerful he who fasts has to be and how even a little carelessness can damage a good cause.
('79', 295, 1, 8, 623712) It is now apparent that in addition to truth and non violence a satyagrahi should have the confidence that, God will grant him the necessary strength and that, if there is the slightest impurity in the fast, he will not hesitate to renounce it at once.
('79', 295, 1, 9, 623965) Infinite patience, firm resolve, single mindedness of purpose, perfect calm, and no anger must of necessity be there.

('79', 295, 1, 11, 624272) I should like readers to note that I have not here dealt with fasts undertaken for bodily or spiritual purification.
('79', 295, 1, 12, 624389) Nature cure doctors should be consulted for the former.
('79', 295, 1, 13, 624445) The greatest of sinners can undertake the latter.
('79', 295, 1, 14, 624495) And for this type of fast we possess a veritable mine of literature.
('79', 295, 1, 15, 624564) Fasts for spiritual purification have really been forgotten in our day.
('79', 295, 1, 16, 624636) If they are ever undertaken, they are either purely imitative or merely for the sake of tradition, and we cannot, therefore, derive the benefit from them that we should.
('79', 295, 1, 17, 624806) Those who want to go in for a satyagrahi fast should certainly possess some personal experience of fasts for spiritual purification.
('79', 295, 1, 18, 624939) Fasts for ridding the body of impurities are also beneficial.
('79', 295, 1, 19, 625001) In the end, of course, there is only one basis of the whole ideal of fasting, and that is purification.

('79', 296, 1, 2, 625290) 280. PLAIN LIVING AND HIGH THINKING 1
('79', 296, 2, 3, 625328) An ideal society is that in which every individual will be able to live a life of progressively inereasing wants with a minimum output of labour.
('79', 296, 2, 4, 625474) Thus writes a friend from Ahmedabad.
('79', 296, 2, 5, 625511) The proposition is pleasing and is backed by plausible argument which many may accept.
('79', 296, 2, 6, 625598) The writer forecast that the Viceroy was bound to refuse the Congress proposal.
('79', 296, 2, 7, 625678) 2 He does not believe in the freedom of the individual, and is therefore of opinion that it was only meet that the Viceroy should turn down the proposal.
('79', 296, 2, 8, 625832) Because his forecast turned out correct he may even hold his argument to be sound and say, “I told you so.” It is therefore necessary for me to take note of the letter.
('79', 296, 2, 9, 626001) The writer may not derive any satisfaction from the Viceroy’s refusal.
('79', 296, 2, 10, 626072) 3 All my colleagues had foretold the result.
('79', 296, 2, 11, 626117) But I wanted to go not so much in the expectation of getting acceptance as, in the event of failure, to return with added strength.
('79', 296, 2, 12, 626249) Nor does the rejection of the proposal mean in any sense that the Viceroy does not believe in individual freedom.
('79', 296, 2, 13, 626363) Britain has not gone that length.
('79', 296, 2, 14, 626397) Europe has no doubt entered upon a new phase in denying individual liberty.
('79', 296, 2, 15, 626473) If this goes, then surely all is lost, for, if the individual ceases to count, what is left of society?
('79', 296, 2, 16, 626577) Individual freedom alone can make a man voluntarily surrender himself completely to the service of society.
('79', 296, 2, 17, 626685) If it is wrested from him, he becomes an automaton and society is ruined.
('79', 296, 2, 18, 626759) No society can possibly be built on a denial of individual freedom.
('79', 296, 2, 19, 626827) It is contrary to the very nature of man.
('79', 296, 2, 20, 626869) Just as a man will not grow horns or a tail, so he will not become an animal with no mind of his own.
('79', 296, 2, 21, 626971) In reality even those who do not believe in the liberty of the individual believe in their own.
('79', 296, 2, 22, 627067) Modern editions of Chenghiz Khan retain their own.
('79', 296, 2, 23, 627118) Just as the writer’s ideas on individual liberty are impossible, so also is his other theory.
('79', 296, 2, 24, 627212) That everyone in this world should be able to maintain as high a standard of life as possible with the least possible
('79', 296, 3, 25, 627330) 1This appeared as “translated from Gujarati”, originally published in Harijanbandhu, 12 10 1940. 2 The Gujarati version has: “.
('79', 296, 3, 26, 627458) my proposal.” 3 The Gujarati version adds: “It is never assumed that such demands will be acceded to.”
('79', 297, 0, 1, 627561) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 297, 1, 2, 627603) output of labour is just as fantastic as to expect a camel to pass through the eye of a needle.
('79', 297, 1, 3, 627699) The writer’s high living would appear to mean luxurious living which is an impossible proposition for any society as a whole.
('79', 297, 1, 4, 627825) And when there is no limit to luxury where shall we stop ?
('79', 297, 1, 5, 627884) All the scriptures of the world have taught the exact opposite.
('79', 297, 1, 6, 627948) Plain living and high thinking is the ideal that has been placed before us.
('79', 297, 1, 7, 628024) The vast majority recognize its truth but are unable to get there because of human frailty.
('79', 297, 1, 8, 628116) It is, however, perfectly possible to envisage such an existence.
('79', 297, 1, 9, 628182) That the crores in India should be guaranteed a certain income is only right, and to achieve this ideal large scale machinery is not only not necessary but wholly destructive.
('79', 297, 2, 10, 628358) Man falls from the pursuit of the ideal of plain living and high thinking the moment he wants to multiply his daily wants.
('79', 297, 2, 11, 628481) History gives ample proof of this.
('79', 297, 2, 12, 628516) Man’s happiness really lies in contentment.
('79', 297, 2, 13, 628560) He who is discontented, however much he possesses, becomes a slave to his desires.
('79', 297, 2, 14, 628643) And there is really no slavery equal to that of his desires.
('79', 297, 2, 15, 628704) All the sages have declared from the house tops that man can be his own worst enemy as well as his best friend.
('79', 297, 2, 16, 628816) To be free or to be a slave lies in his own hands.
('79', 297, 2, 17, 628867) And what is true for the individual is true for society.
('79', 297, 3, 18, 628924) SEVAGRAM, October 9 3, 1940

('79', 298, 2, 3, 629246) ‘A STAB IN THE BACK’?
('79', 298, 3, 4, 629268) I have read Sir Sikandar Hyat’s reported speech 1 on the correspondence between H.E. the Viceroy and myself.
('79', 298, 3, 5, 629377) I was sorry for it.
('79', 298, 3, 6, 629397) Where is the stab in the back when everything is done openly after full discussion and with the utmost consideration for the party affected?
('79', 298, 3, 7, 629538) He is a bad advocate who overproves his case, and I promise that Sir Sikandar will be proved as such.
('79', 298, 3, 8, 629640) Sir Sikandar says that ninety nine per cent of the Punjab is for participation in the war.
('79', 298, 3, 9, 629731) No doubt he is a popularly elected member of the Punjab Assembly, and he is the undisputed Premier of the Punjab.
('79', 298, 3, 10, 629845) Nevertheless it is a big claim that he puts forth for the Punjab.
('79', 298, 3, 11, 629911) Sir Sikandar’s cause will lose nothing by being true to facts.
('79', 298, 3, 12, 629974) And the facts are that the Punjab has been one of the best recruiting grounds for the British rulers.
('79', 298, 3, 13, 630076) This does not necessarily prove that the Punjab is the most patriotic of the provinces.
('79', 298, 3, 14, 630164) In this vast country of ours there are many professions.
('79', 298, 3, 15, 630221) Soldiering is one of them.
('79', 298, 3, 16, 630248) These professionals will lend their services to whomsoever will pay them good wages and enough practice for their profession.
('79', 298, 3, 17, 630374) Therefore, in my opinion, Sir Sikandar can prove no more than that the Punjab has the pride of place so far as the recruiting ground for the British is concerned.
('79', 298, 3, 18, 630537) But the Punjabi soldier is as much interested in the issue as the black soldiers trained by General Franco were interested in his politics or in his ambition.
('79', 298, 3, 19, 630696) They served him because of the pay and the practice in the use of arms which he offered them.
('79', 298, 3, 20, 630790) But politically speaking, if Sir Sikandar can claim that ninety nine per cent of the Punjab is for participation in the war, it can be claimed with much greater force perhaps that ninety 
('79', 298, 4, 21, 630978) 1 According to The Indian Annual Register, 1940, Vol. II, pp.
('79', 298, 4, 22, 631040) 31 2 and 40, Sikandar Hyat Khan, “addressing a gathering of ryots at Nuh (Gurgaon District) on October 1, said that Mahatma Gandhi was among the first Indians to denounce Hitler’s acts of aggression and to declare that his sympathy lay entirely on the side of Britain in this war.
('79', 298, 4, 23, 631321) Since that declaration was made the Congress had been changing its position from time to time until at last Mahatma had formulated his demand for freedom to carry on propaganda against participation in the war.” Addressing another meeting at Lahore on November 1, in connection with the “Muslim Countries Day”, Sikandar, “took the opportunity to elaborate his charges against Mahatma Gandhi”.
('79', 298, 4, 24, 631714) He said: “Mahatma’s campaign amounted not only to stabbing Britain in the back but also a betrayal of the best interests of India and the Islamic world.”

('79', 299, 1, 2, 631910) nine per cent of the seven provinces where the Congress has an over whelming majority are against such participation.

('79', 299, 2, 6, 632306) AUSTRALIAN SOLDIERS
('79', 299, 3, 7, 632326) The Mayor of Bombay has sent me a letter complaining of my reference 1 to him as if he had neglected his duty as the first citizen of Bombay.
('79', 299, 3, 8, 632468) He tells me too that he acted in the promptest manner possible and entered into correspondence with the Government.
('79', 299, 3, 9, 632584) As a responsible citizen he could not rush to the Press or inform the public what he was doing.
('79', 299, 3, 10, 632680) All this is creditable to the Mayor.
('79', 299, 3, 11, 632717) I know him to be business like and anxious to render service without fuss.
('79', 299, 3, 12, 632792) But it is strange that he has read a meaning into my writing which the context shows I could not have meant.
('79', 299, 3, 13, 632901) I have put to him the same question that I have put to all the other parties concerned.
('79', 299, 3, 14, 632989) Surely I must not be taken to have cast any reflection on any single one of them.
('79', 299, 3, 15, 633071) For aught I know they might have taken effective steps without my warning.
('79', 299, 3, 16, 633146) When a series of complaints came to me from various sources, I was found to draw attention to them and show how, from a private citizen to the Governor, the various units in a society would be expected to act in emergencies of the character described by me.
('79', 299, 3, 17, 633404) The latter might, if not handled effectively and in time, give rise to a first class crisis ending in an exhibition of racial passions of a most undesirable type.
('79', 299, 3, 18, 633567) I am happy, therefore, to note that almost all parties seem to have acted as they should have.
('79', 299, 3, 19, 633662) A college girl, who was among the first to complain to me, tells me that, whilst there is no doubt about the general truth of the complaints, the improper behaviour stopped after a few days.
('79', 299, 3, 20, 633853) She tells me that it had stopped altogether before my writing appeared in the Press.
('79', 299, 3, 21, 633938) Whilst, therefore, I am not sorry for what I wrote, as I should have in the public interest, it gives me as much pleasure to note that the mischief was nipped in the bud, as it had caused me pain to give publicity to it.
('79', 299, 3, 22, 634159) I am no believer in a hush hush policy.
('79', 299, 3, 23, 634199) Such incidents, if they are not to be repeated, demand publicity and an effective and immediate remedy.

('79', 305, 1, 2, 641567) 290. CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('79', 305, 2, 3, 641591) I have had three days’ discussion 1 with the Working Committee.
('79', 305, 2, 4, 641655) During it I unfolded my plan of civil disobedience in so far as I was able to envisage it.
('79', 305, 2, 5, 641746) Although I have sole charge of the campaign, I could not think of taking the first step without consulta tion with the members of the Working Committee.
('79', 305, 2, 6, 641899) In non violent action one has to carry the co workers with one through the mind and the heart.
('79', 305, 2, 7, 641994) There is no other way to enforce discipline or obedience to instructions.
('79', 305, 2, 8, 642068) I must admit that it was not plain sailing for me.
('79', 305, 2, 9, 642119) There was stubborn dissent from two members.
('79', 305, 2, 10, 642164) I tried hard to carry conviction to them but I fear I failed.
('79', 305, 2, 11, 642226) They will, however, yield obedience so far as it is possible for them for the sake of discipline.
('79', 305, 2, 12, 642324) The difference of opinion solely centred round the quantity of civil disobedience and the restrictions with which it was hedged.
('79', 305, 2, 13, 642453) I disclose this part of the discussion to show that my plan will fall short of the expectations of those whom the dissenters represent.
('79', 305, 2, 14, 642589) I would simply say to them, ‘Wait patiently and see what happens.
('79', 305, 2, 15, 642655) Carry out instructions to the best of your ability.
('79', 305, 2, 16, 642707) Do nothing to thwart the plan.
('79', 305, 2, 17, 642738) If your reason rebels against it, you will serve the cause by seceding and educating the people along your own lines.
('79', 305, 2, 18, 642856) That would be straight, brave and stimulating, in that the people will learn to appraise the value of different methods.
('79', 305, 2, 19, 642977) You will cause confusion by preaching from the Congress platform anything contrary to the official programme, especially when the whole organization becomes like an army.
('79', 305, 2, 20, 643148) It matters little whether one person offers civil disobedi ence or many.
('79', 305, 2, 21, 643221) The rest have to render such support as they may be called upon to do.’ The plan is simply this.
('79', 305, 2, 22, 643318) Direct action will be commenced by Shri Vinoba Bhave and for the time being confined to him only.
('79', 305, 2, 23, 643416) And since it is to be confined to individual civil disobedience and that too of him only, it will be so conducted by him as to exclude others directly or indirectly.
('79', 305, 2, 24, 643582) But since it is concerned with freedom of speech, the public will be involved to an extent.
('79', 305, 2, 25, 643674) It is open to them either to listen to him or not.
('79', 305, 2, 26, 643725) But much will depend upon what the Government wish to do.
('79', 305, 2, 27, 643783) In spite of all attempt to confine civil disobedience to individuals and for the moment to one only, they can precipitate a crisis by making it a
('79', 305, 3, 28, 643929) 1 From October 11 to 13
('79', 306, 0, 1, 643953) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 307
('79', 306, 1, 2, 643999) crime to listen to him or read anything written by him.
('79', 306, 1, 3, 644055) But I think and believe that they do not want to invite any trouble, though they hold themselves in readiness to cope with every trouble that may face them.
('79', 306, 1, 4, 644212) I have discussed with Shri Vinoba various plans so as to avoid all unnecessary friction or risks.
('79', 306, 1, 5, 644310) The idea is to make all action as strictly non violent as is humanly possible.
('79', 306, 1, 6, 644389) One man’s violence, veiled or open, cannot go beyond a certain limit, but within that limit it would be effective.
('79', 306, 1, 7, 644504) One man’s non violent action would be despised and ridiculed by the non believer in it.
('79', 306, 1, 8, 644592) In truth, while the effect of a given violent action can be reduced to mathematical terms, that of non violent action defies all calculation and has been known to falsify many that have been hazarded.
('79', 306, 1, 9, 644793) How far I shall be able to present an example of unadulterated non violence remains to be seen.
('79', 306, 1, 10, 644889) Who is Vinoba Bhave and why has he been selected?
('79', 306, 1, 11, 644939) He is an undergraduate having left college after my return to India in 1915 1. He is a Sanskrit scholar.
('79', 306, 1, 12, 645044) He joined the Ashram 2 almost at its inception.
('79', 306, 1, 13, 645092) He was among the first members.
('79', 306, 1, 14, 645124) In order to better qualify himself he took one year’s leave to prosecute further studies in Sanskrit.
('79', 306, 1, 15, 645226) And, practically at the same hour at which he had left the Ashram a year before, he walked into it without notice.
('79', 306, 1, 16, 645341) I had forgotten that he was due to arrive that day.
('79', 306, 1, 17, 645393) He has taken part in every menial activity of the Ashram from scavenging to cooking.
('79', 306, 1, 18, 645478) Though he has a marvellous memory and is a student by nature, he has devoted the largest part of his time to spinning in which he has specialized as very few have.
('79', 306, 1, 19, 645642) He believes in universal spinning being the central activity which will remove the poverty in the villages and put life into their deadness.
('79', 306, 1, 20, 645783) Being a born teacher he has been of the utmost assistance to Ashadevi 3
('79', 306, 2, 21, 645855) in her development of the scheme of education through handicrafts.
('79', 306, 2, 22, 645922) Shri Vinoba has produced a text book taking spinning as the handicraft.
('79', 306, 2, 23, 645994) It is original in conception.
('79', 306, 2, 24, 646024) He has made scoffers realize that spinning is the handicraft par excellence which lends itself to being effectively used for basic education.
('79', 306, 2, 25, 646166) He has revolutionized takli spinning and drawn out its hitherto unknown possibilities.
('79', 306, 2, 26, 646253) For perfect spinning probably he has no rival in all India.
('79', 306, 2, 27, 646313) He has abolished every trace of untouchability from his heart.
('79', 306, 2, 28, 646376) He believes in communal unity with the same passion that I have.
('79', 306, 3, 29, 646441) 1 The source, however, has “1916”.
('79', 306, 3, 30, 646476) 2 On June 7, 1916 3 Ashadevi Aryanayakam
('79', 307, 0, 1, 646517) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 307, 1, 2, 646559) order to know the best mind of Islam he gave one year to the study of the Koran in the original.
('79', 307, 1, 3, 646656) He therefore learnt Arabic.
('79', 307, 1, 4, 646684) He found this study necessary for cultivating a living contact with the Muslims living in his neighbourhood.
('79', 307, 1, 5, 646793) He has an army of disciples and workers who would rise to any sacrifice at his bidding.
