('79', 307, 2, 7, 646927) who has dedicated himself to the service of lepers.
('79', 307, 2, 8, 646979) Though an utter stranger to medicine this worker has by singular devotion mastered the method of treatment of lepers and is now running several clinics for their care.
('79', 307, 2, 9, 647147) Hundreds owe their cure to his labours.
('79', 307, 2, 10, 647187) He has now published a handbook in Marathi for the treatment of lepers.
('79', 307, 2, 11, 647259) Vinoba was for years Director of the Mahila Ashram in Wardha.
('79', 307, 2, 12, 647321) His devotion to the cause of Daridranarayana took him first to a village near Wardha, and now he has gone still further and lives in Paunar, five miles from Wardha, from where he has established contact with villages through the disciples he has trained.
('79', 307, 2, 13, 647576) He believes in the necessity of the political independence of India.
('79', 307, 2, 14, 647645) He is an accurate student of history.
('79', 307, 2, 15, 647683) But he believes that real independence of the villagers is impossible without the constructive programme of which khadi is the centre.
('79', 307, 2, 16, 647818) He believes that the charkha is the most suitable outward symbol of non violence which has become an integral part of his life.
('79', 307, 2, 17, 647946) He has taken an active part in the previous satyagraha campaigns.
('79', 307, 2, 18, 648012) He has never been in the limelight on the political platform.
('79', 307, 2, 19, 648074) With many co workers he believes that silent constructive work with civil disobedience in the background is far more effective than the already heavily crowded political platform.
('79', 307, 2, 20, 648254) And he thoroughly believes that non violent resistance is impossible without a heart belief in and practice of constructive work.
('79', 307, 2, 21, 648384) Vinoba is an out and out war resister.
('79', 307, 2, 22, 648423) But he respects equally with his own the conscience of those who, whilst not being out and out war resisters, have yet strong conscientious objection to participation in the present war.
('79', 307, 2, 23, 648610) Though Vinoba represents both the types, I may want to select another who will represent only one type, namely, conscientious objection to participation in the present war.
('79', 307, 2, 24, 648783) It was necessary to introduce Vinoba at length to the public in order to justify my choice.
('79', 307, 2, 25, 648875) This will perhaps be the last civil disobedience struggle which I shall have conducted.
('79', 307, 2, 26, 648963) Naturally I would
('79', 307, 3, 27, 648981) 1 Manohar Divan
('79', 308, 0, 1, 648997) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 309
('79', 308, 1, 2, 649043) want it to be as flawless as it can be.
('79', 308, 1, 3, 649083) Moreover the Congress has declared that it will avoid all avoidable embarrassment to the Govern ment consistently with its own existence.
('79', 308, 1, 4, 649221) For that reason too I had to strive to produce the highest quality irrespective of quantity.
('79', 308, 1, 5, 649314) But Vinoba must fail, as I must, if we do not represent the Congress, let alone the whole nation.
('79', 308, 1, 6, 649412) And we shall certainly not represent either if they do not give us full hearted co operation which is ceaseless prosecution of the constructive programme.
('79', 308, 1, 7, 649567) It is not vocal co operation that is required.
('79', 308, 1, 8, 649614) It is co operation in work that is needed.
('79', 308, 1, 9, 649657) The signs of such co operation will be phenomenal progress in spinning, complete disappearance of untouchability, an increasing friendliness between communities, and an increasing sense of justice in every walk of life.
('79', 308, 1, 10, 649877) Unless rock bottom justice and equality pervade society, surely there is no non violent atmosphere.
('79', 308, 1, 11, 649977) Above all there should be no civil disobedience but what is sanctioned by me.
('79', 308, 1, 12, 650055) This is peremptory obligation binding on every Congressman.
('79', 308, 1, 13, 650115) If it is disregarded, there is no co operation.
('79', 308, 1, 14, 650163) The representative character belonging to Vinoba and me is then challenged.
('79', 308, 1, 15, 650239) And I can say with confidence that, if the full hearted co operation I want is forthcoming, not only will the issue of freedom of speech be decided in our favour but we shall have gone very near independence.
('79', 308, 1, 16, 650448) Let those who will, take me at my word.
('79', 308, 1, 17, 650488) They will have lost nothing and will find that they had contributed greatly to the movement of freedom through truthful and non violent means.
('79', 308, 1, 18, 650631) Let me repeat the issue.
('79', 308, 1, 19, 650656) On the surface it is incredibly narrow— the right to preach against war as war or participation in the present war.
('79', 308, 1, 20, 650772) Both are matters of conscience for those who hold either view.
('79', 308, 1, 21, 650835) Both are substantial rights.
('79', 308, 1, 22, 650864) Their exercise can do no harm to the British if their pretension that to all intents and purposes India is an independent country is at all true.
('79', 308, 1, 23, 651010) If India is very much a dependency in fact as it is in law, whatever the British get from India can never be regarded as voluntary, it must be regarded as impressed.
('79', 308, 1, 24, 651176) This battle of life and death cannot be won by impressed levies, however large.
('79', 308, 1, 25, 651256) They may win if they have the moral backing of an India truly regarded as free.
('79', 308, 1, 26, 651336) Non violent Congress cannot wish ill to Britain.
('79', 308, 1, 27, 651385) Nor can it help her through arms since it seeks to gain her own freedom not through arms but through unadulterated non violence.
('79', 308, 1, 28, 651514) And the Congress vanishes if, at the crucial moment, it suppresses itself for fear of consequences or otherwise by ceasing to preach non violence through
('79', 309, 0, 1, 651668) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 309, 1, 2, 651710) non violent means.
('79', 309, 1, 3, 651729) So when we probe the issue deep enough we discover that it is a matter of life and death for us.
('79', 309, 1, 4, 651826) If we vindicate that right, all is well with us.
('79', 309, 1, 5, 651875) If we do not, all is lost.
('79', 309, 1, 6, 651902) We cannot then win swaraj through non violent means.
('79', 309, 1, 7, 651955) I know that India has not one mind.
('79', 309, 1, 8, 651991) There is a part of India that is war minded and will learn the art of war through helping the British.
('79', 309, 1, 9, 652094) The Congress has no desire, therefore, to surround ammunition factories or barracks and prevent people from doing what they like.
('79', 309, 1, 10, 652224) We want to tell the people of India that, if they will win swaraj through non violent means, they may not co operate militarily with Britain in the prosecution of the war.
('79', 309, 1, 11, 652396) This right of preaching against participation in the war is being denied to us, and we have to fight against the denial.
('79', 309, 1, 12, 652517) Therefore, while that right will be exercised only by those whom I may select for the purpose, all the other activities of the Congress will continue as before unless the Government interfere with them.
('79', 309, 1, 13, 652720) A question has been asked why, if I attach so much importance to quality, I do not offer civil resistance myself.
('79', 309, 1, 14, 652834) I have already said that unlike as on previous occasions I do not wish to do so for the very good reason that my imprisonment is likely to cause greater embarrassment to the authorities than anything else the Congress can do.
('79', 309, 1, 15, 653060) I want also to remain outside to cope with any contingency that may arise.
('79', 309, 1, 16, 653135) My going to jail may be interpreted as a general invitation to all Congressmen to follow suit.
('79', 309, 1, 17, 653230) They will not easily distinguish between my act and speech.
('79', 309, 1, 18, 653290) Lastly, I do not know how things will shape.
('79', 309, 1, 19, 653335) I myself do not know the next step.
('79', 309, 1, 20, 653371) I do not know the Government plan.
('79', 309, 1, 21, 653406) I am a man of faith.
('79', 309, 1, 22, 653427) My reliance is solely on God.
('79', 309, 1, 23, 653457) One step is enough for me.
('79', 309, 1, 24, 653484) The next He will make clear to me when the time for it comes.
('79', 309, 1, 25, 653546) And who knows that I shall not be an instrument for bringing about peace not only between Britain and India but also between the warring nations of the earth.
('79', 309, 1, 26, 653705) This last wish will not be taken for vanity by those who believe that my faith is not a sham but a reality greater than the fact that I am penning these lines.
('79', 309, 1, 27, 653865) SEVAGRAM, October 15, 1940

('79', 310, 1, 2, 653958) 291. A BRITISH ENDORSEMENT
('79', 310, 2, 3, 653985) Mr. Stephen J. Thorne, Secretary to the Society of Friends, sends me the following letter:
('79', 310, 3, 4, 654076) We, a group of friends, want to send you our deep gratitude for your impressive appeal 1 to every Briton to adopt the way of non violence and bring about a cessation of hostilities.
('79', 310, 3, 5, 654258) We drew together immediately on receiving the short version of your statement, and were later able to obtain a fuller text.
('79', 310, 3, 6, 654382) You have received through the Viceroy the response of the British Government to your proffer of help, a response that from your knowledge of the situation you will easily understand.
('79', 310, 3, 7, 654565) To most Britons the call to throw down their arms in a moment of supreme national peril and in face of imminent aggression is indistinguishable from cowardice and treason 2; it is an invitation to save their lives by the surrender of principles of liberty and justice that are dearer than life itself.
('79', 310, 3, 8, 654867) But to those of us who in the peace movement share your faith in non violence, you present a tremendous challenge.
('79', 310, 3, 9, 654982) Few of us are fully prepared to stand up to it; and we are conscious of our own failure to convince our fellow countrymen of the value and practicability of this “more excellent way”.
('79', 310, 3, 10, 655166) The technique of non violent resistance as you have practised it is little understood in the West, especially in its positive and reconciling sense; and for that reason apart from any other, your appeal has not yet met with any wide response.
('79', 310, 3, 11, 655409) Though the British Government’s reply must have been disappointing, we are anxious to make full use of your offered help.
('79', 310, 3, 12, 655531) Your appeal gave expression to a spirit that is moving, we are certain, in the hearts of men all over the world.
('79', 310, 3, 13, 655644) We believe that it would be a step forward if you were willing to address a further message to certain of the spiritual leaders of the world, urging them to act together in taking hold of the situation before the winter brings fresh disaster.
('79', 310, 3, 14, 655887) We hope you will maintain the closest contact with us, sending direct the full text of anything you may say in the days ahead.
('79', 310, 4, 15, 656014) Your friends sincerely, HORACE G. ALEXANDER PERCY W. BARTLETT ANNA BIDDER W. MAUDE BRAYSHAW ROBERT DAVIS A. RUTH FRY CARL HEATH ELIZABETH FOX HOWARD JAMES H. HUDSON FRANCIS E. POLLARD J. CUTHBERT WIGHAM ALEXANDER C. WILSON
('79', 310, 5, 16, 656237) 1Vide “To Every Briton” 2 The source has “reason”, evidently a misprint.

('79', 311, 2, 2, 656352) The Council of Christian Pacifist Groups associates itself with this letter, and looks forward to all early opportunity of discussing the deep issues involved.
('79', 311, 2, 3, 656512) I am thankful to the signatories for their support of my appeal.
('79', 311, 2, 4, 656577) I can assure them that immediately I see the psychological moment, I shall act up to the signatories’ expectation that I should address the spiritual leaders of the world.
('79', 311, 2, 5, 656749) It is quite evident that the very thoroughness of the Nazi method makes them think that nothing but counter violence can check the terror.
('79', 311, 2, 6, 656888) I have suggested that counter violence can only result in further brutalization of human nature.
('79', 311, 2, 7, 656985) Drastic diseases require drastic remedies.
('79', 311, 2, 8, 657028) In this instance nothing but non violence can cure Nazi violence.

('79', 312, 3, 5, 658560) 293. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU”
('79', 312, 4, 6, 658590) October 16, 1940
('79', 312, 5, 7, 658607) In answer to the question, how the present movement would differ from the Salt Satyagraha 1 and, particularly, whether his anxiety not to embarrass the British Government would be the major or even the governing factor in his calculations, Gandhiji replied: It will be the prime factor in every one of my calculations.
('79', 312, 6, 8, 658926) Gandhiji was next asked if he had at he back of his mind the sense of contrast between India and the Dominions, where General Hertzog 2 and Mr. De Valera 3 could preach neutrality or opposition to participation in war but were still free, Gandhiji said: Of course the contrast is painful, so much so that every time British declarations are tested, they prove valueless.
('79', 312, 7, 9, 659297) In reply to a question whether there was any significance in the fact that he had waited until after the Viceroy had rejected the Poona offer and whether he was leading both types of Congressmen, those who agreed with Gandhiji that all wars were violations of the principle of non violence, and those who thought that the rejection of the idea of a National Government compelled them to oppose participation in this war, Gandhiji observed: There is no significance in it so far as I am concerned, but I am representing both types.
('79', 312, 8, 10, 659828) While civil disobedience will proceed on the lines laid down by him, Gandhiji said that the rank and file of Congressmen would concentrate on the constructive programme and absolutely no relaxation in this work was contemplated by him.
('79', 312, 8, 11, 660064) Referring to his premonition about another fast, Gandhiji said: Under what circumstances and on what occasion I shall resort to it I do not know.
('79', 312, 8, 12, 660210) In saying this, I have no mental reservations.
('79', 312, 9, 13, 660257) 1 Of March 12, 1930 2 James B. M. Hertzog, Prime Minister of South Africa, 1924 1939 3 Eamon De Valera, Prime Minister of Ireland, who later became the President
('79', 313, 0, 1, 660419) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 313, 1, 2, 660461) to avoid fast.
('79', 313, 2, 3, 660476) Regarding the charge of inconsistency between his attitude at the commencement of the war and now, he stated that he had already made 2 this point clear.
('79', 313, 2, 4, 660630) He said: It is a different position which faces me now and it would be illogical to ask that the Congress must perform hara kiri.
('79', 313, 2, 5, 660760) Freedom would be used to give moral support to Britain, India would want Britain to succeed—a Britain which has played the game by India.
('79', 313, 3, 6, 660898) Never, he emphasized, would there be the slightest interference with those
('79', 313, 4, 7, 660973) who want to give Britain active support.

('79', 317, 6, 12, 665774) 302. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('79', 317, 7, 13, 665805) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, October 20, 1940
('79', 317, 8, 14, 665840) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, I am exceedingly obliged to you for your telegram 2. I had hoped that the instructions issued were merely local.
('79', 317, 8, 15, 665975) Since sending you my telegram I have had further news that News Agencies had been informed that they were not to distribute my messages directly as they have done hitherto, but that all such messages were to be sent to headquarters at Delhi for censorship before they were distributed.
('79', 317, 8, 16, 666261) I also send you herewith a copy of notices received by registered publications.
('79', 317, 8, 17, 666341) I should like to keep the public informed of the development of individual civil disobedience which is being carried on under my strict supervision.
('79', 317, 8, 18, 666490) In view of the notice, I dread to send anything for printing to the local printing Press, for if I did
('79', 317, 9, 19, 666593) 1 After Vinoba Bhave, who began the individual civil disobedience on October 17, 1940 2 This was from the Private Secretary to the Viceroy; vide footnote 1, “Telegram to Ruiker and Others”, 17 10 1940
('79', 318, 0, 1, 666794) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 319
('79', 318, 1, 2, 666840) send anything and the order were accepted, the local printing Press, which is purely a commercial concern, may come in for penalty.
('79', 318, 1, 3, 666972) For the same reason I have hesitated to send any public statement.
('79', 318, 1, 4, 667039) My chief motive in sending such statements would be to regularize the movement so as to ensure unadulterated non violence.
('79', 318, 1, 5, 667162) Up to now the response has been fully up to expectation.
('79', 318, 1, 6, 667219) I was not certain about the Trade Union Congress.
('79', 318, 1, 7, 667269) But its President who came to see me has assured me that no strike of a political nature will be resorted to without my consent.
('79', 318, 1, 8, 667398) Shri Vinoba Bhave’s addresses are from the highest plane.
('79', 318, 1, 9, 667456) 1 I have been sending Mahadev Desai to follow him and give me a full report of what he says.
('79', 318, 1, 10, 667549) He is a strict disciplinarian and therefore will carry out most difficult instructions.
('79', 318, 1, 11, 667637) His first extempore speech was not as I would have delivered it.
('79', 318, 1, 12, 667702) Living in seclusion he had not followed closely the correspondence between us.
('79', 318, 1, 13, 667781) He had, therefore, put the worst construction on it.
('79', 318, 1, 14, 667834) I immediately sent him instructions that our code was to put the most favourable construction on the opponent’s language.
('79', 318, 1, 15, 667956) He accepted the correction and made the earliest amends by making a public admission.
('79', 318, 1, 16, 668042) And his address of yesterday was unexceptionable.
('79', 318, 1, 17, 668092) His main work, whilst he is free, will be to emphasize the necessity of the constructive programme and not to bother about civil disobedience (which will, for the moment, be confined to himself) being offered by others.
('79', 318, 1, 18, 668312) All this development I would like Congressmen and the public at large to know.
('79', 318, 1, 19, 668391) It is an education in courteous and non violent conduct.
('79', 318, 1, 20, 668448) And although we are ‘at war’ with each other we might observe the law which I claim specially belongs to the human species.
('79', 318, 1, 21, 668572) But I know that the decision rests with you.
('79', 318, 1, 22, 668617) I can only plead.
('79', 318, 3, 23, 668635) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('79', 318, 4, 24, 668665) From a copy: C.W. 7582. Courtesy: G. D. Birla

('79', 321, 7, 9, 672118) 308. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('79', 321, 8, 10, 672146) October 21, 1940
('79', 321, 9, 11, 672163) Mr. Vinoba Bhave was arrested after three this morning.
('79', 321, 9, 12, 672219) This was to be expected.
('79', 321, 9, 13, 672244) I have not advised hartal but have not discouraged spontaneous closing of shops.
('79', 321, 9, 14, 672325) I could not for instance disregard the wishes of managers of the numerous institutions of Wardha which bear Mr. Vinoba’s indelible impress.
('79', 321, 9, 15, 672465) No suspension of work would take place without the willing consent of employers.
('79', 321, 9, 16, 672546) Congressmen should not be impatient about the next step.
('79', 321, 9, 17, 672603) Every imprisonment in individual civil disobedience is a complete step in itself.
('79', 321, 9, 18, 672685) The plan this time is not to have a continuous stream of resisters.
('79', 321, 9, 19, 672753) I am making note of names that are sent to me.
('79', 321, 9, 20, 672800) But senders should not suspend their normal activities.
('79', 321, 9, 21, 672856) There is little chance of my calling them.
('79', 321, 9, 22, 672899) I am not going to invite anyone who does not believe in spinning and khaddar as visible emblems of non violence and removal of the last trace of untouchability and establishment of communal unity as obvious symbols of non violence.
('79', 321, 9, 23, 673131) Nor will all such who are so equipped be necessarily invited.
('79', 321, 9, 24, 673193) The question before me is not whom to send next but to know how the millions react to his imprisonment.
('79', 321, 9, 25, 673297) How many does he represent?
('79', 321, 9, 26, 673325) Those who hug untouchability and regard communal unity as impossible or who believe neither in the charkha nor in the other village industries and, therefore, in the regeneration of the six hundred thousand villages—for such Mr. Vinoba is of no use.
('79', 321, 9, 27, 673575) In their estimation he must be a hindrance to the political, economic and social advance of India.
('79', 321, 9, 28, 673674) And yet without the Congress vindicating its elementary right of preaching non violence at this crucial hour there will be no independence for India.
('79', 321, 9, 29, 673824) Britain’s claim to fight for
('79', 322, 0, 1, 673853) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 323
('79', 322, 1, 2, 673899) democracy is being shattered at every step.
('79', 322, 1, 3, 673943) There is no democracy in India.
('79', 322, 1, 4, 673975) Indians remain, in the words of an Englishman, what they have always been—helots of empire.
('79', 322, 1, 5, 674067) But success in the non violent Congress fight for freedom must mean success for real democracy throughout the world.
('79', 322, 1, 6, 674184) It must mean freedom for the Europeans in Europe and for all the non white races of the earth.
('79', 322, 1, 7, 674279) Such success must not be a camouflage.
('79', 322, 1, 8, 674318) It must be the clearest possible demonstration of non violence.
('79', 322, 1, 9, 674382) The result aimed at is extraordinary.
('79', 322, 1, 10, 674420) The remedy, too, must, therefore, be equally extraordinary.
('79', 322, 1, 11, 674480) It is for Congressmen to show now by their action whether they believe in the non violent method as I have placed it before them and whether they will act up to their belief.
('79', 322, 2, 12, 674655) The Hitavada, 23 10 1940

('79', 327, 11, 14, 681000) 319. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 2
('79', 327, 12, 15, 681030) WARDHA, October 24, 1940
('79', 327, 13, 16, 681055) On the 18th instant the Editor of Harijan received the following notice from the District Magistrate’s Office, Poona:
('79', 327, 14, 17, 681173) I am directed by Government to advise you that no account of incidents leading up to satyagraha by Vinoba Bhave and no report of his speeches or any subsequent developments should be published without previous reference to the Chief Press Adviser, Delhi.
('79', 327, 14, 18, 681428) I would like to bring to your notice that this is in your own interest to avoid prosecution under Rule 38 of the Defence of India Rules.
('79', 327, 14, 19, 681565) Thereupon I entered into correspondence 3 with H. E. the Viceroy.
('79', 327, 14, 20, 681631) Correspondence is still going on.
('79', 327, 14, 21, 681665) But it is necessary for me to take a decision today for, if I did not, there my be waste of public money.
('79', 327, 14, 22, 681771) In view of the reply hitherto received, I have no course left
('79', 327, 15, 23, 681833) 1Vide also “To Satyagrahis” 2 This appeared under the title “Why Suspension.” 3 Vide “Telegram to Private Secretary to Viceroy”, 17 10 1940 and “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 20 10 1940
('79', 328, 0, 1, 682017) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 329
('79', 328, 1, 2, 682063) open but to suspend publication of Harijan, Harijanbandhu and Harijan Sevak.
('79', 328, 1, 3, 682140) I cannot function freely if I have to send to the Press Adviser at New Delhi every line I write about satyagraha.
('79', 328, 1, 4, 682254) It is true that the notice is only advisory, and that therefore I am not bound to act up to it.
('79', 328, 1, 5, 682350) But the consequence of disregard of advice is also stated in the notice.
('79', 328, 1, 6, 682423) I have no desire to risk a prosecution against the Editors.
('79', 328, 1, 7, 682483) The three weeklies have been conducted in the interest of truth and therefore of all parties concerned.
('79', 328, 1, 8, 682587) But I cannot serve that interest if the editing has to be done under threat of prosecution.
('79', 328, 1, 9, 682679) Liberty of the Press is a dear privilege, apart from the advisability or otherwise of civil disobedience.
('79', 328, 1, 10, 682785) The Government have shown their intention clearly by the prosecution of Shri Vinoba Bhave.
('79', 328, 1, 11, 682876) I have no complaint to make against the prosecution.
('79', 328, 1, 12, 682929) It was an inevitable result of the Defence of India Rules.
('79', 328, 1, 13, 682988) But the liberty of the Press stands on a different footing.
('79', 328, 1, 14, 683048) I am unable to reconcile myself to the notice which although in the nature of advice, is in reality an order whose infringement will carry its own consequence.
('79', 328, 1, 15, 683208) I am sorry to have to disappoint the numerous readers of the three weeklies.
('79', 328, 1, 16, 683285) Next week I shall be able to let the public know whether it is to be merely a suspension or an indefinite stopping of the three weeklies.
('79', 328, 1, 17, 683423) I shall still hope that it will be merely a suspension and that my fear will prove to be groundless.
('79', 328, 1, 18, 683524) But should it prove otherwise, I may inform the public that satyagraha is independent of Press advertisement.
('79', 328, 1, 19, 683634) If it is real, it carries with it its own momentum; and I believe the present satyagraha to be very real.
('79', 328, 1, 20, 683740) It will go on.
('79', 328, 1, 21, 683755) I will not be provoked into any hasty action.
('79', 328, 1, 22, 683801) I am still not ready with the next move.
('79', 328, 1, 23, 683842) But as I have said in my previous statement 1, every act of civil disobedience is complete in itself.
('79', 328, 1, 24, 683944) This Press notice shows how effective it has been.
('79', 328, 1, 25, 683995) Every act of repression adds strength to the reality.
('79', 328, 1, 26, 684049) Satyagraha thrives on repression till at last the repressor is tired of it and the object of satyagraha is gained.
('79', 328, 1, 27, 684164) Whether, therefore, I take the next step or not and when I take it, is a matter of no consequence to the public.
('79', 328, 1, 28, 684277) Let those who sympathize with it follow implicitly the instructions I have issued.
('79', 328, 1, 29, 684360) I believe, and my belief has been tested repeatedly, that thought deliberately thought and controlled is a power greater than speech or writing and any day greater than steam which is husbanded and controlled.
('79', 328, 1, 30, 684570) We see the latter every day carrying incredible weights even across steep precipices.
('79', 328, 1, 31, 684656) Thought power
('79', 328, 2, 32, 684670) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 21 10 1940
('79', 329, 0, 1, 684713) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 329, 1, 2, 684755) overcomes much greater obstacles and easily carries greater weights.
('79', 329, 1, 3, 684824) But let me give a practical hint to the non believer in the power of thought husbanded and controlled.
('79', 329, 1, 4, 684927) Let everyone become his own walking newspaper and carry the good news from mouth to mouth.
('79', 329, 1, 5, 685018) This does not mean what boys used to do in the past, viz., trumpeting about of bits of news.
('79', 329, 1, 6, 685111) The idea here is of my telling my neighbour what I have authentically heard.
('79', 329, 1, 7, 685188) This no Government can overtake or suppress.
('79', 329, 1, 8, 685233) It is the cheapest newspaper yet devised and it defies the wit of Government, however clever it may be.
('79', 329, 1, 9, 685337) Let these walking newspapers be sure of the news they give.
('79', 329, 1, 10, 685397) They should not indulge in any idle gossip.
('79', 329, 1, 11, 685441) They should make sure of the source of information, and they will find that the public gets all the information that they need without opening their morning newspaper which, they should know, will contain garbled, one sided information and therefore not worth the trouble of reading.
('79', 329, 1, 12, 685725) For it may be that even the public statements such as I am now issuing may also be stopped.
('79', 329, 1, 13, 685817) It is the condition of life under an autocratic Government, whether foreign or indigenous.
('79', 329, 2, 14, 685908) Harijan, 10 11 1940
('79', 329, 3, 15, 685928) 320. LETTER TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('79', 329, 4, 16, 685960) WARDHA, October 24, 1940
('79', 329, 5, 17, 685985) DEAR JAWAHARLAL, I was glad to have your wire 1. If my statement 2 has been allowed, you will have seen it before this.
('79', 329, 5, 18, 686105) If you are ready, you may now ceremonially declare your civil disobedience.
('79', 329, 5, 19, 686181) I would suggest your choosing a village for your audience.
('79', 329, 5, 20, 686240) I do not suppose they will allow you to repeat your speech.
('79', 329, 5, 21, 686300) They were not ready with their plans so far as Vinoba was concerned.
('79', 329, 5, 22, 686369) But should they let you free I suggest your following the plan 3 laid down for Vinoba.
('79', 329, 5, 23, 686456) But if you feel otherwise, you will follow your own course.
('79', 329, 5, 24, 686516) Only I would like you to give me your programme.
('79', 329, 5, 25, 686565) You will fix your own date so as to leave me time for announcing the date and
('79', 329, 6, 26, 686643) 1Vide footnote 3, “Leter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 21 10 1940 2 Vide the preceding item.
('79', 329, 6, 27, 686728) 3 Vide “Civil Disobedience”
('79', 330, 0, 1, 686756) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 331
('79', 330, 1, 2, 686802) It may be that they won’t let you even fulfil your very first programme.
('79', 330, 1, 3, 686875) I am prepared for every such step on the part of the Government.
('79', 330, 1, 4, 686940) Whilst I would make use of every legitimate method seeking publicity for our programme, my reliance is on regulated thought producing its own effect.
('79', 330, 1, 5, 687090) If this is hard for you to believe, I would ask you to suspend judgment and watch results.
('79', 330, 1, 6, 687181) I know you will yourself be patient and ask our people on your side to do likewise.
('79', 330, 1, 7, 687265) I know what strain you are bearing in giving me your loyalty.
('79', 330, 1, 8, 687327) I prize it beyond measure.
('79', 330, 1, 9, 687354) I hope it will be found to have been well placed, for it is ‘do or die’.
('79', 330, 1, 10, 687427) There is no turning back.
('79', 330, 1, 11, 687453) Our case is invulnerable.
('79', 330, 1, 12, 687479) There is no giving in.
('79', 330, 1, 13, 687502) Only I must be allowed to go my way in demonstrating the power of non violence when it is unadulterated.
('79', 330, 1, 14, 687607) Maulana Saheb telephoned saying I should choose another man for the second satyagraha.
('79', 330, 1, 15, 687694) I told him I could not do so if you consented to come in.
('79', 330, 1, 16, 687752) I would like your reaction to the step I have taken regarding Harijan.

('79', 331, 6, 8, 688530) 323. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS 1
('79', 331, 7, 9, 688558) [After October 24, 1940] 2
('79', 331, 8, 10, 688585) Q. Will Government’s ban on reports of anti war meeting lead to any revision in the plan of individual civil disobedience?
('79', 331, 8, 11, 688708) A. There is likely to be some revision but it will be all in the direction of stiffening non violence.
('79', 331, 9, 12, 688811) You have said 3 that each Indian should be “his own walking paper”.
('79', 331, 9, 13, 688879) Don’t you feel that the ban may only give currency to exaggerated rumours ?
('79', 331, 9, 14, 688955) How do you propose obviating this ?
('79', 331, 9, 15, 688991) If the people do not catch the spirit of my advice, there will undoubtedly be exaggerated rumours and I confess that I have no control over all without exception, and exceptions, however few they may be, can easily upset the apple cart.
('79', 331, 9, 16, 689228) I have no method for obviating the exaggeration.
('79', 331, 9, 17, 689277) The Government should be held solely responsible for mishaps that may arise out of their complete black out by their Press gagging ordinance.
('79', 331, 9, 18, 689419) It seems to me they are outdoing Nazism.
('79', 331, 10, 19, 689460) Do you propose obeying the ban?
('79', 331, 10, 20, 689492) I have no intention of defying the ban.
('79', 331, 10, 21, 689532) Have I not, anticipated it by suspending the publication of the three weeklies controlled by me?
('79', 331, 10, 22, 689629) Civil disobedience as conceived this time is of an extraordinary nature designed to meet an extraordinary situation.
('79', 331, 11, 23, 689746) 1 D. G. Tendulkar explains that the questions were received from “Frank Moraes on behalf of The News Chronicle, London”.
('79', 331, 11, 24, 689867) 2 From the reference to the suspension of “the three weeklies” by Gandhiji; vide “Statement to the Press”, 24 10 1940 3Vide”Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 24 10 1940
('79', 332, 0, 1, 690031) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 333
('79', 332, 1, 2, 690077) What is your reaction to this ban?
('79', 332, 1, 3, 690112) It is said, the language of the ban is taken from similar restrictive orders in Great Britain.
('79', 332, 1, 4, 690207) Is that any justification ?
('79', 332, 1, 5, 690235) My reaction to the ban is that the Government have over reached themselves.
('79', 332, 1, 6, 690311) Language of the ban may be borrowed from Great Britain but how can they borrow the conditions operating in Great Britain?
('79', 332, 1, 7, 690433) In Great Britain it is people’s rule, the Constitution is in full working order.
('79', 332, 1, 8, 690514) In India it is one man’s rule who is responsible to nobody in India.
('79', 332, 1, 9, 690583) The contrast between the two is staggering.
('79', 332, 1, 10, 690627) It is defiance of all propriety to copy the language which may be quite proper for Britain but which is quite improper for India.
('79', 332, 1, 11, 690757) It is like imposing on India in mid summer the British fur coat of mid winter.
('79', 332, 2, 12, 690836) From a facsimile: Mahatma, Life of Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Vol. 6, between pp.

('79', 338, 9, 18, 699699) 337. LETTER TO LORD LINLITHGOW
('79', 338, 10, 19, 699730) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, October 30, 1940
('79', 338, 11, 20, 699765) DEAR LORD LINLITHGOW, I have to thank you about your letter 1 of the 24th instant.
('79', 338, 11, 21, 699848) As to the first paragraph of your letter, I have already given 2
('79', 338, 12, 22, 699913) you my reaction to the notices referred to by you.
('79', 338, 12, 23, 699964) The second paragraph is astounding.
('79', 338, 12, 24, 700000) Reducing your language to simple terms you tell me that I must be punished if I do not behave myself.
('79', 338, 12, 25, 700102) I hardly needed to be given the warning.
('79', 338, 12, 26, 700143) But I do not mind it.
('79', 338, 13, 27, 700165) 1Vide “Letter from Lord Linlithgow”, 24 10 1940 2Vide”Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 25 10 1940
('79', 339, 0, 1, 700258) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 339, 1, 2, 700300) The language used by you shows the pains you have taken to conceal your meaning in as gentle words as the English language and your exalted office will let you.
('79', 339, 1, 3, 700461) But I was wholly unprepared for your assumptions.
('79', 339, 1, 4, 700511) I have nowhere said that I desire freedom to conduct a civil disobedience movement in a way that commends itself to me and that for that purpose I wish to enjoy unrestricted access to the public through the ordinary channels of publicity.
('79', 339, 1, 5, 700750) You will see from my statement 1
('79', 339, 2, 6, 700783) —copy of which is hereto attached—that I have claimed that civil disobedience can be conducted without publicity through newspapers.
('79', 339, 2, 7, 700916) This statement was published before your letter reached me.
('79', 339, 2, 8, 700976) Indeed, if civil disobedience depended for its conduct upon the mercy of the Government against which it was directed, it must be poor stuff, utterly worthless for the purpose intended.
('79', 339, 2, 9, 701162) It seeks through self suffering to convert the opponent.
('79', 339, 2, 10, 701219) You then say:
('79', 339, 3, 11, 701233) Although, however, you evidently wish me to believe that this movement which you have initiated will be more dangerous if you do not enjoy these facilities, I must credit you personally with the desire that it should succeed in its avowed object, that of persuading the public to withhold all support from India’s war effort.
('79', 339, 3, 12, 701559) There is no warrant in my letter for the belief entertained by you.
('79', 339, 3, 13, 701627) The whole purpose of my letter 2 has been missed.
('79', 339, 3, 14, 701677) It was to commend to your sympathetic attention the fact that I was taking extraordinary precautions to ensure non violence, and the further fact that to that end I was restricting the movement to the fewest possible typical individuals.
('79', 339, 3, 15, 701915) I had hugged the belief that you would, as a friend, be pleased with the information and, recognizing the fact, you would not put yourself in the wrong by passing the wholly unnecessary drastic gagging ordinance you have passed.
('79', 339, 3, 16, 702144) You have by that ordinance demonstrated to the world that you could not conduct the war through India except by stifling public opinion.
('79', 339, 3, 17, 702281) I had hoped that you would be satisfied with such aid as the Princes, moneyed men and professional warlike classes could give you.
('79', 339, 3, 18, 702412) They could not come under my or the Congress influence.
('79', 339, 4, 19, 702468) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 24 10 1940 2Vide”Statement to the Press”
('79', 340, 0, 1, 702541) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 341
('79', 340, 1, 2, 702587) I am sure you will not compare India with Britain.
('79', 340, 1, 3, 702638) In Britain you have the Houses of Parliament through which the nation acts.
('79', 340, 1, 4, 702714) Here you have powers derived not from India but from Great Britain that no single individual in the wide world enjoys over so many people.
('79', 340, 1, 5, 702853) I had hoped that you would use them with restraint.
('79', 340, 1, 6, 702905) It was for that purpose that I had sought the last interview and stayed beyond my time so that I might not be said to have rushed you.
('79', 340, 1, 7, 703040) For the moment the hope has been dashed to pieces.
('79', 340, 1, 8, 703091) I ask you to believe me when I tell you that, in every single step I have taken, I have thought of you and your people as your and their true friend.
('79', 340, 1, 9, 703241) One day you will feel the truth of this remark if you do not today.
('79', 340, 1, 10, 703309) But I accept your verdict for the moment.
('79', 340, 1, 11, 703351) I do not want to conduct the movement secretly.
('79', 340, 1, 12, 703399) Nor can I allow non violence to perish by default.
('79', 340, 1, 13, 703450) I might, therefore, give the only thing I have in me to give—my life.
('79', 340, 1, 14, 703520) I told you about the possibility of a fast, prolonged or unto death.
('79', 340, 1, 15, 703589) I was waiting on God to find what is to be the case.
('79', 340, 1, 16, 703642) I am trying hard to avoid it but I may not be able to do so.
('79', 340, 1, 17, 703703) You will have another letter from me when I have come to the final conclusion.
('79', 340, 1, 18, 703782) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru has been with me.
('79', 340, 1, 19, 703824) I had invited him to be the next resister.
('79', 340, 1, 20, 703867) He had consented.
('79', 340, 1, 21, 703885) Your ordinance came after.
('79', 340, 1, 22, 703912) And the fast idea possessed me.
('79', 340, 1, 23, 703944) He has an open mind on the fast.
('79', 340, 1, 24, 703977) But he thinks, and I have agreed with him, that the contemplated resistance by him should be completed before entertaining the idea of the fast.
('79', 340, 1, 25, 704122) Therefore the very next step is to be his civil resistance.
('79', 340, 1, 26, 704182) As soon as the date and place are finally decided, I shall let you have them for your information.
('79', 340, 1, 27, 704281) I hope you will not resent this letter.
('79', 340, 1, 28, 704321) I have written as a friend to a friend and not as a member of the public to you as the Viceroy.
('79', 340, 1, 29, 704417) I have not written to seek publicity or to make a point against you.
('79', 340, 1, 30, 704486) I will not publish this letter or any part of the recent correspondence between us without your consent.

('79', 341, 0, 1, 704667) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 341, 1, 2, 704709) 338. TO THE READER
('79', 341, 2, 3, 704728) You must have seen through my Press notice 1 that the publication of Harijan and the other two weeklies had been suspended.
('79', 341, 2, 4, 704852) In it I had expressed the hope that the suspension might be only for a week.
('79', 341, 2, 5, 704929) But I see that the hope had no real foundation.
('79', 341, 2, 6, 704977) I shall miss my weekly talks with you, as I expect you too will miss them.
('79', 341, 2, 7, 705052) The value of those talks consisted in their being a faithful record of my deepest thoughts.
('79', 341, 2, 8, 705144) Such expression is impossible in a cramped atmosphere.
('79', 341, 2, 9, 705199) As I have no desire to offer civil disobedience, I cannot write freely.
('79', 341, 2, 10, 705271) As the author of satyagraha I cannot, consistently with my professions, suppress the vital part of myself for the sake of being able to write on permissible subjects such as the constructive programme.
('79', 341, 2, 11, 705473) It would be like dealing with the trunk without the head.
('79', 341, 2, 12, 705531) The whole of the constructive programme is to me an expression of non violence.
('79', 341, 2, 13, 705611) I would be denying myself if I could not preach non violence.
('79', 341, 2, 14, 705673) For that would be the meaning of submission to the latest ordinance.
('79', 341, 2, 15, 705742) The suspension must, therefore, continue while the gagging lasts.
('79', 341, 2, 16, 705808) It constitutes a satyagrahi’s respectful protest against the gag.
('79', 341, 2, 17, 705874) Is not satyagraha giving an ell when an inch is asked for by the wrongdoer?
('79', 341, 2, 18, 705950) Is it not giving the cloak also when only the coat is demanded?
('79', 341, 2, 19, 706014) It may be asked why this reversal of the ordinary process?
('79', 341, 2, 20, 706073) The ordinary process is based on violence.
('79', 341, 2, 21, 706116) If my life were regulated by violence, in the last resort I would refuse to give an inch lest an ell might be asked for.
('79', 341, 2, 22, 706237) I would be a fool if I did otherwise.
('79', 341, 2, 23, 706275) But if my life is regulated by non violence, I should be prepared to and actually give an ell when an inch is asked for.
('79', 341, 2, 24, 706396) By so doing I produce on the usurper a strange and even pleasurable sensation.
('79', 341, 2, 25, 706475) He would also be confounded and would not know what to do with me.
('79', 341, 2, 26, 706542) So much for the ‘enemy’.
('79', 341, 2, 27, 706567) I, having made up my mind to surrender every non essential, gain greater strength than ever before to die for the defence and preservation of what I hold to be essential.
('79', 341, 2, 28, 706738) I was, therefore, wrongly accused by my critics of having advised 2 cowardly surrender to Nazism by Englishmen when I suggested that they should lay down external arms, let the Nazis overrun Britain if they dare, but develop internal strength to refuse to sell themselves to the Nazis.
('79', 341, 2, 29, 707024) Full surrender of non essentials is a condition precedent to accession of internal strength to defend the essential by dying.
('79', 341, 3, 30, 707150) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 24 10 1940 2Vide “To Every Briton”
('79', 342, 0, 1, 707217) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 343
('79', 342, 1, 2, 707263) But I am not writing this to convert the English to my view.
('79', 342, 1, 3, 707324) I am writing this to suggest to you that my surrender to the framers of the gagging ordinance is an object lesson to you, the reader, in satyagraha.
('79', 342, 1, 4, 707473) If you will quietly work out in your own life the implications of the lesson, you will then not need the weekly aid from the written word in Harijan.
('79', 342, 1, 5, 707623) Even without your weekly Harijan you will know how I shall myself work out the full implications of giving an ell when an inch is wanted.
('79', 342, 1, 6, 707761) A correspondent pleads with me that on no account should I suspend Harijan, for, he says, his non violence is sustained by the weekly food he gets therefrom.
('79', 342, 1, 7, 707919) If he has really done so, then this self imposed restraint should teach him more than a vapid continuation of weekly Harijan.
('79', 342, 1, 8, 708045) One word as to the practical question.
('79', 342, 1, 9, 708084) You are a subscriber to one of the weeklies.
('79', 342, 1, 10, 708129) I do not know, when, if ever, they will be resumed.
('79', 342, 1, 11, 708181) You are entitled to the return of the unused balance of your subscription.
('79', 342, 1, 12, 708256) On receipt a postcard from you to the Manager, Harijan, Poona, for a refund, a money order for it will be sent to you.
('79', 342, 1, 13, 708375) Those who do not ask for a refund will have their paper sent to them if it is resumed.
('79', 342, 1, 14, 708462) If it is not, the unused balance will be spent in covering any loss that may be caused in winding up.
('79', 342, 1, 15, 708564) And then the balance, if any, will be sent to the Harijan Sevak Sangh for use in the service of Harijans.
('79', 342, 1, 16, 708670) If Harijan is not resumed within six months, it will be deemed to have been finally wound up.
('79', 342, 1, 17, 708764) Meanwhile goodbye.
('79', 342, 1, 18, 708783) SEVAGRAM, October 31, 1940
('79', 342, 2, 19, 708810) Harijan, 10 11 1940

('79', 346, 6, 11, 713711) 347. TO THE READERS
('79', 346, 7, 12, 713731) I had hoped, when I made public my intention 2 of suspending Harijanbandhu, that the suspension might be only for a week and as a result of my correspondence with H.E. the Viceroy it might be possible to publish it again soon.
('79', 346, 7, 13, 713958) But the outcome was just the opposite.
('79', 346, 7, 14, 713997) My hope was without any basis.
('79', 346, 7, 15, 714028) There is no reason to regard this as a bad omen.
('79', 346, 7, 16, 714077) Satyagraha tests the satyagrahi as also the opponent.
('79', 346, 7, 17, 714131) There is certainly a difference between the two tests.
('79', 346, 7, 18, 714186) A satyagrahi’s shortcomings are eliminated as satyagraha progresses, while those of the opponent’s come to light, as a result of which he is transformed.
('79', 346, 7, 19, 714340) But at the moment I do not wish to focus attention on the faults of my opponents.
('79', 346, 7, 20, 714422) I wish to explain briefly to the readers why Harijanbandhu is to be suspended for an indefinite period.
('79', 346, 7, 21, 714526) I had two alternatives before me.
('79', 346, 7, 22, 714560) Either to accept the restrictions imposed by the Government and continue publishing Harijanbandhu under limitations or to reject the restrictions and suspend its publication.
('79', 346, 7, 23, 714735) The second alternative alone would bring credit to a satyagrahi.
('79', 346, 7, 24, 714800) A satyagrahi should offer a hand where a finger is demanded, while practical wisdom would be to drive him away, so that he will never have the courage to ask for the hand.
('79', 346, 7, 25, 714972) However this policy is for those
('79', 346, 8, 26, 715005) 1 Daughter of Jamnalal Bajaj 2Vide “Statement to the Press”, 24 10 1940
('79', 347, 0, 1, 715077) 348 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 347, 1, 2, 715119) who rely on himsa.
('79', 347, 1, 3, 715138) A non violent person depends on the opposite policy.
('79', 347, 1, 4, 715191) A violent person engages himself in safeguarding material and mortal things and either forgets or undermines the inner and the immortal self.
('79', 347, 1, 5, 715333) A non violent person is ever ready to forsake the material things and serves and protects the inner self.
('79', 347, 1, 6, 715439) So it becomes his dharma to offer a hand to one who asks for a finger.
('79', 347, 1, 7, 715510) This dharma ultimately leads to all round happiness.
('79', 347, 1, 8, 715563) Let us examine its result.
('79', 347, 1, 9, 715590) An opponent who gets a hand on asking for a finger is surprised and thereby will possibly be confounded.
('79', 347, 1, 10, 715695) When he has such surprising experiences from time to time, he is likely to give up opposition of the non violent.
('79', 347, 1, 11, 715809) A non violent person, while adhering to his dharma, adds to his strength, his capacity to sacrifice grows, he understands better the value of inner strength, and his strength to face the calamity of any kind increases.
('79', 347, 1, 12, 716028) As a votary of non violence, that is, a satyagrahi, I am left with only the second alternative.
('79', 347, 1, 13, 716124) I experienced a sense of relief when I chose to suspend publication of Harijanbandhu and I repeat the immortal lines of Narsinh Mehta: Better it is that the worldly bonds are broken, Easier it will be to attain the Lord.
('79', 347, 2, 14, 716345) Mahadev says that the correct version is: “I shall worship the Lord in peace.” I don’t know how, but I have always remembered the wrong version and have derived solace from it.
('79', 347, 2, 15, 716522) I, therefore, retain that.
('79', 347, 2, 16, 716549) My faith is daily growing that I will attain God only through such sacrifices, not otherwise.
('79', 347, 2, 17, 716643) Here God means the freedom of India.
('79', 347, 2, 18, 716680) But, Readers, what about you?
('79', 347, 2, 19, 716710) I loved my weekly talks with you as I expect you, too, loved them.
('79', 347, 2, 20, 716777) I tried to explain to you the meaning of satyagraha in various ways.
('79', 347, 2, 21, 716846) But now?
('79', 347, 2, 22, 716855) If you have followed properly my writings in Harijanbandhu, then I am sure you will follow satyagraha better by my sacrifice and my conduct hereafter.
('79', 347, 2, 23, 717006) How long shall I explain it to you by writing and talking to you?
('79', 347, 2, 24, 717072) What you do not get from my conduct, you will never get from my words.
('79', 347, 2, 25, 717143) An ounce of my conduct, that is, what I am doing, is several times more valuable than a ton of philosophizing.
('79', 347, 2, 26, 717254) I have to tell you only this much: wear khadi, spin with perseverence every day, make Harijans your own, treat the followers of other religions with equality and achieve unity.
('79', 347, 2, 27, 717431) Your body may fall, your house and belongings may go, but do not do anything which
('79', 348, 0, 1, 717514) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 349
('79', 348, 1, 2, 717560) your conscience does not allow.
('79', 348, 1, 3, 717592) Examine the thirteen point programme and what I have not mentioned above, you may add to it.
('79', 348, 1, 4, 717685) If you act accordingly, you will not feel the need of a newspaper and be sure that the Ganga in the form of swaraj will come to your doorsteps without any effort.
('79', 348, 1, 5, 717848) Now one thing very practical.
('79', 348, 1, 6, 717878) Your yearly subscription is not over yet.
('79', 348, 1, 7, 717920) You will have some balance due to you in the books of Harijanbandhu.
('79', 348, 1, 8, 717989) You are entitled to ask for the refund of the balance.
('79', 348, 1, 9, 718044) I hope Harijanbandhu will come out again some day.
('79', 348, 1, 10, 718095) If it does, you will get the journal as long as your balance lasts.
('79', 348, 1, 11, 718163) But if you do not want to wait, write a postcard to the Manager, Harijanbandhu, Poona 4. He will send you the balance.
('79', 348, 1, 12, 718282) If the restriction on Harijanbandhu is not lifted within six months, it will be deemed to have been finally wound up, and the balance will be spent in covering any loss that may be caused in winding up.
('79', 348, 1, 13, 718485) The balances of subscriptions will be sent to those subscribers who ask for it and the share of those who do not ask for it will be sent to the Harijan Sevak Sangh for the welfare of Harijans.
('79', 348, 1, 14, 718678) For the present Vandemataram.

('79', 357, 10, 14, 730457) 368. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('79', 357, 11, 15, 730485) WARDHA, November 7, 1940
('79', 357, 12, 16, 730510) I have been receiving numerous telegrams asking me not to undertake the contemplated fast.
('79', 357, 12, 17, 730601) Almost all of the telegrams are from friends who are concerned about my health and who think that if I am alive I can still render useful service to the country.
('79', 357, 12, 18, 730763) There are one or two bitterly criticizing me and telling me that fasting has no place in the politics of the country and that it disturbs the political atmosphere and impairs the efficiency of opposition to the Government in the fight for freedom.
('79', 357, 12, 19, 731011) I wish to thank both the friends and the critics.
('79', 357, 12, 20, 731061) The members of the Working Committee and I also had a long discussion
('79', 357, 13, 21, 731131) 1Vide also letter to the addressee “Letter to Avdulla Haroon Rasheed”, 6 11 1940, and the preceding item.
('79', 358, 0, 1, 731237) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 359
('79', 358, 1, 2, 731283) over the contemplated fast.
('79', 358, 1, 3, 731311) In view of the extension of individual civil disobedience, the idea of the fast naturally remains in abeyance.
('79', 358, 1, 4, 731422) But I must say nothing that I have heard has dislodged me from the position I have consistently held about the relevancy and propriety of fast in all walks of life including the political.
('79', 358, 1, 5, 731611) I admit that it is a new weapon.
('79', 358, 1, 6, 731644) I admit also that the use of that weapon is not open to any but specialists, even as the use of the weapon of civil disobedience is not open to everybody.
('79', 358, 1, 7, 731799) But if the use of civil disobedience is open only to those who are qualified for it, the use of fasting requires infinitely larger qualifications.
('79', 358, 1, 8, 731946) I hold that I possess these qualifications.
('79', 358, 1, 9, 731990) I have had God given opportunities of training myself in this direction consciously since 1906 1, that means 34 years.
('79', 358, 1, 10, 732109) But it cannot be taken mechanically.
('79', 358, 1, 11, 732146) It can only be taken in obedience to the promptings of an unseen power, call it the inner voice, God or whatever other name you like to give to that power.
('79', 358, 1, 12, 732302) I have mentioned the possibility of fasting because something within me is prompting me to it.
('79', 358, 1, 13, 732397) I am myself fighting against it.
('79', 358, 1, 14, 732430) I know that however willing the spirit may be, the flesh is weak.
('79', 358, 1, 15, 732496) I know that being unable to drink an adequate quantity of water during a fast, it becomes almost unbearable, specially in the initial stages.
('79', 358, 1, 16, 732638) But however weak the flesh may be, I know that the weakness can be conquered when that unseen power dominates me to the exclusion of every other force.
('79', 358, 1, 17, 732790) That feeling has not yet come to me and until it does naturally there will be no fast.
('79', 358, 1, 18, 732877) If it does come, I shall myself feel powerless to listen to the kindly intervention of friends or the anger of fierce critics.
('79', 358, 1, 19, 733004) Therefore I will beseech all to hold themselves in patience and watch the developments.
('79', 358, 1, 20, 733092) Of course, it is open to everybody to help me in the crisis through which the country is passing.
('79', 358, 1, 21, 733190) I have shown the numerous ways in which everybody, friend and critic, can help.
('79', 358, 1, 22, 733270) I have no desire to make any elaborate statement indicating the ways in which people can help.
('79', 358, 1, 23, 733365) Having stopped the publication of Harijan weeklies I have lost all desire for making public statements.
('79', 358, 1, 24, 733469) This I am compelled to make in order to thank numerous inquirers, and to allay public anxiety.
('79', 358, 2, 25, 733564) 1 Here the newspaper source has “1906 or 1907”; vide “An Autobiography”, sub title “Brahmacharya” 2 What follows is reproduced from The Hitavada, according to Gandhiji was interviewed by the Associated Press of India.
('79', 359, 0, 1, 733782) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 359, 1, 2, 733824) Asked about the future of the Harijan weeklies, Gandhiji said: You will presently see the valedictory issue 1 of Harijan announcing their stoppage altogether.
('79', 359, 2, 3, 733983) Congress Bulletin, No.

('79', 359, 3, 8, 734106) 369. INSTRUCTIONS TO SATYAGRAHIS
('79', 359, 4, 9, 734139) 1. Under the extraordinary situation created by the Government, I have, after consultation with the Working Committee, extended the scope of civil disobedience and I propose to select, for the time being, resisters from among the members of the Working Committee, the Congress members in the Central and Provincial Legislatures and the members of the A.I.C.C. 2. Those only will be selected who conform to the conditions I have laid down, who are themselves willing to offer resistance and who are otherwise free to do so.
('79', 359, 4, 10, 734662) 3. The method of selection is as follows.
('79', 359, 4, 11, 734704) The members of the Working Committee will send me lists of such members in the first instance and no one will offer civil disobedience whose name I have not passsed.
('79', 359, 4, 12, 734870) No list should contain names of those who are physically unfit to undergo prison life.
('79', 359, 4, 13, 734957) I may supplement the lists by making selection out of the names I have already received or may receive hereafter.
('79', 359, 4, 14, 735071) 4. The names should be sent through messenger to ensure delivery.
('79', 359, 4, 15, 735137) 5. No one will offer civil disobedience without first informing the District Magistrate of his district, of the time when and the place where and the manner in which it is to be offered.
('79', 359, 4, 16, 735324) 6. It is advisable not to hold public meetings for the purpose in cities.
('79', 359, 4, 17, 735398) Meetings may be held in villages.
('79', 359, 4, 18, 735432) The best and the easiest way is to repeat the following slogan to passers by as the resister walks on in a particular direction until he is arrested.
('79', 359, 4, 19, 735582) My preference is for this last method.
('79', 359, 4, 20, 735621) It is harmless, economical and effective.
('79', 359, 4, 21, 735663) No argument is necessary.
('79', 359, 4, 22, 735689) It rivets attention on the single issue of war.
('79', 359, 4, 23, 735737) The idea is to prevent the movement from lapsing into mass civil disobedience.
('79', 359, 5, 24, 735816) 1 Dated November 10, two articles; vide “Statement to the Press”, 24 10 1940 and “To the Reader”
('79', 360, 0, 1, 735913) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 361
('79', 360, 1, 2, 735959) is the slogan: “It is wrong to help the British war effort with men or money.
('79', 360, 1, 3, 736037) The only worthy effort is to resist all war with non violent resistance.” The slogan should be translated into the language of the province in which civil disobedience is to be offered.
('79', 360, 1, 4, 736223) 7. Civil disobedience is to be offered singly.
('79', 360, 1, 5, 736270) It need not be simultaneous.
('79', 360, 1, 6, 736299) The whole of this programme should, if possible, be finished in one month.
('79', 360, 1, 7, 736374) 8. All demonstrations should be avoided when civil disobedience is offered.
('79', 360, 1, 8, 736450) 9. The ordinary channels of publicity being closed, we must rely upon everybody becoming his own newspaper.
('79', 360, 1, 9, 736558) Satyagraha is and must be independent of the ordinary channels.
('79', 360, 1, 10, 736622) We must not feel helpless when these are closed, and they are for the most part even now closed against us.
('79', 360, 1, 11, 736730) It should be realized too that the repetition of the slogan while walking in one direction reduces the movement to its simplest terms.
('79', 360, 1, 12, 736865) 10. Secrecy should be avoided.
('79', 360, 1, 13, 736896) Therefore cyclostyles and the like should be used only when the owners are prepared to lose them.
('79', 360, 1, 14, 736994) The cheapest multiplying method is to use composition trays.
('79', 360, 1, 15, 737055) The formula for making them may be got locally.
('79', 360, 1, 16, 737103) (The A.I.C.C. Office shall try to send it later.) But the infalliable way is to multiply the manuscript by many hands copying.
('79', 360, 1, 17, 737230) This method was extensively used during the last satyagraha.
('79', 360, 1, 18, 737291) 11. Congress funds need not be kept secretly.
('79', 360, 1, 19, 737337) If the Government choose to confiscate them, they may do so.
('79', 360, 1, 20, 737398) In this life and death struggle, we must be prepared to lose all funds and other property.
('79', 360, 1, 21, 737489) We must learn to depend upon the nation financing the movement from day to day.
('79', 360, 1, 22, 737569) Our wants must, therefore, be reduced to the minimum.
('79', 360, 1, 23, 737623) No one need expect monetary assistance from the Congress.
('79', 360, 1, 24, 737681) 12. Our policy should be to avoid classification of prisoners.
('79', 360, 1, 25, 737744) In no case should any attempt be made to ask either for a higher or a lower class.
('79', 360, 1, 26, 737827) An A class prisoner is not bound to take advantage of the special facilities offered to him.
('79', 360, 1, 27, 737920) Nor need he be ashamed of availing himself of them if thereby he retains his health.
('79', 360, 1, 28, 738005) 13. Jail rules and discipline should be strictly observed so long as they are not inconsistent with human dignity.
('79', 360, 1, 29, 738120) No labour should be avoided because it is labour.
('79', 360, 1, 30, 738170) We should know its dignity.
('79', 361, 0, 1, 738198) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 361, 1, 2, 738240) 14. Hartals should be rare.
('79', 361, 1, 3, 738268) They lose their force if resorted to too often.
('79', 361, 1, 4, 738316) They are likely to be prohibited.
('79', 361, 1, 5, 738350) It is better to anticipate the prohibition.
('79', 361, 1, 6, 738394) Our civil resistance is strictly limited.
('79', 361, 1, 7, 738436) It is not general.
('79', 361, 1, 8, 738455) 15. Should the Congress be declared an illegal organization, it should make no difference.
('79', 361, 1, 9, 738546) I shall conduct the movement so long as I am left free.
('79', 361, 1, 10, 738602) In the event of my being arrested, it will become self acting if the people have imbibed non violence.
('79', 361, 1, 11, 738705) Congressmen should remain calm and unperturbed.
('79', 361, 1, 12, 738753) Each one will act on his or her own initiative.
('79', 361, 1, 13, 738801) If he or she feels like offering civil disobedience, the way is clear.
('79', 361, 1, 14, 738872) If he or she is unable, they will devote themselves wholly to one or more items of the thirteenfold constructive programme.
('79', 361, 1, 15, 738996) I do not propose to appoint a successor whether I am in or out.
('79', 361, 1, 16, 739060) Those who belong to the Congress constructive organizations may not offer civil disobedience.
('79', 361, 1, 17, 739154) 16. While the Congress functions as a legal organization, the Provincial Committees, will elect their President if the present one is arrested.
('79', 361, 1, 18, 739298) The person elected should seek confirmation from me.
('79', 361, 1, 19, 739351) I shall be unable to work through him if he does not fulfil my conditions.
('79', 361, 1, 20, 739426) 17. In the provinces where there is no Working Committee Member, the provincial president will put himself in touch with me and send me his recommendations.
('79', 361, 1, 21, 739583) 18. If I am impelled to fast, I expect Congressmen not to feel paralysed but to be stimulated to more intensive effort in the direction of constructive work.
('79', 361, 1, 22, 739741) The fast, if it comes, must result in khadi and village manufactures generally becoming universal, untouchability being a thing of the past, and communal unity a settled fact.
('79', 361, 1, 23, 739917) 19. Congressmen should make it clear in their speech and their action that they are neither pro Fascists nor pro Nazis, but that they are opposed either to all war or at least to the war conducted on behalf of British imperialism.
('79', 361, 1, 24, 740148) They sympathize with the British in their effort to live, but they want also to live themselves as members of a fully free nation.
('79', 361, 1, 25, 740279) They must not, therefore, be expected to help Britain at the cost of their own liberty.
('79', 361, 1, 26, 740367) They bear ill will to no nation.
('79', 361, 1, 27, 740400) They want to play their part in establishing lasting peace in the world.
('79', 361, 2, 28, 740473) M. K. GANDHI SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, November 8, 1940

('79', 364, 6, 9, 743605) 375. LETTER TO SIR J. G. LAITHWAITE
('79', 364, 7, 10, 743641) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, November 11, 1940
('79', 364, 8, 11, 743677) DEAR MR. LAITHWAITE, I have to thank you for your letter of the 2nd instant.
('79', 364, 8, 12, 743754) I must not offer any apology for this letter.
('79', 364, 8, 13, 743800) For, in answer to the Government measures regarding the Press, I have given up making public statements on the struggle between the Government and the Congress, and I want to avoid secrecy regarding my plans.
('79', 364, 8, 14, 744009) I shall, therefore, continue to send you periodical letters unless His Excellency desires otherwise.
('79', 364, 8, 15, 744110) I had hoped to be able to confine civil disobedience to two or three typical cases and supplement them, if necessary and if the call came, with a fast, limited or unlimited.
('79', 364, 8, 16, 744284) But the members of the Working Committee were very much perturbed over the contemplated fast.
('79', 364, 8, 17, 744378) Wires also pressed in upon me from all sorts of men and associations prevailing upon me not to fast.
('79', 364, 8, 18, 744479) I felt that if I was not to fast, I must in some way answer the action of the Government in regard to Pandit Jawaharlal 1. My restraint depended upon a measure of reciprocity from the Government as I had hoped in my letter 2 of the 30th September in the following words:
('79', 364, 9, 19, 744750) I shall hug the hope that it will be possible for the Government to work
('79', 364, 10, 20, 744823) 1 Jawaharlal Nehru was arrested on October 31, under the Defence of India Rules, and was sentenced on November 5 to an aggregate term of four years’ rigorous imprisonment.
('79', 364, 10, 21, 744995) 2 To Lord Linlithgow, vide”Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 30 9 1940
('79', 365, 0, 1, 745060) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 365, 1, 2, 745102) out their policy in the spirit of the Congress position.
('79', 365, 1, 3, 745159) But I do not complain.
('79', 365, 1, 4, 745182) I must not.
('79', 365, 1, 5, 745194) Only I feel I should explain my change of plan.
('79', 365, 1, 6, 745242) The changed plan consists in extending civil disobedience to qualified persons selected from particular groups.
('79', 365, 1, 7, 745354) The groups touched at present are the members of the Working Committee, the Legislators, the members of the A.I.C.C. and a few others.
('79', 365, 1, 8, 745489) I felt that with the Pandit dealt with in the manner he was, and the almost simultaneous arrest of Shri Achyut Patwardhan, who has proclaimed his faith in non violence, I should not restrain members of these groups and the like if they satisfied my test as to non violence and the constructive programme.
('79', 365, 1, 9, 745794) I send you herewith a copy also of the instructions 1 I have issued to Congressmen which you will please show to H.E. There is one other matter to which I wish to draw his attention.
('79', 365, 1, 10, 745977) My son, Devdas, has sent me notes of the recent interview with certain editors by the Hon.
('79', 365, 1, 11, 746068) the Home Member.
('79', 365, 1, 12, 746085) In it the Hon.
('79', 365, 1, 13, 746100) the Home Member is represented as having said: “Mr. Gandhi’s object is to paralyse India’s war effort and thus to help Hitler.” If Sir Reginald 2
('79', 365, 2, 14, 746246) said these words, I can only say that he is wholly wrong.
('79', 365, 2, 15, 746304) I claim that nothing that I have said can warrant Sir Reginald’s extraordinary statement.
('79', 365, 2, 16, 746394) Indeed I have said repeatedly and so have Pandit Jawaharlal and almost all the numerous Congressmen who have been jailed, that we do not want to help Hitler.
('79', 365, 2, 17, 746552) I have never said, I wished to paralyse Government’s war efforts.
('79', 365, 2, 18, 746618) But I have said that those of us who do not believe in war as war or in the war on behalf of British imperialism, which they hold the present British effort to be, should be free to propagate their views in a non violent manner.
('79', 365, 2, 19, 746847) What will, however, help Hitler and the enemies of Britain is the present utterly irresponsible and repressive policy of the Government including the wholly unwarranted arrests and imprisonments.
('79', 365, 2, 20, 747043) I had expected that those in high places would observe fairness and not go to the extent of putting into the mouths of humble workers like me words which they have never uttered.
('79', 365, 3, 21, 747222) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('79', 365, 4, 22, 747252) From a copy: C.W. 7856. Courtesy: G. D. Birla

('79', 370, 1, 2, 751832) considering all the attendant circumstances.
('79', 370, 1, 3, 751877) Risk is no doubt involved in a man taking service from a woman.
('79', 370, 1, 4, 751941) Hence the principle I mentioned can be followed in practice only to a very limited extent.
('79', 370, 1, 5, 752032) Applying it in my own case, I certainly cannot take service from just anyone.
('79', 370, 1, 6, 752110) I too have to be on my guard.
('79', 370, 1, 7, 752140) Considering all this, I have come to the conclusion that if I must take service from a woman, it should only be from Sushila.
('79', 370, 1, 8, 752266) Till such time as she is not here, I should take whatever serivce I can have from you.
('79', 370, 1, 9, 752353) It is altogether another matter what should be done if Sushila finally does not come.
('79', 370, 1, 10, 752439) Under no circumstances can I have A. S. do the massage, etc.
('79', 370, 1, 11, 752500) For it would not do any good neither to her or to me.
('79', 370, 1, 12, 752554) I cannot bear the thought that I am like God to her.
('79', 370, 1, 13, 752607) I do not possess those attributes.
('79', 370, 1, 14, 752642) You should take it that I merely suffer her.
('79', 370, 1, 15, 752687) So you must dissuade her.
('79', 370, 1, 16, 752713) I certainly can dissuade her myself but I should not like to shoulder the responsibility.
('79', 370, 1, 17, 752803) It is true that I rarely sleep facing you.
('79', 370, 1, 18, 752846) The reason is this; I have let her get into a certain habit.
('79', 370, 1, 19, 752907) I cannot suddenly break away.
('79', 370, 1, 20, 752937) Here it is not a question of a person being of the same sex or the opposite sex but of a person as person.
('79', 370, 1, 21, 753044) It would have been the same if I had allowed a man to get into the habit.
('79', 370, 1, 22, 753118) There is one thing about her though.
('79', 370, 1, 23, 753155) She is not able to cling to me.
('79', 370, 1, 24, 753187) I had the desire but with some difficulty I have freed myself from it.
('79', 370, 1, 25, 753258) As for you, I could sleep with you all the time and still it would not be enough for you.
('79', 370, 1, 26, 753348) To satisfy that desire of yours I would have to give up sleeping.
('79', 370, 1, 27, 753414) I could do even that.
('79', 370, 1, 28, 753436) But I have not found it necessary.
('79', 370, 1, 29, 753471) That is why I have been putting up with it as far as possible.
('79', 370, 1, 30, 753534) I have told you that I find it difficult to sleep with somebody in bodily contact with me.
('79', 370, 1, 31, 753625) I would put up with that only if you came to sleep early and left after a little physical contact.
('79', 370, 1, 32, 753724) But I would not be very eager for it because when I am really asleep, I cannot do even that.
('79', 370, 1, 33, 753817) I would like you to be satisfied with whatever physical contact you have while serving me.
('79', 370, 1, 34, 753908) To give you that satisfaction I would be willing not to take service from any other person and have yours.
('79', 370, 1, 35, 754015) I would not test you.
('79', 370, 1, 36, 754037) I would regard it sinful to do so.
('79', 370, 1, 37, 754072) For testing you I would not sleep with you even for a moment.
('79', 370, 1, 38, 754134) My faith is backed by knowledge.
('79', 370, 1, 39, 754167) I had to ask you about the Koran, and theknowledge that I gained thereby was sufficient for me.
('79', 370, 1, 40, 754263) I have no doubt about it at all.
('79', 370, 1, 41, 754296) Now I think I have replied to most of the points.

('79', 376, 7, 22, 762186) Lakshmidas has no fever.
