('79', 376, 10, 26, 762295) 397. DISCUSSION WITH KISHORELAL MASHRUWALA 3
('79', 376, 11, 27, 762340) [November 13, 1940] 4
('79', 376, 12, 28, 762362) As I have mentioned in my writings, I have been feeling for a long time that a prolonged fast is yet to be my lot.
('79', 376, 12, 29, 762477) The war that is raging, the country’s slavery and the importance for the whole world
('79', 376, 13, 30, 762562) 1 From the reference to Urmila; vide the preceding item.
('79', 376, 13, 31, 762619) 2 Addressee’s brother 3 Reporting a summary of the discussion in his circular letter dated November 14, 1940, to Provincial Committees of Gandhi Seva Sangh, Kishorelal Mashruwala said that it took place on the “previous day” 4 ibid
('79', 377, 0, 1, 762851) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 377, 1, 2, 762893) of India attaining its independence through non violence are the considerations that make this supreme sacrifice on my part inevitable.
('79', 377, 1, 3, 763029) At the same time I am a little nervous at the prospect.
('79', 377, 1, 4, 763085) I wish I could see my way.
('79', 377, 1, 5, 763112) I am not trying to move towards the fast.
('79', 377, 1, 6, 763154) I am being drawn towards it.
('79', 377, 1, 7, 763183) In a way it is good.
('79', 377, 1, 8, 763204) For, the time I am taking to prepare myself inwardly for the step is also preparing the masses and all of you for it.
('79', 377, 1, 9, 763322) Maybe people will after a time so much come to expect it that they may begin to ask why I do not start the fast.
('79', 377, 1, 10, 763435) I cannot yet tell under what conditions the fast will come.
('79', 377, 1, 11, 763495) If it comes while I am still out of jail, I shall tell you what you ought to do and, so long as I keep the strength, I shall continue to give you instructions.
('79', 377, 1, 12, 763655) It may be that before starting the fast I shall issue a statement.
('79', 377, 1, 13, 763722) But it is also possible that the Government may arrest me and the fast may come while I am in jail.
('79', 377, 1, 14, 763822) In that eventuality I shall neither be able to issue a statement nor give you instructions.
('79', 377, 1, 15, 763914) And I have already said that I am not going to appoint a successor.
('79', 377, 1, 16, 763982) So you will all have to act as you think best.
('79', 377, 1, 17, 764029) And, if someone then emerges as a guide, he will do so on his own merits.
('79', 377, 1, 18, 764103) I may have to fast in jail.
('79', 377, 1, 19, 764131) But from this you should not conclude that I have already decided on it.
('79', 377, 1, 20, 764204) Even if I should be in jail, I would gladly serve my term if the situation outside should be promising of a solution.
('79', 377, 1, 21, 764322) So far as I can see, the contemplated fast can only be conditional.
('79', 377, 1, 22, 764390) It will not be a fast unto death.
('79', 377, 1, 23, 764424) It will be for the accomplishment of a purpose.
('79', 377, 1, 24, 764472) Spiritually it cannot be considered of the highest order.
('79', 377, 1, 25, 764530) Still the purpose sought to be accomplished is sufficiently pure to deserve sacrifice of life.
('79', 377, 1, 26, 764625) If the purpose is accomplished, the fast can be terminated.
('79', 377, 1, 27, 764685) So this will be striving—a sort of tapasya—in the form of a fast, to attain a specific goal.
('79', 377, 1, 28, 764778) But although the fast will be a conditional one, seeing the present situation and the present attitude of the British, it is not likely that the Government will change their policy to save my life.
('79', 377, 1, 29, 764976) Saving their own lives has become so important to them that they will not hesitate to sacrifice fifty Gandhis for it.
('79', 377, 1, 30, 765094) At the same time they will also not have the wisdom to take to non violence and self purification for the solution of the problem.
('79', 377, 1, 31, 765225) So they will let me make the sacrifice, not from anger but because they will be helpless.
('79', 377, 1, 32, 765315) I have also received a suggestion that before I undertake the fast
('79', 378, 0, 1, 765382) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 379
('79', 378, 1, 2, 765428) or while I am on fast, I should let a few other co workers share in the sacrifice.
('79', 378, 1, 3, 765511) So long as I am alive it will not be a wise proceeding.
('79', 378, 1, 4, 765567) The purpose of this fast is not of merely local importance.
('79', 378, 1, 5, 765627) It has significance not only for the whole of India, but for the whole world.
('79', 378, 1, 6, 765705) The sacrifice here of fifty humble persons cannot carry as much weight as the sacrifice of one world famous figure.
('79', 378, 1, 7, 765821) And if the problem gets solved through such a sacrifice, the sole sacrifice, namely, of myself will be enough.
('79', 378, 1, 8, 765932) What you should do during my fast or after it, if it should end in my death, is a matter to be considered.
('79', 378, 1, 9, 766039) The constructive programme to be sure comprises thirteen different activities.
('79', 378, 1, 10, 766118) It can be further enlarged.
('79', 378, 1, 11, 766146) But there are three items in it that are the most important.
('79', 378, 1, 12, 766207) They are pregnant with revolutionary possibilities.
('79', 378, 1, 13, 766259) They are: khadi, eradication of untouchability and Hindu Muslim unity.
('79', 378, 1, 14, 766330) The MacDonald Award and ‘Pakistan’ are nothing but projections of our mental attitude of treating the Harijans and Muslims as separate from us.
('79', 378, 1, 15, 766474) Remember that the separation is not of their asking.
('79', 378, 1, 16, 766527) It is what we have chosen to give them, what we forced them to ask for.
('79', 378, 1, 17, 766599) Thus the unity between the caste Hindus and outcaste Hindus, and that between Hindus and Muslims and khadi represent a revolution in our own lives.
('79', 378, 1, 18, 766747) And in order to bring about this revolution you should devote all your energies and if necessary you should be prepared to lay down your lives in the manner of Fulsingh Bhagat and Amtul Salaam.
('79', 378, 1, 19, 766941) At the time when civil disobedience is going on, those who are engaged in constructive work, and do not, therefore, want to go to jail, will continue with the work in hand.
('79', 378, 1, 20, 767114) But, when other workers are insisting on a programme of jail going, it will not be right for you to initiate a vigorous programme of constructive work.
('79', 378, 1, 21, 767266) The mood among the people today is for jail going.
('79', 378, 1, 22, 767317) We should, therefore, concentrate on this.
('79', 378, 1, 23, 767360) If nevertheless a situation arises when all the people who want to go to jail have been arrested or I happen to be fasting or some local issue comes up, such as the one that has come up in Sind, then you will have to look after your work and your place.
('79', 378, 1, 24, 767614) Then you should launch an agitation and die if need be and do as your inner voice prompts you.
('79', 378, 1, 25, 767709) If after I am no more, your inner voice prompts you to initiate the tradition of fasting, you may do so.
('79', 378, 1, 26, 767814) But I do not say that it will be necessary.
('79', 378, 1, 27, 767858) You may be called upon to lay down your lives in yet another
('79', 379, 0, 1, 767919) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 379, 1, 2, 767961) set of conditions.
('79', 379, 1, 3, 767980) It is possible that the British or if they are defeated the occupation forces, may resort to repression to cow down people.
('79', 379, 1, 4, 768104) Even State machinery can be destroyed.
('79', 379, 1, 5, 768143) Such destruction to some extent may make things easier for them.
('79', 379, 1, 6, 768208) But the masses by and large will not be so treated.
('79', 379, 1, 7, 768260) They will be subjected to repression.
('79', 379, 1, 8, 768298) For example, if the countryside does not capitulate to the occupation forces on their terms, villages may be surrounded, armed guards could be placed at public wells to keep the public away from them, crops may be destroyed and people may thus be exposed to hunger and thirst.
('79', 379, 1, 9, 768575) The people must not submit.
('79', 379, 1, 10, 768603) We shall have to give them courage; we shall have to undergo hunger and thirst to generate in the people the strength to bear these hardships and die rather than to collaborate with the occupation forces.
('79', 379, 1, 11, 768808) If occasion can be found for me to confer with the co workers who have the same mission, I shall be happy.
('79', 379, 1, 12, 768915) But today I do not wish to plan for any such contingency.
('79', 379, 2, 13, 768973) From Hindi: C.W. 10745. Courtesy: Navajivan Trust
('79', 379, 3, 14, 769023) 398. MESSAGE TO STUDENTS
('79', 379, 4, 15, 769048) WARDHA, November 14, 1940
('79', 379, 5, 16, 769074) I have received several letters from students in Madras and the United Provinces regarding their demonstration over Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru’s arrest and imprisonment, and the threatened reprisals by the Governments concerned.
('79', 379, 5, 17, 769300) The students now desire to have a strike of protest and ask for my advice.
('79', 379, 5, 18, 769375) When the whole world hangs its head in shame over the imprisonment of one of India’s noblest and bravest sons, it is no wonder that the student world in India is shaken to its roots.
('79', 379, 5, 19, 769558) Whilst, therefore, my sympathy is wholly with them, I must adhere to the view that the students were wrong in their walk out as a mark of their resentment over Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru’s imprison ment.
('79', 379, 5, 20, 769759) The Governments of the provinces are more than wrong in their threats of reprisals.
('79', 379, 5, 21, 769843) The students will, however, do well not to resort to the contemplated strike of protest.

('79', 386, 1, 2, 777806) 414. LETTER TO GHULAM RASUL QURESHI
('79', 386, 2, 3, 777842) November 18, 1940
('79', 386, 3, 4, 777860) QURESHI, I have your beautiful letter.
('79', 386, 3, 5, 777899) Who knows what Islam says?
('79', 386, 3, 6, 777926) It has nowhere advocated suicide.
('79', 386, 3, 7, 777960) Amtul Salaam will do as God ordains.
('79', 386, 3, 8, 777997) I understand about the Muslim League.
('79', 386, 3, 9, 778035) It is our job to win them over also.
('79', 386, 3, 10, 778072) Many may have to die before we achieve our non violent victory.
('79', 386, 3, 11, 778136) If you cultivate sincere love, there will be work here itself [without going to jail].
('79', 386, 3, 12, 778223) Get Amina operated upon.

('79', 391, 4, 7, 784892) 425. DISCUSSION WITH TAI CHI TAO 1
('79', 391, 5, 8, 784927) [November 22/23, 1940] 2
('79', 391, 6, 9, 784952) TAI CHI TAO: We are passing through difficult times.
('79', 391, 6, 10, 785005) I want to know how we can get through our difficulty successfully.
('79', 391, 6, 11, 785072) Victory is not enough; future peaceful relations between nations must also be established.
('79', 391, 6, 12, 785163) The President, who is of a deeply religious temperament and had evinced a great interest in the constructive activities here and in Sethji’s temple at Wardha, had a rosary of beads in his hand.
('79', 391, 7, 13, 785357) Gandhiji, after making inquiries about his health begged to introduce him to the spinning wheel which, he said, was among the latest inventions, and plied the wheel as he answered the President’s question.
('79', 391, 8, 14, 785563) GANDHIJI: Just as you are engaged in a terrific life and death struggle, so are we.
('79', 391, 8, 15, 785647) Yours is an ancient country and so is ours and although yours is a much bigger country than ours, ours is not by any means a small country and there is much in common between you and us.
('79', 391, 8, 16, 785834) Speaking personally, I may inform you that I was in touch with the Chinese colony in Johannesburg and gave them legal advice.
('79', 391, 8, 17, 785960) They were a colony of 1,200 and I came in closest I touch with everyone of them and so the Chinese are not strangers to me by any means.
('79', 391, 8, 18, 786097) Although you are engaged in a life and death struggle and so
('79', 391, 9, 19, 786158) 1 The discussion is extracted from a statement by Mahadev Desai who explained that the goodwill mission of Tai Chi Tao, President of Examination of Yuan of Chinese Government, was in return for Jawaharlal Nehru’s visit to China in 1939. The statement said that the visiting President had brought special message for Gandhiji from Chiang Kai Shek and the Kuomintang.
('79', 391, 9, 20, 786524) Vide also “Letter to Chiang Kai Shek”, 26 11 1940. 2 Mahadev Desai says that Tai Chi Tao, his Secretary and others were in Wardha on November 22 and 23 as guests of Jamnalal Bajaj, who had come from Bombay specially for the occasion.
('79', 392, 0, 1, 786758) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 393
('79', 392, 1, 2, 786804) are we, the means we employ for regaining our freedom are different from the means you employ for retaining your freedom.
('79', 392, 1, 3, 786926) This does not mean that I want to criticize the means you have adopted.
('79', 392, 1, 4, 786998) The remedy you employ in self defence is an age old one.
('79', 392, 1, 5, 787055) I am employing a remedy which is unknown to the world on the political field.
('79', 392, 1, 6, 787133) But since you have come all the way from China merely to reciprocate the good wishes that Pandit Jawaharlal carried there, the only service I can render in my humble way is to put forward before you and, through you, the Generalissimo, the new remedy I am applying.
('79', 392, 1, 7, 787399) I found it in South Africa in 1906, when all my resources were exhausted, in order to combat difficulties which might have meant the death of the Indian community in the Transvaal if we had not found this remedy.
('79', 392, 1, 8, 787612) And since 1920, we have applied this remedy more or less successfully, perhaps with more success than otherwise, till at last the Congress has become a powerful body, and in a nutshell, it is this, viz., to be prepared to die as bravely as the bravest Chinese soldier, but without trying to kill your opponent or do the slightest harm to him, whether in offence or self defence.
('79', 392, 1, 9, 787991) If we succeed here in instilling into the mass mind bravery to die without killing, I think that not only shall we have regained our liberty without violence but we shall have presented to the world a remedy to do away with all wars.
('79', 392, 1, 10, 788225) If I have succeeded in giving you the kernel of the movement, I would ask you to watch this movement with interest and bless it on behalf of China.
('79', 392, 1, 11, 788373) More I cannot say until we have regained our liberty with these absolutely peaceful means.
('79', 392, 1, 12, 788464) You will see that it is not without a purpose that I have taken up the wheel at the present moment when, ordinarily speaking, it would be discourtesy to a guest to keep spinning when he comes.
('79', 392, 1, 13, 788657) But I have taken it up both to demonstrate the process and to show you how, externally speaking, I derive all the power of peace from the spinning wheel.
('79', 392, 1, 14, 788811) You will have noticed that the spinning wheel finds a central place in our national flag, and it is the one thing which establishes a living relation and identification with the masses of India.
('79', 392, 2, 15, 789006) President Tai Chi Tao said that he was greatly inspired by the message.
('79', 392, 2, 16, 789078) He had heard a great deal from newspapers about Gandhiji’s peaceful method and all it had accomplished, but he was grateful to hear it from his lips....
('79', 392, 3, 17, 789231) TAI CHI TAO: We had no alternative.
('79', 392, 3, 18, 789267) We had to resist violent aggression after a long waiting.
('79', 392, 3, 19, 789325) But now we have a movement to make our country self sufficient; in our villages, the spinning wheel has returned.
('79', 392, 3, 20, 789439) Nearly ninety per cent of our houses have their wheels, not so modern as yours, but old fashioned.
('79', 392, 3, 21, 789538) We have been thus
('79', 393, 0, 1, 789556) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 393, 1, 2, 789598) compelled by necessity to revive our national village industry.
('79', 393, 1, 3, 789662) All the big factories have been destroyed and bombed and some have moved to the interior and so we have to depend more or less on the spinning wheel which cannot be bombed.
('79', 393, 1, 4, 789835) Your spinning wheel gives me new inspiration.
('79', 393, 1, 5, 789881) Gandhiji now gave a demonstration on the latest model, the Dhanush Takli, and offered both the wheels as presents to President Tai Chi Tao.
('79', 393, 1, 6, 790021) But he had already purchased the wheels in the morning.

('79', 395, 6, 12, 792924) 430. INTERVIEW TO M. L. SHAH 2
('79', 395, 7, 13, 792955) [Before November 24, 1940] 3
('79', 395, 8, 14, 792984) Gandhiji agreed with me that students should have freedom to arrange meetings and take out processions in a peaceful and orderly manner to express their resentment against repressive measures.
('79', 395, 8, 15, 793177) Regarding political strikes, such as those on the arrest of national leaders, Gandhiji advised that students should create an atmosphere which may win the sympathies of the educational authorities, who might themselves close the institutions.
('79', 395, 8, 16, 793420) Gandhiji felt sorry when he heard about forced war contributions from students, and advised the students to resist all such actions.
('79', 395, 8, 17, 793553) He appreciated the potentialities of the students, and if he succeeded in getting their support to his constructive programme, he was confident that the students would form the vanguard of the struggle.
('79', 395, 9, 18, 793756) The Hindustan Times, 25 11 1940
('79', 395, 10, 19, 793788) 1 Also called Tari, sister of Sushila Gandhi 2 The interview appeared as “stated by Mr. M. L. Shah, General Secretary of the All India Students’ Federation, who recently met Mahatma Gandhi at Wardha and explained to him the attitude of the authorities towards the student movements’.
('79', 395, 10, 20, 794072) 3 Reported under the date line “Lucknow, November 24” 4 The report concluded with M. L. Shah’s appeal to the students “to co operate with him to fulfil the assurance which he has given ‘to the noblest and greatest friend of the student community’ by being peaceful in all that they did and said”.

('79', 396, 2, 3, 794442) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, November 24, 1940
('79', 396, 3, 4, 794478) DAUGHTER, I was busy with so many things yesterday that I could not write to you.

('79', 396, 3, 6, 794619) All letters are preserved.
('79', 396, 3, 7, 794646) During the telephone talk today I gave answers according to my lights.
('79', 396, 3, 8, 794717) I said that Qureshi and Zohra might not be sent now.

('79', 400, 11, 14, 800122) 441. LETTER TO SIR J. G. LAITHWAITE
('79', 400, 12, 15, 800158) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, November 27, 1940
('79', 400, 13, 16, 800194) DEAR MR. LAITHWAITE, I would like you to place this before His Excellency and the contents to be telegraphed, if possible, to the Secretary of State for India or to be brought to his notice in such manner as His Excellency may wish.
('79', 400, 13, 17, 800427) The Secretary of State is reported by the Press as follows: 1
('79', 400, 14, 18, 800489) The Congress under Mr. Gandhi’s leadership has decided to express its dissatisfaction by a campaign of defiance of law by instalments.
('79', 400, 14, 19, 800624) What they (my colleagues) have demanded is the right to urge Indians not to recruit, not to work in munition factories or to contribute voluntary contributions to the War Committee.
('79', 400, 14, 20, 800806) While it is not possible in theory to deny the truth of the statement, Mr. Amery should have known that he was giving his
('79', 400, 15, 21, 800928) 1 He was speaking in the House of Commons on November 20.
('79', 401, 0, 1, 800986) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 401, 1, 2, 801028) uninformed audience a view which was not warranted by the following from my Press statement of October 15 1, 1940:
('79', 401, 2, 3, 801143) I know that India has not one mind.
('79', 401, 2, 4, 801179) There is a part of India that is war minded and will learn the art of war through helping the British.
('79', 401, 2, 5, 801282) The Congress has no desire, therefore, to surround ammunition factories or barracks and prevent people from doing what they like.
('79', 401, 2, 6, 801412) And add to the above the following slogan which I have standardized, and on the strength of which civil resisters are being imprisoned: “It is wrong to help the British war effort with either men or money.
('79', 401, 2, 7, 801618) The only worthy effort is to resist all war by non violent resistance.” It is wholly wrong to say that we have demanded the right to urge voluntary contributors not to pay voluntary contributions.
('79', 401, 2, 8, 801815) The truth is that undue pressure and even force is being used on behalf of the British Government to extract money from unwilling parties who in several cases are even too poor to pay.
('79', 401, 2, 9, 802000) Then I take the following from the Secretary of State’s speech about Pandit Nehru: Vinoba Bhave was to have been followed by Pandit Nehru who, however, outstripped Mr. Gandhi both in time and I believe in the character of the speeches he made.
('79', 401, 2, 10, 802244) The speeches were violent and deliberately provocative and were deliberately aimed at hampering the war effort and did so in effect as well as in intention.
('79', 401, 2, 11, 802401) In any case Pandit Nehru’s sentence was a matter not for the executive but for the law.
('79', 401, 2, 12, 802489) If the sentence is judged by him to be excessive, he has the right to appeal.
('79', 401, 2, 13, 802567) I regard this as a cruel libel uttered against a man who has been put behind prison bars.
('79', 401, 2, 14, 802657) There is nothing in his speeches having the slightest odour of violence.
('79', 401, 2, 15, 802730) I must deny that Pandit Nehru outstripped me.
('79', 401, 2, 16, 802776) Indeed the Provincial Government outstripped me.
('79', 401, 2, 17, 802825) They knew that he had come to me to fix up when, where and how he was to offer civil disobedience.
('79', 401, 2, 18, 802924) In my letter 2 of October 30, 1940, I had informed His Excellency that the Pandit was the next to offer civil disobedience and that, as soon as the date and place were finally fixed, I would inform him.
('79', 401, 2, 19, 803127) And yet before he could arrange affairs, his journey was interrupted and he was taken to Gorakhpur for trial.
('79', 401, 2, 20, 803237) It is worse than a cruel mockery to suggest against the charge of a vindictive sentence that Pandit Nehru could have appealed against the sentence, if he had so chosen.
('79', 401, 2, 21, 803406) The Rt.
('79', 401, 2, 22, 803414) the Secretary of State surely knew that Pandit Nehru would not appeal against the sentence.
('79', 401, 3, 23, 803506) 1 The source, however, has “14”; Vide “Civil Disobedience” 2 Vide “To the Reader”
('79', 402, 0, 1, 803588) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 403
('79', 402, 1, 2, 803634) I write this because I feel grieved that one who has the charge of the affairs of a sub continent should have dealt with friendly opponents in a manner ill befitting his charge.
('79', 402, 1, 3, 803812) British statesmen seem to go out of their way to court the doubtful friendship of powers who have no friendly feeling for Britian and to lose no opportunity of estranging those who would gladly befriend them.
('79', 402, 1, 4, 804021) I have written all this in sorrow, not in anger, certainly not for publication.
('79', 402, 2, 5, 804101) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('79', 404, 1, 2, 806364) 445. LETTER TO ABDUL WADUD SARHADI 1
('79', 404, 2, 3, 806401) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, November 28, 1940
('79', 404, 3, 4, 806437) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('79', 404, 3, 5, 806470) Opinions differ in your province itself.
('79', 404, 3, 6, 806511) Everyone is left to his own free choice whether to offer civil disobedience or not.
('79', 404, 3, 7, 806595) But if he does, he has to conform to conditions laid down, one of which is belief in Hindu Muslim unity.

('79', 404, 6, 12, 806863) 446. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('79', 404, 7, 13, 806891) WARDHA, November 29, 1940
('79', 404, 8, 14, 806917) My attention has been drawn to some paragraphs appearing in the Press, purporting to give my opinion about the questions agitating the students.
('79', 404, 8, 15, 807062) I have not read all that has appeared in the Press, if only because I want to conserve my energy, on which of late I have been obliged to put an unduly heavy strain.
('79', 404, 8, 16, 807228) My opinion is firm.
('79', 404, 8, 17, 807248) 2 No provocation should be allowed to justify political strikes by students unless they have made up their mind once for all to abandon their college or school studies.
('79', 404, 8, 18, 807417) Unlike as in free countries, our educational institutions are controlled by the rulers from whom the nation is struggling to free itself.
('79', 404, 8, 19, 807555) Self suppression is, therefore, the price the students must pay for receiving the education evolved and controlled by the rulers.
('79', 404, 8, 20, 807685) They cannot have the cake and eat it, too.
('79', 404, 8, 21, 807728) If they want the education which the schools and colleges impart, and evidently they do, they have to conform to
('79', 404, 9, 22, 807841) 1 The addressee, President, Jamiat ul Ulema e Sarhad, in his letter dated November 23 to Gandhiji, had disapproved of the Civil Disobedience Movement and suggested unity between Congress and Muslim League as a worthy effort.
('79', 404, 9, 23, 808066) 2 Vide also “Message to Students”, 14 11 1940
('79', 405, 0, 1, 808112) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 405, 1, 2, 808154) the rules and regulations laid down for these institutions.
('79', 405, 1, 3, 808214) Therefore, unless the heads of the institutions consent, there should be no political strikes.
('79', 405, 1, 4, 808309) But I have suggested a way out.
('79', 405, 1, 5, 808341) Students have ample time, after school and college hours, of which they are their own masters.
('79', 405, 1, 6, 808436) They can hold meetings, express their sympathy with the national cause in an orderly manner and they can have processions, too, if they like.
('79', 405, 1, 7, 808578) Those who wish to take part in civil disobedience and accept my leadership can do so after suspending their studies for the time being, by conforming to the conditions laid down for offering individual civil disobedience and after receiving my permission.
('79', 405, 1, 8, 808834) Letters being received by me from individual students show that they have little faith in my leadership, for they have no faith in the constructive programme, of which the centre and the most visible part is khadi.
('79', 405, 1, 9, 809049) They do not believe in spinning and if my correspondents are to be accepted as reliable witnesses, their belief in non violence is also a doubtful quantity.
('79', 405, 1, 10, 809206) Students can play an effective part in the national struggle, if they will whole heartedly come under the discipline.
('79', 405, 1, 11, 809324) But if they will act on their own and fritter away their energy in making ineffective demonstrations, they will hinder the national cause.
('79', 405, 1, 12, 809463) I am glad to be able to testify that Congressmen are showing a measure of discipline, which is an agreeable surprise to me for I was unprepared for it.
('79', 405, 1, 13, 809615) Let it not be said of the student world that, at the eleventh hour, they were found wanting.
('79', 405, 1, 14, 809708) Let them remember that I am asking for greater steadfastness, greater courage and greater self sacrifice than can be denoted by undisciplined and thoughtless demonstrations.
('79', 405, 1, 15, 809882) The students should also realize that the number of civil resisters will always be confined to a few, compared with the 350 million forming the nation.
('79', 405, 1, 16, 810034) There is no limit to the number who should take part in working the constructive programme.
('79', 405, 1, 17, 810126) I regard this as the most useful and effective part of the movement for independence, without which civil resistance will cease to be civil and, therefore, be utterly valueless.
('79', 405, 2, 18, 810304) The Hindu, 30 11 1940
('79', 406, 0, 1, 810326) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 407
('79', 406, 1, 2, 810372) 447. LETTER TO VISHVAMBHAR NATH BHARGAVA

('79', 406, 3, 4, 810441) BHAI VISHVAMBHAR NATHJI 1, I have your letter 2. Individual advice can be only subject to the Congress Committee’s.
('79', 406, 3, 5, 810557) If I unknowingly give an opposite advice it should not be followed.

('79', 406, 3, 10, 810825) But even if it arose after the war but was not concerned with the war, an appeal would lie.
('79', 406, 3, 11, 810917) And on occasion it may be one’s duty to file such an appeal.
('79', 406, 3, 12, 810978) I found nothing improper in what Ramnarayan told me about khadi, etc.
('79', 406, 3, 13, 811048) He is very reserved with me.

('79', 406, 5, 22, 811471) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, November 30, 1940
('79', 406, 6, 23, 811507) BRIJKRISHNA, I got your letter.

('79', 408, 1, 2, 813320) 451. ABSTRACT OF LETTER TO MUKUNDLAL SIRCAR 1
('79', 408, 2, 3, 813366) [Before December 2, 1940] 2
('79', 408, 3, 4, 813394) The issue on which individual civil disobedience has been started is undoubtedly that of free speech and free pen.
('79', 408, 3, 5, 813509) But at the end of every issue is independent India.
('79', 408, 3, 6, 813561) The movement was limited, in its original conception, to two or three persons, and then extended to members selected by me belonging to the Working Committee, the A.I.C.C. and the Central and Provincial Legislatures.
('79', 408, 3, 7, 813778) And, according to the occasion and the reaction on me after each move, it is capable of infinite expansion.
('79', 408, 3, 8, 813886) I have called for classified lists of members of Provincial Congress Committee Executives and similarly of District Congress Committees, Firka or Taluk Congress Committees, and lastly of village Congress Committees.
('79', 408, 3, 9, 814102) But whatever the expansion may be, it will never be a mass movement.
('79', 408, 3, 10, 814171) It will always remain, so far as I can see, individual disobedience and will be confined to those who believe in and fulfil my conditions.
('79', 408, 4, 11, 814310) The Hindu, 5 12 1940
('79', 408, 5, 12, 814331) 452. LETTER TO SIR REGINALD MAXWELL
('79', 408, 6, 13, 814367) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, December 2, 1940
('79', 408, 7, 14, 814402) DEAR SIR REGINALD, Mahadev Desai gave me your kind message which he has embodied in the full notes he prepared for me of his doings in Delhi.
('79', 408, 7, 15, 814544) The portion of the notes containing the message reads as follows:
('79', 408, 8, 16, 814610) Well, well, I should have thought that the correct position for a man like Mr. Gandhi to take would have been to address a manifesto to the people of India stating his own position as he did in his appeal 3 to every Briton and then be quiet.
('79', 408, 8, 17, 814852) Give this message from me to Mr. Gandhi.
('79', 408, 8, 18, 814893) I have been fagged out and for some days cutting down the daily work to the minimum.
('79', 408, 8, 19, 814978) Hence the delay in reply.
('79', 408, 8, 20, 815004) Even so, I enter
('79', 408, 9, 21, 815021) 1 The addressee, Acting General Secretary of All India Forward Bloc, had, in a letter, asked Gandhiji about “Individual Satyagraha Movement and whether it would lead to mass civil disobedience”.
('79', 408, 9, 22, 815216) The letter was reported under the date line “Calcutta, December 2”.
('79', 408, 9, 23, 815284) 2 ibid 3 Vide “To Every Briton”
('79', 409, 0, 1, 815316) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 409, 1, 2, 815358) into a discussion of your message for the sake of elucidating truth.
('79', 409, 1, 3, 815427) I know how busy you are and care worn.
('79', 409, 1, 4, 815466) But the only way satyagraha works is by a continuous discovery of truth and action based on it.
('79', 409, 1, 5, 815562) In the progress towards full discovery the satyagrahi has to show that he is ever ready and even eager to learn and appreciate the opponent’s side.
('79', 409, 1, 6, 815710) It is in that spirit that I approach your message.
('79', 409, 1, 7, 815761) You would be wholly right in the advice you have sent me if I was a preacher.
('79', 409, 1, 8, 815839) But I have never adopted that role.
('79', 409, 1, 9, 815875) I am essentially a man of action and a reformer carrying on an experiment never before tried in the political field.
('79', 409, 1, 10, 815992) Hence at the risk of making mistakes even big I must continue to tread the chosen path so long as I have no sense of mistake or distrust of my action.
('79', 409, 1, 11, 816143) My desire is to cause the least embarrassment to the Government consistently with the prosecution of my mission.
('79', 409, 1, 12, 816256) If it is successful, it cannot fail to benefit the British side by side with India and ultimately the world.
('79', 409, 1, 13, 816365) If it fails, the Government cannot be hurt.
('79', 409, 1, 14, 816409) I cannot carry the argument any further.
('79', 409, 1, 15, 816450) Perhaps what I have said is no argument but a bare recital of the motive behind my action and its interpretation in the light of the motive.
('79', 409, 1, 16, 816591) The rest must be left to time.
('79', 409, 1, 17, 816622) Mahadev Desai told me about your dear ones being in the thick of the fight.
('79', 409, 1, 18, 816698) I am conscious of the fact that what applies to you applies to almost all the known British families.
('79', 409, 1, 19, 816800) How I wish I could have stood side by side with them.
('79', 409, 1, 20, 816854) But duty has enjoined upon me a seemingly opposite course.
('79', 409, 1, 21, 816913) I take comfort in the fact that though seeming to be in the opposite camp, I work for the same end as is declared by the British Government, only with the certain conviction that their method can never defeat Hitlerism and mine alone can, if any at all.
('79', 409, 2, 22, 817167) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('79', 409, 3, 23, 817197) From a copy: C.W. 7858. Courtesy: G. D. Birla
('79', 409, 4, 24, 817243) 1 Acknowledging this letter on December 7, the addressee said: “I am glad to know that you are only seemingly in the opposite camp and that your end is the same as ours.
('79', 409, 4, 25, 817413) Although I regret that there should be differences about the method of attaining it, I see that I must leave you to work things out in your own way.”

('79', 414, 3, 10, 825543) 461. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('79', 414, 4, 11, 825571) WARDHAGANJ, December 7, 1940
('79', 414, 5, 12, 825600) I have just been made aware of the movement to withdraw from the match 1, I understand, as a mark of grief over the arrests and imprisonment of satyagrahis, more especially recent arrests of leaders.
('79', 414, 5, 13, 825800) I must confess ignorance of these matches and the etiquette governing them.
('79', 414, 5, 14, 825876) My opinion must, therefore, be taken as of a layman knowing nothing of such sports and special rules governing them.
('79', 414, 5, 15, 825993) But I must confess my sympathies wholly with those who would like to see these matches stopped.
('79', 414, 5, 16, 826089) I express this opinion not merely as a satyagrahi desirous of getting public support in some way or other for the movement.
('79', 414, 5, 17, 826213) I must say at once that the present movement is wholly independent of such demonstrations or adventitious support.
('79', 414, 5, 18, 826328) But I would discountenance such amusements at a time when the thinking world should be mourning over the war that is threatening the stable life of Europe and its civilization and which bids fare to overwhelm Asia.
('79', 414, 6, 19, 826543) 1 The reference is to the pentangular cricket match to be played in Bombay on December 12; vide also “Telegram to Bhalerao”, 12 10 1940
('79', 415, 0, 1, 826679) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 415, 1, 2, 826721) I would like the public of Bombay to revise their sporting code and erase from it communal matches.
('79', 415, 1, 3, 826821) I can understand matches between colleges and institutions but I never understood reasons for having Hindu, Parsi, Muslim and other communal elevens.
('79', 415, 1, 4, 826971) Can you not have some field of life which cannot be touched by the communal spirit?
('79', 415, 1, 5, 827055) I should like, therefore, those who have anything to do with this movement to stop the match, broaden the issue and take the opportunity of considering it from the highest standpoint and decide once for all upon banishing communal taints from sporting world and also deciding upon banishing these sports from our life whilst blood bath is going on.
('79', 415, 2, 6, 827404) The Hitavada, 8 12 1940

('79', 417, 3, 4, 829909) DEAR SIR, Shri Pyarelal Nayyar, my co worker for past twenty five years and co secretary with Shri Mahadev Desai, will offer civil disobedience tomorrow at 9 a.m.
('79', 417, 3, 5, 830072) from the railway gate leading to Wardha from Sevagram.
('79', 417, 3, 6, 830127) He will walk on in the direction of Ahjee and continue until arrested or except for rest and food.
('79', 417, 3, 7, 830226) On the way he will recite the following slogan 3 in Hindustani or Marathi as occasion demands.
('79', 417, 3, 8, 830321) In order to show that this movement is wholly non violent and independent of boisterous demonstrations and in order to warn the public against a repetition of the recent unfortunate exhibition of indiscipline in Patna and Lahore, I am avoiding the usual notice to the public of the proposed civil disobedience tomorrow.
('79', 417, 3, 9, 830641) I have only informed Sheth Jamnalal and Shri Gopalrao, the President of the Provincial Congress Committee, with strict instructions not to advertise the function in any way.
('79', 417, 4, 10, 830815) From a copy: Pyarelal Papers.

('79', 422, 2, 3, 837344) December 9, 1940
('79', 422, 3, 4, 837361) DAUGHTER, The more I think of your letter the more highly I think of you.
('79', 422, 3, 5, 837435) And I feel happy.
('79', 422, 3, 6, 837453) You should do your work on your own responsibility.
('79', 422, 3, 7, 837505) It is true that you came over here on your mission; you went to Sind and will go there again in pursuit of your own mission.
('79', 422, 3, 8, 837630) You will certainly get my counsel; but whatever you do should be your own responsibility.
('79', 422, 3, 9, 837720) You will, of course, consult Jairamdas and others whom you wish to.
('79', 422, 3, 10, 837788) You can go whenever you like.
('79', 422, 3, 11, 837818) It was good that I sent for you here.
('79', 422, 3, 12, 837856) For the present be guided by Dr. Das.
('79', 422, 3, 13, 837894) Do not call on anyone here.
('79', 422, 3, 14, 837922) Give up the temptation of rendering even the least little service to me.
('79', 422, 3, 15, 837995) If you cannot desist, you may well do it.
('79', 422, 3, 16, 838037) But the less you serve me, the less friction there will be.
('79', 422, 3, 17, 838097) You will be with Madam Wadia 1 as long as she is here.
('79', 422, 3, 18, 838152) Seek her advice.
('79', 422, 3, 19, 838169) That will keep you busy for quite some time.
('79', 422, 3, 20, 838214) Now about your work in Sind.
('79', 422, 3, 21, 838243) You have to give up all interest in the [problems of] prisoners and [dispute about] Manzilgah.
('79', 422, 3, 22, 838338) 2 You may listen to everyone; but this is a matter for the courts to decide.
('79', 422, 3, 23, 838415) You have to explain to the Muslims of Sind that in political matters and the like, justice cannot be secured through murder, force or untruth.
('79', 422, 3, 24, 838558) Your going to Sind and even sacrificing your life should be for stopping the bloodshed, whether or no the Muslims get justice or injustice.
('79', 422, 3, 25, 838698) That was my object in sending you, and remains so even now.
('79', 422, 3, 26, 838758) Despite these views of mine, I do not wish to explain things to you or advise you elaborately.
('79', 422, 3, 27, 838853) I shall not be in a position to advise you in political matters since I shall have to listen to and abide by the words of Maulana.
('79', 422, 3, 28, 838984) In respect of bloodshed, it is not necessary to consult him.
('79', 422, 3, 29, 839045) I do think that you should not do anything against the wishes of Maulana.
('79', 422, 3, 30, 839119) It is your duty to meet Muslim Leaguers, to listen to them and to love them.

('79', 423, 10, 17, 840300) [Before December 10, 1940] 2

('79', 423, 11, 19, 840419) He became at once serious and said, why should satyagraha stop if he started his fast; there was no connection between the two.
('79', 423, 11, 20, 840547) Satyagraha would and must go on in spite of the fast.
('79', 423, 11, 21, 840601) I showed him the list.
('79', 423, 11, 22, 840624) He asked me whether I have got full information of those whose names I had suggested.
('79', 423, 11, 23, 840710) I said, “Yes, I have brought that.”
('79', 423, 12, 24, 840746) GANDHIJI: Do you know the ages of those satyagrahis?

('79', 423, 14, 26, 840879) G. That is not sufficient.
('79', 423, 14, 27, 840906) Do you know how many persons are dependent on each of the satyagrahis?

('79', 426, 2, 7, 846289) D. Should the communists be included in the list?
('79', 426, 4, 8, 846339) D. Should we open volunteer camps?
('79', 426, 6, 9, 846374) D. What about meetings?
('79', 426, 6, 10, 846398) G. No meetings should be held for satyagraha, that is creating violent atmosphere.
('79', 426, 6, 11, 846481) Look at the Ghatkopar incident.
('79', 426, 6, 12, 846513) I don’t want to give the slightest opportunity for violence.
('79', 426, 6, 13, 846574) Only slogans should be prononunced.
('79', 426, 6, 14, 846610) Notice to the District Magistrate is sufficient.
('79', 426, 6, 15, 846659) People should not be informed of your satyagraha.
('79', 426, 6, 16, 846709) Maybe the three slogans, viz., (i) not to give money (ii) not to give men for army (iii) to oppose war measures by non violent means—this should be on everybody’s mouth just as Ramanama has become universal.
('79', 426, 6, 17, 846917) Does it require notification to the people?
('79', 426, 6, 18, 846961) Every man, child and woman should repeat that.
('79', 426, 6, 19, 847008) Let the whole atmosphere be surcharged with this mantra.
('79', 426, 6, 20, 847065) You can have meetings no doubt but they should not be for the purpose of satyagraha.
('79', 426, 6, 21, 847150) I told him that persons arrested under Section 129 would be served with restraint orders after they are kept in jail for two months.
('79', 426, 6, 22, 847283) “Should they break the orders immediately?” G. Yes, if their names are approved by me, they must disobey the orders.
('79', 426, 7, 23, 847400) D. What about those who come out after their term of sentence is over?
('79', 426, 7, 24, 847471) I have selected them and I want them to go to jail again and again.
('79', 426, 7, 25, 847539) They require no further permission from me to offer satyagraha.
('79', 426, 7, 26, 847603) This is the last fight, we must sacrifice all for it.
('79', 426, 7, 27, 847657) You don’t offer satyagraha soon.
('79', 426, 8, 28, 847690) D. How will it be possible?
('79', 426, 8, 29, 847718) I am doing this work and any day I am likely to be arrested.
('79', 426, 9, 30, 847779) G. Yes, yes, I am sitting on the mouth of death, anything may happen to you and to me.
('79', 426, 9, 31, 847866) But instruct your successor to mind my order.
('79', 426, 9, 32, 847912) The second list must not begin before January.
('79', 426, 10, 33, 847959) Gandhiji appeared full of hopes and sure of success.
('79', 426, 10, 34, 848012) I took his leave and departed.

('79', 428, 5, 9, 849452) 479. LETTER TO SIR J. G. LAITHWAITE
('79', 428, 6, 10, 849488) SEVAGRAM, WARDHA, December 10, 1940
('79', 428, 7, 11, 849524) DEAR MR. LAITHWAITE, The time has arrived for informing His Excellency of the development that is going on within and the outward expression it is to find.
('79', 428, 7, 12, 849680) In every step I am taking I bear in mind the difficulties through which the brave people of the British Isles are passing.
('79', 428, 7, 13, 849803) Hence I am moving slowly and with the greatest deliberation.
('79', 428, 7, 14, 849864) It is my deep conviction that in all I am doing I am serving the British, in spite of themselves, equally, with my own people.
('79', 428, 7, 15, 849991) This I can do only if I keep the movement completely non violent or as much as is possible for a popular movement to be.
('79', 428, 7, 16, 850112) I know that notwithstanding great care, I am sometimes deceived.
('79', 428, 7, 17, 850177) But I know too that in the aggregate the balance is in favour of honesty.
('79', 428, 7, 18, 850251) To ensure this and to set the tone, I began with my best representative who cannot be called a politician in the accepted sense.
('79', 428, 7, 19, 850380) I refer to Shri Vinoba Bhave.
('79', 428, 7, 20, 850410) Then I took up politicians, pure and simple.
('79', 428, 7, 21, 850455) But I cannot be sure of the probity of large numbers of people with whom I have no personal contact.
('79', 428, 7, 22, 850556) I have perforce to rely upon certificates of political associates.
('79', 428, 7, 23, 850623) I believe that in the majority of cases the selections have been well made.
('79', 428, 7, 24, 850699) But since I am myself not offering civil disobedience, I feel that I must send more men like Shri Vinoba Bhave for I am anxious to show that the movement is not purely political.
('79', 428, 7, 25, 850878) It is much more.
('79', 428, 7, 26, 850895) And so Pyarelal Nayyar has gone today.
('79', 428, 7, 27, 850934) He and Mahadev have been my constant companions all these many years.
('79', 428, 7, 28, 851004) Satyagraha is a movement of self purification and self sacrifice.
('79', 428, 7, 29, 851070) I must continue to part with the best I have.
('79', 428, 7, 30, 851116) And so Mahadev will follow Pyarelal in due course.
('79', 428, 7, 31, 851167) There are many who have no political ambition and yet who have a passionate love for freedom and still greater for the famishing millions.
('79', 428, 7, 32, 851306) Many of these have still to be sent.
('79', 428, 7, 33, 851343) They and the elected
('79', 429, 0, 1, 851364) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 429, 1, 2, 851406) members in the Congress organization who fulfil my conditions as to the charkha, untouchability and communal harmony will be offered.
('79', 429, 1, 3, 851540) I propose to offer them from the beginning of the New Year.
('79', 429, 1, 4, 851600) I must continue to offer such sacrifice until I carry conviction to the ruling power that the satyagrahis represent a definite opinion in the country and that they represent millions.
('79', 429, 1, 5, 851784) Theirs is a mission of peace to vindicate which they are prepared to sacrifice their all.
('79', 429, 1, 6, 851874) It is no less to them a matter of principle of the life and death than to the British power against whom they are seemingly at war.
('79', 429, 1, 7, 852006) They are as much opposed to Hitlerism and Fascism as the latter.
('79', 429, 1, 8, 852071) Only they fight with the weapons of non violence whereas the latter vainly expect to kill Hitlerism by excelling Hitler and Mussolini in the manufacture and use of weapons that these two dictators use.
('79', 429, 1, 9, 852273) I hope this argument will not jar on His Excellency.
('79', 429, 1, 10, 852326) I bring it forward to claim for our movement the same reality and strength that are claimed on behalf of the British.
('79', 429, 1, 11, 852444) They are none the less because they do not apply to the whole of India.
('79', 429, 1, 12, 852516) It was therefore wrong for Mr. Amery to characterize the movement as artificial.
('79', 429, 1, 13, 852597) Do the hundreds who have gone to jail love prison life?
('79', 429, 1, 14, 852653) Oh, for an ounce of imagination to realize that a human being wearing a brown or black skin can have equal susceptibility with the wearers of the white skin!
('79', 429, 1, 15, 852811) The notes that Mahadev prepared for me put these words in your mouth:
('79', 429, 2, 16, 852881) I have to reply to your question about Harijan.
('79', 429, 2, 17, 852929) Well, Mr. Gandhi has to make up his own mind.
('79', 429, 2, 18, 852975) Only let him or you not preach any breach of the law.
('79', 429, 2, 19, 853029) If Mahadev has correctly reported you, may I say that the warning was unnecessary.
('79', 429, 2, 20, 853112) How can an unlawful movement be conducted lawfully by a newspaper guided by the author of the movement?
('79', 429, 2, 21, 853216) But many things remain lawful so long as the Government wish them to remain so.
('79', 429, 2, 22, 853296) I am quite sure that you can prosecute me or Mahadev for many things we have written.
('79', 429, 2, 23, 853382) Harijan, therefore, can be restarted during the pendency of the movement, only if the Government desire it and believe that it was an organ which was serving both the nations, indeed the whole of humanity.
('79', 429, 3, 24, 853588) Yours sincerely,
('79', 429, 4, 25, 853605) From a copy: C.W. 7859. Courtesy: G. D. Birla

('79', 436, 3, 7, 863102) 493. LETTER TO GURUMUKH SINGH MUSAFIR December 15, 1940
('79', 436, 4, 8, 863158) DEAR GIANIJI 1, You have asked me for my interpretation of the teachings of the Ten Gurus 2. Here it is: I regard Guru Granth Saheb as one of the scriptures of the world.
('79', 436, 4, 9, 863329) I consider myself an humble follower of their teachings as of the teachings of Islam, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, Judaism, Hinduism.
('79', 436, 4, 10, 863464) The essence of the teachings (so far as non violence is concerned and that is what you want to know from me) is, that they all enjoin non violence as a duty, but they tolerate violence when the choice before the votary is between cowardly surrender and the use of the sword.

('79', 441, 0, 1, 870326) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 441, 1, 2, 870368) 504. INSTRUCTIONS TO SATYAGRAHIS 1
('79', 441, 2, 3, 870403) WARDHAGANJ, December 17, 1940
('79', 441, 3, 4, 870433) Under Gandhiji’s instructions I have to make the following announcement: All Provincial Congress Committees and other Committees will please note that there is to be no satyagraha during Christmas, that is to say, between December 24 and January 4, both days inclusive.
('79', 441, 3, 5, 870703) Satyagrahis outside the three permitted classes may start satyagraha on and after January 5 and all lists approved by Gandhiji may be finished by April 5. A number of applications are being received here direct from various parts of the country.
('79', 441, 3, 6, 870949) In many cases we have referred them to the Pradesh Congress Committees concerned.
('79', 441, 3, 7, 871031) But we have not been able to reach all applications.
('79', 441, 3, 8, 871084) All intending satyagrahis will please note that they have to apply to the P.C.Cs of their respective provinces clearly stating their names and addresses, age, occupation, their freedom from commitments and illness and declaring faith in Truth and non violence and in the constructive programme.
('79', 441, 3, 9, 871379) Concretely stated, they should express their belief in non violence as the only means of attaining swaraj and the only worthy way of ending all wars within the terms of the Bombay resolution 2 of the A.I.C.C.; that they believe in the vital connection between non violence and constructive programme, and that their faith in the constructive programme is evidenced in regular spinning and habitual wearing of khadi, and insistence on the use of handmade articles and promotion of village industries and crafts, in the total abolition of untouchability, and in the insistence on communal unity.
('79', 441, 3, 10, 871973) The best thing perhaps would be for all provinces to have forms stating all these details which should be filled in by those intending to offer satyagraha in the presence of responsible Congress workers.
('79', 441, 3, 11, 872177) Some provinces have already started this procedure.
('79', 441, 3, 12, 872229) This will prevent a good deal of waste of time and money involved in postage.
('79', 441, 3, 13, 872307) Over and above the fulfilment of the aforesaid conditions, those who have not decided to give up their studies and who have not secured permission of their parents or guardians should not apply.
('79', 441, 3, 14, 872502) I would request the Press not to make unauthorized statements about satyagraha.
('79', 441, 3, 15, 872582) Thus for instance the report that instructions have been sent to Delhi to suspend satyagraha is without foundation.
('79', 441, 3, 16, 872698) The Hitavada, 18 12 1940
('79', 441, 4, 17, 872723) 1 Issued by Mahadev Desai 2 Vide “All India Congress Committee Resolution”, 15 9 1940
('79', 442, 0, 1, 872809) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 443

('79', 443, 1, 2, 874759) 507. LETTER TO P. B. GOLE
('79', 443, 2, 3, 874785) [Before December 18, 1940] 1
('79', 443, 3, 4, 874814) I have been told that you observe untouchability, practically according to the original formula which I had used for all caste Hindus.
('79', 443, 3, 5, 874949) Obviously that is insufficient for Congressmen and specially Congress leaders.
('79', 443, 3, 6, 875028) I had, therefore, said that if what was reported to me about your belief and practice was true, you should not offer civil disobedience.
('79', 443, 3, 7, 875165) When, however, Kishorelalbhai Mashruwala sent me a note that you had felt grieved, I at once invited you to come and see me and you were good enough to respond quickly.
('79', 443, 3, 8, 875334) In the course of our talk I understood that your belief in the necessity of purging Hinduism of the canker of untouchability and the consequent belief in high caste and low caste and outcaste was as pure and as high as that of the tallest Congressman, but in your home you observe strict rules of purity, so that you exclude, irrespective of caste, from the domestic dining chowka, those who do not observe the same stiff rules that the members of your family do.
('79', 443, 3, 9, 875798) This practice has nothing to do with untouchability and had no application to Harijans as such, and stood on its own footing.
('79', 443, 3, 10, 875924) I also understood that outside the domestic circle, you acted precisely as any Congressman would act towards Harijans.
('79', 443, 4, 11, 876043) I am sorry that in my ignorance I attributed to you and Dr. Parasnis a belief which neither of you entertains.
('79', 443, 4, 12, 876154) I was delighted to find I had erred, and that I could claim you as members of the satyagraha band.
('79', 443, 5, 13, 876253) The Hindustan Times, 24 12 1940
('79', 443, 6, 14, 876285) 1 The letter was reported under the date line “Nagpur, December 18”.
('79', 443, 6, 15, 876354) 2 The source reported that it was with these words that Gandhiji “allowed P. B. Gole, ex Congress Minister, C.P. and Berar, to offer satyagraha”.

('79', 444, 5, 7, 876767) 509. DISCUSSION WITH G. D. BIRLA AND DEVDAS GANDHI
('79', 444, 6, 8, 876818) December 18/19, 1940
('79', 444, 7, 9, 876839) I was with Gandhiji at Wardha for two days, that is, on the 18th and the 19th December.
('79', 444, 8, 10, 876927) I asked him what was his next plan.
('79', 444, 8, 11, 876963) He has already informed the Viceroy of it.
('79', 444, 8, 12, 877006) The next stage will continue for another three months.
('79', 444, 8, 13, 877061) During that period nearly 10,000 persons will be in.
('79', 444, 8, 14, 877114) All names will be properly scrutinized.
('79', 444, 8, 15, 877154) “What after that?”, I asked.
('79', 444, 8, 16, 877183) [GANDHIJI:] There is to be no stage after that.
('79', 444, 8, 17, 877231) It will continue indefinitely and I will send in as many as I can.
('79', 444, 8, 18, 877298) Sometimes I get a little worried about the mentality of our young men.
('79', 444, 8, 19, 877369) I know they are impatient.
('79', 444, 8, 20, 877396) They might do something stupid.
('79', 444, 8, 21, 877428) Communism appeals to youth, unfortunately.
('79', 444, 9, 22, 877471) I replied that in the past whenever satyagraha was in the field, communism disappeared for the time being only to reappear after its suppression.
('79', 444, 9, 23, 877617) He agreed.
('79', 444, 10, 24, 877628) He is anxious to send Mahadev in.
('79', 444, 10, 25, 877662) I tried to persuade him not to send Mahadev.
('79', 444, 10, 26, 877707) Gandhiji will be virtually a cripple without him.
('79', 444, 10, 27, 877757) Mahadev very strongly feels that his absence may be harmful for Gandhiji’s health.
('79', 444, 10, 28, 877840) Pyarelal is already in.
('79', 444, 10, 29, 877864) Therefore Mahadev thinks he must be kept out.
('79', 444, 10, 30, 877910) But Gandhiji disagrees: It is a movement of self purification, not for embarrassing anyone.
('79', 444, 10, 31, 878002) As such, I must sacrifice my best.
('79', 444, 10, 32, 878037) I needed Mahadev out for various other noble missions.
('79', 444, 10, 33, 878092) This has enhanced his value further.
('79', 444, 10, 34, 878129) But all the more reason, therefore, for sending him in since the sacrifice will be still greater.
('79', 444, 11, 35, 878227) 1 The addresse, ex President, All India Trade Union Congress, had sought Gandhiji’s advice as he had not been arrested “in spite of offering satyagraha repeatedly”.
('79', 444, 11, 36, 878392) The letter was reported under the date line “Calcutta, December 19”.
('79', 445, 0, 1, 878461) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 445, 1, 2, 878503) I then related to him how I was told in Bombay that Sardar Patel and others in Yeravda were quite cheerful and comfortable.
('79', 445, 1, 3, 878627) I told him that there was too much restriction about interviews about which I had spoken to the Governor of Bombay.
('79', 445, 1, 4, 878743) He was glad to hear that they were all comfortable.
('79', 445, 2, 5, 878795) Devdas at this stage pointed out that things in Madras were different.
('79', 445, 2, 6, 878866) Rajaji was locked up at night.
('79', 445, 2, 7, 878897) Interviews were not allowed to last more than 20 minutes.
('79', 445, 2, 8, 878955) And the C.I.D. remained present at the time of interviews.
('79', 445, 2, 9, 879014) I said, I would bring this matter to the notice of H.E. But Gandhiji said, there was not much to complain against.
('79', 445, 2, 10, 879129) After all, jail was jail and one could not expect much while in.
('79', 445, 2, 11, 879194) If all kinds of freedom was allowed, then there would be no imprisonment in a sense.
('79', 445, 2, 12, 879279) All said, he thought, Government was fighting in a gentlemanly way.
('79', 445, 2, 13, 879347) I was glad to hear this tribute to the Government.
('79', 445, 2, 14, 879398) Good relation is a great thing and its value can never be over estimated.
('79', 445, 3, 15, 879472) I gave my impression of the Viceroy’s speech 1. Devdas at this stage read H.E.’s Calcutta speech to Gandhiji who had not yet read it fully.
('79', 445, 3, 16, 879612) He listened to it very carefully.
('79', 445, 3, 17, 879646) After Devdas finished the reading, I asked Gandhiji what his reaction to it was.

('79', 446, 1, 3, 881729) Discussing the solution for ending the present impasse, I suggested immediate expansion of the Viceroy’s Council by taking in men who were neither Congressmen nor Leaguemen but who would command respect.

('79', 446, 2, 6, 882069) It should definitely end the deadlock.

('79', 453, 0, 1, 895500) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 453, 1, 2, 895542) irrespective of race, colour or creed.
('79', 453, 1, 3, 895581) I hope you will have the time and desire to know how a good portion of humanity who have view living under the influence of that doctrine of universal friendship view your action.
('79', 453, 1, 4, 895761) We have no doubt about your bravery or devotion to your fatherland, nor do we believe that you are the monster described by your opponents.
('79', 453, 1, 5, 895901) But your own writings and pronouncements and those of your friends and admirers leave no room for doubt that many of your acts are monstrous and unbecoming of human dignity, especially in the estimation of men like me who believe in universal friendliness.
('79', 453, 1, 6, 896158) Such are your humiliation of Czechoslovakia, the rape of Poland and the swallowing of Denmark.
('79', 453, 1, 7, 896253) I am aware that your view of life regards such spoliations as virtuous acts.
('79', 453, 1, 8, 896330) But we have been taught from childhood to regard them as acts degrading humanity.
('79', 453, 1, 9, 896412) Hence we cannot possibly wish success to your arms.
('79', 453, 1, 10, 896464) But ours is a unique position.
('79', 453, 1, 11, 896495) We resist British Imperialism no less than Nazism.
('79', 453, 1, 12, 896546) If there is a difference, it is in degree.
('79', 453, 1, 13, 896589) One fifth of the human race has been brought under the British heel by means that will not bear scrutiny.
('79', 453, 1, 14, 896695) Our resistance to it does not mean harm to the British people.
('79', 453, 1, 15, 896758) We seek to convert them, not to defeat them on the battle field.
('79', 453, 1, 16, 896823) Ours is an unarmed revolt against the British rule.
('79', 453, 1, 17, 896875) But whether we convert them or not, we are determined to make their rule impossible by non violent non co operation.
('79', 453, 1, 18, 896992) It is a method in its nature indefensible.
('79', 453, 1, 19, 897035) It is based on the knowledge that no spoliator can compass his end without a certain degree of co operation, willing or compulsory, of the victim.
('79', 453, 1, 20, 897182) Our rulers may have our land and bodies but not our souls.
('79', 453, 1, 21, 897241) They can have the former only by complete destruction of every Indian—man, woman and child.
('79', 453, 1, 22, 897333) That all may not rise to that degree of heroism and that a fair amount of frightfulness can bend the back of revolt is true but the argument would be beside the point.
('79', 453, 1, 23, 897501) For, if a fair number of men and women be found in India who would be prepared without any ill will against the spoliators to lay down their lives rather than bend the knee to them, they would have shown the way to freedom from the tyranny of violence.
('79', 453, 1, 24, 897754) I ask you to believe me when I say that you will find an unexpected number of such men and women in India.
('79', 453, 1, 25, 897861) They have been having that training for the past 20 years.
('79', 453, 1, 26, 897920) We have been trying for the past half a century to throw off the British rule.
('79', 453, 1, 27, 897999) The movement of independence has been never so strong
('79', 454, 0, 1, 898053) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 455
('79', 454, 1, 2, 898099) as now.
('79', 454, 1, 3, 898107) The most powerful political organization, I mean the Indian National Congress, is trying to achieve this end.
('79', 454, 1, 4, 898217) We have attained a very fair measure of success through non violent effort.
('79', 454, 1, 5, 898293) We were groping for the right means to combat the most organized violence in the world which the British power represents.
('79', 454, 1, 6, 898416) You have challenged it.
('79', 454, 1, 7, 898440) It remains to be seen which is the better organized, the German or the British.
('79', 454, 1, 8, 898520) We know what the British heel means for us and the non European races of the world.
('79', 454, 1, 9, 898604) But we would never wish to end the British rule with German aid.
('79', 454, 1, 10, 898669) We have found in non violence a force which, if organized, can without doubt match itself against a combination of all the most violent forces in the world.
('79', 454, 1, 11, 898826) In non violent technique, as I have said, there is no such thing as defeat.
('79', 454, 1, 12, 898902) It is all ‘do or die’ without killing or hurting.
('79', 454, 1, 13, 898952) It can be used practically without money and obviously without the aid of science of destruction which you have brought to such perfection.
('79', 454, 1, 14, 899092) It is a marvel to me that you do not see that it is nobody’s monopoly.
('79', 454, 1, 15, 899163) If not the British, some other power will certainly improve upon your method and beat you with your own weapon.
('79', 454, 1, 16, 899275) You are leaving no legacy to your people of which they would feel proud.
('79', 454, 1, 17, 899348) They cannot take pride in a recital of cruel deed, however skilfully planned.
('79', 454, 1, 18, 899426) I, therefore, appeal to you in the name of humanity to stop the war.
('79', 454, 1, 19, 899495) You will lose nothing by referring all the matters of dispute between you and Great Britain to an international tribunal of your joint choice.
('79', 454, 1, 20, 899638) If you attain success in the war, it will not prove that you were in the right.
('79', 454, 1, 21, 899718) It will only prove that your power of destruction was greater.
('79', 454, 1, 22, 899781) Whereas an award by an impartial tribunal will show as far as it is humanly possible which party was in the right.
('79', 454, 1, 23, 899896) You know that not long ago I made an appeal 1 to every Briton to accept my method of non violent resistance.
('79', 454, 1, 24, 900005) I did it because the British know me as a friend though a rebel.
('79', 454, 1, 25, 900070) I am a stranger to you and your people.
('79', 454, 1, 26, 900110) I have not the courage to make you the appeal I made to every Briton.

('79', 454, 1, 28, 900254) But my present proposal is much simple because much more practical and familiar.
('79', 454, 1, 29, 900335) During this season when the hearts of the peoples of Europe yearn for peace, we have suspended even our own peaceful struggle.
('79', 454, 1, 30, 900462) 2 Is it too much to ask you to make an effort for peace during a time

('79', 457, 1, 2, 904363) 1. They are habitual and regular spinners.
('79', 457, 2, 3, 904406) 2. They are habitual khadi wearers.
('79', 457, 2, 4, 904442) 3. They believe in the necessity of communal unity and removal of untouchability in every shape and form.
('79', 457, 2, 5, 904548) 4. They believe in the necessity of supporting village handicrafts and swadeshi in everything.
('79', 457, 2, 6, 904643) 5. They believe that swaraj for the millions is unattainable without non violence.
('79', 457, 2, 7, 904726) 6. They believe in the Bombay resolution of the All India Congress Committee.
('79', 457, 2, 8, 904804) 7. They believe in an inevitable connection between the above mentioned points and non violence.
('79', 457, 2, 9, 904901) Mahatma Gandhi stresses that nobody is obliged to court imprisonment merely as a matter of discipline.
('79', 457, 2, 10, 905004) Civil disobedience thus becomes a matter of inviolable faith and not discipline.
('79', 457, 2, 11, 905085) Congress does not—at least Mahatma Gandhi does not—expect anybody to offer civil disobedience who does not believe in the urgency of it.
('79', 457, 2, 12, 905222) Mahatma Gandhi considers it disgraceful for any Congressman to say that he offers civil resistance for the sake of mere discipline.
('79', 457, 2, 13, 905354) He has further stressed that lukewarm adherence to the Congress brings us no nearer to our goal; nor can half hearted political belief in the Congress programme, he says, answer the purpose.
('79', 457, 2, 14, 905545) Those who do constructive work are just as good as civil resisters and by their faith and devotion to service, he says, they are rendering greater service to the cause of civil resistance than civil resisters of doubtful complexion.
('79', 457, 2, 15, 905778) Mahatma Gandhi has stressed that we shall reach our goal if civil resistance has the backing of the nation in the shape of conformity to the constructive programme.
('79', 457, 2, 16, 905943) Quality is the thing which is required in the fight and not quantity; of course, both combined would be welcomed.
('79', 457, 2, 17, 906057) The Hindu, 26 12 1940

('79', 461, 1, 2, 910682) APPENDICES
('79', 461, 2, 3, 910693) APPENDIX I
('79', 461, 3, 4, 910704) RAJAGOPALACHARI’S RESOLUTION FOR WORKING COMMITTEE MEETING, DELHI1
('79', 461, 4, 5, 910771) July 3, 1940
('79', 461, 5, 6, 910784) The Working Committee is of opinion that the proposals communicated by His Excellency the Viceroy in his conversation with Mahatma Gandhi do not meet the requirements of the present situation in any satisfactory manner.
('79', 461, 6, 7, 911004) According to these proposals the claim of the Congress that the status of India should be declared by Britain to be one of complete independence remains unsatisfied.
('79', 461, 6, 8, 911170) Any declaration that India shall be in the same position as the self governing countries in the British Commonwealth does not meet the case of India.
('79', 461, 6, 9, 911320) Nor has it any real meaning in the present state of world affairs.
('79', 461, 7, 10, 911387) Apart from this and what is even more important in relation to the immediate activities in regard to Defence efforts, the Working Committee is emphatically of the opinion that the Congress cannot withdraw its non co operation unless the entire field of central government including defence is immediately placed in charge of a national government, which, though formed ad hoc and as a transitory measure, should be so constituted as to command the confidence of all the elected elements of the Central Legislature and of the Responsible Governments in the provinces.
('79', 461, 7, 11, 911954) Unless such a central national government is immediately formed, any efforts in the dire ction of the defence of India will not only be contrary to the fundamental principles of justice and democratic government, but will also prove utterly futile.
('79', 461, 7, 12, 912203) Wardha office, Satyagraha file, 1940 41. Courtesy: Nehru Memorial Museum and Library

('79', 461, 11, 16, 912355) When you ask Britain to admit that India is free or declare that India shall be free from a certain date, you ask for the impossible.
('79', 461, 11, 17, 912489) South Africa and Eire have not asked for it.
('79', 461, 11, 18, 912534) The right to secede at will is equivalent to independence.
('79', 461, 11, 19, 912593) This right has been openly claimed by both Dominions and no one in authority has raised a voice of protest from the British side.
('79', 461, 11, 20, 912723) No one will venture to do so.
('79', 461, 11, 21, 912753) It is a very different
('79', 461, 12, 22, 912776) 1Vide “Letter to Abul Kalam Azad”, 19 8 1940 1 Vide “Letter to V. S. Srinivasa Sastri”, 20 7 1940
('79', 462, 0, 1, 912874) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 463
('79', 462, 1, 2, 912920) thing to demand a resolution or Act of Parliament declaring or granting in express terms the right of secession.
('79', 462, 1, 3, 913033) Why shall we not be realists for once and rest content with Dominion Status, of which we now know the implicit as well as the explicit significance?
('79', 462, 1, 4, 913182) You recently said that Dominion Status will go after the war or change beyond recognition.
('79', 462, 1, 5, 913273) Let it.
('79', 462, 1, 6, 913281) We shall be no worse than the other Dominions.
('79', 462, 1, 7, 913328) The Congress and you believed, or allowed yourselves to be persuaded, when the war began in earnest, that your demand of independence would be complied with.
('79', 462, 1, 8, 913486) As the war grows more grim, you are confirmed in that belief.
('79', 462, 1, 9, 913548) True, Britain could be squeezed today if things were normal in India.
('79', 462, 1, 10, 913618) I mean you would obtain your desire if Britain could be sure that she would gain more that she would lose by compliance.
('79', 462, 1, 11, 913739) She calculates that she would be worse off worse off in the result.
('79', 462, 1, 12, 913807) Who can gainsay it with confidence?
('79', 462, 1, 13, 913843) My own opinion —I am so ignorant it isn’t worth much— is that Muslim displeasure is a greater minus than Congress adhesion is a plus.
('79', 462, 1, 14, 913977) Nobody can gauge the precise extent of Jinnah’s influence.
('79', 462, 1, 15, 914036) As a man and as a politician he has developed unexpectedly.
('79', 462, 1, 16, 914096) Nevertheless, Congress is unable to ignore or neglect him; how can the British Government do so?
('79', 462, 1, 17, 914193) The risk is great.
('79', 462, 2, 18, 914212) To sum up: Independence at Britain’s hands is out of the question.
('79', 462, 2, 19, 914279) Indepen dence of Britain the fortune of war may thrust upon us (God forbid it).
('79', 462, 2, 20, 914359) But indepen dence we shall neither get not keep.
('79', 462, 3, 21, 914408) Rajaji’s resolution in my judgment is foredoomed by being coupled with the independence demand.
('79', 462, 3, 22, 914504) Consistency and prestige perhaps require it, but neither of these is an all important consideration.
('79', 462, 4, 23, 914605) Let me paraphrase the W. C. C. ‘s offer to Britain.
('79', 462, 4, 24, 914657) Grant our independence and in earnest thereof nationalize the Central Government.
('79', 462, 4, 25, 914739) We shall abandon non violence and harness all India’s resources in your aid.
('79', 462, 4, 26, 914816) It is the clear duty now of the strongest and the most patriotic party to grasp at every opportunity of acquiring power and using it for the protection of the people, subordinating and postponing for the moment all other considerations, including independence.
('79', 462, 4, 27, 915077) Instead, Rajaji’s position, stated briefly, is : “Congress can’t do its best till India is independent or declared so.
('79', 462, 4, 28, 915196) Because you don’t enable us to do our best, we won’t do even what we can, though for our own people’s primary needs.”
('79', 462, 5, 29, 915314) Suppose, now, on the contrary, the W. C. C. directed the men who were Ministers in the Provinces to resume office and other measures necessary for the protection of the people.
('79', 462, 5, 30, 915491) Will it not immediately restore the confidence of the public and dispel the fear of anarchy which is now widespread and may soon demoralize the inhabitants of the villages?
('79', 462, 5, 31, 915664) Power carries a responsibility; Congressmen may not say now to the harassed citizens: “You must suffer till the Britisher yields.” Will you not shake off your prepossessions and obsessions and order the provincial
('79', 463, 0, 1, 915878) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 463, 1, 2, 915920) parliamentarians back to their posts of duty?
('79', 463, 1, 3, 915966) Tell them that peaceful existence is prior to independence, and that Britishers and Muslims may be disposed of later.

('79', 463, 4, 7, 916179) LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU1
('79', 463, 5, 8, 916209) August 10, 1940
('79', 463, 6, 9, 916225) MY DEAR BAPU,
('79', 463, 7, 10, 916239) I have just received your letter of the 8th.
('79', 463, 7, 11, 916284) About Hyderabad, I can make no suggestion.
('79', 463, 7, 12, 916327) So much depends on the strength of the people and their organization.
('79', 463, 7, 13, 916397) I think, however, that it is far better for them to concentrate on the rural areas where the chances of communal clashes are probably less.
('79', 463, 7, 14, 916537) I do not see how they can remain passive under the circumstances.
('79', 463, 7, 15, 916603) Yet it may be perhaps better not to precipitate a big crisis immediately in view of the rapid developments of the political situation in India as a whole.
('79', 463, 7, 16, 916758) When this all India situation advances further, Hyderabad people might be in a better position to assert their right.
('79', 463, 8, 17, 916876) In a sense I am not sorry at the development in Hyderabad.
('79', 463, 8, 18, 916935) The impossible attitude that Bahadur Yar Khan and others have taken up will react on them.
('79', 463, 8, 19, 917026) It may of course lead to a great deal of trouble and bloodshed.
('79', 463, 8, 20, 917090) In any event the State Congress people should make it perfectly clear that they cannot reduce by an iota their demand for responsible government.
('79', 463, 9, 21, 917236) I understand the Working Committee is likely to meet in Wardha in eight or nine days’ time.
('79', 463, 9, 22, 917328) I hope to meet you then.
('79', 463, 10, 23, 917353) About the exactions for war funds.
('79', 463, 10, 24, 917388) I have written to the secretary of the U. P. P. C. C. to send you some particulars.
('79', 463, 10, 25, 917472) Some have been published in the Press and are clear enough.
('79', 463, 10, 26, 917532) Some others, though equally clear, might be explained differently.
('79', 463, 10, 27, 917599) For instance an usual case is for a person to be approached for a donation.
('79', 463, 10, 28, 917675) He refuses or offers a smaller sum than what is demanded.
('79', 463, 10, 29, 917733) Immediately or a day or two after, he is arrested on the charge of preventing others from subscribing to the war funds, and thereby charge of preventing others from subscribing to the war funds, and thereby coming in the way of war efforts.
('79', 463, 11, 30, 917974) I have just had a case like this from Allahabad district.
('79', 463, 11, 31, 918032) A poor village shopkeeper was asked to give Rs. 15 or Rs. 20. He said the most he could possibly give was Rs. 15. He was cursed and sworn at and immediately a notice was given to him to appear to show cause why he should not be proceeded against under the Defence of India rules.
('79', 463, 11, 32, 918312) His case is up today in a court here.
('79', 463, 11, 33, 918350) Usually this kind of thing

('79', 464, 1, 4, 918619) A Naib Tahsildar went to the shop of a Congressman on 2nd of August and demanded money for the war funds.
('79', 464, 1, 5, 918725) This was refused and the man stated that as a Congressman he could not do so.
('79', 464, 1, 6, 918803) Thereupon the Naib Tahsildar threatened to take action and had the name of the person noted down.

('79', 464, 1, 8, 919054) He was put in the lock up and for 30 hours he was not given any food or facilities for bathing.
('79', 464, 1, 9, 919150) This arrest was completely illegal as punitive tax can only be recovered by attachment of property and the person concerned, whose name is Omprakash, has considerable movable and immovable property.
('79', 464, 1, 10, 919349) The amount of Punitive Tax concerned was only Rs. 6 which could easily have been realized by attachment.

('79', 464, 1, 12, 919560) That is how the matter stands now.
('79', 464, 2, 13, 919595) Another interesting case is that of Thakur Surendra Bhadur Singh, Taluqadar of Simri in Rae Bareli district.
('79', 464, 2, 14, 919704) He is a Congress M. L. A. His father, the Taluqadar, recently died and thereupon, at his own request, his taluqa was taken under the Court or Wards.
