('79', 464, 2, 16, 919943) He refused to do so as a Congressman.
('79', 464, 2, 17, 919981) He was then told that he held his taluqa on conditions of loyalty and good service and the Court of Wards had a perfect right to give the donation out of the revenues of the taluqa.
('79', 464, 2, 18, 920163) Thereupon he sent a registered notice to the Deputy Commissioner protesting against this imposition and saying that it was wholly illegal.
('79', 464, 2, 19, 920302) His case was that it might or might not be open to the Government to confiscate his taluqa for want of loyalty to them.
('79', 464, 2, 20, 920422) But it was certainly not open to them to give a donation on his behalf and against his will.
('79', 464, 2, 21, 920515) In spite of this the Deputy Commissioner has already or is going to pay this sum to the war fund and Surendra Bahadur singh is thinking of bringing a declaratory suit in a court of law.
('79', 464, 3, 22, 920701) I am getting complaints from various districts of pressure being brought on kisans to pay eight annas or a rupee or more per plough.
('79', 464, 3, 23, 920834) It is obvious that they do not want to pay but are compelled to do so.
('79', 464, 4, 24, 920905) Petty Government servants and minor officials dare not say no when they are asked to contribute.
('79', 464, 4, 25, 921002) A recent case which came to my notice informally but nevertheless correctly was that of stenotypist of a District Magistrate.
('79', 464, 4, 26, 921128) He was asked to give Rs. 200. His salary was Rs. 125 a month.
('79', 464, 4, 27, 921190) He pointed out hesitatingly that he had a large family and it was entirely beyond his capacity to pay that sum.
('79', 464, 4, 28, 921302) He was then told that in any event he and his family would have to starve if the British lost the war.
('79', 464, 4, 29, 921405) So this was a kind of insurance that he had to pay.
('79', 464, 4, 30, 921457) Ultimately it was settled that he should pay Rs. 150 to the war fund.
('79', 464, 4, 31, 921527) A curious thing is that one does not hear

('79', 465, 6, 12, 922481) STATEMENT MADE BY THE VICEROY ON AUGUST 8, 1940 1
('79', 465, 7, 13, 922531) India’s anxiety at this moment of critical importance in the world struggle against tyranny and agression to contribute to the full to the common cause and to the triumph of our common ideals is manifest.
('79', 465, 7, 14, 922736) She has already made a mighty contri bution.
('79', 465, 7, 15, 922781) She is anxious to make a greater contribution still.
('79', 465, 7, 16, 922834) His Majesty’s Govern ment are deeply concerned that that unity of national purpose in India which would enable her to do so should be achieved at as early a moment as possible.
('79', 465, 7, 17, 923011) They feel that some further statement of their intentions may help to promote that unity.
('79', 465, 7, 18, 923101) In the hope they have authorized me to make the present statement.
('79', 465, 8, 19, 923168) Last October His Majesty’s Government again made it clear that Dominion Status was their objective for India.
('79', 465, 8, 20, 923278) They added that they were ready to authorize the expansion of the Governor General’s Council to include a certain number of represen tatives of political parties, and they proposed the establishment of a Consultative Committee.
('79', 465, 8, 21, 923506) In order to facilitate harmonious co operation it was obvious that some measure of agreement in the provinces between the major parties was a desirable prerequisite to their joint collaboration at the Centre.
('79', 465, 8, 22, 923715) Such agreement was unfortu nately not reached, and in the circumstances no progress was then possible.
('79', 465, 9, 23, 923818) During the earlier part of this year, I continued my efforts to bring political parties together.
('79', 465, 9, 24, 923916) In these last few weeks I again entered into conversations with
('79', 465, 10, 25, 923980) 1Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”,9 8 1940 and “Draft Resolution for Congress Working Committee”, 21 8 1940
('79', 466, 0, 1, 924088) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 467
('79', 466, 1, 2, 924134) prominent political personages in British India and the Chancellor of the Chamber of Princes, the results of which have been reported to His Majesty’s Government.
('79', 466, 1, 3, 924297) His Majesty’s Government have seen also the resolutions passed by the Congress Working Committee, the Muslim League and the Hindu Mahasabha.
('79', 466, 2, 4, 924438) It is clear that the earlier differences which had prevented the achievement of national unity remain unbridged.
('79', 466, 2, 5, 924551) Deeply as His Majesty’s Government regret this, they do not feel that they should any longer, because of these differences, postpone the expansion of the Governor General’s Council, and the establishment of a body which will more closely associate Indian public opinion with the conduct of the war by the Central Government.
('79', 466, 2, 6, 924876) They have authorized me accordingly to invite a certain number or representative Indians to join my Executive council.
('79', 466, 2, 7, 924995) They have authorized me further to establish a War Advisory Council, which would meet at regular intervals, and which would contain representatives of the Indians States, and of other interests in the national life of India as a whole.
('79', 466, 3, 8, 925231) The conversations which have taken place, and the resolutions of the bodies which I have just mentioned, make it clear however that there is still in certain quarters doubt as to the intentions of His Majesty’s Government for the constitu tional future of India, and that there is doubt, too as to whether the position of mino rities whether political or religious, is sufficiently safeguarded in relation to any constitutional change by the assurance already given.
('79', 466, 3, 9, 925698) There are two main points that have emerged.
('79', 466, 3, 10, 925743) On those two points His Majesty’s Government now desire me to make their position clear.
('79', 466, 4, 11, 925832) The first is as to the position of minorities in relation to any future consti tutional scheme.
('79', 466, 4, 12, 925928) It has already been made clear my that declaration of last October does not exclude examination of any part either of the Act of 1935 or of the policy and plans on which it is based.
('79', 466, 4, 13, 926111) His Majesty’s Government’s concern that full weight should be given to the views of the minorities in any revision has also been brought out.
('79', 466, 4, 14, 926253) That remains the position of His Majesty’s Government.
('79', 466, 4, 15, 926308) It goes without saying that they could not contemplate the transfer of their present responsibilities for the peace and welfare of India to any system of Government whose authority is directly denied by large and powerful elements in India’s national life.
('79', 466, 4, 16, 926565) Nor could they be parties to the coercion of such elements into submission to such a government.
('79', 466, 5, 17, 926662) The second point of general interest is the machinery for building within the British Commonwealth of Nations a new constitutional scheme when the time comes.
('79', 466, 5, 18, 926821) There has been very strong insistence that the framing of that scheme should be primarily the responsibility of Indians themselves, and should originate from Indian conceptions of the social, economic and political structure of Indian life.
('79', 466, 5, 19, 927062) His Majesty’s Government are in sympathy with that desire, and wish to see it given the fullest practical expression subject to the due fulfilment of the obligations which
('79', 467, 0, 1, 927234) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 467, 1, 2, 927276) Great Britain’s long connection with India has imposed upon her and for which His Majesty’s Government cannot divest themselves of responsibility.
('79', 467, 1, 3, 927423) It is clear that a moment when the Commonwealth is engaged in a struggle for existence is not one in which fundamental constitutional issues can be decisively resolved.
('79', 467, 1, 4, 927592) But His Majesty’s Government authorize me to declare that they will most readily assent to the setting up after the conclusion of the war with the least possible delay of a body representative of the principal elements in India’s national life in order to devise the framework of the new constitution and they will lend every aid in their power to hasten decisions on all relevant matter to the utmost degree.
('79', 467, 1, 5, 928002) Meanwhile they will welcome and promote in any way possible every sincere and practical step that may be taken by representative Indians themselves to reach a basis of friendly agreement, firstly, on the form which the post war representative body should take, and the methods by which it should arrive at its conclusions and secondly, upon the principles and outlines of the constitution itself.
('79', 467, 1, 6, 928399) They trust however that for the period of the war (with the Central Government reconstituted and strengthened in the manner I have described and with the help of the War Advisory Council) all parties, communities and interests will combine and co operate in making a notable Indian contribution to the victory of the world cause which is at stake.
('79', 467, 1, 7, 928747) Moreover they hope that in this process new bonds of union and understanding will emerge and thus pave the way towards the attainment by India of that free and equal partnership in the British Commonwealth which remains the proclaimed and accepted goal of the Imperial Crown and of the British Parliament.

('79', 467, 4, 13, 929188) RESOLUTION PASSED AT CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE MEETING AT WARDHA1
('79', 467, 5, 14, 929255) August 21, 1940
('79', 467, 6, 15, 929271) The Working Committee have read that statement issued by the viceroy on the authority of the British Government on the 8th of August and the report of the speech of the Secretary of State for India in the House of Commons explaining the Viceroy’s statement.
('79', 467, 6, 16, 929529) They note with deep regret that the British Government have rejected the friendly offer and practical suggestion contained in the Poona resolution of the A. I. C. C. on 28th July framed for a solution of the deadlock and to enable the Indian National Congress to withdraw its non co operation and to secure in the present
('79', 467, 7, 17, 929851) 1Vide “Draft Resolution for Congress Working Committee”, 21 8 1940
('79', 468, 0, 1, 929918) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 469
('79', 468, 1, 2, 929964) crisis the patriotic co operation of all the people of India in the governance of India and organization of national defence.
('79', 468, 2, 3, 930090) The Working Committee have read with deep pain and indignation the declara tion and assumptions contained in the statements and speeches made on behalf of the British Government which seek to deny India her natural right of complete national freedom and reiterate the untenable claim that Britain should maintain herself in a dominant position in India in the discharge of the higher functions of the State.
('79', 468, 2, 4, 930498) These claims render false and empty even their own promise to recognize India at an early date, as a free and equal unit in the British commonwealth.
('79', 468, 2, 5, 930648) Such claims and recent events and developments in the world have confirmed the Committee’s convic tion that India cannot function within the orbit of an imperial power and must attain the status of a free and independent nation.
('79', 468, 2, 6, 930877) This does not prevent close association with other countries within a comity of free nations for the peace of the world.
('79', 468, 3, 7, 930998) The Working Committee are of opinion that the assertion contained in the statement made on behalf of the British Government that they will not part with power and responsibility in favour of the elected representatives of the people of India, and that therefore the present autocratic and irresponsible system of gover nment must continue so long as any group of people or the Princes, as distinguished from the people of the States or perhaps even foreign vested interests raise objec tions to any constitutions framed by the elected representatives of the people of India, is a direct encouragement and incitement to civil discord and strife, and amounts to a fatal blow to all willingness to compromise and adjustment of claims.
('79', 468, 4, 8, 931730) The Committee regret that although the Congress has never thought in terms of coercing any minority, much less of asking the British Government to do so, the demand for a settlement of the constitution through a Constitutent Assembly of duly elected representatives has been misrepresented as coercion and the issue of minorities has been made into an insuperable barrier to India’s progress.
('79', 468, 4, 9, 932123) The Congress had proposed that minority rights should be amply protected by agreement with elected representatives of the minorities concerned.
('79', 468, 4, 10, 932267) The Working Committee therefore cannot but conclude that the attitude and assertions contained in these statements made on behalf of the British Government confirm the prevailing feeling that the British authority has been continually operating so as to create, maintain and aggravate differences in India’s national life.
('79', 468, 5, 11, 932590) The Working Committee note with astonishment that the demand for the con stitution of a Provisional National Government composed of persons commanding the confidence of the various elected groups in the present Central Legislature, formed under the 1919 Constitution of India, has been described by the Secretary of State for India as one that would raise the unsolved constitutional issue and prejudge it in favour of the majority and against the minorities.
('79', 468, 5, 12, 933050) The Working Committee are of
('79', 469, 0, 1, 933079) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 469, 1, 2, 933121) opinion that the rejection of this proposal unmistakable indicates that there is no willingness on the part of the British Government to part with any power and autho rity even for the immediate purpose of securing co operation in war efforts.
('79', 469, 1, 3, 933365) The British Government would gather together and carry on with such dissentient groups and individuals as oppose the wishes of the majority of the people of India and with out any co ordination with elected legislatures at the Centre or in the Provinces, rather than concede anything that would work towards the recognition of the rights of the people of India to rule themselves democratically.
('79', 469, 2, 4, 933761) For these reason the Working Committee have come to the conclusion that the statement referred to are wholly opposed not only to the principle of democracy as acclaimed by the British Government in the war, but also to the best interests of India, and they cannot be a party to accepting the proposals contained in the statements, or advising the country to accept them.
('79', 469, 2, 5, 934132) The Working Committee consider that these declarations and offers not only fall far short of the Congress demand, but would be impediments to the evolution of a free and united India.
('79', 469, 3, 6, 934316) The Working Committee call upon the people to condemn the attitude adopted by the British Government by means of public meetings and otherwise, as also through their elected representatives in the provincial legislatures.
('79', 469, 4, 7, 934538) The Indian Annual Regist er, 1940, Vol. II, pp.
('79', 469, 5, 8, 934586) APPENDIX VI
('79', 469, 6, 9, 934598) A STRANGE PLAN1
('79', 469, 7, 10, 934614) As expected, the Congress Working Committee agreed at its meeting in Bombay to hand over the direction of Congress policy to Mr. Gandhi.
('79', 469, 7, 11, 934751) The three cardinal points emerging from the Working Committee’s resolution are that the Congress has no desire to embarrass the British Government in the conduct of the war, that there is to be no mass civil disobedience, but that the Congress must insist “on the fullest freedom to pursue its policy on the basis of non violence”.
('79', 469, 7, 12, 935083) On the first two points there will be widespread agreement.
('79', 469, 7, 13, 935143) “Congressmen”, so runs the resolution, “cannot withhold their admiration for the bravery and endurance shown by the British nation in the face of danger and peril.
('79', 469, 7, 14, 935307) They can have no ill will against them, and the spirit of satyagraha forbids the Congress from doing anything with a view to embarrass them.” This tribute and assurance are opportune, and will be widely welcomed.
('79', 469, 7, 15, 935520) There will also be relief among all classes of the people that whatever action Mr. Gandhi, as dictator of Congress policy, may take, it will not involve mass lawlessness.
('79', 469, 8, 16, 935691) 1 Vide “Some Criticism Answered”
('79', 470, 0, 1, 935724) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 471
('79', 470, 1, 2, 935770) But there are other features of the resolution and of Mr. Gandhi’s exposition of it on Sunday which will arouse misgivings.
('79', 470, 1, 3, 935894) In the first place the resolution makes it clear that the offer of conditional Congress co operation with the British Government in the war has lapsed.
('79', 470, 1, 4, 936046) Moreover, Mr. Gandhi explained very fully what Congress insistence “on the fullest freedom to pursue its policy based on non violence” really means.
('79', 470, 1, 5, 936195) He announced his intention of again seeing His Excellency the Viceroy and seeking from him a declaration that the Congress “can go on preaching anti war propaganda and non co operation with Government in their war effort”.
('79', 470, 1, 6, 936418) If this declaration is given, there will be no civil disobedience; if it is not given, Mr. Gandhi will have to consider what action he should take, but he will do his best to avoid satyagraha.
('79', 470, 1, 7, 936611) This amazing proposal is both impracticable and completely illogical.
('79', 470, 1, 8, 936681) Mr. Gandhi professes his desire not to embarrass the British Government in any way, yet in the same breath he suggests that he should be allowed to do something which will hamper India’s war effort and thus aid the enemy.
('79', 470, 1, 9, 936903) Even Congress papers have already pointed out the impossibility of reconciling the two ideas.
('79', 470, 1, 10, 936997) Anything which hinders India’s war effort must be an embarrassment to the British Government; it cannot be anything else.
('79', 470, 2, 11, 937119) This attitude clearly arises from a grievous misunderstanding of the European struggle.
('79', 470, 2, 12, 937207) In his speech, Mr. Gandhi made two extraordinary statements.
('79', 470, 2, 13, 937268) The first was that the peoples of Europe do not know what they are fighting for; the second that the Government of India should give expression to India’s freedom by permitting the Congress to conduct an anti war campaign in the name of liberty.
('79', 470, 2, 14, 937514) We can assure Mr. Gandhi that the British people know full well what they are fighting for.
('79', 470, 2, 15, 937606) It is far too late in the day for anyone who does not deliberately shut his eyes to hard facts to pretend that the war is merely a struggle between rival systems of so called “imperialism”.
('79', 470, 2, 16, 937796) Mr. Gandhi should read Main Kampf; he should also study the speeches of those who expound Nazi aims, and he should note what Hitler had done to neutral countries in Europe.
('79', 470, 2, 17, 937969) He should also pursue the report of Mr. Patel, the former Indian Trade Commissioner in Hamburg, who throws a flood of light on Nazi methods inside Germany in peace time.
('79', 470, 2, 18, 938139) These things reveal with remarkable clarity the menace which Britain and her Allies are fighting—a menace realized no more keenly than in the United States of America.
('79', 470, 2, 19, 938307) If Mr. Gandhi is right, the British people are wrong; so are the vast majority of Americans and all free Frenchmen, Dutchmen, Belgians, Norwegians, Poles and Danes who are struggling to rescue their country from Hitler’s tyranny.
('79', 470, 3, 20, 938537) The fundamental difference between democracy and totalitarianism is evident to the merest child.
('79', 470, 3, 21, 938634) The one system constitutes the greatest amount of individual freedom consistent with good government; the other regards humanity as a mob of automatons to be directed by the chosen few.
('79', 470, 3, 22, 938820) There is not a single Congressman from
('79', 471, 0, 1, 938859) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 471, 1, 2, 938901) Mr. Gandhi downwards who does not profess himself to be revolted by the totalitarian system and the mass slavery which it connotes; it is, therefore, almost incredible to find Mr. Gandhi calmly announcing that the British people, among others, have no idea what they are fighting for.
('79', 471, 1, 3, 939186) Mr. Gandhi must also know that to preach anti war propaganda and non co operation with the war effort in India is to advocate support for the enemy.
('79', 471, 1, 4, 939335) His plan would create in this country an army of fifth columnists, which is exactly what Hitler desires.
('79', 471, 1, 5, 939440) Surely Mr. Gandhi knows that Hitler has achieved his success hitherto in destroying democracy by the simple expedient of using the freedom which democracy bestows to encompass its downfall.
('79', 471, 1, 6, 939630) If Mr. Gandhi seriously believes in democracy, he cannot pretend that this war is of no consequence to India, or that the people of India should be allowed to take no part in it.
('79', 471, 1, 7, 939809) We sincerely trust that he will reconsider his position before approaching the Viceroy.
('79', 471, 2, 8, 939897) The Times of India, 17 9 1940
('79', 471, 3, 9, 939927) APPENDIX VII
('79', 471, 4, 10, 939940) DANGER OF EXTINCTION 1
('79', 471, 5, 11, 939963) It is very difficult to understand the reported proceedings of the Congress at Bombay.
('79', 471, 5, 12, 940050) Wading through the sea of words, contradiction after contradiction serves to make the darkness more and more visible.
('79', 471, 5, 13, 940168) One tangible point seems to be Mr. Gandhi’s statement that, if the Viceroy will assure him that the Congressmen will be allowed publicly to advocate non co operation in the war effort—stressing the fact that such non co operation must be non violent —there will be no satyagraha of any kind on his part and that, in any case, there will be no mass civil disobedience.
('79', 471, 5, 14, 940536) Our first reaction to this was to wonder why the Congress must always be asking for difficult statements and cannot leave well alone.
('79', 471, 5, 15, 940670) The Government has never prohibited the conscientious teaching of pacifism in India any more than the British Government has interfered with it in Britain.
('79', 471, 5, 16, 940826) The Quaker and the conscientious objector are not penalized in war unless they take action obviously calculated to help the enemy.
('79', 471, 5, 17, 940957) Those who attempt to convert soldiers, sailors and airmen, and suborn these or others engaged in direct war work, are clearly helping the enemy.
('79', 471, 5, 18, 941102) When a whole people is legally conscripted, as is the case in Britain now, the line is still more difficult to draw.
('79', 471, 5, 19, 941219) Every worker is, in a sense, a war worker.
('79', 471, 5, 20, 941262) Nevertheless, conversion to the view that it is wrong to be a combatant even in the most righteous cause is not likely to interfere with the output of the ordinary man who is doing civilian work.
('79', 471, 5, 21, 941458) This is the point of view which is tolerated in Britain and has hitherto been tolerated in India.
('79', 471, 5, 22, 941556) Mr. Gandhi’s own astounding proposal that Britain should
('79', 471, 6, 23, 941613) 1Vide “Some Criticism Answered”
('79', 472, 0, 1, 941645) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 473
('79', 472, 1, 2, 941691) abjectly surrender to Hitler was even, at his own request, put before the War Cabinet which treated it with respect as a sincere opinion and sent a polite reply.
('79', 472, 2, 3, 941853) Why then, if you have got what you want, ask the Viceroy for a difficult statement which many will seek to twist and turn into a cloak for their efforts to help the enemy to conquer India?
('79', 472, 2, 4, 942042) Other passages in Mr. Gandhi’s speech throw light on this.
('79', 472, 2, 5, 942101) What is in his mind is the wholesale arrests of Congress officials and workers which are now continually recorded in the Press, especially in the United Provinces.
('79', 472, 2, 6, 942265) Details are not given, but the arrests are generally made under the Defence Regulations and appear to be because of speeches in connexion with the war.
('79', 472, 2, 7, 942417) Mr. Gandhi says he wishes to point out to the Viceroy that the Congress is in danger of “extinction” during the war because of its creed of non violent non co operation, and he wants liberty for Congressmen to preach their doctrine.
('79', 472, 3, 8, 942650) We have often expressed our view about the fundamental immorality and contradictory character of the doctrine.
('79', 472, 3, 9, 942761) Non co operation is a method of war and not of peace.
('79', 472, 3, 10, 942815) For otherwise unarmed or defenceless people it is quite a reasonable method of making war or defending themselves, but it has no more spiritual value than war and probably much less; for it carries with it a pretentious claim to spiritual value which involves sanctimonious insincerities and mass hypocrisy, making intensified hatreds and accompanied by an extraordinary development of violence of language to compensate for the absence of real manliness in defending what must be defended if life is to be worth living.
('79', 472, 3, 11, 943336) A nation which accepted this doctrine would doom itself to slavery and would breed generations of sycophantic hypocrites crawling before masters who despised them.
('79', 472, 3, 12, 943500) It is no doctrine for India and, if the Congress persists in it, the Congress will certainly be “extinguished”, either because India will have none of it, or because the Congress will so poison the country that Britain cannot save it from three or four totalitarian Powers determined to carve it up, in which case the Congress as an organization will never be heard of again.
('79', 472, 4, 13, 943876) Lust of conquest in one country and pacifism in an unaggressive country are twin poisons working together to produce war.
('79', 472, 4, 14, 943998) The English pacifists have much to answer for.
('79', 472, 4, 15, 944045) They preached the doctrine of surrender to a country innocent of any desire for war and had not the courage to stand on street corners in Berlin and Rome and go to prison.
('79', 472, 4, 16, 944217) The non co operator has a better case.
('79', 472, 4, 17, 944256) He was at war against the Government of India and he did go to prison, but he spoilt his case by pretending to be a pacifist.
('79', 472, 4, 18, 944382) We have no quarrel with the Quaker or with any other quietist.
('79', 472, 4, 19, 944445) He acts according to his conscience, but he seeks no converts, interferes with no one, and does positive good work in war time refusing true help and sympathy to no man whatever his nationality.
('79', 472, 4, 20, 944640) But the man who preaches non resistance and surrender in war time, whatever his motives, is weakening a nation’s will to survive and is
('79', 473, 0, 1, 944776) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 473, 1, 2, 944818) helping to destroy it and to deliver it to the enemy.
('79', 473, 1, 3, 944872) Under this leadership, the Congress has nothing to offer India.
('79', 473, 1, 4, 944936) At the same time, there is not sufficient assurance that the authorities everywhere—and the doubt is perhaps strongest in regard to the United Provinces—are acting intelligently in regard to the arrests of the Congressmen.
('79', 473, 1, 5, 945159) It is not yet the accepted practice either in Britain or in India to arrest a man merely expressing pacifist views, though we do not ourselves see how in a war for survival a nation can tolerate aggressive pacifism, which must plainly be one of the enemy’s assets.
('79', 473, 1, 6, 945424) Having, however, recently seen people who were trying to help the war effort, arrested when they tried to organize an Anti Fascists Day, we cannot help having some doubts whether sufficient care is always taken to prevent injustice.
('79', 473, 1, 7, 945657) It is necessary to arrest men who preach revolution or violence or any form of action to impede war effort.
('79', 473, 1, 8, 945765) But it is not yet the business of the authorities to prevent sincere expression of personal conviction of a non violent character, still less to attempt the extinction of Congress in the name of the war.
('79', 473, 1, 9, 945969) The Congress is in danger of extinguishing itself and needs no interference.
('79', 473, 1, 10, 946046) So are the Pakistanists and the vested interests, some of them British, in the services or in business which stand in the way of the war effort.
('79', 473, 1, 11, 946191) To survive, we have all to shed many prejudices yet and develop new attitudes and new leadership.
('79', 473, 2, 12, 946289) The Statesman, 17 9 1940
('79', 473, 3, 13, 946314) APPENDIX VIII
('79', 473, 4, 14, 946328) LETTER FROM LORD LINLITHGOW1
('79', 473, 5, 15, 946357) SIMLA, September 30, 1940
('79', 473, 6, 16, 946383) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('79', 473, 7, 17, 946400) I think it will be convenient if I record very briefly in writing the origin of the talks that we have had on the 27th and 30th September and their outcome.
('79', 473, 8, 18, 946557) As you will remember, you wrote to me on the 18th September to ask that I should grant you an interview, and you explained in your letter that you were anxious to discuss the situation covered by the recent resolution of the All India Congress Committee, not only in your capacity as guide of the Congress but as a personal friend.
('79', 473, 8, 19, 946889) I was, I need not say, most ready to talk things over with you, and we have now had the advantage of two conversations.
('79', 473, 9, 20, 947009) 1 vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 30 9 1940
('79', 474, 0, 1, 947055) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 475
('79', 474, 1, 2, 947101) In the course of these conversations the situation has been exhaustively discussed, with particular reference to the question of free speech in time of war.
('79', 474, 1, 3, 947258) On that matter, while professing yourself most anxious to avoid in any way embarrassing His Majesty’s Government in the prosecution of the war, you made it clear to me that you regarded it as essential that the Indian National Congress and other members of the public should be in a position to give full expression to their views in relation to the war effort, provided only that such expression was fully non violent.
('79', 474, 2, 4, 947678) I indicated to you the nature of the special treatment laid down by law in the United Kingdom for dealing with conscientious objectors—which I may broadly describe as an arrangement under which, while the conscientious objector is absolved from the duty of fighting and is allowed even to profess his faith in public, he is not permitted to carry his opposition to the length of endeavouring to persuade others, whether soldiers or munition workers, to abandon their allegiance or to discontinue their effort.
('79', 474, 3, 5, 948188) You made it clear to me that you would not regard treatment of that nature as adequate in the conditions of India, and that you regarded it as essential that in India, where in your judgment conditions were wholly different from those existing in Great Britain, the Indian objector, either to all war as such, or to the participation of India in the present war, should be untramelled in the expression of his views.
('79', 474, 4, 6, 948605) It emerged further from our conversation that, while you would not yourself preach to workers engaged on war work at the actual works, in an endeavour there to dissuade them from working on war equipment, you could regard it as essential that it should be open to Congressmen and non Congressmen alike to deliver addresses and otherwise to call upon people throughout the country to refrain from assisting India’s war effort in any way which would involve India’s participation in bloodshed.
('79', 474, 5, 7, 949097) I listened with the utmost care and attention to your argument, and our examination of the situation has been full and close.
('79', 474, 5, 8, 949223) I felt bound, however, in the outcome, to make it clear to you that action such as you suggest would certainly amount not only to the inhibition of India’s war effort, but to that embarrassment of Great Britain in the prosecution of the war which the Congress state that they are anxious to avoid; and that it would clearly not be possible in the interests of India herself, more particularly at this most critical juncture in the war, to acquiesce in the interference with the war effort which would be involved in freedom of speech so wide as that for which you had asked.
('79', 474, 6, 9, 949798) Harijan, 6 10 1940
('79', 475, 0, 1, 949817) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 475, 1, 2, 949859) APPENDIX IX
('79', 475, 2, 3, 949871) LETTER FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU1
('79', 475, 3, 4, 949901) ANAND BHAVAN, ALLAHABAD, October 2, 1940
('79', 475, 4, 5, 949942) MY DEAR BAPU,
('79', 475, 5, 6, 949956) About six weeks ago, when I was in Bombay for the Planning Committee, I had a remarkable experience, which has oppressed me often since then.
('79', 475, 5, 7, 950098) I should have told you about it when you were in Bombay last but the Working Committee and the A.I.C.C. filled my mind and I forgot.
('79', 475, 5, 8, 950231) I did not want to write about it through the post.
('79', 475, 6, 9, 950282) I came back from the Planning Committee during the midday interval for food.
('79', 475, 6, 10, 950359) I had to go back soon after and was pressed for time.
('79', 475, 6, 11, 950413) Just then a young English boy turned up at my sister’s flat.
('79', 475, 6, 12, 950474) He was dressed in khadi—a shirt and loose pyjamas and [a] cap.
('79', 475, 6, 13, 950537) He told me that he was an officer in the army—a Second Lieutenant—and had decided to leave the army and face the consequences.
('79', 475, 6, 14, 950664) He produced a copy of a document which he said he had given to his Commanding Officer and which had been forwarded to Army Headquarters at Simla.
('79', 475, 6, 15, 950810) I read this and was amazed.
('79', 475, 6, 16, 950838) It was a very fine statement.
('79', 475, 6, 17, 950868) I enclose a copy of it and you can read it for yourself.
('79', 475, 7, 18, 950925) His name was Napier.
('79', 475, 7, 19, 950946) He was the great grandson of the Napier who is said to have conquered Sind.
('79', 475, 7, 20, 951022) The family since then had been intimately connected with the army.
('79', 475, 7, 21, 951089) Apparently it came down in the world.
('79', 475, 7, 22, 951127) Young Napier joined as a private a few years before the war began.
('79', 475, 7, 23, 951194) But because he was a bright lad, and possibly also because of his family, he got a scholarship for Sandhurst and later became a commissioned officer.
('79', 475, 7, 24, 951344) He was sent with his regiment to India a month or two after the war began.
('79', 475, 7, 25, 951419) He was stationed at Mhow in Central India.
('79', 475, 7, 26, 951462) Evidently he did not fit in with his brother officers.
('79', 475, 7, 27, 951517) He was more serious and intellectual and he felt drawn towards India, especially to the poorer classes.
('79', 475, 7, 28, 951621) He avoided officers’ messes and spent his time in the bazaar or elsewhere talking to paltry shopkeepers, labourers, etc.
('79', 475, 7, 29, 951742) He tried to pick up Hindustani.
('79', 475, 7, 30, 951774) I think he gave a good part of his salary to the poor.
('79', 475, 8, 31, 951829) This was not liked by his brother officers.
('79', 475, 8, 32, 951873) The Commanding Officer spoke to him about it and they had many arguments.
('79', 475, 8, 33, 951947) He began to dislike his profession, and especially service in India, more and more.
('79', 475, 8, 34, 952031) He wanted to leave it but this was not possible in war time.
('79', 475, 8, 35, 952092) Ultimately he gave the enclosed note to his C.O.
('79', 475, 9, 36, 952141) His regiment was transferred from Mhow to Jhansi.
('79', 475, 9, 37, 952191) This gave him a day and a half or two to join up at Jhansi.
('79', 475, 9, 38, 952251) He decided to burn his boats whatever the consequences and went and sold his uniform.
('79', 475, 9, 39, 952337) This was done chiefly to put a definite
('79', 475, 10, 40, 952377) 1Vide “Letter to Jawaharlal Nehru”, 6 10 1940
('79', 476, 0, 1, 952423) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 477
('79', 476, 1, 2, 952469) end to his military career—also to raise some money.
('79', 476, 1, 3, 952522) He did not, particularly, want to be sent back from India to England.
('79', 476, 2, 4, 952592) He then telephoned to Allahabad to get into touch with me and learnt— found—I was in Bombay and got my address; went straight to Bombay and to my sister’s house from the station.
('79', 476, 3, 5, 952771) This was a novel situation for me and I was completely taken aback.
('79', 476, 3, 6, 952839) My heart went out to this young and terribly sincere boy of 25 but I did not know what to do.
('79', 476, 3, 7, 952933) By coming to Bombay he had deserted—and that too in war time.
('79', 476, 3, 8, 952995) This is the gravest offence in military law and there was no doubt that he would be arrested in a day or two and court martialled.
('79', 476, 3, 9, 953126) I found from him that he was due to report at Jhansi the next morning.
('79', 476, 3, 10, 953197) There was just a chance of his getting back to Jhansi in time if he took the next train which left soon after.
('79', 476, 4, 11, 953308) I wanted to have a much longer talk with Napier but already I had kept the Planning Committee waiting.
('79', 476, 4, 12, 953411) If he had to go back to Jhansi by the next train then there was going to be no other chance.
('79', 476, 4, 13, 953504) I felt he must go back.
('79', 476, 4, 14, 953528) To be charged with desertion was to confuse the issue apart from other consequences.
('79', 476, 4, 15, 953613) He had already made his position perfectly clear to the army authorities and he could face them and fight them on that issue.
('79', 476, 4, 16, 953739) I could hardly conceive of his remaining in the British Army after his declaration of faith.
('79', 476, 4, 17, 953832) Nor could I see how he was to get out of it.
('79', 476, 4, 18, 953877) Army authorities do not permit this kind of thing.
('79', 476, 4, 19, 953928) What was going to happen to him I could not guess, but it seemed to be clear that he would have a very hard time.
('79', 476, 4, 20, 954042) Anyway I felt that this question must not be mixed up with desertion.
('79', 476, 4, 21, 954112) I advised him, therefore, to go back by the next train to Jhansi and to report himself to the C.O. there.
('79', 476, 4, 22, 954218) I further suggested to him not to do so in khadi kurta and pyjamas.
('79', 476, 4, 23, 954286) He said he had shorts, etc., and he would wear them.
('79', 476, 4, 24, 954339) I asked him if he had enough money.
('79', 476, 4, 25, 954375) He said he had quite enough for his purpose.
('79', 476, 5, 26, 954420) He accepted my advice and said he would go back.
('79', 476, 5, 27, 954469) I asked him to communicate with me, if possible, or with my sister, and to let me know what happened.
('79', 476, 5, 28, 954571) We have had no news of him since.
('79', 476, 5, 29, 954605) I am told now that every regiment that is sent to Jhansi, goes off soon after to Egypt.
('79', 476, 5, 30, 954693) I am trying to find out now what had happened to Napier’s regiment.
('79', 476, 5, 31, 954761) It is quite likely that because of his views and his escapade he was kept under arrest and prevented from communicating, and later sent out of India.
('79', 476, 6, 32, 954911) His face haunts me and I often wonder if I advised him rightly.
('79', 476, 7, 33, 954975) Yours affectionately,
('79', 477, 0, 1, 954997) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 477, 1, 2, 955039) [ENCLOSURE—NAPIER’S NOTE]
('79', 477, 2, 3, 955065) August 1940
('79', 477, 3, 4, 955077) Having regard to the fact that the country is at war and it is not possible for an officer to resign his commission in the normal manner I here under at the request of my Commanding Officer set down my considered opinions, in the belief that these are incompatible with the retention of my commission.
('79', 477, 3, 5, 955379) I am infinitely more proud of these opinions than of the fact that my family has an unbroken tradition of service in the British Army for the past 150 years, and that one of my forbears played no small part in conquering India.
('79', 477, 4, 6, 955607) I am opposed to British Rule in India.
('79', 477, 4, 7, 955646) I consider that a country should be ruled by its inhabitants, because freedom is the most important thing of all.
('79', 477, 4, 8, 955760) It is even more important than food, but food is also important.
('79', 477, 4, 9, 955825) In India no one has freedom, and a large proportion of the population have insufficient food, a fact plainly evident to any Englishman who took the trouble to miss his drinks at the club for one evening and go into the country to look.
('79', 477, 5, 10, 956061) I am opposed to the British Empire.
('79', 477, 5, 11, 956097) I consider it to be an association for the making of money, propagated by merchants in England under a hypothetical screen of “Empire glory and the betterment of the native races”.
('79', 477, 5, 12, 956278) I consider this bad for the majority of people in England, bad for India, and bad for the world.
('79', 477, 5, 13, 956375) There is this much difference between Hitlerism and Bolshevism on the one hand and British Imperialism on the other.
('79', 477, 5, 14, 956492) The latter gives liberty and food to some and neither to others.
('79', 477, 5, 15, 956557) The former gives food to all and liberty to none.
('79', 477, 5, 16, 956607) I am opposed to modern European civilization, which is the grandiose name under which the present mess in the vicinity of the North Sea is known.
('79', 477, 5, 17, 956753) I find it difficult to believe that the peoples at present engaged in a mad struggle generated by greed and fear are a force for good in the world.
('79', 477, 5, 18, 956901) European civilization has produced the means for making things, and rather more efficiently the means for destroying what it has made.
('79', 477, 5, 19, 957036) Its most important effect on the mind of the ordinary man is that it has produced an inability to think, and a distrust of those who can.
('79', 477, 5, 20, 957174) It is seen at its best in war time, when everyone has work and money, and is reasonably happy in the pursuit of killing his fellow men.
('79', 477, 5, 21, 957310) In peace time, there is unemployment, starvation and misery.
('79', 477, 5, 22, 957371) Surely even an Englishman can see something wrong there.
('79', 477, 6, 23, 957428) I am opposed to the Englishman as a means of spreading culture and civilization.
('79', 477, 6, 24, 957509) The average Englishman values his body to such an extent that he neglects his mind.
('79', 477, 6, 25, 957593) Certainly the body should be fit, and be exercised to be fit, but why do people assume that the mind needs no exercise.
('79', 477, 6, 26, 957713) An effete mind in a healthy body is a matter for satisfaction to an Englishman, whereas an active mind in a feeble body is a thing of contempt to him.
('79', 477, 6, 27, 957864) English ideas of life are with few exceptions
('79', 478, 0, 1, 957910) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 479
('79', 478, 1, 2, 957956) based on this principle, which is in direct opposition to the Oriental view of life.
('79', 478, 1, 3, 958041) I cannot willingly help the English to propagate suet headed mentality.
('79', 478, 1, 4, 958113) And for the third part of man, that elusive thing called soul!
('79', 478, 1, 5, 958176) The average Englishman neglects this completely.
('79', 478, 1, 6, 958225) The English are an irreligious people.
('79', 478, 1, 7, 958264) The lower classes make no bones about this; on the other hand the higher classes treat religion as a social function.
('79', 478, 1, 8, 958382) By a mixture of hypocrisy and sheer stupidity they manage to convince themselves they are Christians, though in practice they utterly disregard the magnificent precepts of their religion, and if Christ were to appear today in England, they would regard him as a most undesirable fellow.
('79', 478, 1, 9, 958669) One point of the Christian religion is to pray daily.
('79', 478, 1, 10, 958723) You who read this, do you pray daily?
('79', 478, 1, 11, 958761) Would you kneel down in a public place and pray to your God?
('79', 478, 1, 12, 958822) Yet Indians do this every day.
('79', 478, 1, 13, 958853) I am not religious myself, a fact which I consider a cause for regret.
('79', 478, 1, 14, 958924) I am not a Christian, but neither do I pretend to be one.
('79', 478, 1, 15, 958982) Despite this I deplore my unacceptability in the eyes of my Commanding Officer, a thing which no decent Englishman would do, be he Christian or no.
('79', 478, 1, 16, 959130) Nor do I in spite of my irreligion scoff at the beliefs of others, whose ignorance and superstition at the present time is due to a Government which so far from teaching them anything, has in a hundred and fifty years made no attempt to see that they have sufficient to eat.
('79', 478, 1, 17, 959405) I have as much sympathy with the Hindu religion as with the Christian, and infinitely more with the Indian people than with the British.
('79', 478, 2, 18, 959542) Few Europeans object to the British themselves, but most of them object to their hypocrisy, which allows them to feather their nests at the expense of all and sundry while believing themselves in a muddled sort of way to be the saviours of mankind.
('79', 478, 3, 19, 959791) Few Indians like the British or their rule.
('79', 478, 3, 20, 959835) This applies equally inside the Cantonments as outside them.
('79', 478, 3, 21, 959896) The people whose work depends on the British keep their opinions to themselves, but outside the Cantonments any man who is not in receipt of a Government pension will very gladly say what his opinions are.
('79', 478, 3, 22, 960102) As to the opinion of Indians in the Army, particularly those commissioned, I leave it for someone sufficiently painstaking to find out.
('79', 478, 3, 23, 960238) Considering that the state of the average Englishman in such matters is such that after thirty years in the country he can with difficulty speak the language, there seems little chance of this happening.
('79', 478, 3, 24, 960442) But it is quite an important question; and the answer is not merely ‘Yes’ or ‘No’.
('79', 478, 3, 25, 960525) In India all questions have several answers.
('79', 478, 4, 26, 960570) Finally I must assert that I am not taking this course without due consideration, nor was it on the spur of the moment that I suggested to my Commanding Officer that it might be better if I left the Army.
('79', 478, 4, 27, 960775) I have a good position; pay that is roughly twice my requirements (thanks to the munificence of the Government at the cost of a population who need it far more than myself), in addition to a scholarship obtained with some labour at the Royal Military College.
('79', 478, 4, 28, 961035) I am now prepared to leave that, to
('79', 479, 0, 1, 961071) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('79', 479, 1, 2, 961113) leave a profession in which I have always been keen, and to cut myself off from such friends and relations as I have in England.
('79', 479, 1, 3, 961242) ‘Prepared’ is not the right word.
('79', 479, 1, 4, 961276) ‘Hoping’ would be more appropriate.
('79', 479, 1, 5, 961312) I do this against the advice of every Indian in the bazar, who assures me that though he would certainly prefer an Indian Government to a British one, he has no intention of doing anything about it, since his livelihood depends on the British.
('79', 479, 1, 6, 961556) I am well aware that anything I may do will make scarcely a ripple in an ocean which at the present time is as near to being churned with blood as ever before.
('79', 479, 1, 7, 961716) But if one must join in the general fight in this mad world, it is surely a feeble creature who would not fight for what he believes to be right, even if he must do it without a bank balance.
('79', 479, 1, 8, 961908) Freedom is more important than food.

('79', 479, 3, 10, 962016) APPENDIX X
('79', 479, 4, 11, 962027) LETTER FROM LORD LINLITHGOW1
('79', 479, 5, 12, 962056) THE VICEROY’S HOUSE, NEW DELHI, October 24, 1940
('79', 479, 6, 13, 962105) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('79', 479, 7, 14, 962122) I have given all possible consideration to your letter of the 20th October and have seen your telegram of the 21st.
('79', 479, 7, 15, 962238) My further enquiries and the papers which you have sent confirm me in what I told you in my telegram of the 19th October, viz., that no censorship orders were issued by the Central Government.
('79', 479, 7, 16, 962431) What was done was to advise local editors in their own interests to refer for scrutiny any matter which might be a prejudicial report and the publication of which might, therefore, expose them to penalties under the Defence of India Rules.
('79', 479, 7, 17, 962671) This, I am informed, is the usual procedure by which the Press are able to obtain advice in doubtful cases.
('79', 479, 8, 18, 962779) 2. I can, of course, appreciate your desire for freedom to conduct a civil disobedience movement in the way that commends itself to you and I can understand that for that purpose you wish to enjoy unrestricted access to the public through the ordinary channels of publicity.
('79', 479, 8, 19, 963054) Although, however, you evidently wish me to believe that this movement which you have initiated will be more dangerous if you do not enjoy these facilities, I must credit you personally with the desire that it should succeed in its avowed object, that of persuading the public to withhold all support from India’s war effort.
('79', 479, 8, 20, 963380) I must, therefore, assume that any opportunities afforded to you would be used solely for that purpose.
('79', 479, 8, 21, 963484) In so far as you ask for my co operation in such a plan, I must once more make it plain to you as I did in our conversation at the
('79', 479, 9, 22, 963615) 1Vide “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 20 10 1940 and “Letter to Lord Linlithgow”, 30 10 1940
('79', 480, 0, 1, 963705) VOL. 79 : 16 JULY, 1940 27 DECEMBER, 1940 481
('79', 480, 1, 2, 963751) end of September that both I myself as the representative of His Majesty’s Government in this country and the Government of India as responsible for its security have a very definite obligation to perform, and it would be disingenuous of me were I to leave any doubt that activities, the effect of which may be prejudicial in terms of the prosecution of the war and which infringe the law, cannot but attract the provisions of the law; and that it would not be possible for me or for the Government of India, consistently with the formal obligations falling upon us, to acquiesce in them.
('79', 480, 1, 3, 964340) You know how greatly I regret that there should be this conflict of views between yourself and Government as regards the limits within which speeches of a certain character or activities of a certain character affecting the prosecution of the war may be allowed to pass unnoticed, but a point must inevitably be reached at which here as at home and elsewhere in the Empire they cannot but attract, as I have said above, the sanctions which the law provides.
('79', 480, 2, 4, 964798) Yours sincerely,
('79', 480, 3, 5, 964815) LINLITHGOW
('79', 480, 4, 6, 964826) From a copy: C.W. 7853a.
